Posts.Content: Acceptance is our access to peace. Accept that you are now in a campaign to deal with cancer or the possibility of cancer that will be with you the rest of your life. You're in very good company. Regarding the current waiting, you can always thank the doctor for his plan and ask for a biopsy now. I suspect he has to have at least one PSA test in his file to confirm your records and remove the criticism that he rushed to biopsy without one last hope it will mysteriously drop. You have put a lot of emphasis on bike riding so he now must protect himself from your bias towards it even though the idea is fast fading for you as you confront the reality of your situation. Practices have their protocols. They will abide them. When I had my two year post op appointment this morning with my surgeon I discussed this forum and the number of men seemingly unprepared for the risk of prostate cancer. He said only 17% of general practices screen for prostate cancer. He is as busy as the day is long. Become an advocate, but not a zealot. Hang around here. It helps. Begin with forgiving yourself. There is no fault here. You have to be somewhere. This is where you are.

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: This is a situation for a skilled practitioner. If you press he will mostly likely increase his resolve. For now, don't discuss it with him. Speak only when spoken to on the topic. Your persistence at this time may only build more resistance. The manner of his dismissal of his doctor's concern in the face of obvious test results is troubling. He may also not be honest about other symptoms. If distrusting of others is a pattern he will use it towards himself as well, even more so. This goes well beyond a couple of initial tests beginning to head in the wrong direction and ignoring heart to heart conversations he's most certainly had with his doctor and you. Seek counseling for yourself for how to deal with this. Much like being in a relationship with alcoholism or dementia you will need help dealing with his mental state. It is more than denial or fear. It may be depression or a more complicated emotional state. He is showing an acute lack of care for himself. His behavior is not normal. His brother may have suffered from the same condition judging from the outcome. Look to caring for yourself first. I'm sorry this is happening to you. This is similar to the oxygen mask dropping out of the bulkhead of the airplane. Put your mask on first, meaning take care of your self first and gather information and support for dealing with him and your emotions. There is no magic bullet for this. Only work to be done. Even if you conjole, manipulate, or bully him into action he may hold you responsible for the outcome as he chooses to see it, fairly or not. Your first order of business with a counselor is to deal with your anger and frustration with his behavior and separate yourself from his emotional and irrational mental state. You don't want to go down this rabbit hole with him.
Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: So, do you have pain, discomfort, fever, chills, or any symptom associated with prostatitis? No where in the Harvard article is PSA mentioned as an indicator of prostatitis. Leukocytes are common in the urine for many reasons and concerns rely on the count. What was it? Simply drinking more water can help flush them out. Be careful, drinking too much water can also irritate the urinary system as can some foods and supplements. No where in the Harvard article is PSA mentioned as an indicator of prostatitis. I consider mention of antibiotics in the article is a remnant of a soon to end practise. Some doctors are loathed to inform their patients that biopsy and MRI tests regularly generate false negatives. I have not heard of any insurance company requiring an antibiotic be used prior to approving additional biopsy or MRI. A round of antibiotics use to be considered prudent and thorough. An old school low cost way of ruling out infection for physical discomfort symptoms. Now as we squander away the invaluable resource of antibiotics with this ineffective overuse we also corrupt the science of diagnostic medicine with myth. Use of antibiotics as an anti inflammatory is not good health policy, imo.
Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Another, A well-written post, as always. But, you really can't decouple prostatitis from high PSA levels. While that one article did not mention PSA, all you have to do is Google "prostatitis psa levels" to see many links discussing that well-known fact. True, yet if the only sign is an elevated PSA what is there to treat? A symptomless case of prostatitis has no consequence.

Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: Often the prescription of antibiotics is used as a diagnostic tool, but it generally is bad medicine to use in these situations. I consider it a reflection on your urologist. Cipro also has some nasty potential side effects, and can set you up for future antibiotic resistance and biopsy complications. I'm not a fan. Studies have shown any drop in PSA from their use is no more frequent or larger than the control group. The risk is you may get a slight bump down, and give him cause to put off another PSA test for 6 months. You are young for such high numbers, and they do not seem to be erratic. Retesting in July is a good idea. Then it may be time for another MRI (maybe another doctor or a cancer center). MRI's are fallible as an emerging technology, and there is a learning curve in their use for detecting prostate cancer. Being concerned is a healthy and wise reaction. You have a serious potential indicator that is not resolving. I also hear a hint of frustration with your doctor. Don't ignore it. Some cancers can be hard to find and MRI's have their challenges as well. I would not hang my hat on one negative MRI, and your biopsy is almost 4 years old.

Posts.Title: Self prostate massage really benificial?

Posts.Content: Good news! What's your PSA testing schedule going forward? Just checking, no activities in the last 6 months to manipulate your PSA; i.e. prostate health supplements, vitamins, diet, BHP medication, antibiotics, etc? Did you restrict your activities, including the swimming, before the latest test? Going back did your urologist perform your DRE immediately before the PSA test of 4.7? This stimulation can spike a PSA number. Looking for an explaination of the PSA disparity. Is the nodule in the DRE still there? How are your urinary symptoms after another 6 months? The reason I mention this is to caution manipulating your PSA will have no impact on the cancer. Without a PSA history it's difficult to know which number is the norm or if they both are. Having a brother with PC puts you in a 1 in 4 risk of cancer. An abnormal DRE bumps that higher, as do urinary symptoms, as does a steady rising PSA, etc. Keep an eye on it until you have the history to rule out cancer.

Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3879050/ https://images.app.goo.gl/PyybYoJHt1uMUtyB7 If the surgery avoids severing them as the prostate is peeled away the next level of trauma is the heat from cauterizing blood vessels in the surgical cavity. The skill of the surgeon is critical, but size and the extent of the cancer is primary. Also, an enlarged prostate exerts pressure on these nerves and if large enough and for long enough the damage can be permanent regardless of surgery. A prostatectomy can not restore sexual function to already damaged nerves. Same for incontinence already established prior to surgery. I was already experiencing the beginnings of incontinence before surgery with frequency and dribbles. They persist. Fear of surgery side effects is misdirected. They are an inevitable result of the enlargement of the prostate from either BHP and/or cancer. When is a matter of time. Over treatment is the concern. I chose safe over sorry, and still, in hindsight waited too long. What is often ignored is the prostate is a major erogenous zone, similar to the female G spot, stimulated during erection and adding to the intensity and pleasure of the orgasm. This is the true sexual loss with cancer, imo.
Posts.Title: Possible cure for post-prostatectomy ED on the horizon?

Posts.Content: An important fact is the prostate is not enlarged indicating little contribution to PSA by BHP. Did the same doctor do all the biopsies? Where is the location of the PIRADS 4? Or you experiencing any symptoms with a normal size prostate? For me and I'm not a doctor, you already know more than what you will find out from the drug therapy. You have cancer and via your PSA history it is progressing. The problem is you can't find a cancer via biopsy that matches the rest of your profile. It may be past time to move on to other methods; a different cancer team, second opinions on biopsy samples, second opinions on MRI scans. Change something. The drug suggestion seems like your doctor is running out of options. Even if it does what it's suppose to do it doesn't get you a biopsy sample. It just puts you in a bigger "maybe" debate. It has to be frustrating.
Posts.Title: Doc prescribed Finasteride (Proscar) today - questions...

Posts.Content: I'm not a fan. There is no reliable translation factor. The multiplier is arbitrary. If your PSA is indicating cancer why mess with it and lose it as a barometer? If it indicates cancer find it and track it. The odds are you will eventually need treatment and a reliable PSA history is valuable. Some with cancer do not have a reliable PSA. If you do, protect it. It is valuable, imo. My PSA proved to be right on track with the progression of my cancer.
Posts.Title: Doc prescribed Finasteride (Proscar) today - questions...

Posts.Content: Zero is not the zero you think it is in this test. There is no rounding. These are specific measures of the antigen. If you have any movement up off your last test talk with your doctor.
Posts.Title: Dr Surprised but 'not alarmed' at PSA after surgery.

Posts.Content: I don't understand, .06 is a <.1. A new test at .1 is a significant rise from .06, not a translation of an actual .06. My question for the doctor regarding his reasoning around BCR PSA velocity is something I'd ask him for documentation to confirm. Never heard it before. I'd like to know more. I recommend you see the referral next and see if he concurs with another 3 month wait and test. Retesting, and waiting and retesting, are distinct. If you don't trust the number, retest immediately. If you're looking for 3 rises then wait and test, but it's a moot point since you hit .1. Now there is only to confirm it. Retest immediately to confirm the .1. See the referral immediately. If waiting is in order its his call. I see no reason to wait. It appears your margin is an issue. The earliar you give the RO your case the better the outcome.

Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: My concern has always been it's affect on PSA when true values are critical, such as testing for BCR. A surgeon may have less investment in that question than the RO/MO. Let's assume for the moment it does have a real effect. Does it kill all cancer cells or some? Does it postpone the diagnosis of BCR to the detrimental effect of conventional treatments? Most of these tests are measuring PSA, not the cancer. My investment is in the conventional path and it's statistics. While a supplement may have some beneficial effect, what is the effect and how does it impact current treatment thresholds and clinically tested outcomes? Doing some good isn't enough, imo. If you waiting for .2 or .3 for intervention of BCR it "may" do no harm. The difference may be insignificant at those levels. I want to know much sooner than that. The doctor's response is telling. He answers your question with a question. He doesn't know, and the difference it makes will be too small to matter, he assumes, so why not? I ask, so why? Here's another view. Do I want to slow it's recurrence and thereby it's treatment, or, do I want it to manifest itself as soon as possible to gain treatment as soon as possible? Like antibiotics, if I don't hit first and fast with a lethal combination what advantage do I give it by tinkering at it's edges? Maybe none, but I don't know. So what harm can it do? I don't know. That's a strategy for desperation, recklessness, or nonchalance, imo. The doctor answered your question with a question he doesn't have the answer to. This isn't a right or wrong debate. It's more of the emotional component that exists between the medical and patient communities. What can I do when I don't know what to do? Waiting doesn't scratch that itch.

Posts.Content: Cash is king. I got a 20% discount for paying the hospital cash on a $4,200 deductible if I paid before the procedure (hernia repair). The only problem I see is telling an insurance company it cost A at the same time telling a patient it is 1/2 A. If the insurance company never knows it doesn't/can't care.
Posts.Title: mpMRI cost MAY be (much) lower than meets the eye - if a patient self-pays

Posts.Content: Extreme sedentary life style and poor healthcare leads to slower metabolism, symptoms, and delayed detection or none at all. Couple obesity with less education and more poverty. A companion study would be the impact of obesity on the available study population in general. What are the statistics in general for obese men and early detection and treatment? Is obesity a sign of poor healthcare? Generally, it is. The study may be drawing from a very small subset of obese men who have had RP, who are diligent and proactive about their healthcare and treatment and may skew the population by practising a higher level of healthcare than the general population, i.e. early detection and treatment. In other words, the obese men who have had RP are a very small subset of the obese population being more successful with their healthcare than the general population. Multiply the difference by fit men who are prone to be slow to accept healthcare issues; i.e. I'm fit, exercise, and eat right, I don't have prostate cancer or I'll treat it with my lifestyle leading to late detection and delayed treatment.

The drug suggestion seems like your doctor is running out of options. Even if it does what it's suppose to do it doesn't get you a biopsy sample. It just puts you in a bigger "maybe" debate. It has to be frustrating.

Posts.Content: My concern has always been it's affect on PSA when true values are critical, such as testing for BCR. A surgeon may have less investment in that question than the RO/MO. Let's assume for the moment it does have a real effect. Does it kill all cancer cells or some? Does it postpone the diagnosis of BCR to the detrimental effect of conventional treatments? Most of these tests are measuring PSA, not the cancer. My investment is in the conventional path and it's statistics. While a supplement may have some beneficial effect, what is the effect and how does it impact current treatment thresholds and clinically tested outcomes? Doing some good isn't enough, imo. If you waiting for .2 or .3 for intervention of BCR it "may" do no harm. The difference may be insignificant at those levels. I want to know much sooner than that. The doctor's response is telling. He answers your question with a question. He doesn't know, and the difference it makes will be too small to matter, he assumes, so why not? I ask, so why? Here's another view. Do I want to slow it's recurrence and thereby it's treatment, or, do I want it to manifest itself as soon as possible to gain treatment as soon as possible? Like antibiotics, if I don't hit first and fast with a lethal combination what advantage do I give it by tinkering at it's edges? Maybe none, but I don't know. So what harm can it do? I don't know. That's a strategy for desperation, recklessness, or nonchalance, imo. The doctor answered your question with a question he doesn't have the answer to. This isn't a right or wrong debate. It's more of the emotional component that exists between the medical and patient communities. What can I do when I don't know what to do? Waiting doesn't scratch that itch.

Posts.Content: There you go. All good advice that concurs with your doctor. Regarding MRI, here is a recent article. Is MRI the 'Mammography' of Prostate Cancer Screening? http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/h...d57f1cd1a.html Almost all doctor/health system/insurance's protocol is for TRUS biopsy first. In general, TRUS biopsy has a 30% or higher false negative. In the case of younger men with higher PSAs (you) and smaller prostates it is lower. If you have a negative biopsy and a high PSA you can then make an argument to your insurer for an MRI. A guided MRI biopsy, if the MRI shows significant cancer, is still not available everywhere, but can be sought out. All this is further down the line for you IF your TRUS biopsy is negative. Statistically, the odds are the TRUS biopsy will find your cancer if it is there. But again, if not, you are not out of the woods. At your age and PSA it will be easier to prove you have cancer than to prove you do not. At this time, a biopsy tissue sample is the only way to prove cancer and it's grade. This disease is a sneaky bastard if you take your eyes off it. This is a bitter pill to swallow. My suggestion is you give yourself time to accept it, but do not dwell there too long, and do not use it to hesitate moving forward in your diagnoses.

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you are having to deal with this. This is a club nobody wants to join. Imo, you have found your way to the most supportive and knowledgable site available for this conversation. Here is my advice - Get the biopsy! As Chuck says, the biopsy risks are very low, and trading the risk of biopsy for the risk of cancer does not work. You can not avoid risk. You can manage it. This is a disease managed by statistics. PSA numbers approaching 10 are indicative of significant cancer (50%). Your young age with your numbers is more indication this may be significant cancer and less likely to be infection or BHP. Of course, you may be a statistical exception and it is something to wish for. However, this disease is "curable" if detected early. Your doctor's advice is solid. Being aggressive with diagnosis gives you whatever advantage you are going to have. While this is upsetting news, you are fortunate to have it sooner than later. This is just the beginning. Take this on now and the advantage is yours to enjoy a long and fruitful life.

Posts.Content: Arthur Dent, True on the acid reflux, gerds. etc. It may have been the source, but I had no symptoms of it that I could distinguish. The ulcer manifested itself with minor side and lower back pain waking me with more acute pain at 3-4am. I had a fine balance between aspirin therapy, 40 mg/daily and alcohol, and it got out of balance. I'm suspicious of the Cialis and Viagra as well in combination with the others. I've stopped all for the last three months. I quit coffee and switched to one cup of green tea a day. I had also added V8 into my diet and have discovered my body does not like it, too much acid. As I age my sensitivity to all things increases and my tolerance for abusing my body decreases. Keeping the balance requires more intention than when I was younger.

Posts.Content: It is my understanding the incidents of prostate cancer are increasing and are presenting at earliar ages. This story is not finished, and it's a story of public policy. In that context, basing our future on old data is continuing the same flawed thinking that only 1 in 1,000 benefit. The premise is we can't handle the truth of screening and risk responsibly. Maybe so, but do we stop creating a defense to this disease? Most men (80%) will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. Most men in this country will not live to 80. The life expectancy in this country is dropping as the disparity between access to quality education and wealth grows. Screening benefits the class in this country who have an increasing life expectancy. Sadly, these numbers reflect the shift of political fortune in this country. A shrinking middle class and a rapidly expanding lower class is creating a math that supports choicies in health care based on education and priviledge. Those with means and the education to have a responsible approach to choices will choose screening in support of their increasing life expectancy. Those who are in the growing lower class and decreasing life expectancy will benefit from less screening. This is the new America. This is the story.

Posts.Title: Requested a review of LabCorp Blood Testing

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you are having to deal with this. This is a club nobody wants to join. Imo, you have found your way to the most supportive and knowledgable site available for this conversation. Here is my advice - Get the biopsy! As Chuck says, the biopsy risks are very low, and trading the risk of biopsy for the risk of cancer does not work. You can not avoid risk. You can manage it. This is a disease managed by statistics. PSA numbers approaching 10 are indicative of significant cancer (50%). Your young age with your numbers is more indication this may be significant cancer and less likely to be infection or BHP. Of course, you may be a statistical exception and it is something to wish for. However, this disease is "curable" if detected early. Your doctor's advice is solid. Being aggressive with diagnosis gives you whatever advantage you are going to have. While this is upsetting news, you are fortunate to have it sooner than later. This is just the beginning. Take this on now and the advantage is yours to enjoy a long and fruitful life.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Just logged on to my health account and saw this report and thought others might want to see what one looks like. It was taken after my TRUS biopsy and before my surgery. The surgeon requested it and I believe I was told to map the area for his surgery. The TRUS biopsy provided enough information to choose to proceed with the DaVinci RP. This was for his information to see what he was going after. He never shared the results nor said it was available for viewing. (I never asked. My bad.) I found it after another unrelated procedure, EKG for heart palpitations that have since resolved themselves. That's another story that is a related complication from the stress of prostate cancer and treatment this past year. Point being, if you have any other weaknesses in your health this experience may bring them to the surface. End outcome, my heart is fine and ulcer is about healed up. The main contributor to the ulcer and subsequent palpitations was too much alcohol, Viagra, Cialis, and aspirin therapy. Ulcers can stimulate the Vagus nerve messing up the heart signals. I'm a little frustrated because my hospital and doctors are part of the same health system yet each has it's own online patient portal. So now I have to track two sites. Three, if you count Quest Diagnostics. Having said that, having online access to my medical records is a wonderful thing! MRI prostate, with and without contrast Indication for examination: Prostate cancer, elevated PSA Precontrast T1, T2 and diffusion-weighted images of the prostate gland are obtained. Sequential dynamic contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images are obtained. 20 cc gadolinium contrast were used. Prostate gland has a calculated volume of 69 cc. Examination of the peripheral zone reveals areas of restricted diffusion and abnormal T2 signal intensity within the left posterior aspect of the peripheral zone extending from the apex to the base. Similar-appearing areas of restricted diffusion and abnormal signal intensity are identified within the right posterior and posterior lateral peripheral zone at the apex, extending to the level of the mid gland. These areas appear somewhat hyperemic following gadolinium administration. Findings are considered suspicious for multifocal neoplastic process in the peripheral zone for which followup is required. Examination of the transitional zone reveals an ill-defined area of confluence low T2 signal intensity in the right anterior medial transitional zone at the level of the mid gland. This shows restricted diffusion and appears hyperemic. This is likewise considered suspicious and directed biopsy of this area should be considered. No other suspicious abnormality identified in the transitional zone. There are no abnormally enlarged or suspicious appearing pelvic lymph nodes. Visualized bony structures show normal marrow signal intensity. Seminal vesicles appear symmetric. Conclusion: Findings suspicious for multifocal neoplastic process within the peripheral zone bilaterally as described. Abnormal signal intensity right anterior medial transitional zone at the level of the mid gland. This is considered suspicious for a possible neoplastic process within the transitional zone as described. PIRADS 5 Component Results There is no component information for this result. General Information Collected: 04/07/2016 10:31 AM Resulted: 04/07/2016 10:39 AM Ordered By: Kent L Adkins, MD Result Status: Final result Here is a link to a technical article describing a method of review and reporting. https://cancerimagingjournal.biomedc...644-016-0068-2 NCI Training Module. https://training.seer.cancer.gov/prostate/anatomy/

Posts.Title: What my MRI Report looks like.

Posts.Content: No one can claim with certainty any percentage chance the cancer is confined, yet he may still be a good surgeon. Your stats would indicate to me it is not confined. I recommend a cancer center. Your situation is very serious. At your age, PSA, volume, and G4, this is not your garden variety prostate cancer and you may be in for a long haul. Starting with surgery may give you a longer game plan for treatment which you may need. Once you start with radiation you can't go back to surgery. If you start with surgery you can always move on to radiation if not confined.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Feelings and emotions are not to be trusted. All the information you mention is valuable; listening, informing, accessibility, experience with your specific condition, and the same and even more so for their team. Anything more than 6 or 7 variables and we lose track of the comparison matrix so the temptation is to give up and rely on a feeling. Don't. Take notes and make a list. Drill down past the feeling. You have a brain, energy, and skin in the game. Use it. There are warning flags, and they will generate feelings like; I like this one, I don't like this one. Dismiss the feeling and back up to the warning flag; they talk too much, they talk too fast, they are arrogant and offended by questions, they don't like this or that but will do it if you want, etc. I did not like my surgeon, and I was clear in that. He made some social faux pas, but I was clear he was an excellent surgeon, on top of his game, and committed to success and his skill. He was my junk yard dog. People are good at somethings and not good at others. The challenge is to be clear in it. Intangibles are what you don't know, not what is too much work to track. In the end a choice is just that, a choice. It's not a right or wrong. It is thoughtful considered and made. A feeling is a temptation driven by your mind wanting to avoid the work and responsibility. It usually is a warning flag of some unresolved story you have about yourself. Something you don't want to take on. Relying on intuition is an avoidance technuque. Flight or fight is an example of this. On a dark street late at night with no time and few options this works. Not here, and not in long term commitments. Now for your partner, love is not a feeling. It is a commitment and responsibility to what works best for those in love. What it will generate is an experience; joy, sadness, pain, suffering, laughter, peace, satisfaction. It is the integrity and the work to the commitment that is to be trusted, not the experience of it. The experience is the outcome and you accept it in faith and peace because you've done the work.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: I agree that characterizing someone's intent is to scare people is a reach. My volume was high and it was upgraded. My ancedotal experience may lead me to think the longer it grows the greater the chance it will develop into something more. It is cancer. The salieint point is the diagnostics we have are not 100%. Nor are the treatments. There is another recent post about a delayed recurrence of many years with a RP pathology report that indicates such a recurrence is highly unlikely. However pathology reports are not 100%. They do not section the entire prostate. The time it takes is not statistically warranted. Instead they use a method that is highly effective, but not 100%. I don't recall the actual percentage, but it is significant. Cancer can and does go undetected throught out the process. Regarding the other poster, the bright spot is the pathology examination procedures for margins in the process is highly effective, 97-99%. The dark spot is it leaves 1 - 3 percent of men who get a report of no cancer at or beyond the margin with cancer at or beyond the margin. Nobody wants to be those 1 - 3 guys in a hundred yet one stands among us today, probably. There is not right or wrong here. It's a choice and one made with statistics.
Posts.Title: Up- and Down-grading of Gleason scores and treatment decisions

Posts.Content: Acceptance is our access to peace. Accept that you are now in a campaign to deal with cancer or the possibility of cancer that will be with you the rest of your life. You're in very good company. Regarding the current waiting, you can always thank the doctor for his plan and ask for a biopsy now. I suspect he has to have at least one PSA test in his file to confirm your records and remove the criticism that he rushed to biopsy without one last hope it will mysteriously drop. You have put a lot of emphasis on bike riding so he now must protect himself from your bias towards it even though the idea is fast fading for you as you confront the reality of your situation. Practices have their protocols. They will abide them. When I had my two year post op appointment this morning with my surgeon I discussed this forum and the number of men seemingly unprepared for the risk of prostate cancer. He said only 17% of general practices screen for prostate cancer. He is as busy as the day is long. Become an advocate, but not a zealot. Hang around here. It helps. Begin with forgiving yourself. There is no fault here. You have to be somewhere. This is where you are.

Posts.Content: Here are the two gold standards if your condition is normal. Exercise is the best antidote for chronic fatigue. The use of hormones for normal aging is not advisable. If your condition is not the result of normal aging then work with a specialist or endocrinologist. You may also be experiencing depression which may respond to both exercise and medication. Just some thoughts.

Posts.Content: I agree with Michael F. Get yourself in physical shape. BMI between 19 and 25 if not already. Sounds like you're on top of it. Great work on your diagnosis! I will be interested in following your path to your treatment choice.
Posts.Title: Newbies Head Spinning

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Another, A well-written post, as always. But, you really can't decouple prostatitis from high PSA levels. While that one article did not mention PSA, all you have to do is Google "prostatitis psa levels" to see many links discussing that well-known fact. True, yet if the only sign is an elevated PSA what is there to treat? A symptomless case of prostatitis has no consequence.
Posts.Title: My PSA Result is 10

Posts.Content: There you go. All good advice that concurs with your doctor. Regarding MRI, here is a recent article. Is MRI the 'Mammography' of Prostate Cancer Screening? http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/h...d57f1cd1a.html Almost all doctor/health system/insurance's protocol is for TRUS biopsy first. In general, TRUS biopsy has a 30% or higher false negative. In the case of younger men with higher PSAs (you) and smaller prostates it is lower. If you have a negative biopsy and a high PSA you can then make an argument to your insurer for an MRI. A guided MRI biopsy, if the MRI shows significant cancer, is still not available everywhere, but can be sought out. All this is further down the line for you IF your TRUS biopsy is negative. Statistically, the odds are the TRUS biopsy will find your cancer if it is there. But again, if not, you are not out of the woods. At your age and PSA it will be easier to prove you have cancer than to prove you do not. At this time, a biopsy tissue sample is the only way to prove cancer and it's grade. This disease is a sneaky bastard if you take your eyes off it. This is a bitter pill to swallow. My suggestion is you give yourself time to accept it, but do not dwell there too long, and do not use it to hesitate moving forward in your diagnoses.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Good news! What's your PSA testing schedule going forward? Just checking, no activities in the last 6 months to manipulate your PSA; i.e. prostate health supplements, vitamins, diet, BHP medication, antibiotics, etc? Did you restrict your activities, including the swimming, before the latest test? Going back did your urologist perform your DRE immediately before the PSA test of 4.7? This stimulation can spike a PSA number. Looking for an explaination of the PSA disparity. Is the nodule in the DRE still there? How are your urinary symptoms after another 6 months? The reason I mention this is to caution manipulating your PSA will have no impact on the cancer. Without a PSA history it's difficult to know which number is the norm or if they both are. Having a brother with PC puts you in a 1 in 4 risk of cancer. An abnormal DRE bumps that higher, as do urinary symptoms, as does a steady rising PSA, etc. Keep an eye on it until you have the history to rule out cancer.
Posts.Title: Update from June

Posts.Content: I don't understand, .06 is a <.1. A new test at .1 is a significant rise from .06, not a translation of an actual .06. My question for the doctor regarding his reasoning around BCR PSA velocity is something I'd ask him for documentation to confirm. Never heard it before. I'd like to know more. I recommend you see the referral next and see if he concurs with another 3 month wait and test. Retesting, and waiting and retesting, are distinct. If you don't trust the number, retest immediately. If you're looking for 3 rises then wait and test, but it's a moot point since you hit .1. Now there is only to confirm it. Retest immediately to confirm the .1. See the referral immediately. If waiting is in order its his call. I see no reason to wait. It appears your margin is an issue. The earliar you give the RO your case the better the outcome.

Posts.Content: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3879050/ https://images.app.goo.gl/PyybYoJHt1uMUtyB7 If the surgery avoids severing them as the prostate is peeled away the next level of trauma is the heat from cauterizing blood vessels in the surgical cavity. The skill of the surgeon is critical, but size and the extent of the cancer is primary. Also, an enlarged prostate exerts pressure on these nerves and if large enough and for long enough the damage can be permanent regardless of surgery. A prostatectomy can not restore sexual function to already damaged nerves. Same for incontinence already established prior to surgery. I was already experiencing the beginnings of incontinence before surgery with frequency and dribbles. They persist. Fear of surgery side effects is misdirected. They are an inevitable result of the enlargement of the prostate from either BHP and/or cancer. When is a matter of time. Over treatment is the concern. I chose safe over sorry, and still, in hindsight waited too long. What is often ignored is the prostate is a major erogenous zone, similar to the female G spot, stimulated during erection and adding to the intensity and pleasure of the orgasm. This is the true sexual loss with cancer, imo.

Posts.Title: Dr Surprised but 'not alarmed' at PSA after surgery.

Posts.Content: Often the prescription of antibiotics is used as a diagnostic tool, but it generally is bad medicine to use in these situations. I consider it a reflection on your urologist. Cipro also has some nasty potential side effects, and can set you up for future antibiotic resistance and biopsy complications. I'm not a fan. Studies have shown any drop in PSA from their use is no more frequent or larger than the control group. The risk is you may get a slight bump down, and give him cause to put off another PSA test for 6 months. You are young for such high numbers, and they do not seem to be erratic. Retesting in July is a good idea. Then it may be time for another MRI (maybe another doctor or a cancer center). MRI's are fallible as an emerging technology, and there is a learning curve in their use for detecting prostate cancer. Being concerned is a healthy and wise reaction. You have a serious potential indicator that is not resolving. I also hear a hint of frustration with your doctor. Don't ignore it. Some cancers can be hard to find and MRI's have their challenges as well. I would not hang my hat on one negative MRI, and your biopsy is almost 4 years old.

Posts.Content: Just logged on to my health account and saw this report and thought others might want to see what one looks like. It was taken after my TRUS biopsy and before my surgery. The surgeon requested it and I believe I was told to map the area for his surgery. The TRUS biopsy provided enough information to choose to proceed with the DaVinci RP. This was for his information to see what he was going after. He never shared the results nor said it was available for viewing. (I never asked. My bad.) I found it after another unrelated procedure, EKG for heart palpitations that have since resolved themselves. That's another story that is a related complication from the stress of prostate cancer and treatment this past year. Point being, if you have any other weaknesses in your health this experience may bring them to the surface. End outcome, my heart is fine and ulcer is about healed up. The main contributor to the ulcer and subsequent palpitations was too much alcohol, Viagra, Cialis, and aspirin therapy. Ulcers can stimulate the Vagus nerve messing up the heart signals. I'm a little frustrated because my hospital and doctors are part of the same health system yet each has it's own online patient portal. So now I have to track two sites. Three, if you count Quest Diagnostics. Having said that, having online access to my medical records is a wonderful thing! MRI prostate, with and without contrast Indication for examination: Prostate cancer, elevated PSA Precontrast T1, T2 and diffusion-weighted images of the prostate gland are obtained. Sequential dynamic contrast-enhanced T1-weighted images are obtained. 20 cc gadolinium contrast were used. Prostate gland has a calculated volume of 69 cc. Examination of the peripheral zone reveals areas of restricted diffusion and abnormal T2 signal intensity within the left posterior aspect of the peripheral zone extending from the apex to the base. Similar-appearing areas of restricted diffusion and abnormal signal intensity are identified within the right posterior and posterior lateral peripheral zone at the apex, extending to the level of the mid gland. These areas appear somewhat hyperemic following gadolinium administration. Findings are considered suspicious for multifocal neoplastic process in the peripheral zone for which followup is required. Examination of the transitional zone reveals an ill-defined area of confluence low T2 signal intensity in the right anterior medial transitional zone at the level of the mid gland. This shows restricted diffusion and appears hyperemic. This is likewise considered suspicious and directed biopsy of this area should be considered. No other suspicious abnormality identified in the transitional zone. There are no abnormally enlarged or suspicious appearing pelvic lymph nodes. Visualized bony structures show normal marrow signal intensity. Seminal vesicles appear symmetric. Conclusion: Findings suspicious for multifocal neoplastic process within the peripheral zone bilaterally as described. Abnormal signal intensity right anterior medial transitional zone at the level of the mid gland. This is considered suspicious for a possible neoplastic process within the transitional zone as described. PIRADS 5 Component Results There is no component information for this result. General Information Collected: 04/07/2016 10:31 AM Resulted: 04/07/2016 10:39 AM Ordered By: Kent L Adkins, MD Result Status: Final result Here is a link to a technical article describing a method of review and reporting. https://cancerimagingjournal.biomedc...644-016-0068-2 NCI Training Module. https://training.seer.cancer.gov/prostate/anatomy/

Posts.Title: Husband wants second PSA test~

Posts.Content: My concern has always been it's affect on PSA when true values are critical, such as testing for BCR. A surgeon may have less investment in that question than the RO/MO. Let's assume for the moment it does have a real effect. Does it kill all cancer cells or some? Does it postpone the diagnosis of BCR to the detrimental effect of conventional treatments? Most of these tests are measuring PSA, not the cancer. My investment is in the conventional path and it's statistics. While a supplement may have some beneficial effect, what is the effect and how does it impact current treatment thresholds and clinically tested outcomes? Doing some good isn't enough, imo. If you waiting for .2 or .3 for intervention of BCR it "may" do no harm. The difference may be insignificant at those levels. I want to know much sooner than that. The doctor's response is telling. He answers your question with a question. He doesn't know, and the difference it makes will be too small to matter, he assumes, so why not? I ask, so why? Here's another view. Do I want to slow it's recurrence and thereby it's treatment, or, do I want it to manifest itself as soon as possible to gain treatment as soon as possible? Like antibiotics, if I don't hit first and fast with a lethal combination what advantage do I give it by tinkering at it's edges? Maybe none, but I don't know. So what harm can it do? I don't know. That's a strategy for desperation, recklessness, or nonchalance, imo. The doctor answered your question with a question he doesn't have the answer to. This isn't a right or wrong debate. It's more of the emotional component that exists between the medical and patient communities. What can I do when I don't know what to do? Waiting doesn't scratch that itch.

Posts.Content: It is my understanding the incidents of prostate cancer are increasing and are presenting at earliar ages. This story is not finished, and it's a story of public policy. In that context, basing our future on old data is continuing the same flawed thinking that only 1 in 1,000 benefit. The premise is we can't handle the truth of screening and risk responsibly. Maybe so, but do we stop creating a defense to this disease? Most men (80%) will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. Most men in this country will not live to 80. The life expectancy in this country is dropping as the disparity between access to quality education and wealth grows. Screening benefits the class in this country who have an increasing life expectancy. Sadly, these numbers reflect the shift of political fortune in this country. A shrinking middle class and a rapidly expanding lower class is creating a math that supports choicies in health care based on education and priviledge. Those with means and the education to have a responsible approach to choices will choose screening in support of their increasing life expectancy. Those who are in the growing lower class and decreasing life expectancy will benefit from less screening. This is the new America. This is the story.

Posts.Title: Age 39 PSA came back at 2.75

Posts.Content: An important fact is the prostate is not enlarged indicating little contribution to PSA by BHP. Did the same doctor do all the biopsies? Where is the location of the PIRADS 4? Or you experiencing any symptoms with a normal size prostate? For me and I'm not a doctor, you already know more than what you will find out from the drug therapy. You have cancer and via your PSA history it is progressing. The problem is you can't find a cancer via biopsy that matches the rest of your profile. It may be past time to move on to other methods; a different cancer team, second opinions on biopsy samples, second opinions on MRI scans. Change something. The drug suggestion seems like your doctor is running out of options. Even if it does what it's suppose to do it doesn't get you a biopsy sample. It just puts you in a bigger "maybe" debate. It has to be frustrating.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Feelings and emotions are not to be trusted. All the information you mention is valuable; listening, informing, accessibility, experience with your specific condition, and the same and even more so for their team. Anything more than 6 or 7 variables and we lose track of the comparison matrix so the temptation is to give up and rely on a feeling. Don't. Take notes and make a list. Drill down past the feeling. You have a brain, energy, and skin in the game. Use it. There are warning flags, and they will generate feelings like; I like this one, I don't like this one. Dismiss the feeling and back up to the warning flag; they talk too much, they talk too fast, they are arrogant and offended by questions, they don't like this or that but will do it if you want, etc. I did not like my surgeon, and I was clear in that. He made some social faux pas, but I was clear he was an excellent surgeon, on top of his game, and committed to success and his skill. He was my junk yard dog. People are good at somethings and not good at others. The challenge is to be clear in it. Intangibles are what you don't know, not what is too much work to track. In the end a choice is just that, a choice. It's not a right or wrong. It is thoughtful considered and made. A feeling is a temptation driven by your mind wanting to avoid the work and responsibility. It usually is a warning flag of some unresolved story you have about yourself. Something you don't want to take on. Relying on intuition is an avoidance technuque. Flight or fight is an example of this. On a dark street late at night with no time and few options this works. Not here, and not in long term commitments. Now for your partner, love is not a feeling. It is a commitment and responsibility to what works best for those in love. What it will generate is an experience; joy, sadness, pain, suffering, laughter, peace, satisfaction. It is the integrity and the work to the commitment that is to be trusted, not the experience of it. The experience is the outcome and you accept it in faith and peace because you've done the work.
Posts.Title: What Doc is "Best"? Or, Which of the Multiple Opinions is "Right"?

Posts.Content: No one can claim with certainty any percentage chance the cancer is confined, yet he may still be a good surgeon. Your stats would indicate to me it is not confined. I recommend a cancer center. Your situation is very serious. At your age, PSA, volume, and G4, this is not your garden variety prostate cancer and you may be in for a long haul. Starting with surgery may give you a longer game plan for treatment which you may need. Once you start with radiation you can't go back to surgery. If you start with surgery you can always move on to radiation if not confined.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: My concern has always been it's affect on PSA when true values are critical, such as testing for BCR. A surgeon may have less investment in that question than the RO/MO. Let's assume for the moment it does have a real effect. Does it kill all cancer cells or some? Does it postpone the diagnosis of BCR to the detrimental effect of conventional treatments? Most of these tests are measuring PSA, not the cancer. My investment is in the conventional path and it's statistics. While a supplement may have some beneficial effect, what is the effect and how does it impact current treatment thresholds and clinically tested outcomes? Doing some good isn't enough, imo. If you waiting for .2 or .3 for intervention of BCR it "may" do no harm. The difference may be insignificant at those levels. I want to know much sooner than that. The doctor's response is telling. He answers your question with a question. He doesn't know, and the difference it makes will be too small to matter, he assumes, so why not? I ask, so why? Here's another view. Do I want to slow it's recurrence and thereby it's treatment, or, do I want it to manifest itself as soon as possible to gain treatment as soon as possible? Like antibiotics, if I don't hit first and fast with a lethal combination what advantage do I give it by tinkering at it's edges? Maybe none, but I don't know. So what harm can it do? I don't know. That's a strategy for desperation, recklessness, or nonchalance, imo. The doctor answered your question with a question he doesn't have the answer to. This isn't a right or wrong debate. It's more of the emotional component that exists between the medical and patient communities. What can I do when I don't know what to do? Waiting doesn't scratch that itch.

Posts.Content: Zero is not the zero you think it is in this test. There is no rounding. These are specific measures of the antigen. If you have any movement up off your last test talk with your doctor.

Posts.Title: Doc prescribed Finasteride (Proscar) today - questions...

Posts.Content: I agree that characterizing someone's intent is to scare people is a reach. My volume was high and it was upgraded. My ancedotal experience may lead me to think the longer it grows the greater the chance it will develop into something more. It is cancer. The salieint point is the diagnostics we have are not 100%. Nor are the treatments. There is another recent post about a delayed recurrence of many years with a RP pathology report that indicates such a recurrence is highly unlikely. However pathology reports are not 100%. They do not section the entire prostate. The time it takes is not statistically warranted. Instead they use a method that is highly effective, but not 100%. I don't recall the actual percentage, but it is significant. Cancer can and does go undetected throught out the process. Regarding the other poster, the bright spot is the pathology examination procedures for margins in the process is highly effective, 97-99%. The dark spot is it leaves 1 - 3 percent of men who get a report of no cancer at or beyond the margin with cancer at or beyond the margin. Nobody wants to be those 1 - 3 guys in a hundred yet one stands among us today, probably. There is not right or wrong here. It's a choice and one made with statistics.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you are having to deal with this. This is a club nobody wants to join. Imo, you have found your way to the most supportive and knowledgable site available for this conversation. Here is my advice - Get the biopsy! As Chuck says, the biopsy risks are very low, and trading the risk of biopsy for the risk of cancer does not work. You can not avoid risk. You can manage it. This is a disease managed by statistics. PSA numbers approaching 10 are indicative of significant cancer (50%). Your young age with your numbers is more indication this may be significant cancer and less likely to be infection or BHP. Of course, you may be a statistical exception and it is something to wish for. However, this disease is "curable" if detected early. Your doctor's advice is solid. Being aggressive with diagnosis gives you whatever advantage you are going to have. While this is upsetting news, you are fortunate to have it sooner than later. This is just the beginning. Take this on now and the advantage is yours to enjoy a long and fruitful life.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Arthur Dent, True on the acid reflux, gerds. etc. It may have been the source, but I had no symptoms of it that I could distinguish. The ulcer manifested itself with minor side and lower back pain waking me with more acute pain at 3-4am. I had a fine balance between aspirin therapy, 40 mg/daily and alcohol, and it got out of balance. I'm suspicious of the Cialis and Viagra as well in combination with the others. I've stopped all for the last three months. I quit coffee and switched to one cup of green tea a day. I had also added V8 into my diet and have discovered my body does not like it, too much acid. As I age my sensitivity to all things increases and my tolerance for abusing my body decreases. Keeping the balance requires more intention than when I was younger.

Posts.Title: What my MRI Report looks like.

Posts.Content: It is my understanding the incidents of prostate cancer are increasing and are presenting at earliar ages. This story is not finished, and it's a story of public policy. In that context, basing our future on old data is continuing the same flawed thinking that only 1 in 1,000 benefit. The premise is we can't handle the truth of screening and risk responsibly. Maybe so, but do we stop creating a defense to this disease? Most men (80%) will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. Most men in this country will not live to 80. The life expectancy in this country is dropping as the disparity between access to quality education and wealth grows. Screening benefits the class in this country who have an increasing life expectancy. Sadly, these numbers reflect the shift of political fortune in this country. A shrinking middle class and a rapidly expanding lower class is creating a math that supports choicies in health care based on education and priviledge. Those with means and the education to have a responsible approach to choices will choose screening in support of their increasing life expectancy. Those who are in the growing lower class and decreasing life expectancy will benefit from less screening. This is the new America. This is the story.

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: Paying back is a fringe benefit for me if what I have to share is useful. Sometimes I wonder. I'm primarily here first for myself. I have found this site extremely valuable to me and my motivation is to maintain it's integrity for that benefit. I have visited and left other sites that were far afield in content and advice. I consider myself a newbie prepping for possible recurrence. I consider myself under educated even though I have traversed a successful first course of diagnosis and treatment. The disease is so common I want more general knowledge for myself, my 3 brothers, my friends, and my son. I made it successfully to this point due to the intervention of one man. He coincidentally happens to be my primary physician. I was in denial and he made a difference. Because of my experience it is the automatic filter in my listening. I can hear it a mile off. Takes one to know one so to speak. I want to know enough to make a difference for myself and anyone else that may cross my path and is listening. I have 3 brothers all in various stages of denial. It appears to be a family trait.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: There you go. All good advice that concurs with your doctor. Regarding MRI, here is a recent article. Is MRI the 'Mammography' of Prostate Cancer Screening? http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/h...d57f1cd1a.html Almost all doctor/health system/insurance's protocol is for TRUS biopsy first. In general, TRUS biopsy has a 30% or higher false negative. In the case of younger men with higher PSAs (you) and smaller prostates it is lower. If you have a negative biopsy and a high PSA you can then make an argument to your insurer for an MRI. A guided MRI biopsy, if the MRI shows significant cancer, is still not available everywhere, but can be sought out. All this is further down the line for you IF your TRUS biopsy is negative. Statistically, the odds are the TRUS biopsy will find your cancer if it is there. But again, if not, you are not out of the woods. At your age and PSA it will be easier to prove you have cancer than to prove you do not. At this time, a biopsy tissue sample is the only way to prove cancer and it's grade. This disease is a sneaky bastard if you take your eyes off it. This is a bitter pill to swallow. My suggestion is you give yourself time to accept it, but do not dwell there too long, and do not use it to hesitate moving forward in your diagnoses.

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Extreme sedentary life style and poor healthcare leads to slower metabolism, symptoms, and delayed detection or none at all. Couple obesity with less education and more poverty. A companion study would be the impact of obesity on the available study population in general. What are the statistics in general for obese men and early detection and treatment? Is obesity a sign of poor healthcare? Generally, it is. The study may be drawing from a very small subset of obese men who have had RP, who are diligent and proactive about their healthcare and treatment and may skew the population by practising a higher level of healthcare than the general population, i.e. early detection and treatment. In other words, the obese men who have had RP are a very small subset of the obese population being more successful with their healthcare than the general population. Multiply the difference by fit men who are prone to be slow to accept healthcare issues; i.e. I'm fit, exercise, and eat right, I don't have prostate cancer or I'll treat it with my lifestyle leading to late detection and delayed treatment.
Posts.Title: Obesity paradox: increased BMI associated with decreased risk of mets post RP

Posts.Content: No one can claim with certainty any percentage chance the cancer is confined, yet he may still be a good surgeon. Your stats would indicate to me it is not confined. I recommend a cancer center. Your situation is very serious. At your age, PSA, volume, and G4, this is not your garden variety prostate cancer and you may be in for a long haul. Starting with surgery may give you a longer game plan for treatment which you may need. Once you start with radiation you can't go back to surgery. If you start with surgery you can always move on to radiation if not confined.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - High numbers - some pressure to rush treatment from urologist

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry you are having to deal with this. This is a club nobody wants to join. Imo, you have found your way to the most supportive and knowledgable site available for this conversation. Here is my advice - Get the biopsy! As Chuck says, the biopsy risks are very low, and trading the risk of biopsy for the risk of cancer does not work. You can not avoid risk. You can manage it. This is a disease managed by statistics. PSA numbers approaching 10 are indicative of significant cancer (50%). Your young age with your numbers is more indication this may be significant cancer and less likely to be infection or BHP. Of course, you may be a statistical exception and it is something to wish for. However, this disease is "curable" if detected early. Your doctor's advice is solid. Being aggressive with diagnosis gives you whatever advantage you are going to have. While this is upsetting news, you are fortunate to have it sooner than later. This is just the beginning. Take this on now and the advantage is yours to enjoy a long and fruitful life.

Posts.Title: Newbies Head Spinning

Posts.Content: I agree that characterizing someone's intent is to scare people is a reach. My volume was high and it was upgraded. My ancedotal experience may lead me to think the longer it grows the greater the chance it will develop into something more. It is cancer. The salieint point is the diagnostics we have are not 100%. Nor are the treatments. There is another recent post about a delayed recurrence of many years with a RP pathology report that indicates such a recurrence is highly unlikely. However pathology reports are not 100%. They do not section the entire prostate. The time it takes is not statistically warranted. Instead they use a method that is highly effective, but not 100%. I don't recall the actual percentage, but it is significant. Cancer can and does go undetected throught out the process. Regarding the other poster, the bright spot is the pathology examination procedures for margins in the process is highly effective, 97-99%. The dark spot is it leaves 1 - 3 percent of men who get a report of no cancer at or beyond the margin with cancer at or beyond the margin. Nobody wants to be those 1 - 3 guys in a hundred yet one stands among us today, probably. There is not right or wrong here. It's a choice and one made with statistics.

Posts.Content: Here are the two gold standards if your condition is normal. Exercise is the best antidote for chronic fatigue. The use of hormones for normal aging is not advisable. If your condition is not the result of normal aging then work with a specialist or endocrinologist. You may also be experiencing depression which may respond to both exercise and medication. Just some thoughts.

Posts.Title: New and so worried.......

Posts.Content: Paying back is a fringe benefit for me if what I have to share is useful. Sometimes I wonder. I'm primarily here first for myself. I have found this site extremely valuable to me and my motivation is to maintain it's integrity for that benefit. I have visited and left other sites that were far afield in content and advice. I consider myself a newbie prepping for possible recurrence. I consider myself under educated even though I have traversed a successful first course of diagnosis and treatment. The disease is so common I want more general knowledge for myself, my 3 brothers, my friends, and my son. I made it successfully to this point due to the intervention of one man. He coincidentally happens to be my primary physician. I was in denial and he made a difference. Because of my experience it is the automatic filter in my listening. I can hear it a mile off. Takes one to know one so to speak. I want to know enough to make a difference for myself and anyone else that may cross my path and is listening. I have 3 brothers all in various stages of denial. It appears to be a family trait.

Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Content: This advice column which I read and appreciate, until now, indicates the general public awareness of prostate cancer. If you want to treat your prostate cancer screening will be harmful to you. While this statement is simple on the surface it assumes one's approach to prostate cancer remains the same whether you know your status or not. My personal experience has been learning I had prostate cancer made a big difference in my efforts to educate myself and make decisions regarding it. While the outcome may have been the same, to choose treatment or not, the quality of my choice improved dramatically once it was real. Time and studies will eventually determine the impact of the current over diagnosis and treatment mantra. My own experience and watching my brothers, the impact I see is an information campaign that is misused to buttress a dangerous pattern of denial. For example, if I screen myself I am setting myself up for mistreatment, and I will die of something else. True, you may, but an active involvement makes it possible. http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/h...2080f8fd6.html

Posts.Title: Tips for Post Catheter Pads

Posts.Content: Follow your doctor's advice! If this is her first mention of referring you to a urologist for a very concerning PSA history - fire her. If you have been ignoring this very concerning PSA history - which you have - you're fired! Bicycle riding is not the cause of your PSA numbers. Repeat, bycycle riding is not the source of your PSA numbers. Again, bycycle riding is not the source of your PSA numbers. Cancer has two demons: denial and delay. They are your demons. You own them. Cancer is just cancer. Denial and delay are on you. Prostate cancer can not be managed with wishful thinking. Regardless of your biking, you have a persistent and steadily rising PSA. Biking will not generate your PSA numbers. The warning flag for you is you now know the extremes you will go to in your mind to deny and delay. This is a cancer managed with statistics. A PSA at 10 or more puts you in a 60% probability of cancer. Make sure the urologist referral is to a competent and experienced prostate cancer specialist and surgeon. I recommend a major cancer center that specializes in PC. At this point, you want to stop wasting time. Early detection and treatment is the path to successful treatment and managment of what can be a very treatable and managable cancer. You've wasted too much time already! I want this post to be a smack to your forehead. Get out of your head and start taking care of your health! It's taken you 14 years, in the face of rising PSA numbers, to learn biking may have a modest effect on PSA test results? You are in a tough spot. Biking won't fix this, and you have a way of thinking that may kill you. Early action is the key to beating this disease. You are well into squandering that advantage. Finding your way here is a bright spot. Now, can you get out of your head and into the game? Thoughts that matter. Your next step after finding a competent highly skilled prostate cancer urologist is a biopsy. Make sure you get one in the next three weeks.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lumore51 Hi there: Good point...but I guess it all depends on which study you are looking at and the percentage of patients experiencing any given side effect and how it compares to the percentages of patients experiencing that same side effects from another therapy (e.g. surgery). As an example, in this study from 2015: "Erectile function was preserved in 72% of the patients who had Grade 0-1 erectile dysfunction before brachytherapy." and that 80% with ED will respond to pharmacologic agents. So that also comes into play-the treatable of any inivitable side effects https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4570880/ I don't have the numbers for surgical patients-however, I do recall them seeming to be higher-both in theory and based on the anecdotal evidence of men on the various boards when I was researching. In any case, I am happy to report that thus far for, this has not been an issue! I was referencing the article posted in this thread. In general, radiation accounts for a 65% ED number within 5 years. HDR Brachytherapy is improving that number if it is dropping it to 40%. A note about anecdotal evidence and human nature. Surgery is currently the most common treatment. Someone choosing radiation mostly likely has too or is choosing to go against popular wisdom/advice. Both are likely to not complain about the side effects and to accept them. Someone choosing surgery and following conventional wisdom is more likely to struggle with accepting the side effects expecting a successful experience. The last one they blame will be the cancer itself.
Posts.Title: HDRBT article

Posts.Content: The smaller prostate is helpful news. Your PSA is less likely to be mixed with PSA generated from BPH and more likely to be cancer related. I know it's doesn't sound good, but the take away is your PSA may be a reliable indicator. That is valuable going forward. Also, the TRUS biopsy will be more effective. He sounds like he knows what he is doing. I'm impressed with his caution around MRIs. They are an emerging technology for this use and often miss smaller aggressive stuff and low grade stuff. The next PSA test is for him. He's looking to confirm the rising numbers with certainty, while on his watch, and for an indication of velocity. Velocity can't be seen with the 5 year gap before your last number. On density: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3289697/
Posts.Title: First Urologist appointment - not what I expected

Posts.Content: Follow your doctor's advice! If this is her first mention of referring you to a urologist for a very concerning PSA history - fire her. If you have been ignoring this very concerning PSA history - which you have - you're fired! Bicycle riding is not the cause of your PSA numbers. Repeat, bycycle riding is not the source of your PSA numbers. Again, bycycle riding is not the source of your PSA numbers. Cancer has two demons: denial and delay. They are your demons. You own them. Cancer is just cancer. Denial and delay are on you. Prostate cancer can not be managed with wishful thinking. Regardless of your biking, you have a persistent and steadily rising PSA. Biking will not generate your PSA numbers. The warning flag for you is you now know the extremes you will go to in your mind to deny and delay. This is a cancer managed with statistics. A PSA at 10 or more puts you in a 60% probability of cancer. Make sure the urologist referral is to a competent and experienced prostate cancer specialist and surgeon. I recommend a major cancer center that specializes in PC. At this point, you want to stop wasting time. Early detection and treatment is the path to successful treatment and managment of what can be a very treatable and managable cancer. You've wasted too much time already! I want this post to be a smack to your forehead. Get out of your head and start taking care of your health! It's taken you 14 years, in the face of rising PSA numbers, to learn biking may have a modest effect on PSA test results? You are in a tough spot. Biking won't fix this, and you have a way of thinking that may kill you. Early action is the key to beating this disease. You are well into squandering that advantage. Finding your way here is a bright spot. Now, can you get out of your head and into the game? Thoughts that matter. Your next step after finding a competent highly skilled prostate cancer urologist is a biopsy. Make sure you get one in the next three weeks.

Posts.Title: Hello from SW Florida

Posts.Content: State of the art biopsy is a 3T MRI guided biopsy. There are versions of it; fusion guided or live. TRUS biopsy was the standard and is quickly fading. Many urologists still offer it because it is an in office one step procedure, but it is very limited in range of sample area it can reach (less than half the prostate), is a blind sampling and has a 50% false negative record. The 3T MRI highlights significant cancers so the needle biopsy can be direct to the actual potential cancer. May have to assert yourself to get it, but do not be dissuaded. Google it to learn more. Still not readily available everywhere with trained providers, but it is accessible and well worth the effort. This is something to take seriously and move forward on. Not difficult, but the operative words with this cancer is early detection. Once you know what you have or don't have things can often slow down, but now is not the time for that. Again, early detection.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: I was prescribed 5mg Cialis 3 times a week for healing therapy. It has a 17.5 hour half life, and 36 hour quarter life providing an effect up to 36 hours after taking. Viagra (sildenafil) has a 4 hour half life. Cialis is more popular because of this. My understanding is it increases blood flow for healing. I have no reason to doubt it, and my experience was that it did. I noticed it aided the recovery of my continence. Whenever I stopped/forgot there was a slight increase in drbbles, and when I restarted it improved slightly. I no longer take/need it. I did experience lower back pain/discomfort. There were online mfg coupons available for significant savings. https://www.cialis.com/cialis-savings-card.html

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: You will on occassion get conflicting advice. I suggest you seriously question any recommended use of antibiotics as a diagnostic tool for prostate cancer. It creates future risk of complications with resistant bacteria during biopsy and surgery. If a urologist suggests it you may consider it reason to question his skills. Here is just one of many articles and studies that warn against the indescriminate use of antibiotics for elevated PSA. https://www.nature.com/nrurol/journal/v4/n1/full/ncpuro0702.html

Posts.Title: First post from confused man

Posts.Content: Did you read the study I posted? The use of Flomax can be a useful tool as an indicator of prostate cancer. Reduction of PSA indicates BHP. Steady or rising PSA while taking Flomax indicates a higher probability of cancer (67%). You do not yet meet the parameters of the study, but the trends are the same. It is obvious you have an angry prostate that is not playing nice. Your challenge is to find a team that can get to the bottom of this and stick with it. It may be BHP or inflamation, now it is also to rule out cancer. Glad you found your way here, and you have your work cut out for you. I'd suggest a major cancer center. A trail of different doctors, systems, and practioners is not serving you well.

Posts.Content: "This suggests that the life expectancy of healthy elderly men is commonly underestimated and emphasizes that individual health status rather than chronological age should guide treatment choices. A critical aspect of treatment choice is a profile which includes a life expectancy. Very intimidating consideration, but one essential to a life plan, cancer or no cancer. The myth you will die of something else before PC kills or seriouly erodes your quality of life is misguided in so many ways, and while meant as a comforting thought it may be contributing to denial, delay, and undertreatment.

Here is just one of many articles and studies that warn against the indescriminate use of antibiotics for elevated PSA. https://www.nature.com/nrurol/journal/v4/n1/full/ncpuro0702.html
Posts.Title: First PSA

Posts.Content: I'm a big fan of healthy diet. Green tea and olive oil are gold. Limiting refined sugar and wheat is a healthful practise, imo. I do caution about the use of supplements that affect your PSA when you are using your PSA to monitor for cancer, especially recurrence post treatment. If your cancer is localized, early detection of recurrence and early radiation treatment is an effective combination if going for a cure for intermediate risk cancer. I have not yet been convinced that a particular use of food will cure cancer.

Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: Glad to see you back. A few notes in the use of language. Unless you are in a professionally managed and monitored AS program you are not in AS. Managing this on your own is valid and taking time to assess your situation is valid, but it is not AS. Your clarity in this disease will come with clarity in your language. Your thoughts, actions and outcomes will follow a shift to your clear use of language around this disease. Most are not clear that our language drives our knowledge and actions and not our thoughts. Once you are clear in the language of this desease you will be clear in your actions. The use of testosterone, regardless of purpose, can manifest in smaller more agressive cancer that is difficult to find and can present early in younger men. Glad you have stopped it. I have two friends my age who are using it. Once I mentioned my situation and cautioned them about it's use they went silent on it. Most men are irrational when it comes to this disease. Sadly, I believe I am unwanted reminder of their lack of care. It has affected our relationship in they don't ask and don't tell. The burden for me is to quietly watch it unfold. My advice is to continue to monitor and diagnois while you upgrade your healthcare support and lose weight in anticipation. You may now be motivated. Also, be cautious of the rock stars in the industry. Search for those with experience with obese men. Don't count calories, count "added" sugars. Natural sugars bound to their original fiber is okay. It is the added (refined) sugars added to low fat and diet foods to compensate for reduced calories that is the culprit. Most labels now list added sugar. You can eat all the calories of fruit, nuts and vegetables you want. Just don't put "reduced fat" salad dressings or toppings on it. The reduced calories have been replaced with sugar. Consider a fiber supplement to support the reduction in food. One without added sugar. Next add in a low salt diet. Added salt, as a flavor enhancer, is also an indicator of poor quality food which contributes to fat gain. This is more difficult than the sugar. Government standards for salt consumption is twice what it should be. This will almost eliminate all processed carbohydrates, such as bread and processed grain anad snacks products. You will intially loath this diet, but the outcome will make you a believer and may save your life. Keep us posted. Watch "That Sugar Film." It is on Prime, Netflick, and youTube.

Posts.Content: State of the art biopsy is a 3T MRI guided biopsy. There are versions of it; fusion guided or live. TRUS biopsy was the standard and is quickly fading. Many urologists still offer it because it is an in office one step procedure, but it is very limited in range of sample area it can reach (less than half the prostate), is a blind sampling and has a 50% false negative record. The 3T MRI highlights significant cancers so the needle biopsy can be direct to the actual potential cancer. May have to assert yourself to get it, but do not be dissuaded. Google it to learn more. Still not readily available everywhere with trained providers, but it is accessible and well worth the effort. This is something to take seriously and move forward on. Not difficult, but the operative words with this cancer is early detection. Once you know what you have or don't have things can often slow down, but now is not the time for that. Again, early detection.
