Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Welcome. Cut out the coffee, tea, caffeine, soda, and alcohol until you have your continence back. I'm serious! Do the kegel's. Your age, weight, and physical condition will also affect the speed of your recovery. Patience and diligence are your mantra. It takes time, and it takes effort. Don't just wait for it to come back. Go get it. Take ground at every opportunity. If you can make the pads work - use them. If you're wearing old out of shape cotton underwear ditch them! Get hip and switch to synthetic stretch underwear to hold the pads in place. Pay attention to when you dribble or leak and create reminders to use your kegels. For example, getting in and out of the car was always a squirt for me. So I used the mantra "stay together - stay together" flexing my kegels every time I got in and out of the car. Do this for all aspects of stress you encounter. When you urinate exercise stopping the stream, holding it, and releasing it. Do it without tightening your anus. Try to lift your perineum up like an elevator, slowly up and down, stopping half way up on the way up and half way down on the way down. It is no longer an automatic reflex. You have to exercise it relentlessly and it will then become automatic with time and diligence. The side of effect of buffing up your pelvic floor muscles is physically intense orgasms.

Posts.Title: Hello first post

Posts.Content: "This suggests that the life expectancy of healthy elderly men is commonly underestimated and emphasizes that individual health status rather than chronological age should guide treatment choices. A critical aspect of treatment choice is a profile which includes a life expectancy. Very intimidating consideration, but one essential to a life plan, cancer or no cancer. The myth you will die of something else before PC kills or seriouly erodes your quality of life is misguided in so many ways, and while meant as a comforting thought it may be contributing to denial, delay, and undertreatment.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: A biopsy is your next step unless you can wrangle a 3T MRI. Also, consider upgrading doctors to a cancer center that has experience with PCa that presents early. This disease presents in very common ways with common treatments, but it also has rare ways. No reflection on your current doctor.
Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy at 32

Posts.Content: It may be time to start an MRI sticky. Mine was used to prepare for surgery after the biopsy. The biopsy was conclusive for me to choose RP. The doctor, to his credit, was looking for a bigger picture to map his work, location, extent outside the prostate, etc. The positive biopsy warranted the MRI cost. A negative biopsy with elevated PSA warranting an MRI is also now being accepted. From what I have been reading the use of MRI to replace TRUS biopsy as the second level of diagnosis after PSA, DRE, and urinary symptoms is a ways off. Major studies are underway, but they will take time.

Posts.Title: New labs and PSA back

Posts.Content: It's also what will you do if you find something. Also, what is your life expectancy? I estimate mine to be 90. That statistic will expose how much is at risk. What was the Gleason score on your one positive sample? Is anything you are taking/doing impact PSA levels? I agree with DjinTonic's observation. Your PSA history occurs as being impacted by something. Is there an explanation? The numbers indicate a probability it is not a reliable indicator. Without it how can you make an informed choice with no other infromation? The drugs you are taking can significantly impact clinical PSA levels without translation. If so, your PSA is no longer useful to you. In fact, you have no idea of the status of your cancer other than you discovered it 7 years ago. It has only grown. If you were getting a PSA of 5.5 with a very small cancer it may be more aggressive than you think even if what you found was only a small amount of G6. If it continues to be hard to find in a normal size prostate and your PSA continues to increase while on the drugs you are taking it may be a smaller more aggressive cancer. It is obvious you have a bias and want to be done with this. Who can blame you? But, it explains your doctor's concern. I do not recommend you do nothing unless you life expectancy is 5 ot 10 years out.

Posts.Title: Does inadequate PI‐RADS reader training lead to conflicting mpMRI study results?

Posts.Content: My urologist ordered an MRI to map out the extent of the cancer before surgery. I recommend it be considered before whatever your next step is. You may have to ask for it. You now have a good argument for it if the insurance company bulks, you've tested positive for cancer. It will do a good job of showing the extent and location. Not to rain on this parade, but my cancer was upgrade to 3+4 after surgery creating a slightly higher risk than revealed by the biopsy. While 6 cores is less invasive it is also less information. Not sure I'm a fan of that approach once the decision and risk has been taken on to have a biopsy. My MRI PI-RADS was 5 (which I only recently learned). The system may want you to choose your treatment plan allowing the team proceeding to direct obtaining the MRI. To me, the added information may be helpful in choosing your path, but I have no experience with this particular path. I chose surgery based on the biopsy, my research, and the conversation with my surgeon. The MRI was my surgeon's doing. Knowing what I know now, it is good practice. I never asked to be briefed on the MRI. Inexperience! Fortunately, it would have reinforced my choice for surgery. Remember, whatever you choose you can always continue to evaluate along the way and change your direction at any time or with new information. As said already, you are on top of this and it's the best place to be dealing with it.

Posts.Content: It's normal. Another way to consider it is why wouldn't the scrotum be sore? My scrotum took more than a month to return to normal size, color, and longer to regain it's normal feel. Provide good support. Use 100% synthetic stretch briefs/boxers. Ditch the cotton underwear that sag and lose shape/support. The synthetics also work better with continence issues later on. They support the lite pads better and dry faster when you drip after going pad free.

Posts.Title: 7 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: There's more to life than life or death. Comparing death rates as the only measure of success is a low bar with this disease, imo. I waited by practising denial. I finally acted to treat through an aggressive intervention by my GP. I'm glad I did. In hindsight, the choice to act brings with it the view I would have acted sooner once I accepted action to treat as my choice. I was upgraded and the volume was significant. My urologist considered volume an indicator of recurrence. Was I practising some form of AS? Probably. Did it work for me? So far, so good. Would I do it again knowing treatment was still the outcome? No. Early detection and treatment works, but no carte blanc. There is an optimal time to act. Assuming you have a competent surgeon, side effects are the outcome of the aggressiveness of the cancer, i.e. how much has to be cut. SE outside of that parameter may be related to older age, surgery mishaps, and aggravation of already developing SE's from the deterioration of the prostate and plumbing. I was developing incontinence and erection issues before my surgery.
Posts.Title: Is AS Deciding not to decide?

Posts.Content: Just another note, there are/is studies that show better results when treatment is started as early as .03 when adverse conditions are present. Your lymph nodes are an adverse condition. Sounds like your getting sound advice from your docs.

Posts.Content: Pheripheral zone biopsy's are difficult to reach with traditional TRUS type biopsy. I'd expect better results with the MRI fusion type. You got this covered. Surgery is a younger man's game with younger men have better outcomes with the side effects. On the other hand, early presentation of cancer makes it a longer game with the realization you will always be looking over your shoulder. You will just have to learn to live with a cure. That's the worse part of it. Best part, early detection and early treatment give you the best odds.

Posts.Content: Surgery is the number one choice and for good reason. Radiation is improving as they work to control it's toxic nature and deliver it to the cancer. It's no surprise surgery leads the way. It is older technology than radiation. I hoped to be a candidate for surgery. Was pleased when I was. The upfront risk of side effects was clear and limited. Fortunately, I survived them. Three factors contributed to that, imo; the skill and experience of my surgical team, the nature and extent of my cancer, and my age and general health. There is a broad field of radiation choices that appeared designed to address common fears around surgery and those who are not candidates for surgery. There is a clear and developing path to safer treatment with radiation. HDR brachytherapy is one, imo. For me, it was still too new to rely on, and again, I was a clear candidate for a successful surgery experience. I expect to live into my 90s. Unknown side effects 20 years out are a consideration for me. Early HDR brachytherapy treatment protocals used too high a radiation dosage. That's a big oops for those men. I acknowledge and appreciate those brave men being on the leading edge of developing technologies. Whatever your choice, early diagnosis and early treatment is still a gold standard.
Posts.Title: Which treatment is most common?

Posts.Content: Just another note, there are/is studies that show better results when treatment is started as early as .03 when adverse conditions are present. Your lymph nodes are an adverse condition. Sounds like your getting sound advice from your docs.

Posts.Title: Surgical incontinence vs BPH vs Over active bladder

Posts.Content: Cialis at this stage is more therapeutic than erection causing. I used 5 mg 3 times a week. It flushes blood into the area. Taking it intermittently causes blood to flush in and out. It is similar to ice and heat for an injury which causes blood to flood the area and then retreat. This aids in healing. Erections will come later, so to speak. On average a year, or even more. Nerve tissue has been traumatized by being touched, pushed, pulled, bruised, and exposed to heat trapped in the surgical cavity caused by the cauterizing element on the end of the scope used to cauterize blood vessels. Nerve tissue heals at a much slower rate than other tissues. Also, I masturbate at least 3 times a week in addition to fun with the partner. Fun with the partner is for the relationship. Masturbation allows me to work it more intently and to massage blood into the penis making sure I fully engorge the penis, as best I can, and achieve an orgasm. I can witness the improvement over time, but not session to session. These sessions are much longer and designed to be therapeutic. Use it or loose it. The garden variety urologist is a surgeon and looses interest fast after the surgery and focuses primarily on cure and healing result statistics for their own records. They are not the go to guy for ED. Seek one out if you are not having results. I had my first morning woody this morning. It was about 50%, but it was there and uninitiated. It does take time, and you have to do your part.

Posts.Title: Fighting Depression

Posts.Content: Exercise and improve diet, but what's the problem with pills? Depression is the common cold of mental health. Everyone gets it, it is contagious, & you along with many of us have good reason to experience it. Seek treatment if exercise doesn't improve it. It can begin to effect your partner. You can regain your balance naturally, but pharmacutical aids are valid. Just like decongestants and antihistamines can help you through the worse symptoms of a cold antidepressants can do the same for depression. Vitamin D3 works. Especially during the winter months if your short on sunlight depending on where you live and your outdoor activity. Takes a few weeks.

Posts.Title: Fighting Depression

Posts.Content: Create your plan. When will you take the next action based on PSA levels? Then pick a test that will provide the sensitivity you have planned for. If you are not planning to act until a specific number why bother watching it climb or not below that number? On the other hand, why not know? If your plan is to react at .1 there may be peace in accepting it as soon as possible even when you know you will not act until it reaches your target. Is there value in velocity at this level? Will your treatment plan change to sooner if the number is rising quickly? What about a rise that levels off before your target? I know so little about how this diagnostic works post RP that all I have is questions. Does the when and how fast matter? Or, are there only a few scenarios that are possible, i.e. no rise with no treatment, rise and level off with no treatment, or rise and treatment, or rise and no treatment and how soon it rises and velocity doesn't matter at all. I chose a 2 decimal test. For my profile, it seems early enough.
Posts.Title: Ultrasensitive PSA and PSA analogue

Posts.Content: All tests will lead to a biopsy for you based solely on your PSA history. Even a clean MRI or one that suggests low risk cancer can not explain, nor will it be reassurring, in the face of a rising 9.6 PSA. I'll wager a fine meal every conversation you have with urologists will end with a recommendation of a biopsy. Your choice will be fusion guided or not. Hard to see way too many choices in that scenario. The treatment choices, should you have to consider them, will render themselves just as simple fi that time comes. Here's the twist. Simple isn't easy. You can take a multitude of tests and if even one is outside safe parameters you are incomplete. A steady rising PSA offers only one path, a search for cancer until you find it. A biopsy is the bottom rung on that ladder and until you find it you can forget about the confusion of treatment options. Take all the test you want, but the steady rising 9.6 is all you need to move on to biopsy.

Attempting AS or watchful waiting without a plan to biopsy at some designed point is a game of pin the tail on the donkey. As you note, my focus is simple.

Posts.Title: 1 year Post Op Update

Posts.Content: Tell him. Tell him what you are going to tell him. Then tell him. Tell him you love him, and thank him for the gift of love that is now yours to give to his grandchildren. Thank him for the wonderful life he created for you. Thank him for the children you have to enjoy. Thank him for being the source of your life. Thank him for doing a good job. Thank him for the protection, nurturing, and strength he has provided. Grateful and authentic is the being you want to be. Be present for him. Sooner than later, and I recommend you do it alone. There can be other occassions that include others, but this moment alone with you for him is precious, in my opinion.

Posts.Content: Your age, PSA history and current PSA velocity call for a biopsy. Avoiding it only avoids dealing with the possibility of cancer. Taking a long path with many tests of varying degrees of usefulness will result in the same event, a biopsy. Deny and delay and you lose any advantage of early detection. You can't outsmart cancer. All paths for you lead to a biopsy. Nothing else moves this process forward faster. You are lucky. You already know your next step. Some never have a chance to see it coming. Don't squander it, too many brothers have suffered building this path for us.

Posts.Content: Started kegels before surgery. Continent in 3 months. Slight stress dribbles can still occur with caffeinne, carbonation, alcohol, full bowel, or end of day fatigue. I suspect side effects are determined by two factors; the skill of the doctor and the extent of the cancer. If the doctor is qualified it comes down to the extent and type of cancer. There may also be personal characteristics that make the surgery more challenging or healing less robust. Healing (or regeneration) of nerve tissue takes longer than muscle tissue. Both can be damaged and sometimes beyond healing. ED took a little over a year to recover for me. This is mostly nerve related. Therapy and diet are the 2 things you can impact. My understanding is time will tell. How much time I suspect is your question. From what I read, can be more than a year. I have not heard of anything changing after two. My brother has had some improvement at a year, but not complete.

Posts.Title: First Biopsy completed, waiting for results

Posts.Content: I get it. However, 3 years ago he moved into biopsy territory with his 2 -3 numbers. He's let it cook now for three years. He's already expressed a bias to his urologist who is now compelled to work with it. Sure, get another PSA test, but note the doctor's order for it in 2 -3 weeks. That is essentially immediately. Curing cancer and AS begins with a biopsy. I do not dispute the risk of biopsy or cancer. A bias which designs a course to avoid a biopsy is flawed, imo. Attempting AS or watchful waiting without a plan to biopsy at some designed point is a game of pin the tail on the donkey. As you note, my focus is simple.
Posts.Title: ExoDx (Ordered by PCP) Encouraging Score, and Urologist Initial Visit

Posts.Content: Supplements with anti inflammatory qualities are beneficial for just about everything, but will not cure cancer or stop it from presenting. They are also present in a healthy diet in appropriate amounts. If not, its not a healthy diet. In other words, the nature of a "supplement" is to compensate for an unhealthy diet and lifestyle. If it helps you achieve a healthy weight it may work, but if your BMI is not between 19 to 24 the odds are you are overweight and your diet and lifestyle is counter to your health regardless of the supplements you take. Abdominal fat is a higher risk factor for PC than supplements will benefit you, imo. The biggest risk to your health is thinking you are not overweight when you are. Taking supplements may tempt you to think you are doing something. If you continue to be overweight, supplements are only a finger in the dike. If they are an attempt to compensate for a poor diet and lifestyle while you make adjustments, good for you. You have found what is missing in your diet and you can go to work on it. Indulging in supplements may be a warning flag you are missing identifing major components, good and bad, in your diet. Mega dosing on these benefitials may not only be deluding your acceptance of what a healthy lifestyle is but may be counter productive to it if its all you plan to do. No amount of pomegranite juice may be able to compensate for 10 pounds (yes, that little) overweight and a sedentary lifestyle. Consider your cancer is already set in your DNA regardless of your current diet and lifestyle. Interestingly, the switch that is designed to turn off a prostate cell may have been turned off much earliar in your life by an unhealthy diet, lifestyle choice, or stress experienced by you as an infant or embryo or your mother while pregnant with you. That so many are experiencing it implies it may be a culturally prevalent imbalance or stress. Taking something today to undo what was set in the bone a generation before may be folly. Focusing on your current diet and lifestyle as it may impact you as an example and the provider of the same for your children and grandchildren may be a healthier strategy.
Posts.Title: First Biopsy completed, waiting for results

Posts.Content: Started kegels before surgery. Continent in 3 months. Slight stress dribbles can still occur with caffeinne, carbonation, alcohol, full bowel, or end of day fatigue. I suspect side effects are determined by two factors; the skill of the doctor and the extent of the cancer. If the doctor is qualified it comes down to the extent and type of cancer. There may also be personal characteristics that make the surgery more challenging or healing less robust. Healing (or regeneration) of nerve tissue takes longer than muscle tissue. Both can be damaged and sometimes beyond healing. ED took a little over a year to recover for me. This is mostly nerve related. Therapy and diet are the 2 things you can impact. My understanding is time will tell. How much time I suspect is your question. From what I read, can be more than a year. I have not heard of anything changing after two. My brother has had some improvement at a year, but not complete.
Posts.Title: Poll question: post Prostatechtomy

Posts.Content: PIRADS II is "probably benign". It is not a detection of nothing. PSA is high. It is double the normal 2 for his age. fPSA is low. The PSA tests (both) have been a slow and steady increase as evidence of cancer. He is very young indicating a possibility of an aggressive type of cancer. I agree with the second opinion to have a biopsy. False negative will be on the low end of 30% for a young man with a small prostate. This is what early detection looks like, imo. Keep on top of it.

Posts.Content: A recent study I read considers 1,600 to be a level between competent and excellent. However, larger health systems have the ability to attract highly skilled surgeons and select them based on their personal performance statistics. We do not often have access to these statistics. Choosing based solely on numbers seems a poor screening technique, imo. If a surgeon is on the low side in quantity, but part of a larger successful cancer center I'd consider the reputation of the center above an individual surgeon's gross number of surgeries. This makes me less confident of surgeons in private practises. This all seems arbitrary and I think it is, but it is the manner in which our healthcare industry works. The flip side is large institutions can hide poor surgery practises as we recently learned about a "rock star" doctor who claimed an impossible number of surgeries and was exposed for "supervising" other surgeons and taking credit for the surgeries. We often don't know who is performing what part of our procedure once we are put to sleep. It is a very fair and important question to ask and insist on regardless of what you sign.

Posts.Title: De Vinchi Seurgon

Posts.Content: "Radical prostatectomy is a major operation that can cause serious and life-threatening complications such as blood clots in the legs and lungs, abnormal heart rhythms, heart attack, pneumonia, and infections. The risk increases in older men and in those with other medical conditions, such as heart and lung disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, or a history of blood clots. Some studies have shown that side effects, namely urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction, also increase with age." My 71 year old brother survived the surgery, but developed clots in his legs. His heart is strong. His incontinence persists. Older age also implies older cancer and more extensive cutting. The surgery requires the patient be inverted slightly, head down, on the table for an extended period of time. This is added stress to a major surgery. I hear 75 as a common age limit. Less as adverse conditions multiply. The doctors have legitimate concerns.

Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: Don't be too hard on them. Any anti inflammatory influence may effect PSA modestly. It is a very valid caution. In my denial and delay phase I manipulated my PSA with diet and supplements. It made no difference in the progression of my cancer. Once I stopped it rebounded right back to the curve upward overtaking any losses. The time I lost avoiding treatment put me at higher risk for recurrence. Early detection early treatment is the best chance to cure your cancer, any cancer, imo.
Posts.Title: Alfuzosin and PSA

Posts.Content: I am not questioning a couple of small studies. I'm am advising against a view that undermines Mayo's credibility.
Posts.Title: Alfuzosin and PSA

Posts.Content: I was experiencing a decreased flow, smaller bladder capacity (frequent urination), and slight incontinence. All improved with the stream being the most dramatic. I have the stream of a teenager. These improvements alone were enough to consider the procedure a success. Increased bladder capacity has taken more time and is less dramatic. The restriction of your urethra from BHP and/or the cancer causes you to use your bladder muscles more to forceably expell urine. This thickens them reducing bladder volume. This condition is less prone to reverse. I was also beginning to experience some ED. While erections have returned post surgery the nerve damage caused by an enlarged prostate is more likely to be permanent. Cialis helps this. I speculate some men's frustration with ED post surgery is in part related to an already developing ED. My surgeon was clear in letting me know erections will recover from the surgery, if successful, but no better than before.

Posts.Title: Fevers after catheter removal

Posts.Content: Moving your care to a cancer center specializing in prostate cancer for a team approach makes sense. Prostate cancer is treatable. Not all prostate cancer is the same. You have a very serious case of an aggressive form with a head start that may require multidisciplines over an extended period of time. Once that decision is made let the new team perform their own tests and scans. Their expertise extends to both performing and interpreting the scans and tests. Surgeons, radiologists and medical oncologists will confer together for your husband's treatment. He will most likely be considered for all three. His fitness, age, general health, and extent of cancer and aggressiveness will determine if he is a candidate for starting with surgery. If it has progressed beyond surgery, or he is not fit for surgery, then radiation and hormone deprivation therapies (ADT) are used, and many options and combinations are available. Sorting them out and choosing the best for a specific case is an advantage to the team approach. Completing his signature will allow those here with similar experiences to comment. They are here and will support you.

Posts.Content: Sorry this is happening to you. Your husband no longer has the capacity to care for himself. Like a drowning person he will take you down with him if you are not careful. You want to find some help. Do not try to manage this yourself. Regarding his life expectancy, it doesn't matter for you now. The burden and emergency are now and they are you. You can not sustain him or his wishes regardless of how long you may think he lives. You are looking for legal and financial care and help for you. Seek these through social service and non profit agencies. Others here may have direct referrals. Do not think in terms of how long you can maintain the current situation, but how you can separate yourself from sole responsibility for his care. Good luck.

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: A 9.1 PSA warrants a biopsy, imo. Your young age only makes it more so. Be careful going forward with anyone who is advocating you avoid basic healthcare. Someone is causing mischief. Studies are reassuring that it is not the case. Their view that biopsy spreads cancer applies to biopsing all cancers, and biopsy is the only way we have to diagnose any and all cancer with certainty. Are they suggesting nobody have biopsies to diagnose cancer? If there is cancer don't you want to know about it? Not having a biopsy will certainly spread it if it's there, because nothing happens to treat cancer until you have a successful biopsy diagnosing it. Prostate cancer is treatable, but not unless you can find it with a biopsy. Sounds like someone in your family is in denial about cancer and healthcare. They may need your leadership in this more than you need theirs. Be your own advocate. Once you're in the crosshairs everything shifts and you get real serious real quick. Don't get drawn into the weeds.

Posts.Title: Question about Biopsy

Posts.Content: I had two hernia repairs this past year. One was at the site of an old laproscopic surgery incision 25 years ago in my belly button. Just below the RP incision. It had slowly been widening over time. I could actual feel it. About the size of a quarter. Ballooned out the size of a grape when I strained. The other was a more common inguinal hernia. Doc said it was wear and tear from age. It can also present as a side effect of the RP and colonoscopy inflations. They certainly don't help. All told, had my belly inflated 2 times and my colon 3 times. Had both hernias repaired at the same time. Straight forward procedures. They used mesh on both. The belly button was a little tougher to close up I was told. I suspect from all the scar tissue in the area from the laproscopic tools rooting around from both surgeries.

Posts.Content: See the sticky at the top of the forum page, "How to list your stats...." Your stats will be listed as your signature on each of your posts. Or, members can check your profile and see them. See other signatures to see how to do it succinctly. It helps us, but more importantly it helps you keep the salient facts front and center. There is a habit our mind has to focus on the facts that support denial or delay, the two demons of cancer. Your signature is in essence your medical chart. Keep it updated and front and center in all your considerations. It is purposefully limited in size to avoid hiding the facts among irrelevant stuff. It's a useful tool to aid you in beating this. You will continue to refine it as you learn what facts about yourself and the disease are the important ones in your choices as you move forward.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Gleason 9, psa 20

Posts.Content: Moving your care to a cancer center specializing in prostate cancer for a team approach makes sense. Prostate cancer is treatable. Not all prostate cancer is the same. You have a very serious case of an aggressive form with a head start that may require multidisciplines over an extended period of time. Once that decision is made let the new team perform their own tests and scans. Their expertise extends to both performing and interpreting the scans and tests. Surgeons, radiologists and medical oncologists will confer together for your husband's treatment. He will most likely be considered for all three. His fitness, age, general health, and extent of cancer and aggressiveness will determine if he is a candidate for starting with surgery. If it has progressed beyond surgery, or he is not fit for surgery, then radiation and hormone deprivation therapies (ADT) are used, and many options and combinations are available. Sorting them out and choosing the best for a specific case is an advantage to the team approach. Completing his signature will allow those here with similar experiences to comment. They are here and will support you.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Gleason 9, psa 20

Posts.Content: "Radical prostatectomy is a major operation that can cause serious and life-threatening complications such as blood clots in the legs and lungs, abnormal heart rhythms, heart attack, pneumonia, and infections. The risk increases in older men and in those with other medical conditions, such as heart and lung disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, or a history of blood clots. Some studies have shown that side effects, namely urinary incontinence and erectile dysfunction, also increase with age." My 71 year old brother survived the surgery, but developed clots in his legs. His heart is strong. His incontinence persists. Older age also implies older cancer and more extensive cutting. The surgery requires the patient be inverted slightly, head down, on the table for an extended period of time. This is added stress to a major surgery. I hear 75 as a common age limit. Less as adverse conditions multiply. The doctors have legitimate concerns.

Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: Your concern about biopsies spreading cancer is denial and delay. Denial and delay are commonly referred to as the two demons of cancer.
Posts.Title: Been watching and waiting for 7 years but now concerned with PSA and EP

Posts.Content: The presence of cancer at the base (actually at the top towards the abdoman and seminal vesicles) is also a concern. Effectiveness of treatment options for this location is a consideration.

Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Gleason 9, psa 20

Posts.Content: A second opinion is almost always in order, but not if it is an excuse to postpone action. Your insurance man's remark is outdated and dangerously misleading. If he is in an actively monitored surveillance program provided by his health care system and adhering to their protocol I would expect an explanation with his comment describing all he is doing in serious pursuit of his own health and in a concern not to mislead you into resignation. If he has been diagnosed and knows his Gleason scores and volume of cancer there is no wait and see. We have very good prediction tools as to what he may expect. If he knows via biopsy, within reasonable odds, that his cancer is low risk he may be advised to enroll in an active surveillance program and be prepared with a plan for action if it changes. With no more information than what you offer about him I say he is whistling past the graveyard. Many of us have practiced some form of denial and delayed action in the beginning. I know I did. It is what motivates me to participate in this forum. I am here with a story of survival that has to do more with good fortune than my own diligence in the beginning. It is true you may die tomorrow of another blocked artery you are unaware of. So, let it be that. I suggest you continue to deal with what you know and pursue a continued diagnosis and treatment for your cancer under the guidance of your doctors. That spirit has served you well so far. I will add that if your urologist allowed your PSA to go so high without determining the source, regardless of what you may have said, I suggest you find another urologist.

Posts.Title: Psa 25.54

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RogerD Pretty sure I am going with hormones + EBT. The Urologist and RO say the odds are about the same and the side effects sound much worse on the surgery side. Though I understand a lot is based on individual health. The RO had put my numbers into a Sloan Kettering database and it showed under the 'Extent of Disease Probability' that the 'Organ-Confined Disease' was only 17 and the 'Extracapsular Extension' was 80 which meant I would be not be a good candidate for a trial that is going on right now and that radiation would be better because it gets around the prostate into those tiny vessels where the surgery could possibly leave some behind. What concerns me is that I am told that surgery cannot be performed after radiation if it did not work well. You're having the one shot anxiety. Surgery is possible after radiation, but not ideal, only a limited number of surgeons take it on due to the condition of radiated tissue, but it's not the point. The choice, radiation or surgery, each has it's pros and cons. Some choose it thinking one is better than the other which is only partially true. It's choice specific depending on the patient profile. Everyone has doubts. Once you choose don't look back.
Posts.Title: Pretty sure I am going with hormones + EBT

Posts.Content: Be prepared. Also, on BCR the sooner the better for treatment, imo. I would not wait. Your doctor appears to be correct in his recommendation.

Posts.Title: Pretty sure I am going with hormones + EBT

Posts.Content: Diet and supplements will mess with your PSA, but they will not cure or prevent prostate cancer. Funding for this review was provided by Hallelujah Diet a bibicaly based diet. Dr. Aaron Katz sells a veggie/vitamin D supplement. I personally believe vegetables are good in your diet and many older Americans suffer vitamin D deficiency. It is a crucial vitamin. I recommend you have your vitamin D levels tested and take D3 if necessary. Also, get outside in the sun!

Posts.Content: The temptation with this disease is be the bearer of good news. It happens here and with professionals as well. A doctor wants to say, "I got it all" and "you are cured" more than anything. Rarely is it something that can be predicted with certainty. Most of the upset and frustration with this disease is in the lack of integrity in the language around the risks and statistics of this disease. Most of us can come to terms with our physical being and mortality. It's sorting the facts from obtuse language, our hopes, and wishful thinking that is the most difficult aspect of dealing with this, imo. 0.2 is detectable PSA. In addition to taking on this next phase your friend has the added burden of coming to terms with his emotions of being misled (real or imagined) by someone he wants to trust. I suggest you refer him to this site, and avoid discussing his condition unless he asks. When he speaks make listening noises : ) This will be more difficult than trying to "help."

Posts.Title: Got A UTI Now What?

Posts.Content: Here is a good article that concludes that if you are on the drug you should be getting biopsies if your PSA rises regardless of the multipling factor. Your PSA should not be rising on the drug. It may suppress low grade cancer as a form of weak hormone therapy, but it will not stop or slow more aggressive cancers. The risk is men on the drug will postpone biopsies missing the opportunity for early treatment in the presence of aggressive cancers. I suspect the impact of the drug lasts longer than 6 months in terms of restoring your PSA to a reliable indicator. It has been shrinking and supressing cell growth and low grade cancer with low hormone therapy for 5 years. If in addition, you have more aggressive cancer it has had no impact on it. I find it's use troubling and poorly understood concerning cancer. If you have BHP and low grade cancer it can work, but who is ever certain of that? Not many. http://www.drcatalona.com/quest/quest_fall08_1.htm What were your brothers PSA numbers? Some cancers present with low PSA numbers. He's your best model.

Posts.Content: You're right on track. Your young age is a factor not usually encountered in these forums and the general rules sometimes do not apply. My own reading concurs with you that the cancer can behave differently and more aggressively in younger men with the early onset being the first indicator. It is a very important consideration. Keep seeking out expert advice in your health care system that has experience with this particular nuance. Be wary of any AS recommendations. Look for more advanced diagnostic approaches. Ask about 3T MRI to get a better picture of any hidden stuff trying to sneak out early. Even that may have its limits with the smaller lesions even if they are aggressive. Ask about a saturation biopsy. These suggestions are if you want more information to plan your treatment. A safe call is surgery with a doctor skilled in your situation able to assess extent and make the call during surgery to take more or less. Most surgeons do not do pathology screenings during surgery. This may be another option for you. Whatever path you choose ask the doctor specifically how many patients they have treated in your age group and what were the stats going in and what were the outcomes. There is no substitute for successful experience. Keep taking ground. Nobody is going to carry this ball like you will.

Posts.Title: don't know what to believe

Posts.Content: I understand. I took aspirin and drank red wine, had a outdated "healthy" diet, and exercised. I still got cancer. My experience with aspirin was it caused internal bleeding evidenced by dark stool and a couple of ulcer episodes. This may not be a risk for everyone, but for me long term irritation and bleeding of the digestive system didn't work. Especially without the intended result of preventing cancer. I do suspect it artificially lowered my PSA at the time I was denying my cancer. Much like it treats a fever, it may help symptoms. I do subscribe to an anti-inflammatory diet, and am slowly becoming a vegetarian. I find it much more challenging than taking aspirin. This is not a dig, but evidence of the temptations to take short cuts. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/heart-disease/in-depth/daily-aspirin-therapy/art-20046797 This article discusses the risk. Fish oil supplements increases the risk as well as alcohol. Not everyone is susceptible to the bleeding risk. I am. Typically bleeding shows up as dark stool. Healthy stool is the color of cardboard and floats.

Posts.Content: I imagine prostate cancer as the prostate cells generating cancer cells through out the gland. The density, frequency, and speed are all uniquely individual. It is a condition as much as anything. It makes radiation attractive becasue it radiates all the cells with the goal of irradicating cancer cells. Cancer cells have weaken DNA and often can not survive the radiation. Healthy cells do, but they are stressed in the process. Surgery offers a similar therapy by attempting to radical removal the entire gland. Spot treatment seems to put to fine a point of it, imo. I know longer trust the gland.

Posts.Content: Would not have been a problem for me. Your details are important. If there's bad news it could put a lot of stress on things. Incontinence could be stressful dealing with diapers or pads for the first time if it occurs. It took 3 months for me to return to normal. My productivity was way down. A vacation could work if it's a relaxing low stress one. Like lying on the beach. If it's a forced march type of trip it's doable, but why?

Posts.Title: First visit with Surgeon PRE-Surgery

Posts.Content: I'll play the second opinion urologist. "3.6 is normal for your age. Don't worry about it. We will check it again in a year." You can check it again now. My view, I'd do it based on the 1 point in a year move. I'd also confirm it immediately. Be prepared for a grey zone. It may drop a little, but not all the way back. Then what? Or it goes up some more. Recheck your PSA, either way, get the biopsy, imo. Then the next is a MRI if you need it. You have a script for a biopsy. Use it. Now if this guy isn't the guy to see you through the next 20 years then shop urologists. But, he gets a vote from me for ordering a biopsy.

My local health service can not/will not test below 0.06. I thought I was helping by giving them the testing business. Mea culpa. It's not their model. They were unclear in the language and options. They called the 0.02 limit ultrasensitive. Lesson learned, your primary is good for screening. Go through your urologist/MO/RO and a national lab for post treatment testing.

Posts.Content: I see no medical advantage in local treatment. It is irrelevant to a medical decision. Its much easier to go to the mountain than pretend there is a mountain in your backyard. America is an amazing country and traveling a few hours is a small inconvenience compared to people in other countries that have no options than dying from disease. Sounds like your mother telling you to eat your vegetables and be grateful you're not a starving child in Africa.
Posts.Title: NW Indiana Robotic RP recommendation

Posts.Content: I assume you're asking preradiaion treatment. The only nuance is if it has a < sign in front of it. The < sign means it is measuring somewhere, or not at all, below 0.1 and can be moving around below that limit and you will not know. If the < sign is not there it means you actually measured 0.1 twice in a row and that is considered detectable by most/many. If those are the first measurements after your surgery many/most may conclude the surgery was a failure for a cure. The repeat number is somewhat unexpected. The expectation is it will rise depending on the time between tests.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: Welcome, while late to the party, you appear to be on top of this now. If you have questions, feel free to ask. Short of information, follow your doctor's recommendation on the hormone therapy, lose weight if your BMI is not between 19 - 24, have surgery sooner, and practise your kegels. All of which I suspect you already know. Based on what you have shared, I suspect the doctor's concerns are: understaging, a lower than normal PSA for the cancer detected, and obesity (a BMI over 25). The body scans are of limited value at this point other than to rule out a treatable distant metastisis. Since I assume you know this I say it for others, the location of the known extension in fatty tissue is an accelerant. Did the doctor recommend, in your best interest, another surgeon to move the surgery forward?

Posts.Title: New Member, Wife

Posts.Content: A side bar to the above encouragement. The way your brain works matters with this disease. You can't out think this. Those who try squander their opportunity. The brain is wired to avoid (shows up as denial) or delay. Early detection, early treatment is the key to staying ahead of this disease at every stage. The treatment protocols work if they are used. Shifting the brain from avoidance to treatment makes a difference with cancer. Some doctors, mostly men, share this same disfunction. Pairing up with a doctor who doesn't take this disease seriously may be more of the same for many men. To support this fact of professional denial, only 17% of internists and GPs screen for prostate cancer. Unexplainable and bad medicine, but still, it is a fact. The cancer doesn't have a brain. It is a mechanism. ADT disrupts the mechanism. You want a new drug. There isn't one. It's all we got. That and an overwhelming will to live. Use your will to shift your head in this matter.
Posts.Title: Lupron and on and on?

Posts.Content: You do not share enough of your history to make a useful comment on your specific case while searching for evidence to dismiss a doctor's recommendation. So, there's that. If the 3T scan is lighting up cancer then you want to know what it is, where it is, and how much it is. PIRADS 2 (which you are implying without sharing the score) is worth investigating. Rarely does this forum advise not following a doctor's recomendation unless it is obviously heading into the weeds. This is not that. Here's a tale. "My PSA climbed from (less than yours, so there's that again) and my GP referred me to a urologist for the first time. My urologist retested/confirmed the PSA. I decided at that point to do a prostate MRI, even though it wasn't covered by insurance. It came back with a PI-RADS 2. I made the decision to wait. Just today ( year later) I had a MRI, post-diagnosis. It came back PI-RADS 5. What was a surprise was that my radiology oncologist reviewing the radiologist's findings on today's MRI took a good look at the old MRI and told me that there were indications on that MRI that bore further investigation even though PIRADS2. Like a complete idiot, I didn't bother to get the first full MRI report, I just took their word for it, and thought PI-RADS 2, 30% chance of something and 70% chance of benign/nothing. Lesson #1 - get the full MRI report and get it in the hands of someone you trust for a 2nd opinion. It really matters who is reading your MRI. Kind of pissed that I could have had a year's jump on killing this. Today's MRI indicated (2) PI-RADS4 lesions and (1) PI-RADS 5 lesion which "closely abuts the base of the seminal vesicles, which have a mildly low T2 signal, raising concern for bilateral seminal vesicle involvement". This is also now being confirmed/2nd opinion'd with yet another radiologist....." Your comment, "didn't find anything at all" is not true and is classic denial in the face of obvious evidence and professional opinion. Get the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Targeted Prostate Biopsy (confusion)

Posts.Content: No urologost should claim you are 100% curable. There are no guarantees. You have a good chance, high probability, good prognosis, optomistic, etc. Consider a new doctor.

Posts.Content: The increased use of Cipro is leading to an increase in infection complications in biopsies. If you were given Cipro for any number of reasons related to prostate cancer, prostatitis, and UTI you are at an increase risk of complications and this includes our community in general. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4039591/ If you get another biopsy make sure it includes a general array and not just an MRI targeted area. If you prostate is large you may want to include more than the standard 12.

Posts.Title: Lupron and on and on?

Posts.Content: Welcome and sorry for the news. As you will see we like to see your history and biopsy report information in your signature. It is an indicator that you have it, read it, and understand it. By referring to a "few (3?) other spots" my assumption is 5 samples came back with cancer. (That typically rules out AS.) It indicates a casual dismissive approach that you may want to sharpen into more serious focus. Everyone has a unique response to the news, but almost universally there is an immediate bias of denial and preferred treatment methodology which shows up in how we present (or not) the facts of our diagnosis and disease. For example, why did you wait 2 years watching your PSA climb past the warning flag of 4? It doesn't matter now except as an indicator of how you are inclined to approach what comes next. Also, your doctor's slow response to an alarming PSA and your urologist prescribing a BHP medication with such a high PSA raises a concern about both. Typically a PSA over 10 puts you in a higher risk group and is seldom an indicator of a benign problem. Regardless, cancer has to be ruled out. It is not likely your prostate doubled it's size in 2 years from BHP or that BHP is responsible for such a fast and steady rise in your PSA. Your elevated PSA is an indicator there may be more to know about your cancer than revealed by the biopsy. TRUS biopsy is an inexpensive in office valuable diagnostic tool, but it is fallible with a 30% or more false negative and it goes has high as 50% in older men with larger prostates. You are fortunate that it detected your cancer the first time. First thing to realize, it is no guarantee of the whole picture. For clarity, your comment 12.9% involvement of the prostate is not correct. Percent involvement by cancer of the prostate is usually known by surgical removal of the prostate and a pathology report. A pathology report of the biopsy will indicate a percent involvement of cancer of each sample only. A biopsy sample is a minute part of the entire prostate and you probably had only 12 samples taken. Imagine a piece of tissue thinner than a wet kite string less than 3/4" long. Most likely 12 of those were taken. Much of your prostate was unsampled especially if it has doubled in size. I think your on the right track seriously considering radiation. I'd advise against ruling out surgery without more information. Surgery is a younger man's game both in fitness to recover continence and erectile function and less concern for the longer term side effects of radiation. If I were you I would want to see more diagnostic information and suggest you ask for a 3T MRI, and preferably one that can be fused for a guided biopsy. Everyone, surgeon or radiologist, is going to want to know more about where and what your cancer is before proceeding with treatment. My surgeon wanted an MRI before surgery to map the area even though I had already agreed to surgery. I expect a radiologist will want the same. The advantage for you is you can withhold treatment choice until you have the information as well. If you go to a major cancer that has an experienced prostate cancer team they will be able to share this information easily. This is a very treatable disease and not one to be taken lightly if you want success treating it. If you were electing surgery with the information in hand not much more need be done and once the gland was removed you would have a clearer picture of what it is, where it is, and if it has gone beyond the prostate. Choosing radiation requires more information, imo. As often said on this forum, if you choose radiation you only have one shot it at. You want to know where and what it is before you take that shot. http://news.cancerconnect.com/prosta...ostate-cancer/

Posts.Content: There are other forms of arthirtitis that cause pain, psoriatic arthiritis is one. Sometimes the joint problems begin before the skin lessions or the lesions are mild and diagnosised as eczema or dry skin such as cracked heels.
Posts.Title: Aches and Pains and Prostates

Posts.Content: I had no expectations. It's cancer. It played out just as I was informed. I had no illusions about what was at risk, and what may happen. Posts.Content: My own experience with health care professionals is they have a bias towards conservative treatment. When dealing with life the industry is reluctant to take risks associated with newer treatments. This isn't a bad thing. It's just a thing to be aware of in your own advocacy. I suspect the majority of doctors are as generally informed as we are. Professionally, they just won't go there. The research component of the industry will go there, but day to day healthcare usually does not. I think we want it that way. It does give us a responsibilty to be our own advocates. Its counter productive to be hard on competent professionals when dealing with diseases we do not yet fully understand and for which we been provided a myriad of effective treatment possibilities, imo.

If your serious about diet get your BMI between 19 and 25. Use diet to get and stay healthy. Using it to cure cancer is about something else. A lifetime of diet may have contributed to your cancer, but I will ascert it occurred on a DNA level early on in your life in the the development of your DNA and influenced by heredity and evironment, such as cultural diet. Don't get lost n the weeds.

Posts.Title: Disappointing 2nd opinion

Posts.Content: Unless you have other issues it will improve quickly. I remember looking down as it just ran out. Within a few days I was good with the big pads and one or two nights with diapers and a sit pad in bed. Only ended up using a few diapers. Did you do kegels in preparation? Start them now. It will take a few days for the numbness to clear up and catheter use itself leaves some incontinence because everything stops being used. I don't see a signature so have no info on your age. Typically, the older you are the longer it takes. Surgeon should be able to tell you if he had to take a lot and will have a good idea on how quickly it will come back. 3 months is good. 6 months is average. Getting to a point where pads work happens quickly. I was back to work with the catheter. I have an office job.
Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Content: The power is in the choice. No choice, no power. A forum dedicated to explaining and defending isn't a forum. It's a mob. Our culture is currently dealing with temptations to bully, conjole, and manipulate agreement. Unfortunately, it spills over into forums like these and they lose their value. In language, it is the distinction between deciding and choosing. When we decide we kill off what we decide against. When we choose we leave what we do not choose alive and valid for ourselves and others for another day. Not to stirr a hornet's nest, but the best example of this today is belief in religion that relies on righteousness when wanting to be right overides what works, choice, and being with others.

Posts.Content: Strengthen the core. Do planks and other core exercises. It will improve your golf game. Check your vitamin D at your next physical. Sounds like you will be fine in that regard with all your outdoor activities. My experience was once I chose a treatment path I moved up the schedule. Sooner still applies. This is still a time depended process with no guarantees. I get the take your time to evaluate plan, but it's event sensitive. Once complete time is no longer of value unless there are other considerations.

Posts.Content: Do not ignore it. Deal with it. The reason many of us choose surgery is to have this two punch combination if we need it. Your young, healthy, and in love. Enjoying yourself isn't something you have to put on hold as you go about the business of taking care of yourself. If you want to continue to impress your new relationship be responsible for taking care of yourself. I want to acknowledge you for moving past a doctor that was less than aggressive in diagnosing your cancer. Regarding your post surgery infection, were you given antibiotics previously for prostate symptoms such as urinary issues or your rising PSA?

Posts.Content: Whatever the treatment plan the next doctor will want an MRI just for the lay of the land. Diagnosing what it is is no longer as valuable as where it is. An MRI lets him know how far he may have to go. Your concern about how far it has gone is valid, and of value to your treatment plan as well. I suspect it is in the next doctor's plan to have an MRI. If not, I'd wonder why?

Posts.Content: The use of ineffective supplements is not advisable including testosterone. Saw palmetto has no affect beyond placebo. It does not shrink the prostate, lower PSA significantly, or treat cancer. The turmeric may reduce your PSA slightly. You do not want this effect if you are using your PSA to track your cancer. Stay out of the weeds.

Posts.Title: golf school and PC

Posts.Content: Yes, do not think of prostate cancer as a tumor to be extracted. Think of it as a condition of your prostate. You now know any of your prostate cells can now be capable of producing the type PC you have. If the biopsy found one area there is a high probability it exists elsewhere or it is capable of producing it elsewhere in the prostate. Technology has not advance to the point we can treat lesions or these cells as they develop on goingly. The technology is capable of identifying prostates that produce cancer, the grade of cancer and then treating the prostate in whole. It's a one shot deal with some follow (clean) up strategies. The success of the surgery regardless of type relies on the skill of the surgeon. This is somewhat different than many surgical procedures. For DaVinci, 300 procedures is considered a minimum. One small study puts expert at over 3,000 procedures. It is a technically challenging procedure that requires some specific apptitudes not found in all who aspire to be surgeons.

Posts.Title: 3+3 = decision time

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark524 1) Don't believe everything you read/hear. I had an 3T MRI 6 months ago which came back clean. My Uro still suggested a biopsy afterwards even though they did not see anything. A few people pointed towards a recent study from a top Doc in Switzerland showing in the study that 100% of the people with a clean 3T MRI who had a biopsy afterwards came back with a clean biopsy. Taking that into account (or perhaps using that as an excuse not to risk the biopsy infection possibility) I waited 6 months for another PSA and when it came back even higher I called my doc to schedule the biopsy. Looking back without reading that survey I may not have waited. Then again there is always the possibility that everything is true. Your cancer was undetectable when scanned. Would now be detectable or still not, and/or you are fortunate your biopsy caught it. The study may have been accurate as well, but you would have to drill down into the details to see why it may skew as it did and who financed the study. I am one for tracking the langauge. I would not refer to an MRI scan being clean. I'd say it did nto detect anything. There is a distinction which you are now aware of. There is a high probability you had cancer cells that were undetectable during the MRI. If caught in a biopsy sample they may be visible under a microscope. Like everything around this disease 3T is becoming a very useful tool, but nothing yet trumps a physical sample showing cancer.

Posts.Title: Saw palmetto

Posts.Content: High dosage of vitamins and herbal supplement are now responsible for 20% of all liver damage. One particular is green tea extract which contains compounds not found in brewed green tea. Unless you have a proven and monitored difficency, such as D and calcium, they are best avoided. They are untested and unregulated and often produced in countries with little to no oversight. Fat soluable supplements can end up stored in the liver. If you are relying on these supplements to counter the symptoms of BPH or cancer they will not cure these conditions and have only temporary effects. The conditions will progress and in the case of cancer may contribute to a phase of denial and delay impacting your overall success dealing with the disease. Also, weight loss and body building supplements are notably responsible for this kind of damage.

Posts.Content: Do not ignore it. Deal with it. The reason many of us choose surgery is to have this two punch combination if we need it. Your young, healthy, and in love. Enjoying yourself isn't something you have to put on hold as you go about the business of taking care of yourself. If you want to continue to impress your new relationship be responsible for taking care of yourself. I want to acknowledge you for moving past a doctor that was less than aggressive in diagnosing your cancer. Regarding your post surgery infection, were you given antibiotics previously for prostate symptoms such as urinary issues or your rising PSA?

Posts.Content: Wow! You have come a long way. I agree surgery will probably include radiation follow up. Others will have more to offer.
Posts.Title: OH - What to do?

Posts.Content: Relax. At this point everything is numb to sensation. It takes time. Nerves and muscle tissue take time to recover, swelling has not gone away, etc. If you can stop your stream at this time your ahead of the game. I remember just standing there watching urine run out of my penis with no sensation at all. Weird, and normal. Take care of yourself. Go easy on the Kegels for a few weeks.
Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: Your PSA may be within a normal range. Your age and BHP may be enough to hand your urology care over to a urologist. Often this transition happens after an issue is detected. Effective healthcare suggests it happen before. A young urologist is best equiped to serve you through the next 30 years that is almost certain to include prostate issues of some sort. The young urologist can establish a baseline and make lifestyle suggestions if your GP/internist hasn't already. Sounds proactive to me. Gives meaning to healthcare over illcare. To your credit you are asking questions best answered by a urologist. Your doctor is listening to you. Kudos to them!
Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: Let's not ignore the obvious. What you are describing is your friend dying of prostate cancer. It is a long and painful way to die. Questioning his competence to manage his healthcare at this time may not be helpful. Viewing his doctors as conspiring to profit from his illness may be why he's not sharing with you. What you describe makes him incompetent and his healthcare team crooks and murders. He may not appreciate your low opinion of him disguised as concern. People differ in their approach to serious illness and death. He is dying and your job is to just be. Stop the questioning and apologize for what he obviously considers inappropriate concern. It's his life. He gets to say how it goes. He may not want to spend his last days explaining advanced prostate cancer to you or listening to how you are dealing with it. It is not uncommon for friends of those dying from cancer to perceive the chemo treatments as the ultimate cause of death. Sometimes it is, and the patients are understanding of the risks associated with last effort chemo therapy treatments. His choice. You may want to acknowledge him for his inspiring courage, strength, and will to battle his disease. I have a friend who is managing his prostate cancer with diet, herbs and vitamins. His wife constantly asks how I am doing in front of him putting me in an awkward position of saying I'm doing fine. His response is always to be tight lipped. I honor him in this and never question him. More importantly for you, how are you doing? What's your current PSA?
Posts.Title: Worried about a friend with prostate cancer possibly being overtreated / scammed

Posts.Content: I had bladder spasm near the end of my catheter period. Very, very, very painful. Uncontrollable. Just had to beathe through them and wait them out. Similar to birth contractions, but probably not as large. I found pushing some with them relieved some of the discomfort. Resisting them and trying to make them stop only made it worse. When I asked the doctor he said it was a sign of healing. I assumed attempt by the bladder to reject the catheter. Mine was in for longer than normal. They continued mildly after removal of the catheter whenever I urinated and ended within a few days. It is a muscle cramp. If you had an enlarged prostate and reduced stream your bladder (a muscle) has gotten muscled up forcing urine through the restricted urethra. When it cramps you will feel it. Try some electrolytes.

Posts.Title: 2 weeks post RALP , 4 days post catheter

Posts.Content: There have been some studies that indicate salvage radiation is most effective when administered as early as possible. Some say as early as .03. You will need to have at least 2 rising numbers to confirm this. The intent of an ultraPSA test is to get those 2 rising numbers earliar than later. Most health systems still use numbers as high as .3 and .2 as the threshold for follow up radiation. It is accepted that these are arbitrary numbers established for some time. The thinking behind early detection early treatment is to treat the recurrence, if detected, while it is still as small as ppossible and as localized as possible. Salvage radiation is somewhat of a shotgun approach to the bed of the former prostate. It can be directed to specific areas where your pathology reported margins or higher grades of cancer. The sooner, the smaller the area, the more effective it is at hitting and treating localized cancer cells left behind. The counter argument is it may be remnants of health tissue, or a low grade cancer that will never catch up to it's former self to do any harm, or postpone possible side effects from treatment as long as possible (especially if your still healing from surgery) without reducing the chances of successful treatment. However, it is also said G3 can not exist outside the prostate. So depending on what you believe, it's not G6 indicating it's a higher grade (what was your pathology?) or healthy tissue. My position for my case is to consider it cancer. Either way, the uPSA supports the standard of early detection early treatment is the most effecive method of dealing with this disease. The longer it takes to BCR the better your prognosis. I am suspect of the old bedside manner that manages what I know and keeps information from me for my peace of mind. It is an old and worn reason and the best they have to what amounts to an arbritary threshold at this point. I am at a 30% risk of BCR. My surgeon said we will monitor your PSA on an annual cycle. I said thanks, but I prefer every 6 months. He said okay. I take an intermediate test that's low threshold is <0.02. The margin is a little tight for getting my notice prior to .03, but possible if it happens slowly. I am consdiering changing to the uPSA. I like that your docotor is open to it. Retesting was your first step. Next step is to talk with the radiation team and see where they are on their protocol, and set them up to be taking over your care from the surgeon. His work is done. Everyone will be fine with pushing this off to higher numbers if that is your approach. On the other hand, staying in front of this all the time seems the most effective approach to me. In the end, the radiation team you select is the one to make the call now.

Posts.Title: What A Relief! Decision Made so on to the cure

Posts.Content: Your PSA will hopefully drop because you killed the cancer cells producing PSA with radiation or stunned them into remission. Healthy cells are still doing there thing and producing PSA, so you will have some PSA and hopefully it is low and stable. To your question, does radiation cure/stop BPH or prostatitist or will your numbers continue to bounce around never giving you the chance to be certain of recurrence? I don't know, but will consider it is the same as before; bouncing around equals BHP or prostatitis; steady rise equals cancer; both bouncing around and steady rise equals both BHP or prostatitist and cancer. Most men have BPH. It is a natural process of aging in the prostate. So cancer usually comes with BPH. Those with less BPH and a more steady PSA are fortunate. Regardless, if it continues to bounce higher, on average, you probably have cancer. In other words, if you graphed enough data's points, when you look close at the line it is bouncing, but when you step back and look at the whole line it is graphing up and not returning to a true stable number. Looking at your signature, I'd say you are at risk of having cancer. I have not heard much on the presence of BPH or prostatitis impacting a treatment choice. Or own moderator had a prostate so large from BPH it was creating it's own side effects and influenced a choice to proceed with surgery. Does radiation offer the same treatment outcome, i.e no more concern for an enlarging or inflamed prostate. Great question.
Posts.Title: BPH, Prostatitis and Different PCa Treatments

Posts.Content: Waiting only helps cancer if there is cancer there. Going the radiation route based on pathology is playing the odds. It's the smart play. In case you need reminding, you're high risk, lots of cancer, was not organ confined in a high risk area (bladder neck and SV) and you took testosterone. You may have had a good surgeon, but they are not that good. You've been lucky once. Don't push it, imo. Listen to your doctor.

Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: My father passed from kidney cancer. It is difficult to detect early enough. At this age, the odds are high it has metastized and treatment options are limited and he is dealing with serious quality of life issues and his remaining time. It is reasonable he take some time to do this. A cure is likely not possible and his time is limited with no good choice moving forward. The poster's delimma is he now has an advanced case of prostate cancer that was both detectable and treatable and he chose not to treat it. He has an obvious need to talk about it and I suggest he do so with a professional and not his friend or anonymously on an internet web site. His friend's reaction may not be a pleasant one. This is about the poster having had a choice and his friend not having the same choice. I doubt the poster's action had any influence on his friend's situation. To the friend's credit he is taking a reasonable amount of time to consider his options and path forward. It's apples and oranges.
Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: Don't make stuff up in your head. Unless you ask or he tells you he is following your example unwisely you really don't know. Peeling the onion deeper, it reflects your own personal insecurities that you are a poor example for others. Are either of you going against professional advice at the expense of your own health and responsibility? You may consider you are not giving him credit for making choices for himself. We see in others what we do not see in ourselves. You may consider some counseling to resolve your feelings about your choice for yourself. As a friend, do not share your concern with him about your lack of faith in his ability to do what is best for himself. While you may have this concern for yourself it is best not to share your personal doubts about your choice as a concern for him. Or, in other words, give him the same power and freedom you have given yourself. I will challenge your assumption that being anonymous makes a difference in any of this. You presence sharing here is no less powerful and responsible than with your friend. Being anonymous does not shift responsibility for yourself or others. It is only a pretense that it does. As humans we do one thing very well, we share. If we choose life, we share life. If we choose joy and love, we share joy and love. If we choose pain and suffering, we share pain and suffering. If we choose doubt, we share doubt. Look to what you share to see what you have chosen for yourself. You are doubting your friend. Sharing openly, your own personal experience, is essential for prostate cancer awareness. Just don't make it about others. You may be friends because you share the same ways of being in life. People have a way of finding each other. Your caring for your friend may be a canary in the coal mine for you. Take your blessing where you can get them. Take care of yourself if you can, and in doing so, you will be a good friend. This is getting long, but important. If you have flown you know the oxygen mask drill. Put your mask on first before you try to help others with theirs. It is a basic tenet of being.
Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: Most everyone uses health insurance of some sort or medicare. I am unaware of any treatment that money will buy that is better than what is provided with most health insurance or medicare. Statistically, having a higher education means you will; make more money, live longer, live healthier, and recent studies indicate you will be happier. Having more money doesn't mean you will be more responsible for your health. Awareness, a clear head, and health insurance are the biggest advantages if they provide access to early detection and treatment. In my experience of these, a clear head is the biggest advantage. Depression runs in my family and appears to be the biggest predicter of health care responsibility. The more depressed you are the more likely you are to not seek timely care and to be tempted into denial and delay in all matters including one's education, fitness, and general health. Depression promotes a general decline as we follow our thoughts and scarifice our will. For most with a higher education a resistance to mental health care is the weak link in their healthcare system, not money, access or availability, imo. To answer your question it is education and mental health, not money, making the difference. Having the means is an outcome of one's education and mental health. It is not the source. Peeling the onion one more layer, peace is accessed through acceptance and happiness through gratitude. Being is our access to power. Money is just money. Poverty, on the other hand, is the outcome of oppression. Accumulating excessive wealth is a sign of a lack of balance and mental health and a temptation to well being. Finally, blame doesn't work and the best thing you can do for your children is leave nothing behind including remorse. Sacrifice, as a way of being, is a temptation to turn away from our own power and avoid responsibility for the gift we have been given.
Posts.Title: Does your economic status influence your treatment choice..

Posts.Content: I suspect the rate of prostate cancer is increasing. We do not know the cause. Detection will increase as the population ages, as awareness increases, and as the cancer expands in the population. It's cancer. Blaming detection for overtreatment doesn't work. They are separate and distinct. I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think social stigma also plays a role. Men are reluctant to accept the responsibility for the disease, will not discuss it, and practise denial and delay which feeds complaint and bitterness over the natural outcome of delayed detection and treatment. The denial and delay syndrome is driven by men themselves not stepping up and taking responsibility for their health.
Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: I went a different route and wished I hadn't. GP recommended a urologist when PSA hit 5's at 60yrs. At the time, there was much hoopla about over diagnosis & treating. I claimed other reasons and said lets retest. I made some diet changes, retested, and it dropped slightly. Again at the time, those who thought they new better suggested 2-3 years on PSA testing. Fast forward 3 years and the next test was 7. If cancer is present attempts to lower your PSA on your own may have a slight effect, but rise will continue again relentlessly. GP insisted on referral to urologist. Biopsy showed lots of G 3+3 upgraded to 3+4 after RP. Point, there are other possible reasons for a spike. There is one that can threaten your life. I recommend you procede with the diagnosis path of your choice, but proceed. I was lucky. Today you have more than luck at your disposal. Currently, at least one TRUS biopsy is in most men's future before an insurance company will provide a MRI guided biopsy. TRUS biopsy is 50% false negative so it may not be definitive. Other additional blood tests are available with the PSA. Take advantage of them. Still holding my breath on recurrence. My prognosis is good, and could have been better with a more aggressive and persistent diagnostic phase. This disease will most likely catch up to most men. Stay ahead of it as long as you can. Good sign that you found your way here.
