Posts.Title: Radiation Opinions Sought and Be Your Own Advocate

Posts.Content: Are you in any other higher risk groups besides your age; black, obese? Was your father's cancer prostate cancer, if so, what was it and the outcome? I'd suggest a second opinion on the biopsy samples and a MRI with a second biopsy before you choose to move forward with treatment. What does your urologist recommend, and are they experienced with prostate cancer? Where were each of the samples located? Do you have symptoms? Why were you screening for PSA? What is your PSA history? What's your prostate size? Before you choose what to do take the time to make sure everything is on the table before you and you have identified everything there is to know and not know. Be clear in what bias you may have. Often the choice is difficult because it seems there isn't enough personal information to limit the choices. Often time helps by providing more information about what the cancer is doing; is it growing, is it picking up velocity, is it acting like something different than what the biopsy shows, etc. One snapshot is often not enough to know what's going on. Complete your signature so you can see everything in front of you. If you are inclined to not be forthright with yourself about your condition your choice will be flawed. Make sure you're not looking for confirmation and teeing up the information to get a specific result from us. For me, your age puts you in a higher risk group. I like HDBT if truly low risk and more investgatuve work will be done to confirm you as a candidate. You don't know enough at the moment to choose it. Surgery is a different choice and you do know enough to choose it.

Posts.Title: Incontinence suggestions for returning to work after Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: I suspect the rate of prostate cancer is increasing. We do not know the cause. Detection will increase as the population ages, as awareness increases, and as the cancer expands in the population. It's cancer. Blaming detection for overtreatment doesn't work. They are separate and distinct. I never understood the overtreatment mantra. I think it is linked to the other myth you will die of something else before you die of PC. As life expectancy increases and the cancer expands to more and younger men and more aggressive forms public perception will change. I think social stigma also plays a role. Men are reluctant to accept the responsibility for the disease, will not discuss it, and practise denial and delay which feeds complaint and bitterness over the natural outcome of delayed detection and treatment. The denial and delay syndrome is driven by men themselves not stepping up and taking responsibility for their health.
Posts.Title: USPSTF Backtracks, Now Says PSA Test Is 'Individual Decision'

Posts.Content: Something is missing in what you have shared. I suspect your post surgery pathology was not complete and a higher grade cancer may have been present and was missed or undergraded. Pathologists do not survey the entire prostate. While examination of the margins has the best statistics, missed cancer in the examination of the margin range from 1-3%. Something was left behind with a Grade 4 or more. It does point to the dangers of G4. The problem now is where do you direct the radiation? There are other forms of treatments that are available for metastized PC. This is a game of kick the can down the road, and your experience is a reminder to the rest of us that it is never over for any of us.

Posts.Content: Three suggestions; stop all alcohol and caffeine. In addition to those three suggestions, when you get up from sitting contract the muscle first and clamp your penis with your hand. Full bowels also place pressure on the bladder. Keep them empty and preferably first thing in the morning. Restore your core muscles, do planks. Get your BMI between 19 and 24. All doable if you want it.

Posts.Content: Most everyone uses health insurance of some sort or medicare. I am unaware of any treatment that money will buy that is better than what is provided with most health insurance or medicare. Statistically, having a higher education means you will; make more money, live longer, live healthier, and recent studies indicate you will be happier. Having more money doesn't mean you will be more responsible for your health. Awareness, a clear head, and health insurance are the biggest advantages if they provide access to early detection and treatment. In my experience of these, a clear head is the biggest advantage. Depression runs in my family and appears to be the biggest predicter of health care responsibility. The more depressed you are the more likely you are to not seek timely care and to be tempted into denial and delay in all matters including one's education, fitness, and general health. Depression promotes a general decline as we follow our thoughts and scarifice our will. For most with a higher education a resistance to mental health care is the weak link in their healthcare system, not money, access or availability, imo. To answer your question it is education and mental health, not money, making the difference. Having the means is an outcome of one's education and mental health. It is not the source. Peeling the onion one more layer, peace is accessed through acceptance and happiness through gratitude. Being is our access to power. Money is just money. Poverty, on the other hand, is the outcome of oppression. Accumulating excessive wealth is a sign of a lack of balance and mental health and a temptation to well being. Finally, blame doesn't work and the best thing you can do for your children is leave nothing behind including remorse. Sacrifice, as a way of being, is a temptation to turn away from our own power and avoid responsibility for the gift we have been given.

Posts.Content: Why? What's equal about them? They are uniquely different with different side effects and one is clearly not better than another in a universal context. To my point, two men can be equal in all aspects except sexual practices preference and prefer one set of side effects to the other.

Posts.Title: Does your economic status influence your treatment choice..

Posts.Content: "Superior efficacy" reveals the bias. They are looking for a single superior treatment for localized cancer. Why? A one size fits all treatment for men who want different outcomes based on different profiles and expectations seems to be a bias for one right answer. Here is one consideration not often mentioned. A gay man may want a treatment that leaves his prostate in place to maintain a more active sex life. The prostate is a more important erogenous zone for him than a heterosexual. He may be willing to take a different set of risks. The most compelling bias we have is to be right in our own mind, and we "prove" this to ourselves by recruiting others to agree with our view. At the moment, there is no one cure for all profiles with no side effects. You would need an algorithm that computes all profiles against all side effects including a preference matrix for the side effects.

Posts.Content: Don't make stuff up in your head. Unless you ask or he tells you he is following your example unwisely you really don't know. Peeling the onion deeper, it reflects your own personal insecurities that you are a poor example for others. Are either of you going against professional advice at the expense of your own health and responsibility? You may consider you are not giving him credit for making choices for himself. We see in others what we do not see in ourselves. You may consider some counseling to resolve your feelings about your choice for yourself. As a friend, do not share your concern with him about your lack of faith in his ability to do what is best for himself. While you may have this concern for yourself it is best not to share your personal doubts about your choice as a concern for him. Or, in other words, give him the same power and freedom you have given yourself. I will challenge your assumption that being anonymous makes a difference in any of this. You presence sharing here is no less powerful and responsible than with your friend. Being anonymous does not shift responsibility for yourself or others. It is only a pretense that it does. As humans we do one thing very well, we share. If we choose life, we share life. If we choose joy and love, we share joy and love. If we choose pain and suffering, we share pain and suffering. If we choose doubt, we share doubt. Look to what you share to see what you have chosen for yourself. You are doubting your friend. Sharing openly, your own personal experience, is essential for prostate cancer awareness. Just don't make it about others. You may be friends because you share the same ways of being in life. People have a way of finding each other. Your caring for your friend may be a canary in the coal mine for you. Take your blessing where you can get them. Take care of yourself if you can, and in doing so, you will be a good friend. This is getting long, but important. If you have flown you know the oxygen mask drill. Put your mask on first before you try to help others with theirs. It is a basic tenet of being.
Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: Undetectable. It is the lowest limit on some tests. Mine, for example. I'd prefer a lower limit test, but it will do. My doctor's lab recently changed to a <.06 as there PSA test of choice. I balked and my specimens gets directed to another lab to keep my results consistent. If I had concerns I'd push for 3 decimal test. You're good. Ready, set, relax. I'd recommend you stay on a 6 mos schedule and enjoy every day. Looking forward, the lowest limit I've seen in studies for effective response is .03. Many reputable institutions put it at 0.1. You need 3 consecutive rises to establish BCR. The response varies. You know the drill. I almost forgot. Congratulations!

Posts.Title: Swollen Penis and scrotum

Posts.Content: "Superior efficacy" reveals the bias. They are looking for a single superior treatment for localized cancer. Why? A one size fits all treatment for men who want different outcomes based on different profiles and expectations seems to be a bias for one right answer. Here is one consideration not often mentioned. A gay man may want a treatment that leaves his prostate in place to maintain a more active sex life. The prostate is a more important erogenous zone for him than a heterosexual. He may be willing to take a different set of risks. The most compelling bias we have is to be right in our own mind, and we "prove" this to ourselves by recruiting others to agree with our view. At the moment, there is no one cure for all profiles with no side effects. You would need an algorithm that computes all profiles against all side effects including a preference matrix for the side effects.
Posts.Title: RALP vs RT: a study of treatment decision-making in men with localised PCa

Posts.Content: Why? What's equal about them? They are uniquely different with different side effects and one is clearly not better than another in a universal context. To my point, two men can be equal in all aspects except sexual practices preference and prefer one set of side effects to the other.

Posts.Title: Gone backwards last 2 days

Posts.Content: My father passed from kidney cancer. It is difficult to detect early enough. At this age, the odds are high it has metastized and treatment options are limited and he is dealing with serious quality of life issues and his remaining time. It is reasonable he take some time to do this. A cure is likely not possible and his time is limited with no good choice moving forward. The poster's delimma is he now has an advanced case of prostate cancer that was both detectable and treatable and he chose not to treat it. He has an obvious need to talk about it and I suggest he do so with a professional and not his friend or anonymously on an internet web site. His friend's reaction may not be a pleasant one. This is about the poster having had a choice and his friend not having the same choice. I doubt the poster's action had any influence on his friend's situation. To the friend's credit he is taking a reasonable amount of time to consider his options and path forward. It's apples and oranges.

Posts.Content: Chronic dehydration? Begin measuring the amount of fluid you intake a day. I was subconsciously tempted to drink less to manage post RP incontinence. Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: You are a candidate for treatment based solely on your volume of cancer, imo. The G4 is known to metatisize and your amount is not incidental. Your age, family history, physical condition, fitness, life expectancy, and PSA history all contribute to your treatment choice. We do not have this information in your signature. My experience so far has been a succesfull one with surgery. Continence and erection have all returned. These side effects are influenced most by the extent of the cancer discovered to be removed (difficult to know before hand and unavoidable) and the skill of the surgeon (just as hard to determine). I'd assume a large successfull cancer center will have less risk of a less than acceptable surgeon. They can also walk you through all the treatment options in one stop.

Posts.Title: Update - TIme for a Biopsy ???

Posts.Content: I have noticed incontinence begins to show up when I stop my kegel exercises. Continuing with these exercises, a few sets a day, seem to be critical maintenance. Two years out and alcohol, caffeine, and carbonated beverages still irritate the bladder and cause dribbles when I consume more than 1 drink of any of them. Very manageable. I have switched from coffee to green tea and it makes a difference. I no longer drink alcohol every day. Both practises seem appropriate for my age and diet. Beer is a double effect with both carbonation and alcohol. I have also noticed consuming bladder irritants can have an accumulating effect. If I drink them daily, within a week, I notice incontinence creeping back in. To keep from being discouraged consider the cancer, if untreated, will have caused more extreme incontinence than you are dealing with now. It is a multiprong approach; kegels, weight, and diet. Another risk is we are tempted to manage incontinence by drinking less. This leaves us dehydrated which weakens us. Try a diary for a few days to track your liquid through the day. You may be drinking less during the day and more in the evening than you think. Reality and perception often need accountability tools to bring them into alignment. What may be hiding is your incontinence progress is less than you think it is, but at 4 months it sounds pretty good. Our brains have a mind of their own and can not be trusted. What truly runs us is our word and integrity to it. It usually is a combination of things.

Posts.Content: I'll speak to a surgery point of view. The big advantage to surgery besides removing the bulk of the cancer is the physical examination of the removed prostate, lymph nodes, bladder neck and seminal vesicles. It confirms some of the unknowns, corrects possible misinformation, and can reveal areas where the cancer may have moved beyond the surgery limits. This info helps with follow up treatment plans. You also have the follow up option of radiation after the surgery. Surgery is not generally considered an option after radiation. Nobody wants to go in there after radiation. Too much scar tissue and damaged tissue. I heard it described as having the consistency of a mealy peach. For me, radiation first was the option if the cancer was thought to be beyond the reach of a first attempt at a cure via surgical removal. In other words, taking advantage of possible early detection, youth, and physical fitness gave me a longer game plan. One I thought I may need. My family history is long lived. Using surgery to treat older men and more advanced cases of cancer has a much higher risk of incontinence and ED, imo. There is no avoiding the side effects of the cancer either way. If the cancer is going to force treatment beyond the prostate, the side effects will follow. Although, radiation has made big improvements in reducing damaging power and improving targeting. In radiation, side effects commonly take longer to show up. There is no right answer or better path for us as a group. It is what works best for your profile, and the outcome is what it is. The many treatment options are not really choices in side effects, but choices in treatment. The best treatment choice may not be the best side effect choice. Choosing based on avoiding side effects is a valid choice unless you're not clear it is what you are doing. My commitment is not that you get it right. Nobody knows what it is for you. My commitment being here is you are honest with yourself and the facts as you go about it.

Posts.Title: Combined ADT + RT after Surgery

Posts.Content: Radiation or surgery is the big question, and in the end it is not as complicated as it appears to you now. Be patient, read and participate, stay out of the weeds, and it will come to the surface for you. There are definite pros and cons that mostly stack up depending on your profile. There is no one size fits all answer. They are not interchangable. One is not universally better than another. One is often more suited than another based on your profile which includes your physical condition, general health, age, and type, volume, stage, and location of your cancer. This is really a good thing. It provides options. Professionals may disagree, but when they do they know why. You will too. This is a good palce to get your education. One caution. Be aware (not beware) of bias. We all have it. We are inclined to think our choice is the best and we look for agreement to support it. Another common mishap is to quickly make a choice thinking there is comfort in having made the right/best choice and then it's all bias from there. Don't get stuck there. You have time. It reminds me of the story of the man crossing a field and he come to a wall that is too tall to climb and too long to see either end. He stares for a while, and then tosses his hat over the wall. You will make your way over the wall and get your hat. We all do. What really helps is to complete your signature. It is a distillation of the facts as you know them written simply, like your chart. Seeing it in front of you on a regular basis without all the distractions of possibilites and unknowns that will swirl in your head helps to ground you with what you know. It also helps us help you keep grounded in the facts of what you know. You have already come a long way with detection and acknowledging you are a candidate for treatment. If you have any doubts, you are a candidate for treatment. The Gleason 4 + 3 is something you want to deal with. The next question is it's location. Your biopsy report will indicate the sample location. There can be more. PC is multifocal. Gleason 3 is a turtle, slow and passive. Eventually it can pose a risk to functions just from it's volume, but the general view is it can not survive outside the prostate. Gleason 4 is a rabbit, quick to multiply and move about. Gleason 5 is a bird. It flies. Gleason 3+3 or 6 is all turtles all the way down. Gleason 3+4 or 7 can act like 6 if the 4 is a small percentage, less than 3 - 5%. Gleason 4+3 is a 7 you want to treat. You can see how the combinations and increased risk grows with Gleason 8, 9, and 10. Gleason 8, 9, and 10 can often be assumed to have already left the barn in treatment considerations. If you see my signature, my biopsy was all graded G 6, but a large volume. Based on that, my age (young), and my PSA velocity I chose treament. Post pathology revealed it was really G 3+4 and a good amount. I'm glad I chose to treat it. It was up to no good. I am currently two years post surgery. My continence (back in 3 mos) and erectile function (back in slightly over 1 year) are 100%. My PSA is undetectable using an ultrasensitive test with a lower limit of <.02. I test every 6 months, see my surgeon once a year, and my plan is to see a RO for salvage radiation if it hits .03.

Posts.Title: New Member Confused by the numbers

Posts.Content: That helps. It's a lot of cancer, and you are not a candidate for AS. Convention protocol is surgery for that volume and being young. Such volume at such an early age indicates an aggressive cancer despite the G6 score. It has begun its mischief early. This is a time game. You will be managing your treatment options across time to give you the best option to die of something else. Currently, when the journey begins, 50, 60, 70s, shifts your treatment options. You may consider a second opinion on the samples. A higher G score may impact your treatment options. This is common. It's a G6 that will ultimately cause problems, if not already, based just on volume and its early start. It can restrict your urethra, cause incontinence, compress erectile function nerve paths causing ED, push into the bladder and bowel disrupting their function, etc. I'd advise against picking treatment options at this time. It does reveal your bias against surgery and that is useful for you to know. Your bias is a negative aspect at this time. You will have to set it aside to be objective. Meet with the doctors for each option and develop your choice with information and professional input. In other words, keep an open mind. No treatment protoccol is without it's risks, and none has yet risen to the status of best protocol for every diagnosis. It's a sophisticated decision matrix based more on you and your cancer than personal preference. Major cancer centers make this process convenient with most protocals provided in house. Radiation side effects occur later. Your young age now puts dealing with these side effects into play if you choose radiation. Consider your family history and general health to objectively estimate your normal life expectancy. For example 65% of men with experience ED 5 years after radiation. Both radiation technology and surgery has improved, for different reasons, over the years. Current study outcomes lag behind this curve because of the time they take. My bias is confirmation bias. I am on a surgery first with radiation as follow up if necessary path. So far so good. One year post surgery and no recurrence. Fingers crossed. I take my next 6 month (18 total) PSA test in a month. Below is a basic outline of radiation options. https://www.cancer.org/cancer/prosta...n-therapy.html
Posts.Title: Not sure what treatment any help?

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here. You are getting "some" good advice from your doctors. Due to your young age and high PSA numbers for an extended period of time there is a possibility you have more aggressive cancer still undetected. The two cores that did hit cancer are significant percentages for only two samples of the 12 to hit cancer. I do not consider a range of 5.4 to 7.4 at your age "stable." I question your urologist's letting it go so long without a more aggressive diagnosis effort. The key to beating this disease is early detection and your numbers call for an aggressive diagnosis protocol, imo. The standard 12 sample TRUS biopsy is a hit and miss (30% to as high as 50% false negative). When it finds cancer it is an efficient first line in office diagnosis tool, but it is not 100%. The larger your prostate the bigger the chance it may miss significant cancer. Younger men generally have smaller prostates so there is a better chance it will detect the cancer if it is present. However, you have had an elevated PSA for sometime indicating maybe a larger prostate. How big is your prostate? Also, in younger men, smaller more aggressive cancer can be harder to hit (reach) with the blind biopsy method. Although, I assume if the biopsy was not MRI guided it at least indicated areas for the doctor to try to sample manually. His skill then comes into play. If you are going to get an MRI a 3T MRI gives a much better report, and then it can be used to guide the biopsy sampling in real time. I question your urologist's rather casual attitude to your elevated numbers at your young age. There can always be another reason such as BHP, but you now have confirmed cancer making that possibility a low percentage play which I believe it always was. I like what I am hearing from the MO and RO. I am not so confident in your urologist and suggest you follow his advice for a second opinion from a urologist highly skilled in RP (radical prostatectomy) as your next step. I did not take this route, but from what I have learned you are well served by taking yourself to a cancer center with experience in prostate cancer. Your young age indicates this has a possibility of being something you want to deal with aggressively, especially during diagnosis and treatment planning. It places a burden on an inexperienced patient to manage a professional team of independent contractors. The cancer center takes an in-house team approach.

Posts.Content: No more cotton for me. They quickly lose their shape and are slow to dry from dribbles. 100% synthetic, polyester and spandex. The faster drying time worked better for dribbles after pads. Darker colors also camoflage the eventual stains.

You may consider a second opinion on the samples. A higher G score may impact your treatment options. This is common. It's a G6 that will ultimately cause problems, if not already, based just on volume and its early start. It can restrict your urethra, cause incontinence, compress erectile function nerve paths causing ED, push into the bladder and bowel disrupting their function, etc. I'd advise against picking treatment options at this time. It does reveal your bias against surgery and that is useful for you to know. Your bias is a negative aspect at this time. You will have to set it aside to be objective. Meet with the doctors for each option and develop your choice with information and professional input. In other words, keep an open mind. No treatment protoccol is without it's risks, and none has yet risen to the status of best protocol for every diagnosis. It's a sophisticated decision matrix based more on you and your cancer than personal preference. Major cancer centers make this process convenient with most protocals provided in house. Radiation side effects occur later. Your young age now puts dealing with these side effects into play if you choose radiation. Consider your family history and general health to objectively estimate your normal life expectancy. For example 65% of men with experience ED 5 years after radiation. Both radiation technology and surgery has improved, for different reasons, over the years. Current study outcomes lag behind this curve because of the time they take. My bias is confirmation bias. I am on a surgery first with radiation as follow up if necessary path. So far so good. One year post surgery and no recurrence. Fingers crossed. I take my next 6 month (18 total) PSA test in a month. Below is a basic outline of radiation options. https://www.cancer.org/cancer/prosta...n-therapy.html
Posts.Title: Not sure what treatment any help?

Posts.Content: You are a candidate for treatment based solely on your volume of cancer, imo. The G4 is known to metatisize and your amount is not incidental. Your age, family history, physical condition, fitness, life expectancy, and PSA history all contribute to your treatment choice. We do not have this information in your signature. My experience so far has been a succesfull one with surgery. Continence and erection have all returned. These side effects are influenced most by the extent of the cancer discovered to be removed (difficult to know before hand and unavoidable) and the skill of the surgeon (just as hard to determine). I'd assume a large successfull cancer center will have less risk of a less than acceptable surgeon. They can also walk you through all the treatment options in one stop.

Posts.Title: Should I have a biopsy or wait 6 months to repeat the MRI

Posts.Content: I have noticed incontinence begins to show up when I stop my kegel exercises. Continuing with these exercises, a few sets a day, seem to be critical maintenance. Two years out and alcohol, caffeine, and carbonated beverages still irritate the bladder and cause dribbles when I consume more than 1 drink of any of them. Very manageable. I have switched from coffee to green tea and it makes a difference. I no longer drink alcohol every day. Both practises seem appropriate for my age and diet. Beer is a double effect with both carbonation and alcohol. I have also noticed consuming bladder irritants can have an accumulating effect. If I drink them daily, within a week, I notice incontinence creeping back in. To keep from being discouraged consider the cancer, if untreated, will have caused more extreme incontinence than you are dealing with now. It is a multiprong approach; kegels, weight, and diet. Another risk is we are tempted to manage incontinence by drinking less. This leaves us dehydrated which weakens us. Try a diary for a few days to track your liquid through the day. You may be drinking less during the day and more in the evening than you think. Reality and perception often need accountability tools to bring them into alignment. What may be hiding is your incontinence progress is less than you think it is, but at 4 months it sounds pretty good. Our brains have a mind of their own and can not be trusted. What truly runs us is our word and integrity to it. It usually is a combination of things.

Posts.Content: Check on all of it both before and after my prostate cancer. I eat well and exercise my entire life. It helps, but am not convinced it's the source. I suspect genetic switches are turned on by heredity and environmental conditions prenatal to adulthood. For me, the first clue is BHP and prostate enlargement is the outcome of prostate cells living longer and not dieing at the same rate as they regenerate. Those are potentially genetic functions. Environment, such as diet, are certainly thought to be related to increase rates of PC, but it may be coincidental to good health habits in general.

Posts.Title: Should I have a biopsy or wait 6 months to repeat the MRI

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here. You are getting "some" good advice from your doctors. Due to your young age and high PSA numbers for an extended period of time there is a possibility you have more aggressive cancer still undetected. The two cores that did hit cancer are significant percentages for only two samples of the 12 to hit cancer. I do not consider a range of 5.4 to 7.4 at your age "stable." I question your urologist's letting it go so long without a more aggressive diagnosis effort. The key to beating this disease is early detection and your numbers call for an aggressive diagnosis protocol, imo. The standard 12 sample TRUS biopsy is a hit and miss (30% to as high as 50% false negative). When it finds cancer it is an efficient first line in office diagnosis tool, but it is not 100%. The larger your prostate the bigger the chance it may miss significant cancer. Younger men generally have smaller prostates so there is a better chance it will detect the cancer if it is present. However, you have had an elevated PSA for sometime indicating maybe a larger prostate. How big is your prostate? Also, in younger men, smaller more aggressive cancer can be harder to hit (reach) with the blind biopsy method. Although, I assume if the biopsy was not MRI guided it at least indicated areas for the doctor to try to sample manually. His skill then comes into play. If you are going to get an MRI a 3T MRI gives a much better report, and then it can be used to guide the biopsy sampling in real time. I question your urologist's rather casual attitude to your elevated numbers at your young age. There can always be another reason such as BHP, but you now have confirmed cancer making that possibility a low percentage play which I believe it always was. I like what I am hearing from the MO and RO. I am not so confident in your urologist and suggest you follow his advice for a second opinion from a urologist highly skilled in RP (radical prostatectomy) as your next step. I did not take this route, but from what I have learned you are well served by taking yourself to a cancer center with experience in prostate cancer. Your young age indicates this has a possibility of being something you want to deal with aggressively, especially during diagnosis and treatment planning. It places a burden on an inexperienced patient to manage a professional team of independent contractors. The cancer center takes an in-house team approach.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: First things first. I can not imagine any competent health system suggesting a man in his 60s does not need annual PSA screening, or worse, no annual physical. Your brother in law may not have heard what was said correctly. I expect a different set of words came out of the doctor's mouth than got reported back home. An annual physical is critical for the aging if just for the essentials; blood pressure, cholesterol, weight, preventable and treatable cancer screening such as skin, colon and prostate, then there is diabetes, liver and kidney function, glaucoma, eyesight, dental, etc. What you have learned about your brother in law is he has an unworkable relationship with his healthcare. I doubt any provider at Mayo ever told him what he said, and if they did, those who care about him including himself know better than to believe such a statement. Someone should accompany your brother in law on all future healthcare visits and exams. Your brother in law's current preventable life crisis is proof of the folly of his story. This is not personal, but shining the light on how the mind fails us, if we let it, when we most need it. Or we blame others, some person at Mayo, for our own choices. Even if he was told such a thing, it is surprisingly bad advice to take. I go on about this because the first thing for him and those around him to getting back on track caring for himself is to accept responsibility for his situation and not blame Mayo or his own good health for failing to care for it. Here is the really astounding thing. We all do it, and when we step over the obvious we know we are doing it. Still, we do it. Just as importantly, don't let him blame himself. Blame doesn't work. What has been learned is he can not be trusted with his own healthcare. He needs those close to him to help keep his head clear. Are there signs of dementia or depression to explain his lack of self care?

AgeInfo.Phrase: suggesting a man in his 60s does not need annual PSA

Posts.Title: PSA over 100

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate A new study by one of the top prostate cancer centers refutes the widely-repeated talking point that younger men with low risk PCa should have surgery because they can better recover from it. No, any advantage of faster healing is out-weighed by more years of living with life-altering side effects. http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...693-0/fulltext The study says something different. It studied only satisfaction with erectile recovery. A similar study for incontinence will be interesting and for BCR. The study supports AS, but not broadly as your statement implies, only as it applies to erectile recovery and as it applies to perception in younger men. I support AS as a rigouros program that chooses treatment at the most effective time for the best outcome. Early detection and treatment produces the best outcome for life threatening forms of this disease, imo. I waited too long in ignorance and denial. I am disappointed with my erectile recovery, but find it servicable after one year. I put the responsibility for that on the disease, not the state of medicine or my choice when to act. In hindsight and knowledge I would have acted two years earliar to improve my overall outcomes and anxiety over BCR as a quality of life issue now from waiting too long then. More studies are in order, I'm sure they are coming, that support not treating non life threatening cancers. What drives the choice for me still ranks it; life, bladder control, erections.
Posts.Title: MSKCC Study - No Advantage to Surgery in Low Risk Younger Men

Posts.Content: You are a candidate for treatment. Beware of treatment bias. Your age and cancer location and grade make you a better candidate for surgery, imo. You are not a candidate for AS. Your most serious considerations in choice of treatment is the G4 at the base and your age. This puts you in a higher risk group. G4 can move out quickly and the presence at the base adjacent to the seminal vesicle, a higher risk pathway, is an unfavorable finding. To your age, it has an early start indicating a more aggressive disease. Your PSA velocity and your volume are also important indicators. Surgery is an effective way to excise the cancer in a critical location and provide the pathology to determine it's extent and grading at the base and the best chance at determining if the treatment got it all There is always the risk of recurrence with G4 or higher. Surgery keeps radiation as a follow up option. You have done well to catch it and the TRUS biopsy worked. However, you report a clean bill of health with a 3T MRI in Feb. It missed it which is troubling and seems common enough with this new technology. The cancer you detected with the biopsy was there at the time of the first MRI. It was also of a large enough volume and risk to make that miss a concern for others. Again, PSA was the reliable test. I am begininng to come to the realization that currently a 3T MRI is not yet the diagnostic tool that will replace the PSA test. You are very fortunate to have detected it and have a good shot at a "cure." Cure is used loosely with prostate cancer and always has a time limit to it, 5 years, ten years, etc. Whatever treatment path you choose will include ongoing PSA testing for possible recurrence. Your final pathology will be a better predictor of the odds. In general it's around 30%. Your team's challenge is to stop the G4 from moving north. The prostate terminology is reverse of what we'd think. The prostate base is towards our head and the apex is towards our feet.

I suspect someone at the Lab has to make the effort to change preferences at the request of the doctor. My doctor likes to make that early morning call with the results. As a standard of practise it's understandable at critically milestones, but for ongoing monitoring of an informed patient it makes no sense. If this is your first true post RP PSA I understand his desire to deliver the news personally. They may be some coaching he wants to add to the news. I have been impressed with his management of you. And, I am impressed with you. Your transformation here has been unlike any other. Well done!

Posts.Title: My 9-month post-surgery visit

Posts.Content: That is a common discription of bladder spasms, albeit light. I had severe bladder spasms near the end of my catheter period. Once the catheter was removed they quickly dissipated over the course of a day or two down to the "shiver", and then gone. I had the "shivers" at the end of urinating as a kid so I am now familiar with both. I do not have them as an adult. They are similar feelings. The question is why are they lingering if they are not normal for you? The bladder can still be traumatized and sensitive to cramping. Infections are generally a burning sensation which this is not. It is possible to irritate the bladder with too much water intake. Make sure your water intake is normal and you are not overdoing your water consumption. Just some thoughts.

G4 can move out quickly and the presence at the base adjacent to the seminal vesicle, a higher risk pathway, is an unfavorable finding. To your age, it has an early start indicating a more aggressive disease. Your PSA velocity and your volume are also important indicators. Surgery is an effective way to excise the cancer in a critical location and provide the pathology to determine it's extent and grading at the base and the best chance at determining if the treatment got it all There is always the risk of recurrence with G4 or higher. Surgery keeps radiation as a follow up option. You have done well to catch it and the TRUS biopsy worked. However, you report a clean bill of health with a 3T MRI in Feb. It missed it which is troubling and seems common enough with this new technology. The cancer you detected with the biopsy was there at the time of the first MRI. It was also of a large enough volume and risk to make that miss a concern for others. Again, PSA was the reliable test. I am begininng to come to the realization that currently a 3T MRI is not yet the diagnostic tool that will replace the PSA test. You are very fortunate to have detected it and have a good shot at a "cure." Cure is used loosely with prostate cancer and always has a time limit to it, 5 years, ten years, etc. Whatever treatment path you choose will include ongoing PSA testing for possible recurrence. Your final pathology will be a better predictor of the odds. In general it's around 30%. Your team's challenge is to stop the G4 from moving north. The prostate terminology is reverse of what we'd think. The prostate base is towards our head and the apex is towards our feet.

Posts.Title: Update after 14 months

Posts.Content: Just to reinforce, all other indications must indicate the need for a biopsy or the doctor would not be ordering a MRI (age, family history, urinary symptoms, DRE, and PSA). The MRI only adds to the information already exsiting to support a biopsy, or it doesn't. If the MRI does show something then the doctor will add extra biopsy samples in the area shown as possible by the MRI. A standard 12 core array is usually done in addition to additional samples in the areas suggested by the MRI. MRIs are NOT conclusive, only helpful. It is an emerging technology for this use. They can be helpful if there is possibly a serious cancer that may be hard to reach with a biopsy. Even if the MRI shows nothing a biopsy is most likely in order or the MRI would not have been ordered. In most cases, an MRI is not ordered unless a first biopsy was negative and all other more reliable indicators call for a biopsy. Only a biopsy can detect cancer. Even biopsies can have a surprising significant false negative. An MRI, at this time, can only suggest a possiblity of cancer in any specific place wihtin the prostate. Prostate cancer is multifocal and can be hard to sample. It's not like it's a single mass easily hit with a needle.

Posts.Title: Dce

Posts.Content: Hahaha! She's having too much fun at work. I'll bet she's got that move down. Not so thrilled with your doctor's putting recurrence on the patient as an outcome of managing anxiety thereby inflammation thereby cancer. A little too new age for me. There is an emerging school of thought in genetics that DNA is more responsible for this than we know, and that DNA is more flexible and changing than fixed and slow to mutate. The trigger is stress and environment and occurs in the womb and during infant care. There are much higher rates of genetically responsible health issues in children suffering the stress of poverty. Long story short, worrying about your anxiety now (see what I did there) is closing the barn door after the horse is gone. He's right about the inflammation, imo, but the truth may be the die is cast much earliar, as is our tendency to be anxious.

Posts.Title: HUMOR - This forum blocked in Turkmenistan

Posts.Content: First things first. I can not imagine any competent health system suggesting a man in his 60s does not need annual PSA screening, or worse, no annual physical. Your brother in law may not have heard what was said correctly. I expect a different set of words came out of the doctor's mouth than got reported back home. An annual physical is critical for the aging if just for the essentials; blood pressure, cholesterol, weight, preventable and treatable cancer screening such as skin, colon and prostate, then there is diabetes, liver and kidney function, glaucoma, eyesight, dental, etc. What you have learned about your brother in law is he has an unworkable relationship with his healthcare. I doubt any provider at Mayo ever told him what he said, and if they did, those who care about him including himself know better than to believe such a statement. Someone should accompany your brother in law on all future healthcare visits and exams. Your brother in law's current preventable life crisis is proof of the folly of his story. This is not personal, but shining the light on how the mind fails us, if we let it, when we most need it. Or we blame others, some person at Mayo, for our own choices. Even if he was told such a thing, it is surprisingly bad advice to take. I go on about this because the first thing for him and those around him to getting back on track caring for himself is to accept responsibility for his situation and not blame Mayo or his own good health for failing to care for it. Here is the really astounding thing. We all do it, and when we step over the obvious we know we are doing it. Still, we do it. Just as importantly, don't let him blame himself. Blame doesn't work. What has been learned is he can not be trusted with his own healthcare. He needs those close to him to help keep his head clear. Are there signs of dementia or depression to explain his lack of self care?

Posts.Title: Should I get another 3T MRI

Posts.Content: I had this experience and erection recovery still took a full year. I consider it a good sign, but not proof of potential recovery. The nerves that control the valves that hold the blood in the erect penis are the ones traumatized by treatment. Blood still flows easily into the penis and even physical straining or pushing downward, as in a bowel movement, can begin to engorge the penis. It's not proof you can keep it there. The nerves that are responsible for orgasm are not effected by the surgery. Sexual excitement and orgasm are still functioning. You can achieve orgasm without an erection. I suggest you learn how to manipulate an orgasm without an erection as part of your recovery therapy, and do it often. I found standing during masturbation helped to keep blood in the penis. Massaging blood into the penis during masturbation is possible. Everything helps during recovery. My doctor prescribed Cialis, 5mg (small dosage) 2-3x a week to encourage blood flow during recovery. And intentionally not more often or larger doses unless attempting sex. Much like ice and heat on a sprain, the idea is to pulse the blood through the region for best healing therapy. Nerve tissue can be traumatized simply by the heat generated and trapped by the cauterization tool used in the surgical cavity. Nerve tissue takes much longer to heal/recover than other tissue. Nerves do have the capacity to regenerate. Do not be discouraged. Be patient. Love is patient.

Posts.Content: Yes. There is a courtesy to the doctor delay and a portal data update delay. Someone in the docs office should be able to request the data update not be delayed. Still may take a few days. After my latest go around with the doctor's office and Quest the retest updated immediately. They have the capability. I suspect someone at the Lab has to make the effort to change preferences at the request of the doctor. My doctor likes to make that early morning call with the results. As a standard of practise it's understandable at critically milestones, but for ongoing monitoring of an informed patient it makes no sense. If this is your first true post RP PSA I understand his desire to deliver the news personally. They may be some coaching he wants to add to the news. I have been impressed with his management of you. And, I am impressed with you. Your transformation here has been unlike any other. Well done!

Posts.Title: Completed SRT

Posts.Content: You're wise to acknowledge his primary personality. If you accept it without judgment it will allow you to be with him without being hooked by his depression and anger. Your litmus test is your own emotions. If you find yourself becoming annoyed or frustrated with his behavior take a break. This is his end game and most of us live it as we have lived our lives. Expecting him to transform his view of life from one of blame (source of his anger and justification for his depression) to one of acceptance and the access to peace it provides will only be a source of upset for you. Give him his space, more for you than him. Medically, options for him are limited and do not require much from you other than helpful support/companionship. Support groups may be helpful if he's open to working on his head. It is what can make a difference in his quality of life. Don't expect it. Hold it always as a possibility for him. You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink. On the medical side, antidepressants work, but once again he has to accept it as a condition he wants to deal with. Denial and delay are common ways of being as evidenced by his current physical and emotional health. Inside depression it is a self fulfilling swirl downward. Depression is also contagious. Think of it as the common cold of mental health. We all experience it periodically and it is shortlived. For chronic cases, such as his, look out for yourself first. This is the part of prostate cancer that doesn't get much play. The news is there are standard protocol treatments for this phase.
Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tybeeman I am a believer. I have been doing it religiously for over a year. The first time I did it my penis on came up 1/3 of the tube. The it almost filled the tube. I started injection and developed a little case of Peyronie. so not it pumps out long but i lost grath. Interested to see if anyone else has had that problem with the injections and the pump. Get a good pump, don't go cheap I developed Peyronie within only a few injections and stopped. Showed as bottlenecking at the base or site of injections. Only disappointment so far with the process (not ED but the risk with injections). Erections are still slowly recovering. I was impatient and a casualty of the statistics.

I mentioned it to my uro and he looked at me like I had two heads. I don't think he figured it would work, I thought maybe I could get a script, bit my state does not have medical marijuana yet. If marijuana killed cancer most of America would be cancer free.
Posts.Title: Is prostate cancer irreversible?

Posts.Content: It takes decades sometimes a lifetime to develop cancer. As already stated above, when I asked if it was environment or genetics the doctor said yes. Recent studies indicate DNA contributing to disease is more prevalent than first thought. And environment in the womb and early childhood contributes more to disease causing shifts in our DNA than first thought. DNA switches/shifts/triggers happen much quicker and more often than we first thought. It may well be your mother's DNA and life habits during your fertilization, gestation and infancy that turns on the future cancer switch. That can not be reversed. It is set in your DNA. Degrading cellular DNA is the source of BHP. Prostate cells no longer die at the same rate as we age. They live longer causing the prostate to enlarge. Something similar may be at the root of PC. Degrading DNA is the root of all aging and its maladies.
Posts.Title: Is prostate cancer irreversible?

Posts.Content: Damn - that sucks! I have no experience with AUS. I do have experience with being disconnected from my wife and thinking she's not quite there, and certainly not in the game. It's a lonely place. Sounds like you've been carrying the ball. Best advice I can give for that situation is keep oil on the water. Doesn't sound like something you can fix. In fact, there's peace in accepting it doesn't need fixing. It's just the way it is. The support group sounds like a very good idea. Maybe it doesn't have to be cancer related. I have a group of buddies, anywhere from 2 to 4, and we meet once a week every Thursday, same time, different place mostly but we have some regular haunts, for drinks and dinner. The only thing we have in common is we know each other and we have all been divorced. We call it the HMWHC. It's not that we hate women. It's a reverse mantra to remind us we do love them, just hard to live with sometimes. Maybe most of the time for the less fortunate. It began with supporting a guy who just loss his wife and getting him out of the house. It's a different cast of characters now, but what I did learn was how valuable it is to me to have a steady and regular time with some bros. No agenda, just get together once a week for a few hours and be with each other. When the first group began to disband, and it happens, I worked to put another one together, and it's still going. Funny thing, I was single at the time, and women thought it was pretty hot. They get it and hang together a lot. Men not so much. My current partner encourages it. She sees what it does for me, and it makes me easier to be around and attractive! Seems to be a universal woman magnet to have some independence. I read most of what is on these sites, and participate when I have experience. Sometimes it seems like we're tapping on bars communicating between cells in solitary confinement because we never meet each other, but it works. I'd say what you are doing with this post is what I call clearing. You may be angry and venting, but anger doesn't work. Almost all the time it works just to be able to say what's so to someone. Not to fix it, but just to clear it out. You can always do that here. I'll listen.

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: A diagnosis of cancer is done by biopsy. Usually a TRUS biopsy. Googling many of the phrases and terms you will begin to hear is a good start. Get a copy of the pathology report and history of PSA tests and DRE exams from his doctor. Is your father computer literate? Most health systems have patient portals for accessing test results and reports. Will your father share his user name and password so you can access these for/with him? Begin to build a history at a glance like the signature you will see on this forum. It is important to see a simple timeline of test results and history. It keeps you focused and out of the weeds.
Posts.Title: 2nd Generation Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Theraputic Cialis made a noticeable difference for me. 5mg 2 - 3 times a week. It flushes blood through the site and aids healing and recovery. It is important to not take it daily so it surges. Similar to ice and heat therapy on a muscle injury. The alternating heat and cold expands and contracts the blood flow pumping blood through the site.
Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: First, retest to confirm first test. Recommend first biopsy be a 3T MRI fusion biopsy both targeted and random. Protocol is a standard TRUS biopsy first. A PSA of 29, if confirmed, is not standard. Move yourself ahead in line when you can and skip standard steps in the diagnostic protocol when you can with the guidance of your doctor. Your urologist will support you with this. Keep it moving forward. You will have time to consider as you go. Don't let the system put you off. Be persistent. They will accommodate. Set up your signature. We will be here. Lots of knowledge and first hand experience on this forum. Best I've found.
Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: Usually numbers this high indicate cancer. You are correct to take this seriously. That said, PC is both treatable, "curable", and manageable. It has many forms from nonaggressive to very aggressive. As you put your team in place you may what to consider a cancer center that has a strong PC practice. They offer multiple disciplines and a coordinated team approach if you should need it.

Funny thing, I was single at the time, and women thought it was pretty hot. They get it and hang together a lot. Men not so much. My current partner encourages it. She sees what it does for me, and it makes me easier to be around and attractive! Seems to be a universal woman magnet to have some independence. I read most of what is on these sites, and participate when I have experience. Sometimes it seems like we're tapping on bars communicating between cells in solitary confinement because we never meet each other, but it works. I'd say what you are doing with this post is what I call clearing. You may be angry and venting, but anger doesn't work. Almost all the time it works just to be able to say what's so to someone. Not to fix it, but just to clear it out. You can always do that here. I'll listen.

Posts.Content: Remove the prostate and hope you're not to late. It is the source of anxiety, much medical risk, and nothing but bad news. I'm surprised it hasn't been recommended sooner. I suspect it has. Like an appendix and tonsils it serves no useful purpose at his age. Sadly, poorly performed prostatectomies have created an over reaction that borders on hysteria against removal of the gland that is the source of nothing but trouble in older men. Cancer is not the only valid reason to consider its removal. The younger you are the better your recovery in all categories. Maybe we can help ease concerns if you have been resisting this. Removal of the prostate is only complicated by the presence of cancer. Without the risk of cancer you have only to deal with the risk of incontinence and ED. Cancer may be the inevitable outcome of his BHP. Remove the prostate and you remove the risk. The other possibility is a small but aggressive cancer has metastized. If that's the case you deal with it as it develops, and it may be very manageable. In the mean time you have helped yourself prepare for that scenario by removing a disabling urinary disorder while your are still healthy and able. One last possibility that may complicate a removal. Is there cancer in the bladder?
Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Has foley removed 12 days. Wore pads for 3 months. Control returned over those 3 months. Lose some control now if I have more than 4 hard drinks. Carry a lite pad for such an ocassion which doesn't happen very often. Couldn't be happier. Good strong stream. Up once a night. Bladder volume still on the small side. Always that way, but more so as prostate enlarged. You never recover that aspect.
Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: Damn - that sucks! I have no experience with AUS. I do have experience with being disconnected from my wife and thinking she's not quite there, and certainly not in the game. It's a lonely place. Sounds like you've been carrying the ball. Best advice I can give for that situation is keep oil on the water. Doesn't sound like something you can fix. In fact, there's peace in accepting it doesn't need fixing. It's just the way it is. The support group sounds like a very good idea. Maybe it doesn't have to be cancer related. I have a group of buddies, anywhere from 2 to 4, and we meet once a week every Thursday, same time, different place mostly but we have some regular haunts, for drinks and dinner. The only thing we have in common is we know each other and we have all been divorced. We call it the HMWHC. It's not that we hate women. It's a reverse mantra to remind us we do love them, just hard to live with sometimes. Maybe most of the time for the less fortunate. It began with supporting a guy who just loss his wife and getting him out of the house. It's a different cast of characters now, but what I did learn was how valuable it is to me to have a steady and regular time with some bros. Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: <0.1 is a standard test measure for those not interested in following their PSA by ultra sensitive tests. It is standard test protocol for most institutions unless there are adverse conditions requiring earliar expected detection. It is officially recognized as "undetectable". If you have reason to want to measure your PSA with a more sensitive test you will have to ask. As already shared, it is never seen as <0.100 which implies a 3 decimal ultrasensitive test, but a 3 decimal test will never present this way. That part is strange unless you are adding the zeros.

Posts.Title: Post RP incontinence survey

Posts.Content: You're wise to acknowledge his primary personality. If you accept it without judgment it will allow you to be with him without being hooked by his depression and anger. Your litmus test is your own emotions. If you find yourself becoming annoyed or frustrated with his behavior take a break. This is his end game and most of us live it as we have lived our lives. Expecting him to transform his view of life from one of blame (source of his anger and justification for his depression) to one of acceptance and the access to peace it provides will only be a source of upset for you. Give him his space, more for you than him. Medically, options for him are limited and do not require much from you other than helpful support/companionship. Support groups may be helpful if he's open to working on his head. It is what can make a difference in his quality of life. Don't expect it. Hold it always as a possibility for him. You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make him drink. On the medical side, antidepressants work, but once again he has to accept it as a condition he wants to deal with. Denial and delay are common ways of being as evidenced by his current physical and emotional health. Inside depression it is a self fulfilling swirl downward. Depression is also contagious. Think of it as the common cold of mental health. We all experience it periodically and it is shortlived. For chronic cases, such as his, look out for yourself first. This is the part of prostate cancer that doesn't get much play. The news is there are standard protocol treatments for this phase.
Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Terry's Cellar It's my understanding that the post radiation tissue left behind is no longer like the original prostate tissue before radiation and that it is very unlikely to promote new Pcs. I know mine currently does not produce normal ejaculate. What I produce now may come from the Cowpers gland. Every study I looked at showed the recurrence rate for RT was equal to RP. A lot of the studies actually gave the success edge to high dose radiation treatments like SBRT and HDBT. There is little question in my mind from follobywing a couple of different forums that I see far more posts from the side effects of RP than RT. My surgeon said he could remove my prostate and the cancer. He said I could regain most of my urinary function in a year at so. He said most guys respond pretty well to medications that help with erections. He did not say I should expect penile shortening or mention I might ejaculate some urine during climax if I could achieve an erection. I took my chances with radiation and have no regrets. The studies I investigated including Dr. Kings 10 year results suggest that any future ED is only equal to that of untreated men. For me I found little value in a post surgical pathology of my prostate when weighed against the quality of life issues surgery presented. Just my two cents. No argument here. We're both satisfied. The next conversation is in 5 years.
Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: Good advice from MM. Time to move on to a RO. Was his PSA ever a <0.02? If you had any adverse conditions in your surgery pathology which includes never being undetectable after surgery, best outcomes for follow up radiation indicate the sooner the better. Even as early as .03. One of the advantages of surgery is you can follow up with radiation if necessary. Now is the time to find out what that means which begins with a RO who specializes in prostate cancer, and not the surgeon, imo.

Posts.Title: Update and question

Posts.Content: That works for me. With my prostate gone any improvements in radiation will also benefit me in salvage treatments. The one aspect of radiation that still concerns me is "healthy" prostate cancer cells are left behind. These are the same "healthy" cells that produced the cancers that started the whole thing. I see radiation as kicking the can down the road and it seems for most men it kicks it far enough. For me, I'm satisfied my prostate is gone, but that could just be my justification bias and having survived the potential side effects. Just a note, 65% of men using radiation treatments will have ED in 5 years. Side effects are real regardless of treatment choice. Breast cancer which is a similar disease, common, well researched, and many forms of treatment still relies on surgery to remove the source of the cancer, breast cells. Still, it recurrs. Albeit a much larger gland. I agree that finding more convenient and less obtrusive forms of treatment is the future. I think the doctor, if the quotes are accurate, is being optomistic.
Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: First, retest to confirm first test. Recommend first biopsy be a 3T MRI fusion biopsy both targeted and random. Protocol is a standard TRUS biopsy first. A PSA of 29, if confirmed, is not standard. Move yourself ahead in line when you can and skip standard steps in the diagnostic protocol when you can with the guidance of your doctor. Your urologist will support you with this. Keep it moving forward. You will have time to consider as you go. Don't let the system put you off. Be persistent. They will accommodate. Set up your signature. We will be here. Lots of knowledge and first hand experience on this forum. Best I've found.
Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: Usually numbers this high indicate cancer. You are correct to take this seriously. That said, PC is both treatable, "curable", and manageable. It has many forms from nonaggressive to very aggressive. As you put your team in place you may what to consider a cancer center that has a strong PC practice. They offer multiple disciplines and a coordinated team approach if you should need it.

Posts.Content: https://www.consumerreports.org/diet...-inflammation/ "And curcumin supplements, like all supplements, are not regulated in the same way medications are. That means that they may not contain what the label advertises and that claims have not been vetted. Just because they are natural doesnt mean they are necessarily helpful or even benign, Several studies and periodic Food and Drug Administration nationwide recalls have shown turmeric powder can be contaminated with heavy metals such as lead, says Tunde Akinleye, a chemist in Consumer Reports food safety division." "They found that the group that took curcumin actually had a slightly higher risk of acute kidney injury (17 percent risk for that group vs. 10 percent risk for those in the placebo group), though the authors note this should be investigated further in future studies; it may have been a statistical anomaly." "In general, however, curcumin taken orally, whether as a spice or as a supplement, is not well-absorbed and is quickly eliminated from the bodyone of the reasons that some experts have been skeptical about claims of its effects in humans. One 2017 study compared curcumin to a missile that continually blows up on the launch pad, never reaching ... its intended target.

He said most guys respond pretty well to medications that help with erections. He did not say I should expect penile shortening or mention I might ejaculate some urine during climax if I could achieve an erection. I took my chances with radiation and have no regrets. The studies I investigated including Dr. Kings 10 year results suggest that any future ED is only equal to that of untreated men. For me I found little value in a post surgical pathology of my prostate when weighed against the quality of life issues surgery presented. Just my two cents. No argument here. We're both satisfied. The next conversation is in 5 years.
Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: Remove the prostate and hope you're not to late. It is the source of anxiety, much medical risk, and nothing but bad news. I'm surprised it hasn't been recommended sooner. I suspect it has. Like an appendix and tonsils it serves no useful purpose at his age. Sadly, poorly performed prostatectomies have created an over reaction that borders on hysteria against removal of the gland that is the source of nothing but trouble in older men. Cancer is not the only valid reason to consider its removal. The younger you are the better your recovery in all categories. Maybe we can help ease concerns if you have been resisting this. Removal of the prostate is only complicated by the presence of cancer. Without the risk of cancer you have only to deal with the risk of incontinence and ED. Cancer may be the inevitable outcome of his BHP. Remove the prostate and you remove the risk. The other possibility is a small but aggressive cancer has metastized. If that's the case you deal with it as it develops, and it may be very manageable. In the mean time you have helped yourself prepare for that scenario by removing a disabling urinary disorder while your are still healthy and able. One last possibility that may complicate a removal. Is there cancer in the bladder?
Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Title: RP Exactly One Week From Today - Any Last Minute Advice?

It has many forms from nonaggressive to very aggressive. As you put your team in place you may what to consider a cancer center that has a strong PC practice. They offer multiple disciplines and a coordinated team approach if you should need it.

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: <0.1 is a standard test measure for those not interested in following their PSA by ultra sensitive tests. It is standard test protocol for most institutions unless there are adverse conditions requiring earliar expected detection. It is officially recognized as "undetectable". If you have reason to want to measure your PSA with a more sensitive test you will have to ask. As already shared, it is never seen as <0.100 which implies a 3 decimal ultrasensitive test, but a 3 decimal test will never present this way. That part is strange unless you are adding the zeros.
Posts.Title: 1st PSA test after da vinci is .1?

Posts.Content: First, retest to confirm first test. Recommend first biopsy be a 3T MRI fusion biopsy both targeted and random. Protocol is a standard TRUS biopsy first. A PSA of 29, if confirmed, is not standard. Move yourself ahead in line when you can and skip standard steps in the diagnostic protocol when you can with the guidance of your doctor. Your urologist will support you with this. Keep it moving forward. You will have time to consider as you go. Don't let the system put you off. Be persistent. They will accommodate. Set up your signature. We will be here. Lots of knowledge and first hand experience on this forum. Best I've found.
Posts.Title: New member, no dx yet, psa 29

Posts.Content: It takes decades sometimes a lifetime to develop cancer. As already stated above, when I asked if it was environment or genetics the doctor said yes. Recent studies indicate DNA contributing to disease is more prevalent than first thought. And environment in the womb and early childhood contributes more to disease causing shifts in our DNA than first thought. DNA switches/shifts/triggers happen much quicker and more often than we first thought. It may well be your mother's DNA and life habits during your fertilization, gestation and infancy that turns on the future cancer switch. That can not be reversed. It is set in your DNA. Degrading cellular DNA is the source of BHP. Prostate cells no longer die at the same rate as we age. They live longer causing the prostate to enlarge. Something similar may be at the root of PC. Degrading DNA is the root of all aging and its maladies.
Posts.Title: Is prostate cancer irreversible?

Posts.Content: I will add to your question. Are these clear 4s and clear 3s, or do they exist on a scale? Some 3s are closer to 4s and some 4s are closer to 3s. I suspect there are gradients. There are high and low grades within the classifications resulting in different multiplication rates across the spectrum. As mentioned, I suspect the grades are tied to measured outcomes to accomodate statistical forecasting. In the end a 3+4 is more risk than a 3+3 with a larger jump to 4+3. Think of it as multiplying rates being exponential functions. A small shift results in a much larger reproduction number on an exponential curve. And your prostate is probably producing them at a fixed rate, i.e. 10 - 3s to 1 - 4 etc, etc, etc, while a prostate that is producing more primary 4s is producing them at a faster rate than primary 3s and secondary 4s being produced in another prostate. And the 4s are reproducing faster than the 3s. 5s are birds, 4s are rabbits, 3s are sloths.

The choice will render itself as an outcome of the process. Toss your hat over the wall and have faith you will get there too.

Posts.Title: Is prostate cancer irreversible?

Posts.Content: Death from PC is not a useful measure, imo. Avoiding RP, RT, ADT, drugs, and chemo is a meaningful measure, imo. Early detection early treatment is still my mantra. Arguing for delayed treatment is risky behavior. Gleason score is the missing info here. If the OP had RP for G6 he's in a very low risk situation. Beyond that what can we say? Early treatment begins at .03 and goes up from there depending on adverse conditions. Still, the RO is best equipped to manage this conversation. I'm a 20% risk of BCR. Once I lose my undetectable status I will meet with an RO and take it from there. No disrespect to surgeons.

I spend a lot of time managing my healthcare and on this site, but with a peaceful distinction. I have transformed concerns to considerations. Concerns are anxiety producing, considerations require work and moving forward. They are the business of living. A percentage of men will remain on AS because their cancer is indolent and not life threatening. For most, it is acceptance of constant vigilance until death from another way appears on the horizon or treatment becomes the path. It is this acceptance that brings peace. For all of us, peace is priceless regardless of our state of health. Our access to peace is the transformation of our concerns to considerations.

Posts.Title: 3 month post op Dr visit

Posts.Content: "Healthy" prostate cells are producing prostate cancer cells. Healthy prostate cells grow and die on a DNA schedule to maintain a healthy prostate. As we get older, some of us have prostate cells that begin to live longer causing our prostates to enlarge and create problems. This is thought to be separate from cancer, but it is a shift in DNA performance. There is a shift in cell DNA that causes a normal cell to produce a cancer cell. Old age is another shift in DNA performance. Our DNA eventually starts to wear out or degrade. If we can sort this out we may have a means for immortality. Cancer is a chicken and the egg question. Which comes first? There is an answer. The egg comes first. Any mutation or change in the DNA is created first in the egg. So, a new breed of chicken or change in any way is first manifested in the egg or the birth of a new cell. A new chicken comes first through the egg. Cancer is essentially an act of cell generation. Back to prostate cancer. Usually cancer cells are produced by an individual prostate within a close grouping; 3s and 4s, 4s and 3s, 4s and 5s, etc. Rarely, you see a third; 3s and 4s with some 5s. Once generated a prostate cancer cell will continue to replicate itself as a cancer cell and at a faster rate than it dies (if it does die). This is what causes cancer to "grow". A good question is will the remaining "healthy" cells continue to add fuel to the fire by continuing to manufacture new cancer cells as the older cancer cells continue to multiply. Cancer growth is exponential, and most are predatory. They go off the reservation consuming other resources. Finally, will radiation kill both prostate cancer cells and the "healthy" cells that are producing them? This brings me back to the question for your doctor. If radiation kills the cancer cells and leaves the "healthy" cells, what keeps those reamaining healthy cells from starting all over again and continue to produce cancer cells as they first did. I believe they do, however, prostate cancer is slow growing and resetting the clock with treatment buys you the time you need to die of something else. The dilemma in surgery is some cells, healthy or cancerous, may be left behind to reset the clock. So, it then becomes which process suits you best. Each has pros and cons based on the individual statistics of the cancer and you. The more aggressive the cancer the less time time you have after resetting the clock. The older you are the less it matters.

Posts.Title: MRI and PSA update

Posts.Content: I had a inguinal hernia repair this year. There are some possible causes, i.e. inflating the colon during a colonoscopy can generate one, sometimes RPs can present it. After the repair my surgeon said mine was just the wear and tear that comes with age. Very easy procedure and now its behind me. He did an open surgery due to RP although he gave me the choice of open or laparoscopic. He said there can be a lot of scar tissue in the area after RP. He also repaired a navel hernia that developed after a varacosele laparoscopic surgery decades ago that used the navel for a port. I'm good to go for another couple of decades.
Posts.Title: Approaching 1st Year Post RALP

Posts.Content: Mine developed quickly. Noticed it the shower. Protruded about the size of 1/2 a small egg. No discomfort. I could flatten it when lying down. It is part of the bowel escaping throught the hole in the abdominal muscles where the spermatic cord descends to the nether regions. You have one on each side. They diagnosed it officially with an ultrasound. Doc said I could wait till after a vacation I planned, or longer if I wanted. I opted to take care of it immediately. Went on vacation one week after surgery. My girlfriend carried (rolled) my bags for me. Less to worry about. I travel some for pleasure and don't like the idea of it maybe acting up when I'm on the road or later when I'm older and not so surgery capable. Recovery was easy with some lifting restrictions for two weeks. Four weeks back to normal. One day off off from my desk job. One of the most common surgeries. I have mesh and it seems very stable. I've become acutely aware of the cost of anxiety in my quality of life. Walking around with something I can take care of produces a surprising amount of stress and anxiety.
