Posts.Title: Post RALP frequency of urination

Posts.Content: For clarity, this patient was not in an AS program. This is a serious case of prostate cancer best started on a path of treatment with no further delays. Don't look back. It is treatable and manageable, but for others, this is not surveillance (AS) and never was. The volume, PSA, and Gleason score indicate this grade of cancer has been developing for a while. A big part of moving forward powerfully is accepting how you got here and putting it behind you. It's all too common a story. There is a lot available to you and you are fortunate to have your head in the game now. First check is confidence in your health team. Did trust in them get you to this point or did ignoring their advice. If the former, you may consider making a change. You have the time and the responsibilty to get this back on a path to a cure.

Posts.Content: Here's the nut. It's a good amount of G6, and all on one side. Sure, if that's what it is you can slow down a bit, but it will not. Your history shows that. It appears to be growing and if any G7 is involved case closed on treatment, imo. The second opinion on the biopsy samples is very valid in your case, imo. Why wouldn't you want to confirm the G6? I understand the doctor's dismissal, he has already chose treatment. Are there other factors you are not sharing? Family history? If you wait, then another biopsy and preferrable an MRI guided one. The drugs are a complication. They will alter your PSA which has been a valuable tool up till now. You can no longer rely on it to track your cancer. That's a big loss, imo. If PSA continues to rise on the drug there is a slight elevated risk of more serious cancer. I had 8 cores of G6 at a much older age. Turned out to be G7 now I play the PSA testing anxiety game watching for BCR. Your 54 and taking drugs to pee. What will time get you? It's not sarcasm. If not now, when? Posts.Title: PSA Bounce Post CK

Posts.Content: Inflammation and infection are not the same. Both affect PSA. Certain activities can increase PSA short term, exertion, sexual activity, stimulation of the prostate itself including biking, or a DRE prior to testing. Drugs, diet, and supplements can also lower your PSA including some BHP drugs. A 7 is still high. Investgate until you are certain of the cause. A reliable PSA number is invaluable if diagnosing for cancer. Avoid attempts to manipulate it thinking your reducing your risk of cancer until you are certain of the cause. Regardless of anomalies a steady rise over time is a possible indicator of cancer. Therfore establish a reliable baseline and monitor it over time. A reliable PSA history is a useful tool for men not unlike BMI, blood pressure, cholesterol, blood sugar, liver and kidney functions tests. There are additional blood tests that add to the PSA such as free PSA that increase the value of the test.
Posts.Title: New test results which are confusing

Posts.Content: "Healthy" prostate cells are producing prostate cancer cells. Healthy prostate cells grow and die on a DNA schedule to maintain a healthy prostate. As we get older, some of us have prostate cells that begin to live longer causing our prostates to enlarge and create problems. This is thought to be separate from cancer, but it is a shift in DNA performance. There is a shift in cell DNA that causes a normal cell to produce a cancer cell. Old age is another shift in DNA performance. Our DNA eventually starts to wear out or degrade. If we can sort this out we may have a means for immortality. Cancer is a chicken and the egg question. Which comes first? There is an answer. The egg comes first. Any mutation or change in the DNA is created first in the egg. So, a new breed of chicken or change in any way is first manifested in the egg or the birth of a new cell. A new chicken comes first through the egg. Cancer is essentially an act of cell generation. Back to prostate cancer. Usually cancer cells are produced by an individual prostate within a close grouping; 3s and 4s, 4s and 3s, 4s and 5s, etc. Rarely, you see a third; 3s and 4s with some 5s. Once generated a prostate cancer cell will continue to replicate itself as a cancer cell and at a faster rate than it dies (if it does die). This is what causes cancer to "grow". A good question is will the remaining "healthy" cells continue to add fuel to the fire by continuing to manufacture new cancer cells as the older cancer cells continue to multiply. Cancer growth is exponential, and most are predatory. They go off the reservation consuming other resources. Finally, will radiation kill both prostate cancer cells and the "healthy" cells that are producing them? This brings me back to the question for your doctor. If radiation kills the cancer cells and leaves the "healthy" cells, what keeps those reamaining healthy cells from starting all over again and continue to produce cancer cells as they first did. I believe they do, however, prostate cancer is slow growing and resetting the clock with treatment buys you the time you need to die of something else. The dilemma in surgery is some cells, healthy or cancerous, may be left behind to reset the clock. So, it then becomes which process suits you best. Each has pros and cons based on the individual statistics of the cancer and you. The more aggressive the cancer the less time time you have after resetting the clock. The older you are the less it matters.

Posts.Content: 12 needle biopsy samples were taken of his prostate. Nine of them contained cancer. AS programs generally restrict participation to no more than 2 in 12. He has a high volume of cancer that precludes any reasonable consideration of AS. There are other details such as both sides of his prostate and Gleason scores with 4 as primary that also preclude AS. The remark about the size of his prostate implies it is enlarged primarily due to cancer and not other common benign reasons. The biopsy report will list the size. I'd ask that you complete your signature with his history as you see in others here. It helps move the conversation along to the pertinent topics. It also educates you in what is critical information and keeps what amounts to his medical chart front and center.

Posts.Content: I will add to your question. Are these clear 4s and clear 3s, or do they exist on a scale? Some 3s are closer to 4s and some 4s are closer to 3s. I suspect there are gradients. There are high and low grades within the classifications resulting in different multiplication rates across the spectrum. As mentioned, I suspect the grades are tied to measured outcomes to accomodate statistical forecasting. In the end a 3+4 is more risk than a 3+3 with a larger jump to 4+3. Think of it as multiplying rates being exponential functions. A small shift results in a much larger reproduction number on an exponential curve. And your prostate is probably producing them at a fixed rate, i.e. 10 - 3s to 1 - 4 etc, etc, etc, while a prostate that is producing more primary 4s is producing them at a faster rate than primary 3s and secondary 4s being produced in another prostate. And the 4s are reproducing faster than the 3s. 5s are birds, 4s are rabbits, 3s are sloths.

Posts.Content: It may be the beginning of bladder spasms. I hope it goes no further. The bladder is a muscle that contracts to expel urine. A spasm is like a charlie horse. At full strength I compare it to child birth contractions. For me, they were unstopable, random, and increased frequency with time. Not much they can do for them if they get worse. Keeping still tends to minimize them. Afterwards, my doctor referred to them as a sign of healing. May be the bladder trying to expel the catheter. What worked for me was to not resist/fight it by trying to relax it. It only makes it last longer. When it got bad for me I went with it. (Read it on the internet.) I pushed as if I was peeing hard, and pushed through the whole spasm. It was slightly less painful, but more importantly, shortened them. Isolate the pushing to pretending to urinate . Don't strain the whole area for obvious reasons. That's the best I got. Up till then I was working, and going out when necessary. Once they began and became frequent I spent the last two days on the couch. I would get up for them, bend over and grab something, and use breathing techniques. I hope this doesn't happen for you, and don't want to scare you. I just wished I had known about it first. It would have relieved anxiety about it. I did call the doctor's office and they confirmed it, said much doesn't help. I found pain medication didn't help very much and may irritate the bladder. Dealing with it also left me tired. It becomes a pain management experience. Having said all this, it could be something else so stay on top of it, and don't hesitate to call your doctor to confirm this for yourself, if you become concerned, if it becomes a continuos irritation, fever develops, or to ask for it to come out sooner. I see no reason for unnecessary pain just to manage an office schedule. It's a 5 minute procedure. This is the internet and not your doctor. Wishing you well. PS: they immediately became lighter after the catheter was removed and stopped within a day or two.

Posts.Title: Recent articles on Gleason Grading

Posts.Content: I will add if you are new to this and see men here discussing treatment options such as radiation when their PSA reaches 0.1, 0.2, or numbers close to that they are discussing cancer recurrence after surgical removal or other whole gland treatment for cancer of their prostate and their PSA should now theoretically be 0.0. You will also read signatures that list very low PSA numbers from hormone therapy (HT) treatment used to suppress testosterone that drives the PSA numbers very low. As HighlanderCFH says, normal for your age is anywhere between 0.0 and 2.5. (Copied from the site link below.) The guidelines below are adapted from the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines In Oncology (NCCN Guidelines) for Prostate Cancer Early Detection. Please use these guidelines to have a discussion with your physician about your personal risk and make a plan for screening. Age 40: Talk to your physician about screening and your personal risk Age 45-49: Have a baseline PSA and DRE. If PSA above 1 ng/mL, repeat at 1-2 year intervals until age 50. If PSA below 1 ng/mL repeat PSA at age 50. Age 50-70: If PSA is below 3ng/mL, repeat screening at 1-2 year intervals Age 70 and over: Talk with physician and assess general health to decide together if routine PSA screening should continue. https://zerocancer.org/learn/about-p...osis/psa-test/ Personally, at 50 and above I would have a PSA test (see ASAdvocate post above for a well advised more thorough test also discussed on the link) done every year as part of my annual physical exam. The Learn tab on the link above is a good primer. The entire site is a good reference site.

Posts.Title: Inguinal lump after 2-3 years of watchful waiting

Posts.Content: I will add what you don't want to hear. Gleason 3 is a turtle. Gleason 4 is a rabbit. Gleason 5 is a bird. The cancer lesion/tumor does not grow it's way out of the prostate. Cells travel their way out depending on their aggressiveness. A 3 will sit there and grow. A 4 runs. A 5 flies. The size and time are less important than the aggressiveness. The aggressiveness is its speed to mobilize. Don't mess around with 4 and 5s. They may remain small, hard to find, and have low PSA values, but their aggressiveness to leave and metastisize is the risk. Your fortunate to have discovered it. Early detection and early treatment is the path to success with this disease. Two demons work against us; denial and delay.

Posts.Title: CT and MRI

Posts.Content: You're not shallow. Cancer sucks. The extent of the cancer determines the damage. If it is tangled with the nerves it really doesn't matter what your choice of treatment is the outcome is the same. Cut or burn, if you damage the nerves you damage the nerves. It may take a little longer for the damage from the radiation to show up and it may be more extensive with collateral damage. If the cancer is extensive you may no longer be a candidate for surgery. That leaves radiation, hormones, and chemo. Don't give up, your wife may not share your ideas about what makes a man.
Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed with stage III T3C

Posts.Content: I'd characterize what you will be tracking in your PSA is a steady rise over time that acclerates, irratic or not. The doctor may recommend annual testing. You may request it be 6 months until your comfortable it's not a trend. While treatment side effects may impact your erections so will cancer (or BHP) simply through size. An expanding prostate can place pressure on the same nerves threatened by surgery with a similar outcome, ED. I fully recovered from side effects. The key is early detection early treatment. You are now in the game. Stay aware of the risk and manage it. Shift your language and your behavior will follow. Give up worry or concerns. Make them considerations. Presented with a choice, consider and choose. No worry. No concerns. You got this. Your healthcare system is working for you. It's your job to keep that in place.
Posts.Title: Premature worrying?

Posts.Content: Here's an answer to one question you ask. My incontinence improved with surgery. I was experiencing urgency incontinence before surgery as a result of a 65 gr prostate. Now I have no urgency incontinence, and I very rarely experience stress incontinence, maybe once a week if I drink alcohol or lots of caffeine. Meaning I can avoid it with diet choices. I do not wear pads. However, surgery will not improve ED if you already have it. To answer your overall question, you may be collapsing definitions. Combine the top two catagories of your study and the numbers work. No incontinence ( good) and occassional leakage ( that does not effect QOL) and the numbers align. The catagory we are concerned with is poor. The catagory that impacts QOL. It really doesn't matter for you. You want to be studying treatment results not side effect results. Pick the most effect form of treatment for your profile, a highly skilled practitioner for that treatment and the side effects will be what they are. One side effect of delaying treatment is fewer choices in treatment options. You may be on the cusp between surgery and radiation. The confidence your cancer is still confined to the prostate is low for me. Since you have no symptoms that will be improved by surgery (your prostate has remained small - I really question this result and suggest you confirm your prostate size) radiation may be a better fit. It's a question for each of the doctors. You want to be talking with surgeons and ROs. Age, fitness, extent and type of cancer , and the skill of the operator determine the most effective treatment for the cancer - not side effect studies. There is no one best treatment type. They all have a different sweet spot and the selection that will work best depends on your personal patient profile, imo. Fear of side effects can drive you to second quess what works best to cure your cancer. Only after you have narrowed your treatment choice will a consideration of side effects come into play, and then just to prepare yourself. People seldom change quickly. Focusing on side effects studies and not treatment efficacy studies is more of the old you. Like focusing on benign causes for rising PSA and not the risk of cancer. Work out your best treatment choice to play for a cure. Side effects will be what they are. You are way past avoiding side effects or biopsies. That thinking is what got you here. Go to work on your treatment choice.

Posts.Content: "PI means cancer has been found in the spaces around the nerves near the edge of the prostate, found on biopsy. MichiganMan16 makes the salient point, intraductal carcinoma discovered in biopsy is an uncommon finding and generally calls for aggressive treatment.

Posts.Title: I really knew little about my pathology report and understood even less

Posts.Content: Not certain perinureal invasion within the prostates translates into the nerve damage outside the prostate you are talking about. Enlargement of the prostate can press on the nerves and damage them over time. The surgeon can cut them. The heat from the carterizing tool on the scope increases temperature inside the abdominal surgical cavity traumatizing the nerves. Bleeding is stopped and blood flow is disrupted and rerouted. It all takes time. Nerves take longer to heal than other tissue, and they can restore themselves. It takes time if its going to happen. Others with experience can speak to the toll your particular regime may have on erections.

Posts.Content: Surgery is like burning down the barn after the horse has escaped. There is a window where removing the source of the cancer may help extend time, but not likely for your father's condition as you describe it. The treatments he will be considering are systemic and if successful will force the cancer into a form of remission for an unknown period of time. If effective, they are effective everywhere the cancer is including the prostate. The stress of surgery at this time becomes a burden on his quality of life. So sorry this is happenning for you and your Dad.

Posts.Content: I did not have bruising there. Blood drained to the scrotum and there was swelling and discoloration there. That aside, never hesitate to call your doctor. Posts.Title: Bruising on abdomen after robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: I will add what you don't want to hear. Gleason 3 is a turtle. Gleason 4 is a rabbit. Gleason 5 is a bird. The cancer lesion/tumor does not grow it's way out of the prostate. Cells travel their way out depending on their aggressiveness. A 3 will sit there and grow. A 4 runs. A 5 flies. The size and time are less important than the aggressiveness. The aggressiveness is its speed to mobilize. Don't mess around with 4 and 5s. They may remain small, hard to find, and have low PSA values, but their aggressiveness to leave and metastisize is the risk. Your fortunate to have discovered it. Early detection and early treatment is the path to success with this disease. Two demons work against us; denial and delay.
Posts.Title: How fast does a Gleason 8 prostate tumor grow

Posts.Content: Surgery is like burning down the barn after the horse has escaped. There is a window where removing the source of the cancer may help extend time, but not likely for your father's condition as you describe it. The treatments he will be considering are systemic and if successful will force the cancer into a form of remission for an unknown period of time. If effective, they are effective everywhere the cancer is including the prostate. The stress of surgery at this time becomes a burden on his quality of life. So sorry this is happenning for you and your Dad.

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: Just sayin'. It made a difference for me. I was able to distinguish real dribbles from the coffee induced incontinence. I went back to it after my continence returned. I ultimately gave it up for good, but it took a while. I have it now only on very special occassions. It is an easy habit to return too. I found as I aged it was too much for me. Not just the caffeine, but the acid as well. My daily drink is now green tea with honey, lemon, and ginseng. It gives me a little boost, but without the longing for another cup and the addiction. Sadly, alcohol is following the same pattern. Your continence will eventually return from what you describe. It will be different, and more fragile and suceptible to diet/fluid influences. If you are proceeding to radiation you want to regain it before you start that process. Giving up coffee will jump start it for you. You do not have to give up sex. You are without an erection at the moment. You can still be a good partner for your mate. Do it for her. Takes a different commitment, such as, wanting to please her.

Posts.Title: Post RALP bicycle riding and Leakage - turns out to be no big deal

Posts.Content: You can do therapy for ED if nerves were spared during surgery. It is recommended. I started Cialis at 3 mos, 5mg, 3x a week (not daily) flushes blood into the area for healing. I've started needle injections at 6 mos with Trimix. Erections are at about 50% without the Trimix. I expect recovery to take a year or more. I am experiencing some natural responses. Nerves are traumatized by the surgery and take longer to recover than other tissue. The surgery cuts and carterizes blood vessels. It takes time for blood to find other routes and the carterizing generates heat inside the surgery area traumatizing nerves. Masturbate with whatever you have. Orgasms should be 100% even without erection. Use it any way you can or lose it.

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: You are getting good care. Your diagnostic treatment is exemplary. Detection of cancer in the anterior zone is difficult. It is undersampled in the standard TRUS biopsy. Surgery is a reasonable option for you. PC is treatable and "curable". Early detection early treatment is the mantra for this disease. You got the first part covered. It's not recommended you think you know all there is to know about the cancer or it's extent. Sometimes there is more to know. Surgery has certain advantages; a pathology report of the gland, lymp nodes, seminal vesicsles, etc; your young age has much better outcomes recovering from side effects; radiation remains possible if necessary for follow up, as does hormone therapy. With a possible extension you want to know where and what it is for future radiation if necessary. Manifesting at a young age, G4, and possible extension are negatives, but everything else is good news. I know it's difficult to accept, but you will learn a clear treatable path forward is the best news. You have that. On the emotional side, while your experiences are unique to you they are normal. My suggestion is to accept them, give some time to acknowledge them, and move past them. Don't fight them. You got this! Again, very impressed with your care. Your detection was state of the art in my opinion. It can be the most challenging aspect of this disease. Regarding sharing the news, secrets with those close to you are energy sucking ventures . Being honest and transparent never fails. Faith in your power to handle this is more valuable than having a plan. As for a plan, you couldn't have done better than what you have done so far.

Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: The use of antibiotics as a diagnostic tool is bad medicine. It encourages the overuse of antibiotics. PSA often drops after antibiotics as it will in study control groups. It will bounce back up if cancer is present. The MRI is a good move. His prostate is near normal size indicating no BHP giving more value to rising PSA is a result of cancer growth. If in the states, I'd recommend a second opinion on reading the biopsy samples. His Gleason score may be higher. They can be misread. Cancer with low PSA can be higher risk. Even if the biopsy is being read correctly treatment is recommended because of the volume. There may be higher Gleason that is undetected as indicated by the PIRADS 4. The 3 samples in the area of the PIRADS 4 were not enough if it missed it. With this disease success is achieved with early detection and early treatment. What treatment options are available to you?
Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: He is a candidate for treatment. Surgery is still the gold standard, by a slim margin, if detected early enough. Many radiation options are available and require a consultation with an RO. His general health and life expectancy are considerations in choosing treatment options. I had a successful surgery experience. Others here are more knowledgeable about radiation.
Posts.Title: PCa with normal PSA

Posts.Content: Exercise, like walking, immediately after surgery reduces the risk of blood clots in the legs of older patients which can be fatal. Belly fat and obesity increases the risk of certain cancers which include prostate cancer. Some types of fat, specifically abdominal fat, store toxic components some of which are considered to be cancer causing. Most overweight people do not think they are overweight and are surprised when shown their BMI measure. Cultural diet choices are considered a possible contributor to prostate cancer in the general population, such as eating red meat. Most overweight men eat red meat, high fat, high calorie, high carbohydrate, and high sugar diets. Anti-inflammatory diets are thought to impact prostate cancer and general health in a positive way. General fitness is a factor in suitability for DaVinci surgery. Some men in poor health can not risk surgery eliminating an early and powerful option. Being in poor health complicates and conspires to thwart all medical treatment. Abdominal fat makes most PC treatment choices more difficult to perform. DaVinci surgery inflates your belly to create work space. Stressed abdominal muscles require rehabilitation to restore their effectiveness. They are critical to posture and future lower back health. Exercise and diet combat general depression. Depression is a common and natural response to aging and the realization of cancer. Depression suppresses motivation and self caring, critical factors in early detection, treatment, and following through on commitments (integrity) necessary in dealing with PC. I have three brothers all of which deal with varying degrees of depression. The two of us who exercise have dealt with it early and effectively. The two who do not have procrastinated in dealing with it. One resulted in critical adverse conditions. The other has yet to deal with it and the result will not be pretty. Exercise and weight are general indicators of being responsible for your health. They are primary guages on the dashboard. It is never too late to go back to them. A sedentary life style, obesity, and poor diet will shorten your life and degrade its quality. Such a view is at odds with a desire to survive prostate cancer. It is not sustainable. For an obese person, cardiovascular disease and diabetes may do you in before prostate cancer. In all things where we think we may be stuck without direction or a path forward the simple act of taking action, any positive physical action, can transform our view (head) of what's possible for ourselves. If you are over weight and eating poorly you are being driven by thoughts that are not in your own self interest. Shift your physical actions to healthy ones and the thoughts will follow. A fit body and a clear head is invaluable in navigating the pitfalls of prostate cancer which never end. Irresponsible self care can demoralize the healthcare providers you are asking to help you. Healthcare is a team sport. Doing your part will inspire those whose help you seek. Wax on. Wax off.
Posts.Title: Why are weight loss & exercise important to fight PCa

Posts.Content: Not certain perinureal invasion within the prostates translates into the nerve damage outside the prostate you are talking about. Enlargement of the prostate can press on the nerves and damage them over time. The surgeon can cut them. The heat from the carterizing tool on the scope increases temperature inside the abdominal surgical cavity traumatizing the nerves. Bleeding is stopped and blood flow is disrupted and rerouted. It all takes time. Nerves take longer to heal than other tissue, and they can restore themselves. It takes time if its going to happen. Others with experience can speak to the toll your particular regime may have on erections.
Posts.Title: New here.

Posts.Content: Here's an answer to one question you ask. My incontinence improved with surgery. I was experiencing urgency incontinence before surgery as a result of a 65 gr prostate. Now I have no urgency incontinence, and I very rarely experience stress incontinence, maybe once a week if I drink alcohol or lots of caffeine. Meaning I can avoid it with diet choices. I do not wear pads. However, surgery will not improve ED if you already have it. To answer your overall question, you may be collapsing definitions. Combine the top two catagories of your study and the numbers work. No incontinence ( good) and occassional leakage ( that does not effect QOL) and the numbers align. The catagory we are concerned with is poor. The catagory that impacts QOL. It really doesn't matter for you. You want to be studying treatment results not side effect results. Pick the most effect form of treatment for your profile, a highly skilled practitioner for that treatment and the side effects will be what they are. One side effect of delaying treatment is fewer choices in treatment options. You may be on the cusp between surgery and radiation. The confidence your cancer is still confined to the prostate is low for me. Since you have no symptoms that will be improved by surgery (your prostate has remained small - I really question this result and suggest you confirm your prostate size) radiation may be a better fit. It's a question for each of the doctors. You want to be talking with surgeons and ROs. Age, fitness, extent and type of cancer , and the skill of the operator determine the most effective treatment for the cancer - not side effect studies. There is no one best treatment type. They all have a different sweet spot and the selection that will work best depends on your personal patient profile, imo. Fear of side effects can drive you to second quess what works best to cure your cancer. Only after you have narrowed your treatment choice will a consideration of side effects come into play, and then just to prepare yourself. People seldom change quickly. Focusing on side effects studies and not treatment efficacy studies is more of the old you. Like focusing on benign causes for rising PSA and not the risk of cancer. Work out your best treatment choice to play for a cure. Side effects will be what they are. You are way past avoiding side effects or biopsies. That thinking is what got you here. Go to work on your treatment choice.

Posts.Title: Biopsy 2nd opinion and Extra Capsular Extension

Posts.Content: Not in your shoes, yet, but preparing myself by getting informed. So far my experience with cancer is information comes as statistics. The variables are your age, general health, and family history of life expectancy and health conditions. In other words, how long do you expect to live and what other life threatening/shortening issues are you confronted with such as weight, blood pressure, diabetes, alcohol, smoking, etc? Much like planning your financial retirement. The game is to finish with a zero balance spending what you earn with good health practices on life experiences. Now is the time when your diet, BMI, exercise, genetics, and mental health factor into the statistical outcome of your diagnosis and treatment options. It's different for everyone. There was a time when other things would kill you first, but earlier diagnosis and always improving treatment options for everything now puts prostate cancer in the decision matrix. It may not sound like it, but that's a good thing.

Specifically, the lymph nodes. Just listening I hear the big question, surgery and radiation or radiation. Keep working, it will bubble up for you.

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: I'd characterize what you will be tracking in your PSA is a steady rise over time that acclerates, irratic or not. The doctor may recommend annual testing. You may request it be 6 months until your comfortable it's not a trend. While treatment side effects may impact your erections so will cancer (or BHP) simply through size. An expanding prostate can place pressure on the same nerves threatened by surgery with a similar outcome, ED. I fully recovered from side effects. The key is early detection early treatment. You are now in the game. Stay aware of the risk and manage it. Shift your language and your behavior will follow. Give up worry or concerns. Make them considerations. Presented with a choice, consider and choose. No worry. No concerns. You got this. Your healthcare system is working for you. It's your job to keep that in place.

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: As an example of a limited view of statistics in this consideration. We know, "The most common causes of cancer death continue to be lung, prostate, and colorectal cancers in men and lung, breast, and colorectal cancers in women. These 4 cancers account for 45% of all cancer deaths, with 1 in 4 cancer deaths from lung cancer." Now they are introducing the statistic of not just death, but years lost to determine how "destructive" a type of cancer is. While prostate cancer deaths may be more than breast cancer deaths, the years lost in men is much less than women. Men who die of PC may statistically only lose a year off their life while women may lose many more years making breast cancer statistically more destructive. Yet, what is the loss of quality years of life for men who's lives are extended by terminal cancer treatment who show up statistically only losing a year of life from PC? A long course of multiple prostate cancer treatments of a preventable terminal case of prostate cancer may extended a man's life to nearly his expected lifetime, but are those many years of extended cancer treatment before death worth a statistically average life span? Death from cancer as a meaningful statistical measure is just the crude and cruel beginning of this story. Statistically, we are very good at treating cancer. We are not so good at detecting and curing cancer. For me, AS is the current answer to the early screening and detection debate. Large cancer centers seem to be the epicenter for it. As a question of public health policy, do we advocate for early screening in general practise and push screened patients to large cancer center AS programs? Or, do we push AS programs to general practises as a part of screening? For now, I propose a PSA screening of 3-4 by your GP forwards you to a cancer center AS program. It's simple, and places the seriouness of your potential risk in the appropriate context. It is asking too much for your local GP or urologist to run an AS program, imo.

Posts.Content: The use of antibiotics as a diagnostic tool is bad medicine. It encourages the overuse of antibiotics. PSA often drops after antibiotics as it will in study control groups. It will bounce back up if cancer is present. The MRI is a good move. His prostate is near normal size indicating no BHP giving more value to rising PSA is a result of cancer growth. If in the states, I'd recommend a second opinion on reading the biopsy samples. His Gleason score may be higher. They can be misread. Cancer with low PSA can be higher risk. Even if the biopsy is being read correctly treatment is recommended because of the volume. There may be higher Gleason that is undetected as indicated by the PIRADS 4. The 3 samples in the area of the PIRADS 4 were not enough if it missed it. With this disease success is achieved with early detection and early treatment. What treatment options are available to you?

Posts.Title: Started Treatment

Posts.Content: It's no coincidence. Many things effect PSA. It may be the hemp oil reducing your PSA by reducing immunity inflamation, but it is not reducing your cancer. The risk in manipulating your PSA is you no longer have a reliable indicator of your cancer activity. You are treating a symptom of cancer not the cancer. An example, we often know we are sick because we have a fever. Taking some Tylenol to reduce the fever doesn't cure the illness. In the example, the illness will most often cure itself so treating symptoms has an advantage of providing comfort. In your case the cancer will not cure itself and hemp oil will not do it either and now you lost the baseline of the best method you had of measuring its progress. If you've chosen to stop treating your cancer it's not a problem. Be sure to inform your cancer healthcare team you are self medicating.
Posts.Title: is it a coincidence..

Posts.Content: PNI is what cancer does. It tends to migrate to nerve pathways which are natural pathways out of the prostate. It is generally consider of little value to predicting anything useful about the cancer other than it's acting like cancer. Some biopsies miss it. Some hit it. It is thought hitting it means there is more than less of it meaning more cancer, but you're pass that point. Other measures are much more useful once cancer has been detected. So, good to know, but no surprise. Your doctor didn't mention it because it has little to no bearing on his considerations. Nor should it in yours. You have cancer, a meaningful volume of it, and it includes G4+3. Move on to other things. On the other hand, a 4+3 at the base is cause for concern. You are fortuante, this is a difficult area to reach with TRUS biopsy and often not sampled adequately. G 4+3 is a notably more aggressive G7 cancer than 3+ 4 and the location at the base is a higher risk location because cancer often ascends (travels) up and out along the seminal vesicles. Prostate anatomy is upside down. The base is closer to your head and the apex is closer to your feet. The seminal vesicles exit the area near the top, or base of the prostate. There are multiple personal considerations in treatment choice; ethnicity, family history, age, fitness; health; morbidities; and life expectancy. As already mentioned, there is no one best treatment size that fits all. There is a treatment choice, and there may be more than one, that may fit your profile best. Keep doing your research, acknowledge the anxiety of not knowing what will work best for you and your comfort level now, but rest assured you will quickly get there. This forum is one of the best resources out there, warts and all. We work hard to stay out of the weeds and stay with proven and mainstream medicine. Supplements, prostate health products, extreme diet and vitamin/mineral programs may affect your PSA, but it will not treat the cancer. Avoid them now. Practise what you know to be good health practises based in diet, exercise, and weight. You want your PSA to remain unadulterated. It is now one of your best friends until you have this behind you. Welcome. I'm impressed as well with your signature. Keep in mind this is for you. It is an exercise that allows you to see the facts of your case in a complete glance. In our minds eye we tend to cherry pick the good news and forget the bad letting it fall off the table. For example, what was the free PSA? This is valuable and useful infromation.

Posts.Title: Perineural Invasion

Posts.Content: Everything is normal except you! (humour) You will be continent within 3 months, imo. You are still in the rest and recuperate period for at least a month. The zen approach is to first accept it. Resisting it will only prolong it. It is a natural aspect of the healing process. Imagine everything in the region is behaving like a leg or foot gone to sleep. It will return. There are things you can do to help. My doctor gave me a script for a half dose of Cialis 2-3 times a week. Not for ED, but to enhance blood flow to the area for healing. Cialis lingers for up to 3 days, but the idea is to pulse increased blood flow, not elevate and sustain it. Relax on the kegels. You can be overdoing them. No more than 3 sets a day for now just to let them know you're paying attention. After 9 days everything is swollen and numb. Give it time to heal. Kegels are for muscle tone, but more importantly for redeveloping nerve/muscle control. Nerve tissue takes longer to recover than other soft tissues. It just takes longer to refresh those connections. Blood flow has also been disrupted with the cauterization and blood has to find new pathways. As you recover, you will be best in the morning and regress as the day goes on and the muscles tire. Don't overwork them. For almost a year I could not disntiguish the need to fart, from a bowel movement, from urinating. A full bowel now causes a slight increase in stress dribbles. Keep your bowels moving. Stress continence will require specific effort, but now is too soon to go to work on them, imo. These are mucle memory connections best practised after healing when muscle control has returned and you are retraining automatic responses. My example of the last thing to work on was getting in an out of a car. Once I realized it, I created a mantra, "stay together, stay together" from an old Cheech and Cong movie. Everytime I get into and out of a car I'd repeat the mantra to remind myself to prepare. It was close to 5 months when I took on that last issue. It is now automatic and is no longer necessary. Hard sneezes are still a problem. If I can , I just grab myself and clamp it. It works (in private) , but do not do this until you are fully healed, several months. Coffee, carbonated beverages, and alcohol, among other things, irritate the bladder. The bladder has just undegone a major trauma. Over indulgence of any of those will result in dribbles for me. More than two manhattans in a row and I will dribble at the slightest stress. If I want to drink more I pull out a light pad. I kept one in my back pocket for a year after I stopped wearing them regularly. Happy hour or a night out always created opportunities for putting one back in, and I didn't sweat it. You have a system thatvwill work use it and enjoy. I find myself drinking less alcohol on a daily basis. I now regularly put a glass of water between all my alcohol drinks. I gave up all 3 during my recovery. I switched to green tea for my morning caffeine. It was enough to make a difference. I find coffee to be too intense for me in general as I age. I miss it the most. Use 100% synthetic stretch underwear. I use short boxers. It holds the pads in place better and dries faster than cotton. Darker colors also hide the stains. They do provide more support for the region. It took a while for the swelling to resolve 100% in the scrotum. They are sexier. Ditch the stretched out cotton tighty whities. The key to kegels is not to clamp your anus. That's not the muscle group. The kegels lift your pelvic floor. It's a head pat stomach circle exercise. Some benefit from PT to learn this distinction. One exercise is to control the kegel contraction like an elevator going up and down. Go half way up and stop. Hold it and then take it all the way up. Take it down the same way, stopping half way. The biggest challenge is not obsessing and over reacting. Ready, set, ....relax. And keep hydrated.
Posts.Title: Question for you DRY guys post RP

Posts.Content: I had a Peyronie's experience. After the first injection I noticed a slight depression in the area of the injection site. I should have stopped then. I gave myself 4 more shots over the course of 2 months. Each more painful than the last. I stopped, but have significant bottlenecking at the base at the site of the injections. I am now deformed, but still functional. In hindsight, I would have been more patient. I eventually recoverd my erections in full in a year and a half. For you, after six years I'd give it a try. It can work. I had Peyronie's, but didn't know it. The shape was normal. Imagine the chances of that. The injections exposed it. My doctor was unaware of injections causing Peyronie's. My doctor said erections or incontinence will not be improved with a successful surgery. They may return to pre surgery levels, but not better than. One suggestion is to work with a doctor who specializes in ED. My urologist was good at surgery, but not ED. My first injection and erection was in his office and under his supervision. When I pointed out the slight divot at the injection site he said may be Peyronie's yet he let me walk out with the script. I believe a more experienced doctor would have stopped it right there. As I understand it, the nerves damaged by the procedure are the nerves that shut the valves when the penis is engorged and hold the blood in the erect penis under pressure. You should be able to fill your penis with blood (standing helps). The problem is keeping it there for the time you need. The injections do work and while off putting you do get used to it.

I think those in the know and current with the state of the art will have more aggressive attitudes and treatment recommendations. If you're in this patient group, I'd be wary of those professionals who still perpetuate the myth you have time and it's a slow moving disease. Especially, when they have no way of knowing what you have. A question to ask the professionals along the way is if they have any personal experience with prostate cancer, whether themselves or someone close. I often hear a disconnect in some of the shared experiences here between the patient's concern and the professional's lack of it. Thanks for the work you do here!

Posts.Content: Size matters. As AS mentions, density is a useful statistic. TRUS biopsy, for another, has a 30% false negative with a normal size prostate up to 50% false negative on an enlarged prostate. Bigger prostate, the smaller the percentage the 12 needles sample. A large prostate can frustrate the search for cancer and explain negative biopsies when other signs indicate cancer. The science behind the growth. Prostate cells regenerate. As men age the DNA that controls the age of individual prostate cells changes and they live longer. As cells continue to regenerate and the rate at which they die slows the gland enlarges. Or, it's cancer growth, or both. It's a fact that can mean different things. The ultrasound of a TRUS biopsy is reasonably accurate at measuring it's size. Individual doctor's DRE, not so much. Mine would only say it was enlarged. The TRUS measured it at 57gr. Mine was enlarged and the final pathology report weighed it at 65gr. 35% was a G7 (3+4) tumor. I had urinary symptoms, developing ED and incontinence. Size can be a sign of BHP. More cells can produce higher PSA. Size can produce urinary symptoms, ED, and incontinence in the presence of BHP, cancer, or both. So, other factors being equal, a smaller prostate with equal PSA (assuming it's a reliable indicator) to a larger prostate may indicate cancer vs BHP. This is more common in younger men. Couple this with more aggressive cancers can present early equals smaller prostates, younger men, higher grade cancers. Older men with larger prostates developing cancer later have a higher probability of less aggressive cancer, maybe. Size is a fact that provides useful information that impacts a diagnosis differently in different scenarios. The prostate snatchers stuff has a bias so be careful. Seek out the actual statistics behind its generalizations to have something useful.

AgeInfo.Phrase: pathology report weighed it at 65gr <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine - Study Finds No Increased Risk for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: "There was, however, no indication of cancer outside the prostate area." Among other things you report the doctor said, this statement can not be said with confidence. Were you in the meeting? Someone, in addition to your father, who is clear and objective should also attend all meetings going forward. Your father has a high level of cancer and the odds are very high he will have reoccurrence immediately. That much G4 is a serious matter. Early detection, early treatment is the key to successful treatment all the way down the line with this disease at each phase. Your father did not benefit from early detection and treatment. Do not make the same mistake again. Regardless, it is time to prepare for the next phase and move on to an RO and MO to guide you forward. Your urological surgeon's work is done. Follow up treatment will depend on your father's health and general life expectancy. It will most likely include hormone deprivation therapy and radiation. Scans will be done to determine if the cancer has metastized to other parts of the body. These scans are not highly sensitive and a negative scan does not mean it has not spread. It means it is had not spread or is not detectable yet. It is time for the oncologists to take over your father's care. I'd recommend a major cancer center with experience in prostate cancer. I apologize in advance if this is too blunt. My intent is to make a brief, clear and honest assessment of your father's situation.

As men age the DNA that controls the age of individual prostate cells changes and they live longer. As cells continue to regenerate and the rate at which they die slows the gland enlarges. Or, it's cancer growth, or both. It's a fact that can mean different things. The ultrasound of a TRUS biopsy is reasonably accurate at measuring it's size. Individual doctor's DRE, not so much. Mine would only say it was enlarged. The TRUS measured it at 57gr. Mine was enlarged and the final pathology report weighed it at 65gr. 35% was a G7 (3+4) tumor. I had urinary symptoms, developing ED and incontinence. Size can be a sign of BHP. More cells can produce higher PSA. Size can produce urinary symptoms, ED, and incontinence in the presence of BHP, cancer, or both. So, other factors being equal, a smaller prostate with equal PSA (assuming it's a reliable indicator) to a larger prostate may indicate cancer vs BHP. This is more common in younger men. Couple this with more aggressive cancers can present early equals smaller prostates, younger men, higher grade cancers. Older men with larger prostates developing cancer later have a higher probability of less aggressive cancer, maybe. Size is a fact that provides useful information that impacts a diagnosis differently in different scenarios. The prostate snatchers stuff has a bias so be careful. Seek out the actual statistics behind its generalizations to have something useful.

AgeInfo.Phrase: pathology report weighed it at 65gr <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Low PSA, Low Gleason Score but Bone Mets??

Posts.Content: Find a urologist you are comfortable with who specializes in prostate cancer and get a biopsy. DREs are done quickly by experienced docs. They are simple procedures. Judge your experience by his lack of patience and time with you. Be wary of the "normal ranges" of PSA as safe. Pay attention to a steady rise over time. It may bounce a bit, but prostate cancer is slow growing (unless an aggressive variety) and your PSA will rise accordingly. There are exceptions: some have lower PSA values in the presence of cancer. Some have BPH in addition to cancer which can confuse the PSA line, but even then the overall trend is always a steady up. Your young age is your warning flag here. In general, I'm am reluctant to offer the view it is more often BPH than cancer even when it may be. Too many men are too eager to believe in anything but cancer as the risk they are facing. Both are troublesome, both require monitoring, both may require treatment at some time, so get yourself into the care of an experienced prostate cancer urologist and be prepared. You will be managing the care of your prostate now for the rest of your life, BPH or cancer or both. 80% of all men will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. When the little organ starts to act up is important to what you have ahead of you. Don't ignore it. Be prepared and address issues as they present. You don't have to like your urologist, but he has to be: highly experienced, qualified, patient, informative, clear, brief, and recommended by peer professionals. There are only a few male friends I consider objective enough about their prostate health whom I will accept as knowledgable to make a urologist recommendation. So be wary of bias in friends and family. Denial and delay are the two demons of all cancer. It is especially poignant with prostate cancer because many men fail miserably in being responsible around this one issue for obvious reasons, and it is most often curable if detected early, and manageable for a long time if not.

Posts.Title: Impact of sexual activity on PSA

Posts.Content: A steady and rising PSA is most often a sign of cancer regardless of other tests. You keep testing until you find it or not. You do not stop looking for it. Velocity is important. Is your PSA picking up velocity? To answer your question, any positive test trumps the other negatives. A steady and rising PSA over 10 is a positive test for a high probability of cancer, imo. You want to know the cause of your PSA number. MRI's miss stuff. It misses the stuff your looking for, small G6. It can also miss small aggressive stuff. The rest of your info is critical. If you are focusing on just the combination of tests and symptoms that support a bias be careful. Cancer has no bias. But, that's all me. Others here are more versed in AS. However, the previous question is a good one. Are you in a program, and what are their criteria? In other words, what does your doctor say? It's hard for them to ignore those PSA numbers, for good reason. They often prove to be accurate indicators. It is frustrating. I was lucky. I waited too long and there was plenty to find.

Posts.Content: Practise the kegels. They will strengthen the orgasm's contractions. Anxiety can have a huge impact on the experience and can be a distraction. There are plenty of reasons to be anxious during this period. The prostate is an erogenous zone. Without it, it is a different experience. I did not find it less, just different. The overall experience has improved from pre RP for me.
Posts.Title: Orgasm post RALP

Posts.Content: I'd suggest waiting to share. Sharing takes energy. Reserve your energy, privacy, and job future for what you have ahead of you. After the surgery you will have a better idea of what lies ahead of you and if sharing helps or distracts. When and if you do share begin with the chain of command as it effects your job. Not to alarm but to have a real conversation, you may have more treatment to deal with after the surgery that will require more conversations with your employer about accomodating your job. Operating on a need to know basis keeps some powder dry if you should need it. Once this is behind you and you have a helpful story to tell then you may become an advocate. Now is not that time, imo. At this time, you will not be able to hide your own concerns, uncertainty, and aniexty. This kind of sharing is only useful to you with those closes to you and committed to supporting you. Sharing something innocuous can be helpful, i.e. "It is elective surgery and more of an inconvenience than anything else. See you in two weeks." And remember to smile. In short, play it close to the vest to start.

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: Indicator of cancer is generally a steady rise. BHP can be eratic. You can have both. In that case, the bottom number continues to rise. In otherwords, eratic but a steady increase in the baseline. Activities that stimulate the prostate can vary the PSA, but generally not that much. Some prostate medications can reduce PSA, but not Flomax. Diet and supplements can too, but again not that much. Different labs can have varying results that are minor so use the same lab, but again not that much. The 3.5 is somewhat up for your age. The others are pretty high. The 3.5 can also be a mistake. It happens. We have a member with eratic PSA. In the end, only a physical biopsy can detect cancer. Just to keep you clear. Difficulty peeing is a cancer symptom. So if you're taking Flomax you're dealing with possible cancer symptoms. Set up your signature with PSA and date history, family history, DRE, is it enlarged, etc. A profile is how you diagnosis this disease. You build the evidence that paints the picture. BHP can complicate the hunt for cancer. It does not necesssrily lead to cancer, but they are also common together. PSA over 10 and a rise of more than .5 in a year are indicators of a higher risk of cancer. Next PSA test include a freePSA test. It will provide additional risk info.

Posts.Content: A diverse variety of foods with their original nutrients and fiber intact. Avoid processed foods, red meats, deli meats, sugar, high salt, dairy, caffeinne, alcohol, and anything you know constipates you. A mediteranian diet is a good diet going forward. Your bowls will be sluggish due to trauma to blood flow and nerves in the area. Keep them soft and moving. Use softeners if you have too. Stay ahead of it. Don't wait until it's a problem.
Posts.Title: Pre and post surgery meals

Posts.Content: Related note. Avoid the opioids if you can. They will constipated you. Opioids are safest if restricted to 3 days. No one can predict an individual's threshold to addiction. I've heard it can be a fast as 5 days. Please despose of them responsibly. Do not flush or throw them out. They are accumulating in our water sources. It is likely a ridiculously high dosage will be prescribed. If so inclined, let your doctor know you didn't need it and do not appreciate the over prescribing of opioids.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Consult1 One urologist told me that he can tell where he has to take more tissue out by how sticky the tissue is that he is removing. Cancer tissue tends to clump together while healthy tissue peels away easily. That is a useful remark for many to understand how cancer can get left behind. The cancerous cell is "sticky". It sticks to the knife and the remaining tissue. Once described here like peeling a hard boiled egg. Some tissue separates cleanly, some pulls and tears. The cancerous tissue tends to cling and tear making a clean close removal a challenge near the edges. Or something like that.

Posts.Title: Healed from prostatectomy, PSA at 4.7 after 5 Months, what's next?

Posts.Content: It is a question I asked my surgeon. (I recommend you ask yours at your next appointment.) He then checked what percentage of my prostate was tumor -35%. (That surprised me.) He said 20% chance of recurrence. It's a common statistic. It will always be a statistic and never certainty. Your volume matters and closeness to the edge along with Gleason scores. All in all a very good and thorough report and treatment.

Posts.Title: I'am outta here....

Posts.Content: Best advice is to complete your signature. Reviewing treatment options works when you have a clear and written outline of your cancer profile. You think you know it, but seeing it written before you causes invaluable insights. Denial and delay are the two demons of cancer. Hard to hide from the facts when they are written before you and others. If left to swirl in your head they will be shaped by emotions. G4 is serious stuff. It can move quickly and unpredictably and not likely to grow quietly in place. G3 is the stuff that causes people to dismiss PC. G4 is not G3. It is the difference between most likely indolent and aggressive cancer. Do not think you can manage the details of this journey in your head. Your head will play tricks on you and can not be trusted alone. Have someone accompany you to doctor visits. They take notes, you listen. Keep a list of questions. You will think of something to ask and then forget. Keep it simple and complete.

Posts.Title: How I dealt with my Geason 10 diagnosis

Posts.Content: I've heard, 300, 500, and a 1,000. I used 1,000 as a benchmark and accepted over 800 in my doctor. I've read a recent study that set the number at 1,600 between competent and excellence. It is a difficult procedure to learn. The doctor operates a joy stick at a computer screen in the corner of the room. Assistants attend to the patient in the room inverted (head down) on a table. The surgeon enters the abdomen from above. You can watch a Youtube of the procedure. Some people (surgeons) may never have the aptitude for operating via robot technology and maintain relative presence of left right and up down. While the anatomy is the same the skill set is entirely different between scapel and robot. Even if the surgeon has the aptitude it's a long and steep learning curve.
Posts.Title: Surgeon experience

Posts.Content: It is a question I asked my surgeon. (I recommend you ask yours at your next appointment.) He then checked what percentage of my prostate was tumor -35%. (That surprised me.) He said 20% chance of recurrence. It's a common statistic. It will always be a statistic and never certainty. Your volume matters and closeness to the edge along with Gleason scores. All in all a very good and thorough report and treatment.

Posts.Title: Seeking New York City general practitioner with experience with digital rectal exams

Posts.Content: From never sick a day in my life, to cancer, is a big shift. It takes time. Cancered out is a great phrase. Who wouldn't be. Some examples. Healthcare may be new for you, embrace it. It's the new normal at our age. Its a new experience for you. As you get better at it you will begin to appreciate the outcomes. Since my prostatectomy (2 yrs back) I've had knee surgery (second on same knee), irregular heart beat scare and testing, and a double hernia (iguinal and belly button) surgery. All while working, traveling, being with my 97 year old mom in her end game, bounce back, end game again, bounce back, and now hospice end game, and being in the best relationship of my life. Go figure, as the going gets harder the living gets better. Anything you want to do in retirement start doing now. I amped up my trout fishing. Going again in two weeks and am using it to renew my relationship with my brother who just moved back in town to retire. One of my favories, I meet once a week for dinner and drinks with a small group of guy friends. Same day and time and different places, but some favorites. There is always something we help each other with during the conversations, usually without knowing it. This also makes you much more attractive to women. We have a name, "The He-Man Women Haters Club." (You can use it, but be warned, it takes some kahunas because it is easily missunderstood.) It is definitely a hook for some (all the better) but it does have a reference in American culture that suits our age. We explain it as a reverse mantra. Its to remind us we love our women and we are men. It's serious fun, and I miss it when we can't make it happen which is often enough because we are all busy. Once a week is a good working time period. It was started to help a guy get out who had just lost his wife. It worked and he moved on, and I suspect we will see him again some day because it does work, and everyone needs something that works when they need it. Don't fight it. Allow yourself the time to be with it. Fighting it holds it in place. Accepting it allows you to be with it, and eventually you will tire of it. Fighting it keeps it in place and it can become chronic because it has some hidden payoff for you. Cancer is inconvenient. One more thing. Most of us, by age, are in our end game, the last period/quarter/inning, pick you sport. There's more wrapping up of old injuries, stretching and warming up, sitting on the bench, mentoring the young players, and making a difference whether you're in the game or not. I'm now one of the veteran players in the club house. Every championship team needs one or two to win. I earned it and I still enjoy the game.

AgeInfo.Phrase: working  traveling  being with my 97 year old mom in her

Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: My G6 was G7. I'll bet a fine meal it was G6 first. By this I mean, my prostate began producing G6 aggressively and at some point began producing G7. Diagnosing the G6 early and sending me on my way calling it Rainbows and Unicorns to live happily ever after free of cancer would not have protected me from the eventual G7. I made the choice to remove my prostate solely on the basis of an aggressive G6. No fear. What it was, was G7. How did I conclude my G6 was dangerous to my health? It's volume and my age. The writer makes the case for not doing what he concludes should be done. Bizarre. Beware anyone who withholds knowledge to save you from yourself.
Posts.Title: Gleason 6 Tumor: Is It Cancer, and Should It Be Treated?

Posts.Content: RobLee, the new standard for biopsy is moving from a PSA of 4 to a PSA of 3. It also varies based on ethnicity. FishSpear, good work. You got this. You are a candidate for AS, as you know, just want to reinforce it. My bias is surgery if a cure is possible and if you need one. Any decision matrix must also include a life expectancy. Difficult to confront, but your assessment of your fitness and family history helps in projecting a number. A large consideration in life expectancy is your BMI. The health consequences of gaining weight as we age is the largest contributor to reduced life expectancy; high blood pressure, high cholesterol and heart disease, diabetes, and less activity. Get a second opinion on the Gleason scoring of all your samples. Everything changes if G4 is present. The premier lab for this is Epstein at John Hopkins. Did the biopsy include a random array in addition to the targeted samples? Looks like it with the 13. Just want to confirm. And where was the one G6 in the prostate? Most of the diagnostic tools we have are marginal, at best, including MRIs. However, if your PSA is steady (not bouncing around) it can be the most reliable indicator, imo. Yours is rising recently, steadily and with the possiblity of some velocity indicating more may be going on than just one G6. You found an excellent forum here.

Posts.Content: Others will step in with more supportive comments. If you want to fear for something fear for your life, but fear is not a good state to be in. Allow yourself sometime to experience it because it is a natural reaction, but set a time limit and commit to moving past the fear. ED is the last of the three concerns; cure, continence, and ED. Posts.Title: Confused and scared

Posts.Content: A steadily rising and high PSA and a small prostate is a high probabilty of cancer. The smaller prostate makes it much easier to find. All good news. The odds are improving you will find it and what it is. The MRI is the map. The biopsy is the gold. While its tempting to try to predict the nature of the cancer from the MRI only the biopsy provides this information. You're collecting the pieces of the puzzle.

Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: I experienced increasing pain with Trimix. Turns out I had Peyronies disease and didn't know it. My penis appeared normal. After about 5 shots I quit, but not before I developed some deformity described as bottle necking at the base at the injection sites. Be careful. See your urologist. If there is any pain - stop! Trimix is not recommended for those with Peyronies. Trying injections was the only mishap in my adventure. Wish I had been more patient. It took a little over two years for my erection to return. I'd rather have taken the time and not deformed my penis. Still works, a little bent, narrow at the base with a slight curve to the right, and shorter becasue of lose of length where the plaque developed. Probably more than you want to know, but hey, its healthcare.

Posts.Title: painful erections post RALP

Posts.Content: I would not play chicken with it. If you want to consider AS get a second opinion on the scoring. I chose treatment of G6 based solely on volume. There was too much of it. Turned out to be G7. If it's not acting benign it probably isn't. Your PSA and prostate size are both suspiciously low for your age, volume and grading of cancer. Rather than being a positive consideration it is now a concern. I do not see a path for you to AS. You do not fit a specific profile you can trust, imo. Then there's the doctor's recommendation. It begs the question why the MRI and biopsy with such a low PSA. Which beings us back to something being uncertain. What is your life expectancy currently? It is a valid question now if you are considering non-treatment and have other morbidities. There is enough information to recommend treatment. There is not enough to recommend AS. I end up back at a second opinion on the scoring if you are not inclined to treat. Something is different here for you and that is never a good sign with cancer.

Posts.Title: How I dealt with my Geason 10 diagnosis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD Thanks for the tip about leaning forward and raising the feet on the toes. It helps. So it this a temporary thing or is this the way it is going to be from now on? It has always been a helpful technique for everyone, but more so for us. It has taken me a year to find the right combination of fiber and diet to have healthy bowel movements. I have other issues. However, once you have regularity mastered the urge to have a movement unaided does eventually return. It took me about a year. If you have watched a youtube video of the procedure you will notice they use an electrical cauterizer on the end of the scopes to cauterize blood vessels as they make their way through the procedure. I think it may disrupt blood flow and nerves leaving the colon muscle sluggish for a while. It is speculated that the heat trapped in the surgery cavity generated by the cauterizing tool may traumatize the nearby nerves. Tissue damage of this nature takes longer to heal as blood finds other routes, and nerve tissue takes longer to heal and regenerate than other tissue. The colon is a muscle, has a memory, is more voluntary than involuntary, is trained, and likes regularity and robust use. The use of aids to move your bowels or low fiber diets can make the colon sluggish and weak. There is light at the end of the tunnel if you develop a regime that exercises your colon daily. One another note, as we work to regain our continence we are tempted to drink less water. The consequences of this contribute to dryer stool and overall fatigue. Water is the vehicle for energy in everything. And one more thing, the antibiotic regimes particulary for the biopsy, can destroy your intestinal flora especially in the colon. This can contribute to dryer less digested stool and less mucus. I found a high quality probiotic designed to release lower in the colon helped. It took a while. Sometimes more fiber just generates larger more constipating stool until balance is restored. Oatmeal, which was a stable of mine, proved to be constipating because of its absorbency. Go figure. Commercial dairy probiotics were useless to me. Saurkraut and cabbage worked for me. Inexpensive dry high fiber breakfast cereals actually worked for me. I mean the really tastless low sugar high fiber unappealing ones. Ugh! But, a good bowel movement is one of life's simple pleasures. Fighting cancer is an active participation sport demanding you pay attention to the conversation your body is having with you. Medical procedures and treatments are only a part of game, at worse, a passive approach to this disease is fatal, at best, a poor and depressing quality of life. I view this as a wake up call to reconnect with my body. In the end its a simple formula made up of three things- diet and exercise, diet and exercise, and diet and exercise. Stay engaged. Your body is a wonderful vessel designed to make this voyage. Care for it like it is your own and use it. A passive and sedentary lifestyle is tiring and depressive. Our bodies are built for being spent.

If it does, in this case, the doctor's reaction is to advise the patient that one more rise triggers recurrence and a plan is determined for consideration and preparation of choices. Why use the ultrasensitive test if it does not correlate to a specific treatment regimen?
Posts.Title: PSA anxiety again....

Posts.Content: If you're looking for suggestions; I recommend a second opinion on reading the MRI. I'd also insist on a biopsy based simply on your PSA and if your free PSA was as noted by Michael F. Nothing about your continuing rising PSA sounds good to me. If you are working to reduce your PSA I have to ask why when it is trying to tell you something. You have not ruled out cancer.
Posts.Title: My PSA Keeps Elevating

Posts.Content: Yep. Not sure of the cause, but suspect some nerve damage. Also the rectum has more room and is aligned slightly differently. When sitting on the toilet raise up on your toes. Also try leaning forward slightly at the same time. We give the same advice to young children or have them raise their feet by using a stool for their feet to raise the knees. It takes a little bit of the bend out of the last turn.

Difficult to confront, but your assessment of your fitness and family history helps in projecting a number. A large consideration in life expectancy is your BMI. The health consequences of gaining weight as we age is the largest contributor to reduced life expectancy; high blood pressure, high cholesterol and heart disease, diabetes, and less activity. Get a second opinion on the Gleason scoring of all your samples. Everything changes if G4 is present. The premier lab for this is Epstein at John Hopkins. Did the biopsy include a random array in addition to the targeted samples? Looks like it with the 13. Just want to confirm. And where was the one G6 in the prostate? Most of the diagnostic tools we have are marginal, at best, including MRIs. However, if your PSA is steady (not bouncing around) it can be the most reliable indicator, imo. Yours is rising recently, steadily and with the possiblity of some velocity indicating more may be going on than just one G6. You found an excellent forum here.
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm a new member

Posts.Content: From what I am learning from my short experience with this disease is there is no "all is well." Once begun this vigil is never over. My health system is using the <0.02 and I have no illusions that my PSA may be moving below this limit, or not. I know this only from what I have learned on my own initiative and this wondetful site. If a health system is going to use the ultrasensitive test then the anxiety created by knowing sooner than later is managed by knowing what treatment options are available sooner than later. The anxiety produced by a doctor wanting to know while putting off discussion of what happens next with the patient, or not being clear that no action will be taken until it reaches a much higher level when options exist to treat earlier with higher success rates is why we find ourselves left to discover these things here rather than our doctor's office. I am not pursuing this conversation here to say one way is right, but to demonstrate the argument for the poster to empower them to pursue a more aggressive path of treatment made possible with ultratesting if they want it in the face of a doctor who may not be preparing them for it. The temptation on the doctor side is to operate on a need to know basis assuming they need to know more than the patient. The result is needless anxiety. The impact here is not that the patient knows too much about their PSA, but they don't know enough about what their options are with that information. Imo based on what the poster is sharing, the doctor's actions are not aligned with the test he is using. In a perfect world, the last test would have generated an in office conversation about what happens if the next test shows a third rise. If the health system's protocol is to not take action until .1 or higher the <0.02 test is sufficient. A simple 2 minute conversation in the beginning about recurrence, the testing for it, and their treatment protocol around it relieves any anxiety caused by knowing some but not all of what the doctor knows. I understand a doctor's motivation to deal only with what happens next. They don't experience anxiety because they know what happens next. Patient's have it because they don't know what happens next. A doctor may not see anxiety as a medically relevant symptom. I do, for many reasons which is another conversation. If a health system is going to choose to use the ultrasensitive test then education of the patient should align with that choice. If patients don't push back with that need the doctor will not address it. Personally, I found my doctor's conversation about PSA testing and recurrence after the surgery to be inadequate. I'm sure his answer would be we will deal with that when and if it happens. I will let him know my thoughts when we meet again. That's my responsibility.
Posts.Title: PSA anxiety again....

Posts.Content: Your experience makes the case for not using the ultrasensitive test that measures to 0.000. While wanting to know is the other side of the debate it produces information that will not contribute to any meaningful action. The other two tests leave plenty of time to take action.
Posts.Title: PSA anxiety again....

Posts.Content: Follow the instructions they give you. If he is fit it's pretty light duty. Personal lubricant (KY) to lube the catheter at the tip of the penis. Be careful not to hook the tube on things while you carry it around the house. Avoiding constipation is the biggy to avoid straining and unecessary pressure from compacted stool while all that plumbing heals. Use stool softners.
Posts.Title: And . . . here we go!

Posts.Content: Just received my 18 months post op PSA, <0.02! I have a short story to tell. When I got my test results they had changed their test to a new assay with a lower test limit of <0.06. The result posted was <0.06. It took thee phone calls starting with my GP who said he would check into it, but it's still undetectable. I said I understand, but now I'can't compare results and I have lost 0.04 in detection. Waited a week, and when he didn't get back to me I called the surgeon's office. Said it was still undectable. I said I know, but I lost 0.04 points in detection. They said call the lab. I did. Similar conversation, and they confirmed they changed their test, but still undetectable. I said I understood, but not good enough. The lab called my doctor, then called me back and said we will change your test. When you come in ask for Quest and ultra sensitive and we will note your file as well. Retest results came back in, and it was interesting to note the test was sent to California. Took 2 days and was posted to my portal. Technology is amazing! Now, <0.02 is not ultra sensitive as I understand it, but good enough for me at this point. Despite everyone's good intentions and hard work you still have to be an advocate for yourself. Now, I will call everyone back, let them know I'm happy and how it was resolved, and thank them for their work to get me back on track. Hopefully, it was a learning experience for everyone. I have to think that even if it occurrs to them as an annoyance in their day they will appreciate my advocacy as an intregal part of their own commitment to provide excellence in service and healthcare, person by person.
