Posts.Title: Biopsy scheduled - I've got Shingles...!

Posts.Content: Confirm the Gleason 4 with a second opinion. Epstein's lab at Hopkins is the state of the art. If G4 is confirmed you are a candidate for treatment. Your young age, G4, and volume are the critical factors. Because cancer wasn't hit on one side doesn't mean it's not there. Your young age is the most critical factor. G4 presenting so early implies an aggressive form of cancer, imo. At 54 it has a head start, and it will not go away or slow down. Silver lining, you caught it early making it very treatable. Early detection, early treatment is the mantra for aggressive forms of this disease. You have time to consider and educate yourself. Stay main stream and out of the weeds. Welcome to the club. G4, age, and volume do not make you a good candidate for AS, imo.

Posts.Title: Worried about my number

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 I had a biopsy in 2014. 1 core positive <<5% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 Active Surveillance Second biopsy 2017. 4 cores positive < 30% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 So does that mean I'm safe? Seems to me, all currently available treatments are from the caveman era. It's pretty disappointing. And then it seems you have to do a coin flip to choose the doctor that you want to mutilate or burn you. How sick is that. Sorry to be so frank in my opinion. I'm ready to deal with the after effects so I'll be flipping the coin soon. Time to move on to the rest of my life. I'm realizing that I have to develop a sense of humor to trudge through this mess to get to the GOOD SIDE. I guess comedy and tragedy really are two heads of the same coin. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for Gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67 Safe? Or you serious? You have confirmation of prostate cancer. It is now your responsibility to manage it. If ignored it can kill you. If managed you can live a long life and die of something else. Your choice.

Posts.Title: Worried about my number

Posts.Content: A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. Studies have shown that some who experience sepsis after biopsy also had antibiotic treatment for elevated PSA. Your age, PSA, symptoms, and negative urine culture are evidence enough to test for cancer and not treat for a bacterial infection. Studies also show there will be a chance of a slight decrease in your PSA as a result of the antibiotics in the presence of cancer that some will use as a reason to postpone a biopsy. There is a belief, which I consider now to be outdated and verging on harmful myth, that prostate cancer is slow growing and you will not die from it and it leads some to take a casual approach to it's symptoms and diagnoses. I did. There is some truth in it, but many will tell you that during the diagnoses is not the time to take the possibility lightly. That truth only applies when there is some evidence that supports it, such as a biopsy grading it as non aggressive. Living with prostate cancer is no cake walk even if it doesn't kill you! Your symptoms presenting at a young age increase the possibility of it being a more aggressive form of the cancer. Regarding your question about late stages, probably not, but it is not a relevant question (not a bad question). Prostate cancer has high probability of a "cure" when detected early. There are some grades that are relatively indolent and hang around growing slowly. Other's are more aggressive and head out into the body quickly. All of them benefit from early diagnosis, and will be something you treat and manage the rest of your life.

Posts.Title: Worried about my number

Posts.Content: I have a question. Radiation is suppose to kill the cancer cells, because they are by nature weaker cells, and spare the healthy cells. What stops the radiate prostate from continuing to produce cancer cells? For me, I lost confidence in my prostate to play nice and wanted it removed to halt any further mischief such as future BHP or the remaining cells producing more cancer cells. It is my understanding radiation does not "kill" the prostate. It only "kills" the cancerous prostate cells at the time of the treatment. The prostate is left alive and "well" to continue to do what it has already proven itself to do which is continue to produce both healthy and cancerous prostate cells in the future. In the poster's case, it has proven itself to produce a more aggressive type of cancer cell at an early age. The radiation has no way of determining which healthy cells will eventually be triggered to start producing cancerous cells. Radiation leaves behind a difficult if not impossible mess of damaged tissue to try to clean up 25 years from now. Future radiation is not a useful option making matters worse for all the surrounding tissue/organs, and surgeons do not like operating in or around radiation damaged sites because the radiated tissue is no longer normal healthy tissue. Most prostate cancer is slow growing and begins later in life and most men outlive it. Not so in a younger man with more aggressive cancer. The term "cure" in prostate cancer does not mean what we first think it means, i.e. permanent. The word is used in the context of time, 5 years, 10 years, 15 years and does not apply well to the younger man or aggressive cancer. For me, its a kick the can down the road game and at the moment there are only 3 kicks I have at it; surgery, radiation, and hormone therapy. Time is the variable to determine how many kicks I'll need. A younger man with aggressive cancer may need all three and more. An old man may need none. Everyone else falls somewhere between.

Posts.Title: 28 Year old and have most symptoms of PC

Posts.Content: Pathology reports are not 100%. They may choose to use time and cost saving methods and take a sampling of slices based on their observation of the gland and judgment. Interestingly, their observation of the margins is over 90% accurate. Or, one doctor's 6 is another's 3+4. That being said I am not yet convinced than Gleason 6 can not survive alone. It may not be fatal but that is a whole other calculus. It may be internet creep, i.e. Gleason 6 rarely metastasizes talk turns in to it can't survive outside the prostate. It may survive and grow slowly, but still not metastasize. It seems there is a lot we still don't know.

Posts.Content: I had 8 cores of 3+3 biopsy and chose surgery. Path was tumor 35% of 60gr organ. I do not consider it slow or indolent. It was upgraded to 3+4, but that possibility was not a considerstion in my choice. Had I known it was going to remain 3+3 I still would have chosen surgery. Just too much cancer indicating it wasn't slow growth imo. There is G scores and there is volume. I think the percentage of cells producing 3s is a valid consideration. I never felt pressured. Nobody ever suggested it could be worse than the information in hand.

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Good news! Don't work it too hard! Give it time to heal. Another temptation is to drink less in an effort to manage your recovering continence. It snuck up on me. I didn't realize I was doing it until I started paying attention to the color of my urine. It was consistently too dark. Keep yourself hydrated during this period. Watch your urine color; lemonade color - good, apple juice color - dehydrated. Dehydration will slow the healing and risk a UTI.

Posts.Title: Need advice

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear this news. You've found a good source that is served by many experienced men with this disease. I am relatively new to this. This is what I can share. You are very fortunate to have discovered this. Your age, the amount of cancer and it's locations are serious indicators of something you may want to consider treating aggressively. Your age indicates this may be more aggressive than the Gleason scores you have available suggest. You can get a second opinion on the grading. There is also a chance they can be upgraded when examined after surgery. That happened in my case. I believe your doctor's are giving you very good advice. I am very impressed with an oncologist recommending surgery. It points to the seriousness of your situation, that it is still possible to play for a cure keeping the possibility of radiation as your second line of defense. Open vs Robotics debate is unclear to me. My understanding is outcomes at this point rely entirely on the skill of the surgeon. Robotics has a greater learning curve and cost, but ultimately may win out due to the ability of the surgeon to see under magnification what he is doing. Cyberknife is for low and intermediate risk cancers. While it is tempting to look at your Gleason scores and make a case for it I am more concerned with your age and that you have a prostate that has begun producing cancer that with time may not be so friendly. MRI is quickly becoming a more reliable diagnostic tool than TRUS and PI-RADS 4 indicates the possibility of a high risk of significant cancer. Again, more valuable information than the Gleason score at this point. (I assume these samples were from a random biopsy.) You want to play this game for a cure or long life. Erections are third on the list after your life and continence and not worth risking your life, imo. I am curious how you discovered this so early without symptoms or family history. It is unusual to be testing PSA so early. You are very lucky! Do not squander what you have been given by trying to finesse this disease. It's an underestimation of it's seriousness that I see happen too much, imo. It's a beast that can be beat if diagnosed early. You've got that part covered.

Posts.Title: Life expectancy for advanced prostate cancer in an 81 year old man with an 8 Gl score

Posts.Content: It is true studies are underway, and there is not enough clinical evidence for most to change current treatment protocals. It is the nature of salvage radiation to be most effective against low risk/stage disease. Recurrence in low risk disease has a higher likelyhood of being confined to the prostate bed. SR is effective treating such a limited area. If 3 can't survive outside the gland, then it's 4 or greater creating the BCR. Low detection levels may catch it before it has metastized. Time and waiting on G4 & 5 give it a chance to run or fly which 4 and 5 do. I suspect the thinking was to wait and make the recurrence risk certain and worthy of the side effects. Detection and radiation technology have improved dramaticaly, and what if you're playing for a cure? Why wait? Once you know, waiting is to it's favor not yours if you plan on using SR, imo. For me despite current (outdated?) protocals, if you are going to use the limited value of SR, the sooner the better. AS, imo, is for a high probability treatment will never be necessary. If treatment is a high probability then sooner is better. When playing for a cure sooner is the optimum time for treating prostate cancer, imo. The other option for low to intermediate risk is surgery and done. As always it considers age and other morbidities. The back up is HT and chemo. This is a useful discussion. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2848745/

Posts.Content: There are three tests; 0.1, <0.02, and 0.001. The 0.001 is the ultrsensitive. They are all sensitive and accurate to their limit. There is no jiggle room within each test. The value in the ultrasensitive is the ability to establish a trend before 0.030. 0.03 is now considered the most effective threshold for salvage radiation. If you are using the <0.02 test you may not see it coming as soon.

Posts.Title: Dr. Bal Carter, at Johns Hopkins, retiring....

Posts.Content: The nerves that control the blood held in erections run down alongside the prostate. One on each side. They are not within the prostate. Removing the prostate without damaging them is difficult. Heat from the cauterizing tool in the surgical cavity, disruption of blood flow from the cutting and cauterizing of blood vessels, pushing and pulling off tissue around the nerves all can contribute to damage. Most can heal, but nerve tissue heals much slower than other tissue. If the surgeon sees cancer they will remove it even if it has invaded the space around the nerve. If the nerve is cut it will most likely not be restored with healing. They are difficult to see. A small electrical wire is used to stimulate and reveal them to the surgeon who can visually see them inside the surgical cavity. An advantage of DaVinci. Sometimes the prostate gets large enough that the pressure of the enlarged prostate pressing on the nerve next to it will damage it permanently. Obesity can have a similar effect. Orgasms are controlled by another nerve not at risk with RP. This is the nerve just beneath the head of the penis on the underside. You will still have the ability to have orgasms even if you lose the ability to have an erection. It is recommended you begin exercising both functions after the surgery and continue to have orgasms without erections. My erections took a year to a year and a half to recover from a textbook surgery.

Most medical institutions have patient portals to access results on line. Actively participate until a treatment plan is in place. I'd like to know the MRI report results.
Posts.Title: New Here, seeking guidance, father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Patience. This takes time to heal. Nerves have been traumatized and blood vessels cartarized. Nerves ( feeling in the area) need to heal and nerve tissue takes longer to heal than other tissue. Blood needs to find other pathways to healing tissue and muscle. Also, it is a temptation to manage the return to continence by drinking less. You may not realize you are doing it. Make note of how much you drink a day to stay hydrated. Wait until your bladder is full then attempt to stop your urine stream mid stream. Eventually you will see this slow or even stop your stream. This will be a good sign. This exercise is only to reassure you it will return. It is not a good exercise for recovery. Do your kegels, but not to an extreme. Muscles will tire and fail before the day is through. One aspect of kegels is to tone the pelvic floor muscles. More importantly, it is to learn to identify them apart from the anus muscles and learn to control them to the point it becomes automatic. Lifting your pelvic floor muscles without tightening your anus is a pat your head rub your tummy exercise. Practise lifting them slowly and stopping and holding on the way up and on the way down. Like an elevator. Alcohol (also hinders healing)and caffeine irritate the bladder and cause a natural loss of control. Consider giving them up until you have your continence back and then reintroduce them and note the effect. You will have to manage their use from here on. Remember - ready, set, relax. Patience and time are now your friends. Your body knows what to do.

Posts.Title: PSA increase follow up:

Posts.Content: Confirm the Gleason 4 with a second opinion. Epstein's lab at Hopkins is the state of the art. If G4 is confirmed you are a candidate for treatment. Your young age, G4, and volume are the critical factors. Because cancer wasn't hit on one side doesn't mean it's not there. Your young age is the most critical factor. G4 presenting so early implies an aggressive form of cancer, imo. At 54 it has a head start, and it will not go away or slow down. Silver lining, you caught it early making it very treatable. Early detection, early treatment is the mantra for aggressive forms of this disease. You have time to consider and educate yourself. Stay main stream and out of the weeds. Welcome to the club. G4, age, and volume do not make you a good candidate for AS, imo.

Posts.Content: I am relatively new to this game, and it does not surprise me. Having been diagnosed with 3+3 via biopsy, upgraded to 3+4 via pathology, and having a tumor size at 35% of a 65gr prostate creating continence issue I have a lot of respect for G6 as a cancer - "the disease caused by an uncontrolled division of abnormal cells in a part of the body." The disgruntled who rant about G6 being indolent cancer, over treatment, and money hungry doctors do not add to the conversation to defeat this disease, imo. Many of us want to believe the better part of the message - G6 does not kill. Maybe it doesn't, but in many it is cancer and can cause quality of life issues (incontinence or urinary track obstruction) and indicates a higher risk of more aggressive cancers being present and some of these considerations may be worthy of treatment. I stopped participating in another forum because the shrillness of their message around this issue is a distraction to science, medicine, caring, and may be misleading. Thanks for letting me rant some myself.

AgeInfo.Phrase: size at 35% of a 65gr prostate creating continence issue I

Posts.Content: Eat a healthy diet. Using diet and supplements to manipulate your PSA will have no effect on cancer. It may mask your most valuable BCR indicator -your PSA. Your battle is with cancer not your PSA.
Posts.Title: Diet after RALP

Posts.Content: Surgery is a typical treatment recommendation for young men. Recovery is easier, side effects recover quicker, and it gives you a longer treatment game plan with radiation, and hormone therapy should you need them later down the road. If you start with radiation surgery is off the table. Cures are measured with time, 5 years, 10 years, etc. As a young man, you are more interested in a longer game plan. You may be a candidate for AS. It requires diligent ongoing testing and monitoring. The key is active. Sometimes you can avoid treatment or kick it down the road a bit. Because of your young age you will be dealing with this for a longer time. Recurrence is the concern, and what to do if and when. Also, because it is presenting at such a young age there may be more aggressive cancer in there not hit by the biopsy, or it may develop with time.
Posts.Title: 1st Time Poster...

Posts.Content: Supplements are a common addiction and part of the denial process. An ongoing healthy diet with regular exercise is work. It promotes general health and strength. Supplements are easy. You buy them and consume them with little effort. Get your BMI between 19 and 25. Reducing body fat takes work and discipline to transform your life habits. Taking supplements does little to nothing to transform your habits or improve health. One example, drinking a high sugar processed fruit juice such as pomegranite juice substitues processed sugar and damaged/empty micro-nutrients for real food. Mega dosing on herbs and vitamins can only stress your liver and kidneys and irtitate your bladder and urethra. It's never too late to begin a healthy diet and exercise regime. It will develop strength. It will not directly cure cancer. Your heightened state of renewed commitment to your health is a good thing. Looking for quick fixes is a warning flag of old behaviors. You know what a healthy life style is. You've known it all your life. Yet here you are. Relax and go about the business of transforming your diet and sedentary life style. Reduce your weight. Stop alcohol. Reduce caffeine. Drink water and tea. Exercise. Reduce red meats. Increase fresh vegetables. Increase olive oil. Eliminate processed foods, fats, dressings. You know the drill. Spend time buying fresh foods, preparing them, and eating them. Learn to eat what's in season. Do not, I repeat, do not focus on reducing your PSA. Your PSA is your friend. Reduce your BMI. I just got back from Italy, you know what? They are thin!

Posts.Title: 1st Time Poster...

Posts.Content: That is a number so far from current studies I suspect his stats are influenced by his typical patient profile being unique or a quirk in the lab he uses. Making such a public declaration of an anomaly like that makes me wonder what's going on. This debate seems stuck in time. Radiation appears to win the short term "cure" side effects. This is great for old men with prostate cancer. But increasingly, younger and younger men are being diagnosed with prostate cancer due both to early screening and a disease that is expanding into a younger demographic. We still do not know the mechanism behind it. I'd like a new drug. A simple injection that shrinks and disapears the tumors with no side effects. Immune therapy seems to be coming on strong. Bottom line, I'm not happy with either radiation or surgery. They both seem to have a very small sweet spot (ideal patient profile).

Posts.Title: Biopsy concerns

Posts.Content: I did begin to measure pad weights with a small food scale when it seemed the leaking was dimishing yet I couldn't tell a difference. I'd add them for a day. Then compare a week later. Weigh an empty pad first. I did it mostly to reinforce small changes. Like weighing yourself everyday when you are losing weight. Once you're down to one lite pad the tendency is to slack off on improvements, i.e. stop working your kegels, stop using them when you start a stress move, etc. It did take an extra effort near the end to close the leaks associated with everyday stess moves; i.e. getting in and out of the car, standing up, etc. Mostly just being mindful of the moment and using your kegels with intention. You can always grap yourself and clamp down, if your alone, during a stress move (sneeze, cough, etc.). Regarding the weighing, it was not a straight line. There were small setbacks and variations. Probably due to tiredness, drinking, irritants, and just being human. Coffee, alcohol, caffeine, and other foods/drinks will irritate the blader and contribute to leaking. Some of these never stop having an effect. For example, if I have more than a few drinks I will start to leak if tired. Another example, end of day activities when your kegels are simply tired. When sleeping or lying gravity is not working against you. First improvements are always noticed with sleeping because you are taking gravity out of the equation. Sitting helps as well becauce pressure is pushing upward from the sitting position. The concern never quite goes away, but it does become automatic with time. I always carry a lite pad and very very rarely use it. Usually late at night when drinking. A caution. Subconsciously you may be tempted to drink less to control performance in this matter. Don't. Don't dehyrate yourself. Regarding alcohol, it will inhibit healing. I'd give it up for at least 3 months.

Posts.Content: I have a question. Radiation is suppose to kill the cancer cells, because they are by nature weaker cells, and spare the healthy cells. What stops the radiate prostate from continuing to produce cancer cells? For me, I lost confidence in my prostate to play nice and wanted it removed to halt any further mischief such as future BHP or the remaining cells producing more cancer cells. It is my understanding radiation does not "kill" the prostate. It only "kills" the cancerous prostate cells at the time of the treatment. The prostate is left alive and "well" to continue to do what it has already proven itself to do which is continue to produce both healthy and cancerous prostate cells in the future. In the poster's case, it has proven itself to produce a more aggressive type of cancer cell at an early age. The radiation has no way of determining which healthy cells will eventually be triggered to start producing cancerous cells. Radiation leaves behind a difficult if not impossible mess of damaged tissue to try to clean up 25 years from now. Future radiation is not a useful option making matters worse for all the surrounding tissue/organs, and surgeons do not like operating in or around radiation damaged sites because the radiated tissue is no longer normal healthy tissue. Most prostate cancer is slow growing and begins later in life and most men outlive it. Not so in a younger man with more aggressive cancer. The term "cure" in prostate cancer does not mean what we first think it means, i.e. permanent. The word is used in the context of time, 5 years, 10 years, 15 years and does not apply well to the younger man or aggressive cancer. For me, its a kick the can down the road game and at the moment there are only 3 kicks I have at it; surgery, radiation, and hormone therapy. Time is the variable to determine how many kicks I'll need. A younger man with aggressive cancer may need all three and more. An old man may need none. Everyone else falls somewhere between.

Interestingly, their observation of the margins is over 90% accurate. Or, one doctor's 6 is another's 3+4. That being said I am not yet convinced than Gleason 6 can not survive alone. It may not be fatal but that is a whole other calculus. It may be internet creep, i.e. Gleason 6 rarely metastasizes talk turns in to it can't survive outside the prostate. It may survive and grow slowly, but still not metastasize. It seems there is a lot we still don't know.

Posts.Content: I will challenge the bias for surgery being in favor of technology. Nothing is more advanced technology than radiation, imo. Yet, patients are not rushing to it. The commitment to less intrusive means of treatment is what drives it all, imo. Technology is just a means to an end. I'd argue physicians and their industry are conservative and embrace technology only as it proves itself more effective. The steep learning curve for DaVinci is an insider secret that influenced physicians to wait. Declaring blind touch the best method for removing a cancerous prostate is nostolgia, imo. I'd argue they lack faith in the past numbers on side effects as a result of a dramatically new technology. Most traditionally educated surgeons, imo, will initially resist the idea of accepting surgery becoming robotic.

Posts.Title: Diabetes Complication?

Posts.Content: Confirm the Gleason 4 with a second opinion. Epstein's lab at Hopkins is the state of the art. If G4 is confirmed you are a candidate for treatment. Your young age, G4, and volume are the critical factors. Because cancer wasn't hit on one side doesn't mean it's not there. Your young age is the most critical factor. G4 presenting so early implies an aggressive form of cancer, imo. At 54 it has a head start, and it will not go away or slow down. Silver lining, you caught it early making it very treatable. Early detection, early treatment is the mantra for aggressive forms of this disease. You have time to consider and educate yourself. Stay main stream and out of the weeds. Welcome to the club. G4, age, and volume do not make you a good candidate for AS, imo.

Posts.Title: How Long to Wait?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Duck2 Feed a cold, starve a fever, so what is happening in this suggestion is starve both good and bad cells. I know nothing about this method, but.... Starving prostate cells of testosterone can cause unhealthy cancer cells to be stunned into remission for long periods of time or forever, or even kill them. Healthy cells can survive this. Also, treating cells with (toxic) radiation is similar. Prostate cancer cells have less DNA redundancy and most can not survive radiation while most healthy cells can. While healthy and unhealthy cancer cells both get treated with radiation the cancer cells have less ability to survive it than the healthy ones. You can compound this weakening effect with testosterone starvation causing the cancer prostate cells to be even more vulnerable to the radiation. Management of toxic treatments can be a useful tool treating cancer. Chemo is another. Ideal? No, but it works enough in part to extend life or survive cancer. Does it work with nutrition? I don't know, but the concept is sound with other harsh treatments. There is some truth in the line, "What doesn't kill you can make you stronger." On the other side you may not be as healthy as before, but the cancer may be less so. I have a good friend that eventually succumbed to chemo therapy as a last effort. It worked for a while, but probably added to her demise. She survived breast cancer for 10 years. She was grateful and so was I. It was the ten years I knew her. Personally, I think a healthy diet is more beneficial than an unhealthy one, but I can see the possiblity only test studies can reveal.

Posts.Title: Are we moving in the right direction (aggressive PC diagnosis)

Posts.Content: Many want to make the choice between radiation and surgery a choice between the best treatment choice, i.e. one is a better choice than another. How I see it is they are different treatments. It's like asking what's a better way to travel; planes, trains, or automobiles? If it's very close you can walk. To far to walk you can drive. To far to drive you can fly. Each mode is more effective than another for a specific travel profile. Some are afraid to fly so they drive or take a bus. They all get you somewhere. They all work for what they are designed to do, and they are not universally interchangeable. They are different. Surgery and radiation each have a specific patient profile that makes them more effective for that profile than the other. I will not go so far as to say they are interchangable. One can be done in lieu of the other in lots of profiles. It doesn't mean it is better. There are clear patient profiles where the majority of professionals will agree on the mode of treatment. Then a clear profile where either will work with pros and cons. Then there are those profiles that exclude one treatment as not medically possible or recommended. There are multible biases; provider bias, patient bias, and confirmation bias. Provider bias: surgeons prefer surgery and radiologist prefer radiotherapy. Yet competent professionals will acknowledge when the patient's profile trumps their skill set and is better served by the other. Patient bias: each of us has a bias for surgery or radiation independent of what we know and our own profile. For example, going in I'd hope my profile matches up with surgery. That bias comes from thinking if it's small, unentangled, and can be cleanly removed - remove it. My bias is against radiation as toxic and crude and used when the line between healthy and diseased tissue can not be made with a scaple. Sounds very reasonable, but it is still a bias that tempts me to hear only those things about my profile supporting surgety. (Someone with a radiation bias can speak for that.) Confirmation bias: a patient chooses and then begins to listen for any and only evidence that supports his choice as the best choice. This is automatic and we all do it. The upside is we have a multitude of effective, tried, and proven treatment choices. The best advice is to stay out of the weeds and go main stream, imo. This is a little off topic, but it applies to how we misuse language. If you use the words right and wrong, better or worse, good or bad you are making a moral judgment. Those words are exclusive to moral language yet we collapse them into other judgment choices. The consideration is what will work and how effective will it be. We want to be right more than anything often times at the expense of what works.

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Patience. This takes time to heal. Nerves have been traumatized and blood vessels cartarized. Nerves ( feeling in the area) need to heal and nerve tissue takes longer to heal than other tissue. Blood needs to find other pathways to healing tissue and muscle. Also, it is a temptation to manage the return to continence by drinking less. You may not realize you are doing it. Make note of how much you drink a day to stay hydrated. Wait until your bladder is full then attempt to stop your urine stream mid stream. Eventually you will see this slow or even stop your stream. This will be a good sign. This exercise is only to reassure you it will return. It is not a good exercise for recovery. Do your kegels, but not to an extreme. Muscles will tire and fail before the day is through. One aspect of kegels is to tone the pelvic floor muscles. More importantly, it is to learn to identify them apart from the anus muscles and learn to control them to the point it becomes automatic. Lifting your pelvic floor muscles without tightening your anus is a pat your head rub your tummy exercise. Practise lifting them slowly and stopping and holding on the way up and on the way down. Like an elevator. Alcohol (also hinders healing)and caffeine irritate the bladder and cause a natural loss of control. Consider giving them up until you have your continence back and then reintroduce them and note the effect. You will have to manage their use from here on. Remember - ready, set, relax. Patience and time are now your friends. Your body knows what to do.
Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: What I like about this study is they avoided speculating on cause. The results speak for themselves. When you let an outcome hang out there unexplained and undefended you allow the space for the impact on those who's bias is to immediately deny the cause you present. It is a very powerful way to make a point. Those who advocated for the reduction in screening are left to their own thoughts. It took a lot of discipline for the designers of this study to limit their study to just the results, but highly effective. Glad to see it. My girlfriend emailed this to me yesterday, and her conclusion was as obvious as it is to most except those who were responsible for the reduction in screening. It will take longer for them to adjust their thinking to the facts. It works to give them the space to be alone with the facts and their responsibility in it.

Posts.Title: What's your thoughts on a female doing the DRE exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee Interesting (or disturbing) that SRT is seen as having only 'marginal benefit' in cases of SVI. Typically SVI is viewed as very serious adverse pathology and is justification for immediate adjuvant radiation. SVI may be an indicator it's too late for localized treatment success in that direction. The location of the extension can be an indicator of risk recurrence and treatment success. Cancer at the base is higher risk in general. It may be more difficult to reach effectively without unacceptable side effects. SVs extend up and behind the bladder. Early detection and treatment may still be a gold standard.
Posts.Title: Extraprostatic extension (EPE) and Adjuvant Radiation

Posts.Content: That's a horse of a different color. A search reveals over 38% of the general population in the US will be diagnosed with a cancer at some time in their lives. These statistic are available for specific types of cancer as well and are available for the UK. Developing prostate cancer for men is 11.5% and dying of it is 1 in 41 or 2.45%. These numbers are increasing. An average age group, statiscally, to approach a rate of 3% is 25-49 which has a 3.8% rate. You must live in a very young community or a 3% rate may indicate a less than average rate of cancer screening. Your local healthcare group may be revealing a less than average rate of cancer screening rather than a high level of proactive care. Or, your community may be a statistical cancer healthy anomally.

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: Many want to make the choice between radiation and surgery a choice between the best treatment choice, i.e. one is a better choice than another. How I see it is they are different treatments. It's like asking what's a better way to travel; planes, trains, or automobiles? If it's very close you can walk. To far to walk you can drive. To far to drive you can fly. Each mode is more effective than another for a specific travel profile. Some are afraid to fly so they drive or take a bus. They all get you somewhere. They all work for what they are designed to do, and they are not universally interchangeable. They are different. Surgery and radiation each have a specific patient profile that makes them more effective for that profile than the other. I will not go so far as to say they are interchangable. One can be done in lieu of the other in lots of profiles. It doesn't mean it is better. There are clear patient profiles where the majority of professionals will agree on the mode of treatment. Then a clear profile where either will work with pros and cons. Then there are those profiles that exclude one treatment as not medically possible or recommended. There are multible biases; provider bias, patient bias, and confirmation bias. Provider bias: surgeons prefer surgery and radiologist prefer radiotherapy. Yet competent professionals will acknowledge when the patient's profile trumps their skill set and is better served by the other. Patient bias: each of us has a bias for surgery or radiation independent of what we know and our own profile. For example, going in I'd hope my profile matches up with surgery. That bias comes from thinking if it's small, unentangled, and can be cleanly removed - remove it. My bias is against radiation as toxic and crude and used when the line between healthy and diseased tissue can not be made with a scaple. Sounds very reasonable, but it is still a bias that tempts me to hear only those things about my profile supporting surgety. (Someone with a radiation bias can speak for that.) Confirmation bias: a patient chooses and then begins to listen for any and only evidence that supports his choice as the best choice. This is automatic and we all do it. The upside is we have a multitude of effective, tried, and proven treatment choices. The best advice is to stay out of the weeds and go main stream, imo. This is a little off topic, but it applies to how we misuse language. If you use the words right and wrong, better or worse, good or bad you are making a moral judgment. Those words are exclusive to moral language yet we collapse them into other judgment choices. The consideration is what will work and how effective will it be. We want to be right more than anything often times at the expense of what works.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: You're on the cusp between surgery and radiation. Considerations are general health and life expectancy. Side effects of surgery are higher risk of permanent incontinence. Did Dad and uncles have surgery and if so what were the pathology reports? Looking for evidence of possible higher Gleason than 6. What is the prostate size?

Posts.Title: What to do at age 68?

Posts.Content: Why are you being screened for prostate cancer at your very young age? Why was the MRI done before your biopsy? Why is the doctor recommending surgery? Are you in a higher risk ethnic group? MRIs can miss detecting both small low grade and small aggressive cancers. Biopsy can miss also and there is a risk of other more aggressive cancer being present and undetected. Your young age is a wild card. Your survival challenge is greater because your exposure is longer. A cancer that begins growing so soon will have a longer time to generate mischief regardless of it's aggressiveness. Volume alone can eventually impact quality of life causing all the symptoms of more aggressive cancers. In general, early detection and early treatment yields better results with this disease. You are a candidate for AS, but more diagnostic efforts are part of that protocol to monitor your cancer. "A" means active. Your PSA is high for your age and cancer type. A second opinion on the Gleason scoring is recommended, imo, as well as genetic testing. You are fortunate to have discovered this.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Studies have shown that detection and treatment as early as .03 improves treatment outcomes. You need 3 decimals to see that coming in time. My health system uses .2 as the mark between undetectable and detectable. I do not agree with it. Remember, these are all moving targets as we develop a protoccol that works best for everyone. It's not noise for everyone.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I don't have the full paper, but there may not have been enough power in the design to make that statistically significant. This was one experiment. It does not mean that you can generalize that as the actual number in reality. In other words, if you ran the study with another group of that size, it may be equally likely that you get a 3-man disadvantage. So why post it if it is statistically insignificant?
Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: I believe early detection early treatment is still the gold standard with this disease. uPSA means early detection.
Posts.Title: PSA vs. uPSA

Posts.Content: You have both a high volume of cancer and an aggressive cancer in the primary 4. Your health is your primary responsibilty. Those who love and care for you will agree. My advice is to choose the treatment and schedule that places your health and well being first. As a son and father it is what I would do and want my children to do and hope my children would want me to do. I'd also share this information with my immediate family once I made my choice. Without a long discourse, witholding information is manipulative. We can handle it and one thing doesn't overshadow another. Life is messy and it finds a way to bring joy to those who live it full out with nothing hidden. Placing any responsibility for nothing but the best outcome for you on your view of what is best for someone else doesn't work. This is an inconvenience for you. You can handle this without drama and worry. Not that there won't be some, but you get to say how this goes and your family will follow your lead.

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Also, if your PSA is an effective indicator and the supplement reduces or manupulates it in anyway you will lose your very valuable baseline. Manipulation of PSA does not impact the cancer and it will continue to grow only now your PSA can not be trusted to track it for you. Also, short term relief of symptoms is a booby prize that gives the cancer a head start. If you are having difficult urinating remember your body is trying to tell you something. Self diagnose at your own peril. Just because some food, diet, or supplement regime reduces your PSA or makes it easier to pee for a while does not mean it is reducing the cancer. At the moment, there is no magic pill. If your goal is to detect and treat cancer stay within conventional protocols. They work. Do not wander into the weeds.
Posts.Title: Saw Palmetto

Posts.Content: My choice was surgery to remove as much of the source of the cancer as possible and to determine as complete a pathology of the cancer as possible. Then radiation to follow. Since both surgery and radiation are effective in different ways I wanted the most effective benefits of both. Fortunately my age, physical and mental fitness, diagnosis, and resources were suited for this approach. I am playing the game with one goal, to die of something else. Knowing that achieving a goal is most successful when separated into smaller incremental goals I do not expect this to happen in one event, but a series of smaller consecutive events until the day I pass of something else. In support of Jim's very important note regarding test limitations, it is not certain your cancer is confined to your prostate, and your scans are clear of detectable levels of cancer. The scans are not certain either. You have Gleason 4 cancer and your PSA is over 10. Those facts are more certain. As a technical writer you can understand the temptations that exist in the use of language, and how we step over the details to hear what we want. This also applies to the temptation to over think an issue to avoid the obvious and unpleasant realities. It explains your lengthy post and conclusion to pursue a treatment that is very much less used than others raising the very obvious question why? And in your signature, May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy. Not certain how that can be guaranteed. In the same reference to use of language, referring to Gleason grading as a flip of the coin is dangerous thinking. It is a professional assessment made by experienced doctors of pathology using a scoring system many decades in the making. They may differ slightly, but rarely are mistakes made and it is not a random selection. You may seek a second opinion of your Gleason score. Also, your rise in PSA did not come out of the blue. A 3.9 was a serious warning flag yet you allowed 2 years to pass before checking it again, and may even have ignored a recommendation to consider a biopsy then. All of this is not to beat you up or point out what you did wrong. It is to warn you how we use language to mislead ourselves and justify who, what, and where we are in our lives. My advice, get clear in your language and get out of your head. For most of us, this disease becomes an opportunity to clear our heads and learn again how to focus on what is real and important. It shows up first in our language.
Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: My GP did annual PSA and DRE. Then stopped. When I asked why he said we now do them every 3 years instead of annually. That was the beginning of PC is over diagnosed and treated. We will be paying for that for decades. Eventually they went back to annual exams, but that little piece of information fed my denial to act for several years. Fortunately his persistent intervention led to my diagnosis and treatment. I made a point of thanking him profusely. He got it.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Mine was painful but bearable. Inserting the probe is uncomfortable. The device is spring loaded so you will hear popping noises as each needle is deployed. Use breathing techniques. You will also do a bowel cleanse beforehand. Suspend your exercise routines afterwards until sufficiently healed.
Posts.Title: prostate biopsy due to sudden elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Welcome! Include the prostate size at the time of the biopsy in your signature. This impacts the effectiveness of the biopsy among other things. If you do not have the information that is being asked for here then get an actual copy of the biopsy report. Many health systems have online patient portals where reports are listed. If not, call the doctor's office and get it. Start a digital and paper file of all lab tests and pathology reports inclduing your PSA. The signature information is important mostly for you. It helps us respond, but more importantly it lists the salient facts for you. We can lost in our heads with all this stuff. It is a clear and concise reminder over time of what you do know. It's a layman's chart.

Posts.Title: PSA vs. uPSA

Posts.Content: When I asked my doctor the chance of recurrence his response was, "What percentage was your tumor?" Like you G6 was upgraded to G7, but everything else was good. It was the first and only time I've heard recurrence linked to volume. I suspect the 4 in G7 can run. We often think of cancer growing out in a mass, but they can move on a cellular level. It is an aspect of aggressiveness. They behave differently. My volume was 35%. He put me at 80% no BCR. There is always the other 20%. That sucks.
Posts.Title: 3 months post RALP and discouraged

Posts.Content: Well said. My doctor said, "This will be an annoyance for you." He was right. The biggest challenge for me is to stay in the moment and not worry my life away waiting for the next PSA test.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Sounds like your experiencing the ED associated with radiation treatments. I have read that 65% of men with radiation treamtents will experience ED within 5 years. I suspect it will progress without a chance of recovery. Trimix needle injections worked for me during my recovery although I had some unknown Pyronnie's which was made worse by the injections and I stopped after 5 or 6. I suggest you start with you doctor.

Posts.Title: Peach pits

Posts.Content: Many want to make the choice between radiation and surgery a choice between the best treatment choice, i.e. one is a better choice than another. How I see it is they are different treatments. It's like asking what's a better way to travel; planes, trains, or automobiles? If it's very close you can walk. To far to walk you can drive. To far to drive you can fly. Each mode is more effective than another for a specific travel profile. Some are afraid to fly so they drive or take a bus. They all get you somewhere. They all work for what they are designed to do, and they are not universally interchangeable. They are different. Surgery and radiation each have a specific patient profile that makes them more effective for that profile than the other. I will not go so far as to say they are interchangable. One can be done in lieu of the other in lots of profiles. It doesn't mean it is better. There are clear patient profiles where the majority of professionals will agree on the mode of treatment. Then a clear profile where either will work with pros and cons. Then there are those profiles that exclude one treatment as not medically possible or recommended. There are multible biases; provider bias, patient bias, and confirmation bias. Provider bias: surgeons prefer surgery and radiologist prefer radiotherapy. Yet competent professionals will acknowledge when the patient's profile trumps their skill set and is better served by the other. Patient bias: each of us has a bias for surgery or radiation independent of what we know and our own profile. For example, going in I'd hope my profile matches up with surgery. That bias comes from thinking if it's small, unentangled, and can be cleanly removed - remove it. My bias is against radiation as toxic and crude and used when the line between healthy and diseased tissue can not be made with a scaple. Sounds very reasonable, but it is still a bias that tempts me to hear only those things about my profile supporting surgety. (Someone with a radiation bias can speak for that.) Confirmation bias: a patient chooses and then begins to listen for any and only evidence that supports his choice as the best choice. This is automatic and we all do it. The upside is we have a multitude of effective, tried, and proven treatment choices. The best advice is to stay out of the weeds and go main stream, imo. This is a little off topic, but it applies to how we misuse language. If you use the words right and wrong, better or worse, good or bad you are making a moral judgment. Those words are exclusive to moral language yet we collapse them into other judgment choices. The consideration is what will work and how effective will it be. We want to be right more than anything often times at the expense of what works.
Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: 49% - 65% that it is cancer. Do not wait. Get a biopsy. 3T-MRI guided if you can. The odds that it is BHP or prostatitis are less, 5% - 19%. Urinary symptoms are the big yellow flag, PSA is the big red flag. Complete your history for us. Pay close attention to how seriously the urologist advocates for a diagnosis. http://www.mayomedicallaboratories.c...rpretive/81944 "Higher total PSA levels and lower percentages of free PSA are associated with higher risks of prostate cancer." Check the charts in the article. Like baseball this is totally a percentages game. You never really know. You only know the odds.

A word of caution, there is no comfort in a negative biopsy. If you are undergoing a biopsy there is a concern of cancer by other measures; age and symptoms, race, family history, rising PSA, MRI, and DRE. A negative biopsy has no impact on the other markers.
Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. Studies have shown that some who experience sepsis after biopsy also had antibiotic treatment for elevated PSA. Your age, PSA, symptoms, and negative urine culture are evidence enough to test for cancer and not treat for a bacterial infection. Studies also show there will be a chance of a slight decrease in your PSA as a result of the antibiotics in the presence of cancer that some will use as a reason to postpone a biopsy. There is a belief, which I consider now to be outdated and verging on harmful myth, that prostate cancer is slow growing and you will not die from it and it leads some to take a casual approach to it's symptoms and diagnoses. I did. There is some truth in it, but many will tell you that during the diagnoses is not the time to take the possibility lightly. That truth only applies when there is some evidence that supports it, such as a biopsy grading it as non aggressive. Living with prostate cancer is no cake walk even if it doesn't kill you! Your symptoms presenting at a young age increase the possibility of it being a more aggressive form of the cancer. Regarding your question about late stages, probably not, but it is not a relevant question (not a bad question). Prostate cancer has high probability of a "cure" when detected early. There are some grades that are relatively indolent and hang around growing slowly. Other's are more aggressive and head out into the body quickly. All of them benefit from early diagnosis, and will be something you treat and manage the rest of your life.

Posts.Content: After RP I asked my doctor what my risk of recurrence was. He said let me check your tumor size. It was 35% of a 67gr prostate. He said 10%. The point being it's a consideration, but I don't know the parameters. I was surprised it was considering I was a G 3 +4. My take away was time makes a higher risk of untreated lower risk cancers.

Posts.Title: PSA testing change 2017

Posts.Content: The 4+3 is not slow growing and you have a significant amount of it. Be careful to not collapse your facts, i.e. PC is slow growing, into all the facts. The majority of prostate cancer is slow growing. The majority of PC is 3+3 and 3+4. You have 4+3. It is not slow growing and it is not like 3+4. Because of your young age surgery now and radiation later is the most common path. Best case scenario is surgery does the trick, but with 4 +3 recurrence is more of a concern. Let's say your recurrence happens in 10 years. You then treat with radiation at 64. If it comes back in another 10 years you have hormones at 74 and that gets you what it gets you. Short story, surgery first buys you a longer treatment game. As a youg person, my view is to treat this as a chronic disease you manage such as diabetes. PC "cures" mostly are windows of time. Radiation leaves the prostate in place. Generally not a problem for an older person who will die of something else before the prostate regenerates the cancer that was irradicated by the radiation, if it was a slow growing type, i.e. 3s or 3+4s. If a higher grade it can regenerate sooner. With a successful surgery only minute amounts of prostate remain to continue to harbor or generate cancer. Again if you are producing 3s and 3+4s not a big problem, but if you are producing 4s and up it moves quicker. This scenario is more managable with follow up radiation and/or hormone therapy. Worst case scenario is that of a good friend of mine with 4+3 and 57. Surgery missed a significant portion. The suspicion is they were to go wide on the right and went wide on the left instead. Follow up radiation was not very effective, and he is now looking at hormone therapy from this point forward. All side effects are present. Not a happy camper. So, best advice imo, don't dally with primary G4, start with surgery, and most important find a competent team.

Posts.Title: Trial: identifying clinically significant lesions in Low Risk Ca pts.

Posts.Content: My choice was surgery to remove as much of the source of the cancer as possible and to determine as complete a pathology of the cancer as possible. Then radiation to follow. Since both surgery and radiation are effective in different ways I wanted the most effective benefits of both. Fortunately my age, physical and mental fitness, diagnosis, and resources were suited for this approach. I am playing the game with one goal, to die of something else. Knowing that achieving a goal is most successful when separated into smaller incremental goals I do not expect this to happen in one event, but a series of smaller consecutive events until the day I pass of something else. In support of Jim's very important note regarding test limitations, it is not certain your cancer is confined to your prostate, and your scans are clear of detectable levels of cancer. The scans are not certain either. You have Gleason 4 cancer and your PSA is over 10. Those facts are more certain. As a technical writer you can understand the temptations that exist in the use of language, and how we step over the details to hear what we want. This also applies to the temptation to over think an issue to avoid the obvious and unpleasant realities. It explains your lengthy post and conclusion to pursue a treatment that is very much less used than others raising the very obvious question why? And in your signature, May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy. Not certain how that can be guaranteed. In the same reference to use of language, referring to Gleason grading as a flip of the coin is dangerous thinking. It is a professional assessment made by experienced doctors of pathology using a scoring system many decades in the making. They may differ slightly, but rarely are mistakes made and it is not a random selection. You may seek a second opinion of your Gleason score. Also, your rise in PSA did not come out of the blue. A 3.9 was a serious warning flag yet you allowed 2 years to pass before checking it again, and may even have ignored a recommendation to consider a biopsy then. All of this is not to beat you up or point out what you did wrong. It is to warn you how we use language to mislead ourselves and justify who, what, and where we are in our lives. My advice, get clear in your language and get out of your head. For most of us, this disease becomes an opportunity to clear our heads and learn again how to focus on what is real and important. It shows up first in our language.

Hmmmm (fortunately, I do most of the other dietary things Another suggested) I have found maintaining my D3 level with the appropriate support of calcium and a few other vitamins and minerals that work in conjunction with D3 for bone health over time has improved my joint issues. It is generally accepted older Americans, for whatever reason and there are suspicions why, are showing up deficient in D3. A few years ago my internist recommended a 2,000 unit daily supplement as standard. I consider it main stream for the moment. We will see.

Posts.Title: How do you prevent cancer from returning, vitamins?

Posts.Content: Not that I am aware. You can have a diet including supplements and exercise that improves your overall health and is designed specifically for older men. Some of the things that I do and watch are; Maintain BMI 19-24 (Very hard to do if you don't change your diet/life style) Exercise 80mg of chewable aspirin every other day General multivitamin D3 and monitor your levels (recommend min 2000 units daily, I take 4000, it is very individual therefore the D3 testing) Calcium, K2, and magnesium to support D3 Olive oil as #1 oil in diet. Use liberally Avoid or moderate use of vegetable oils, again use olive oil Make your own salad dressing oil, vinegar, and spices/herbs in the bowl with the salad. Avoid manufactured dressings. No palm oil and hydrogenated oil/spread products Less red meat (once a week) More Omega 3 fatty acids in diet (not supplements), i.e. salmon, sardines, etc. Less refined sugar and carbohydrate products and sugary drinks/juices including fruit juice Use honey as a sweetner No artificial sweeteners A colorful vegetables diet beans onions Fruit Green tea (I have 1 cup a day and take mine w/ginger, lemon, & honey) Moderate nuts and seeds Moderate alcohol Less all things dairy Some of the spices/herbs are considered beneficial and anti-inflammatory, i.e. garlic, ginger, turmeric (Curcumin), black & cayenne pepper, oregano. A Mediterranean or Asian diet Fermented foods for colon health including kimchi, kefir, all cultured after/if pasteurized Make your own hummus. Stupid easy. Eat it with fresh vegetables not chips/pita. Chew your food and eat slowly, drink water moderately with your food as you eat. (not cold water) Never eat from the container. Take a portion and step away to eat it. No smoking/vaping Actual fresh food as the source of the above is better than supplements. Sometimes fresh frozen maintains more nutrients to market than "fresh" vegetables/fruit picked green and time spent getting to market. Home made smoothies are a good way to maintain calories while upping fresh nutrient value. What I have noticed as I age is my body is more efficient with my calories, or I am less active, and as we age our digestive systems become less effective processing some nutrients. Regardless, I eat less and can not waste precious calories on foods that don't contribute to my nutrient needs. This is where supplements come in. For me, they become a necessary component in maintaining nutrient content levels in low calorie/volume diets. The sugar feeds cancer is a myth. What sugar does is shortcut the body into consuming it for energy in lieu of consuming/processing more complex foods thereby missing their nutrients. Sugars, corn syrups, and other naturally sourced processed sweeteners have been stripped of their nutrient content while maintaining high caloric content. Be careful embracing supplement regimens for cancer. They are generally untested with unknown side effects. My example is I used chondroitin for joint health only to discover it was found in the removed prostates of men with cancer and is highly recommended to be avoided. http://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supp...y/hrb-20058926 "Chondroitin may promote spread or recurrence of prostate cancer." Source supplements carefully. Many studies exist that reveal supplements do not match their label often with additional unknown compounds. They are an unregulated industry, financially lucrative, highly promoted, and market driven by wishful thinking looking for better health without the work and discipline to make life style changes. It would not surprise me to discover supplement manufacturers/online retailers use trolls on sites like these to promote the latest supplement regimen for something.

Posts.Title: How do you prevent cancer from returning, vitamins?

Posts.Content: I assume prostate cells regenerate the gland by dividing. Enlarging prostate is caused by older cells not dying in a normal cell life time period. Something shifts and they live longer, and the gland begins to enlarge. To me, that alone is a precursor of a shifting dna similar to cancer if not cancer, i.e. precancerous activity. I assume a "healthy" cell produces a cancerous one i.e. G3, 4, 5, etc. Does a cell produce just 3s, or 3s and sometimes 4s. Or, does the way a cell shifts to producing cancer cells remain static? A specific "healthy" cell will only produce 3s. It seems most common they will produce relatively close to a specific aggressiveness, i.e. 3s & 4s, or 4s & 5s, 8s & 9s, etc. In this scenario I can see how one specific gland may have a set pattern of aggressiveness. Now, are they points on a line, i.e. some 3s are more aggressive than other 3s? I suspect so leading to some 3s become volume problems while others do not. 2s are never a problem. 3s may be or not depending on their aggressiveness within the range of 3. 4s and up are always a problem regardless of amount. "Healthy" cells if producing 4s will continue to produce 4s. Do they produce them at a consistent rate across the gland? Will 4s always represent 5% of a specific glands tumor production? Even if this is the case, 4s now have a life of their own and they prefer to live it elsewhere in the body. Time is a factor so now the reference to doubling time. At some point, depending on your age and the nature of that 4, it will overwelhm the 3s and the effective outcome of metastasis will be 4s galore. Is time the only distinction between 3+4 and 4+3?

AgeInfo.Phrase: aggressiveness  i e  3s & 4s  or 4s & 5s  8s

Posts.Title: What am I missing?

Posts.Content: Welcome! Include the prostate size at the time of the biopsy in your signature. This impacts the effectiveness of the biopsy among other things. If you do not have the information that is being asked for here then get an actual copy of the biopsy report. Many health systems have online patient portals where reports are listed. If not, call the doctor's office and get it. Start a digital and paper file of all lab tests and pathology reports inclduing your PSA. The signature information is important mostly for you. It helps us respond, but more importantly it lists the salient facts for you. We can lost in our heads with all this stuff. It is a clear and concise reminder over time of what you do know. It's a layman's chart.

Posts.Title: please welcome me to the club

Posts.Content: Those are all good signs. It took a year for me and is still improving two years later. Nerve tissue is much slower to heal than other tissue. Even when spared the nerves are traumatized by the procedure. The specific nerves affected are the ones that operate the valves that hold/trap the blood in the penis during erection. Standing helps gravity keep the blood in the penis as you "exercise." Sustaining the erection will come last, so to speak. In the meantime, learning to orgasm with a less than fully erect penis takes some practise. We are conditioned that one precedes the other. This is more of a mental exercise. The nerves that facilitate the orgasm itself are unaffected by the procedure. Patience is the word. Experiment with the ED drugs. Cialis was more effective than Viagra for me. Still, they only increase blood flow. They do not stimulate the nerves that hold the erection in place. Blood flow does aid the healing of those nerves. What once was automatic fun now seems like work. Toss in uncertainty and anxiety shows up to ruin the party. This is an inconvenience for the two of you. For now, make lemonade. Together you will experience a different view of intimacy. For him, it now becomes about you.

Posts.Content: Not that I am aware. You can have a diet including supplements and exercise that improves your overall health and is designed specifically for older men. Some of the things that I do and watch are; Maintain BMI 19-24 (Very hard to do if you don't change your diet/life style) Exercise 80mg of chewable aspirin every other day General multivitamin D3 and monitor your levels (recommend min 2000 units daily, I take 4000, it is very individual therefore the D3 testing) Calcium, K2, and magnesium to support D3 Olive oil as #1 oil in diet. Use liberally Avoid or moderate use of vegetable oils, again use olive oil Make your own salad dressing oil, vinegar, and spices/herbs in the bowl with the salad. Avoid manufactured dressings. No palm oil and hydrogenated oil/spread products Less red meat (once a week) More Omega 3 fatty acids in diet (not supplements), i.e. salmon, sardines, etc. Less refined sugar and carbohydrate products and sugary drinks/juices including fruit juice Use honey as a sweetner No artificial sweeteners A colorful vegetables diet beans onions Fruit Green tea (I have 1 cup a day and take mine w/ginger, lemon, & honey) Moderate nuts and seeds Moderate alcohol Less all things dairy Some of the spices/herbs are considered beneficial and anti-inflammatory, i.e. garlic, ginger, turmeric (Curcumin), black & cayenne pepper, oregano. A Mediterranean or Asian diet Fermented foods for colon health including kimchi, kefir, all cultured after/if pasteurized Make your own hummus. Stupid easy. Eat it with fresh vegetables not chips/pita. Chew your food and eat slowly, drink water moderately with your food as you eat. (not cold water) Never eat from the container. Take a portion and step away to eat it. No smoking/vaping Actual fresh food as the source of the above is better than supplements. Sometimes fresh frozen maintains more nutrients to market than "fresh" vegetables/fruit picked green and time spent getting to market. Home made smoothies are a good way to maintain calories while upping fresh nutrient value. What I have noticed as I age is my body is more efficient with my calories, or I am less active, and as we age our digestive systems become less effective processing some nutrients. Regardless, I eat less and can not waste precious calories on foods that don't contribute to my nutrient needs. This is where supplements come in. For me, they become a necessary component in maintaining nutrient content levels in low calorie/volume diets. The sugar feeds cancer is a myth. What sugar does is shortcut the body into consuming it for energy in lieu of consuming/processing more complex foods thereby missing their nutrients. Sugars, corn syrups, and other naturally sourced processed sweeteners have been stripped of their nutrient content while maintaining high caloric content. Be careful embracing supplement regimens for cancer. They are generally untested with unknown side effects. My example is I used chondroitin for joint health only to discover it was found in the removed prostates of men with cancer and is highly recommended to be avoided. http://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supp...y/hrb-20058926 "Chondroitin may promote spread or recurrence of prostate cancer." Source supplements carefully. Many studies exist that reveal supplements do not match their label often with additional unknown compounds. They are an unregulated industry, financially lucrative, highly promoted, and market driven by wishful thinking looking for better health without the work and discipline to make life style changes. It would not surprise me to discover supplement manufacturers/online retailers use trolls on sites like these to promote the latest supplement regimen for something.

Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: I'll take issue with the garden variety description. Your father has a high volume of cancer of an aggressive type. Treatment will be the recommendation. Scans are an indicator of the seriouness. They will show if detectable levels of cancer have metastized. There are limits to the sensitivity of these tests. Clear scans are a good thing, but not certainty the cancer has not begun to spread below the levels of the test. You can not assume clear scans mean confined to the prostate. Regardless, it is a good thing to have discovered it, and many options are available for treatment, and a long life is possible. Stay on top of it, be positive, and be prepared to accept it. He will be living with it as a concern from now on. PNI is what this cancer does. It has not proven to be an indicator of much, except it is cancer, so don't dwell on it. Prostate cancer will follow the nerve pathways out of the gland. That is PNI. It is present most of the time when cancer is present.
Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed with PC & trying to understand labs

Posts.Content: The volume and high Gleason at the base (part of prostate towards your head) increases risk of seminal vesicle invasion and metastatic cancer. You may consider body scans before deciding on treatment.
Posts.Title: Dad has been diagnosed with prostate cancer - can use some help

Posts.Content: Track your PSA history. Regardless of spiking if it has a steadily rising baseline it bears attention. Your PSA is high regardless of its pattern. Your prostate is twice normal size. This is not moderate, imo, and causes a concern about the experience of who is reading it. Pheripheral zone cancer is difficult to biopsy. A fusion guided biopsy is next. Using MRIs for PC is new business and skill/interpretation/experience can vary. Stay on top of this and do not hang your hat on just one fact such as this MRI reading. All signs indicate cancer at a very young age which is an aspect of aggressive cancer, imo. Completing your signature is essential to filling in the blanks for you. There is more history here than you have shared to direct you.
Posts.Title: MRI Results-- please advise

Posts.Content: I have discontinued the needle injections. I've done approximately 6 injections and there is a lot of discomfort and it is increasing. Some is due, I think, to the mix which I could change, but more importantly I have developed some Peyronie's. I am encouraged by my progress altogether, but it is slow. I expect a year. I am going to go back to the Cialis therapy and give it another try. I was having much more success with it than Viagra. There may have been another reason for my lower back/pelvis pain and some have suggested I switch to Levitra which I will do if the Cialis continues to cause the lower back/pelvis pain. I did just recently wake with what I will call a Balsa woody. It is encouraging because it is spontaneous. I also masturbate 3 times a week massaging blood into the penis to keep it flushed. The pump may be my next move. I am getting enough improvement to believe it will recover if I keep it active. Nerve tissue is slower to recover than other tissue and it was certainly traumatized.

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Your age and the volume of cancer you have indicates eventual treatment. The question then is what type treatment and when. You're still a candidate for surgery, but that window narrows as cancer volume expands and age increases. Surgery sooner than later is best for surgery outcomes. If you choose radiation you may want to meet with a radiation team to assess your options for eventual treatment. Then you will have completed the AS game plan which includes a plan for future treatment. AS doesn't put everything on hold. Regarding your language, you may think you are a good candidate for AS, but the medical community does not agree. So be clear in that. Your plan is more watchful waiting or let's wait 6 months and see what happens. Not that there is anything wrong with this. I make this distinction becasue AS is a very succesful program that many will be tempted to coop as cover for non treatment, indecision, or simply waiting. This calculation also includes a best guess at your normal life expectancy usually based on family history. In the end, a biopsy is a crude and incomplete diagnostic tool. Part of your calculation includes acceptance you only have a piece of the picture. Bottom line, most medical professionals will disagree with your choice. The peculiar state of the prostate conversation today means most will not push back hard on whatever you decide. They state their view and move on. What did your doctor recommend?

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Pathology reports are not 100%. They may choose to use time and cost saving methods and take a sampling of slices based on their observation of the gland and judgment. Interestingly, their observation of the margins is over 90% accurate. Or, one doctor's 6 is another's 3+4. That being said I am not yet convinced than Gleason 6 can not survive alone. It may not be fatal but that is a whole other calculus. It may be internet creep, i.e. Gleason 6 rarely metastasizes talk turns in to it can't survive outside the prostate. It may survive and grow slowly, but still not metastasize. It seems there is a lot we still don't know.

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: What is your life expectancy? I put mine at between 85 and 90 on thelie side. Of course, you can die anytime, but some things are obvious; family history, fitness habits, and your personal commitment to your health. There are life expectancy calculators on line. Most insurance companies provide them. They seem remarkably accurate. They are the masters of actuarials. They put mine at 86. It seems accurate, if conservative. You can play with the differences of weight, exercise, drinking and smoking. They do not go into family history or mental health. I've had several parents and grandparent live into their 90s so there is that. Assess your mental health. Depression, even if not chronic, can be a factor in your thinking and can impact your view of your healthcare. Your PSA history indicates a reluctance to deal with healthcare issues effectively. Early detection early treatment is the mantra for prostate cancer, or any cancer. PC seems to have gotten a dangerous reputation as being non life threatening. You now know differently, or do you? If you do nothing, it is unlikely you will die of something else as most men are eager to quote (if not believe). Research death from prostate cancer. It can happen as quickly as 3 to 5 years. Research PC lymphatic invasion as the adverse condition you are confronting. PC can be successfully managed for a long time in many cases. You don't know if you don't try. We have plenty of history and diagnostic tools to help, but it is clear we can't predict how it is going to go for any one person. In fairness to you it's also a question for your doctors; what will happen if I do nothing? And, it is a very good question we all ask ourselves. If more men asked it and got it answered for themselves in a timely manner (sooner) we'd have less of them here. There may come a time for all of us when we are confronted with a treatment option worse than death. Imo, this isn't it for you unless you are dying of something else in the next 5 years you haven't shared with us. I may be wrong, but it seems you hesitated once before with this disease and here you are. Do it again and you may not have this second chance a third time.
