Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: I have a question. Radiation is suppose to kill the cancer cells, because they are by nature weaker cells, and spare the healthy cells. What stops the radiate prostate from continuing to produce cancer cells? For me, I lost confidence in my prostate to play nice and wanted it removed to halt any further mischief such as future BHP or the remaining cells producing more cancer cells. It is my understanding radiation does not "kill" the prostate. It only "kills" the cancerous prostate cells at the time of the treatment. The prostate is left alive and "well" to continue to do what it has already proven itself to do which is continue to produce both healthy and cancerous prostate cells in the future. In the poster's case, it has proven itself to produce a more aggressive type of cancer cell at an early age. The radiation has no way of determining which healthy cells will eventually be triggered to start producing cancerous cells. Radiation leaves behind a difficult if not impossible mess of damaged tissue to try to clean up 25 years from now. Future radiation is not a useful option making matters worse for all the surrounding tissue/organs, and surgeons do not like operating in or around radiation damaged sites because the radiated tissue is no longer normal healthy tissue. Most prostate cancer is slow growing and begins later in life and most men outlive it. Not so in a younger man with more aggressive cancer. The term "cure" in prostate cancer does not mean what we first think it means, i.e. permanent. The word is used in the context of time, 5 years, 10 years, 15 years and does not apply well to the younger man or aggressive cancer. For me, its a kick the can down the road game and at the moment there are only 3 kicks I have at it; surgery, radiation, and hormone therapy. Time is the variable to determine how many kicks I'll need. A younger man with aggressive cancer may need all three and more. An old man may need none. Everyone else falls somewhere between.

Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: That's a trend, and 0.03 is now considered the best level for salvage radiation. Others will weigh in here, but from what I read you want to be talking to the radiology and oncology doctors and no longer rely on your urologist who's primary skill was the surgery. Sooner rather than later. Old news was salvage radiation at 0.1. The caveat is that continence and erection improvement stop with the onset of radiation. What you have when radiation starts is generally the best it will get. A case can be made for holding off on radiation to allow healing to improve the other conditions. This is a conversation to be having now with the radiologist so you are informed in your choices.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fishinguy I had a surgeon with well over 3500 surgery's, he did two per day, occasionally more. When talking to the people prepping me they saw my previous appendix scars and commented about scar tissue. I asked if that would be an issue, they said they didn't think so but that the surgeon was extremely particular how equipment was placed into me, and the angle of every piece. That told me two things, 1) he had a team he's worked with very often and they knew what he expected and 2) muscle memory must be very important to him and how he moves those instruments. I've had wonderful results from my surgery. Agreed. My surgeon valued his team above everything else. I had my choice of hospital locations. I asked his preference and he chose a location I would have avoided. His reason, the team was far superior. When I met them I concurred : ) The team head nurse had done more than twice the procedures than my surgeon.

Posts.Title: Need advice

Posts.Content: A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. Studies have shown that some who experience sepsis after biopsy also had antibiotic treatment for elevated PSA. Your age, PSA, symptoms, and negative urine culture are evidence enough to test for cancer and not treat for a bacterial infection. Studies also show there will be a chance of a slight decrease in your PSA as a result of the antibiotics in the presence of cancer that some will use as a reason to postpone a biopsy. There is a belief, which I consider now to be outdated and verging on harmful myth, that prostate cancer is slow growing and you will not die from it and it leads some to take a casual approach to it's symptoms and diagnoses. I did. There is some truth in it, but many will tell you that during the diagnoses is not the time to take the possibility lightly. That truth only applies when there is some evidence that supports it, such as a biopsy grading it as non aggressive. Living with prostate cancer is no cake walk even if it doesn't kill you! Your symptoms presenting at a young age increase the possibility of it being a more aggressive form of the cancer. Regarding your question about late stages, probably not, but it is not a relevant question (not a bad question). Prostate cancer has high probability of a "cure" when detected early. There are some grades that are relatively indolent and hang around growing slowly. Other's are more aggressive and head out into the body quickly. All of them benefit from early diagnosis, and will be something you treat and manage the rest of your life.

Posts.Title: Odds of PCa on elevated PSAs

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear this news. You've found a good source that is served by many experienced men with this disease. I am relatively new to this. This is what I can share. You are very fortunate to have discovered this. Your age, the amount of cancer and it's locations are serious indicators of something you may want to consider treating aggressively. Your age indicates this may be more aggressive than the Gleason scores you have available suggest. You can get a second opinion on the grading. There is also a chance they can be upgraded when examined after surgery. That happened in my case. I believe your doctor's are giving you very good advice. I am very impressed with an oncologist recommending surgery. It points to the seriousness of your situation, that it is still possible to play for a cure keeping the possibility of radiation as your second line of defense. Open vs Robotics debate is unclear to me. My understanding is outcomes at this point rely entirely on the skill of the surgeon. Robotics has a greater learning curve and cost, but ultimately may win out due to the ability of the surgeon to see under magnification what he is doing. Cyberknife is for low and intermediate risk cancers. While it is tempting to look at your Gleason scores and make a case for it I am more concerned with your age and that you have a prostate that has begun producing cancer that with time may not be so friendly. MRI is quickly becoming a more reliable diagnostic tool than TRUS and PI-RADS 4 indicates the possibility of a high risk of significant cancer. Again, more valuable information than the Gleason score at this point. (I assume these samples were from a random biopsy.) You want to play this game for a cure or long life. Erections are third on the list after your life and continence and not worth risking your life, imo. I am curious how you discovered this so early without symptoms or family history. It is unusual to be testing PSA so early. You are very lucky! Do not squander what you have been given by trying to finesse this disease. It's an underestimation of it's seriousness that I see happen too much, imo. It's a beast that can be beat if diagnosed early. You've got that part covered.

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: During surgery the prostate has to be separated from all the surrounding tissue. It doesn't just hang in space. After surgery, the removed prostate is examined. If cancer cells are found within a specific measurement of millimeters (don't recall the exact number) from the edge of the specimen it can statistically be assumed there is a chance there is cancer on the otherside of the cut and therefore left behind. A supporting fact is cancer cells tend to be stickier than healthy cells. They can cling to healthier tissue making it difficult to cleanly separate them. I have heard it described here by someone quoting a doctor, it is like peeling a hard boiled egg. Sometimes it peels off easily and sometimes it clings and tears. Back to the original question. You can't know for sure if cancer is left behind, but if cancer is found measured within a small specific distance to the specimen/knife cut edge there is a statistical significant chance some was left behind.

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 I had a biopsy in 2014. 1 core positive <<5% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 Active Surveillance Second biopsy 2017. 4 cores positive < 30% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 So does that mean I'm safe? Seems to me, all currently available treatments are from the caveman era. It's pretty disappointing. And then it seems you have to do a coin flip to choose the doctor that you want to mutilate or burn you. How sick is that. Sorry to be so frank in my opinion. I'm ready to deal with the after effects so I'll be flipping the coin soon. Time to move on to the rest of my life. I'm realizing that I have to develop a sense of humor to trudge through this mess to get to the GOOD SIDE. I guess comedy and tragedy really are two heads of the same coin. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for Gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67 Safe? Or you serious? You have confirmation of prostate cancer. It is now your responsibility to manage it. If ignored it can kill you. If managed you can live a long life and die of something else. Your choice.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Cancer Upgrade Question

Posts.Content: 49% - 65% that it is cancer. Do not wait. Get a biopsy. 3T-MRI guided if you can. The odds that it is BHP or prostatitis are less, 5% - 19%. Urinary symptoms are the big yellow flag, PSA is the big red flag. Complete your history for us. Pay close attention to how seriously the urologist advocates for a diagnosis. http://www.mayomedicallaboratories.c...rpretive/81944 "Higher total PSA levels and lower percentages of free PSA are associated with higher risks of prostate cancer." Check the charts in the article. Like baseball this is totally a percentages game. You never really know. You only know the odds.

Posts.Title: Odds of PCa on elevated PSAs

Posts.Content: A note about the antibiotic drill for elevated PSA. Imo, it is bad medicine. The over use of antibiotics for elevated PSA, particularly short term, is a serious issue that can later result in complications during the biopsy and surgery. Studies have shown that some who experience sepsis after biopsy also had antibiotic treatment for elevated PSA. Your age, PSA, symptoms, and negative urine culture are evidence enough to test for cancer and not treat for a bacterial infection. Studies also show there will be a chance of a slight decrease in your PSA as a result of the antibiotics in the presence of cancer that some will use as a reason to postpone a biopsy. There is a belief, which I consider now to be outdated and verging on harmful myth, that prostate cancer is slow growing and you will not die from it and it leads some to take a casual approach to it's symptoms and diagnoses. I did. There is some truth in it, but many will tell you that during the diagnoses is not the time to take the possibility lightly. That truth only applies when there is some evidence that supports it, such as a biopsy grading it as non aggressive. Living with prostate cancer is no cake walk even if it doesn't kill you! Your symptoms presenting at a young age increase the possibility of it being a more aggressive form of the cancer. Regarding your question about late stages, probably not, but it is not a relevant question (not a bad question). Prostate cancer has high probability of a "cure" when detected early. There are some grades that are relatively indolent and hang around growing slowly. Other's are more aggressive and head out into the body quickly. All of them benefit from early diagnosis, and will be something you treat and manage the rest of your life.

Posts.Title: New Math?

Posts.Content: Surgery is a typical treatment recommendation for young men. Recovery is easier, side effects recover quicker, and it gives you a longer treatment game plan with radiation, and hormone therapy should you need them later down the road. If you start with radiation surgery is off the table. Cures are measured with time, 5 years, 10 years, etc. As a young man, you are more interested in a longer game plan. You may be a candidate for AS. It requires diligent ongoing testing and monitoring. The key is active. Sometimes you can avoid treatment or kick it down the road a bit. Because of your young age you will be dealing with this for a longer time. Recurrence is the concern, and what to do if and when. Also, because it is presenting at such a young age there may be more aggressive cancer in there not hit by the biopsy, or it may develop with time.

Posts.Content: I would not play chicken with it. If you want to consider AS get a second opinion on the scoring. I chose treatment of G6 based solely on volume. There was too much of it. Turned out to be G7. If it's not acting benign it probably isn't. Your PSA and prostate size are both suspiciously low for your age, volume and grading of cancer. Rather than being a positive consideration it is now a concern. I do not see a path for you to AS. You do not fit a specific profile you can trust, imo. Then there's the doctor's recommendation. It begs the question why the MRI and biopsy with such a low PSA. Which beings us back to something being uncertain. What is your life expectancy currently? It is a valid question now if you are considering non-treatment and have other morbidities. There is enough information to recommend treatment. There is not enough to recommend AS. I end up back at a second opinion on the scoring if you are not inclined to treat. Something is different here for you and that is never a good sign with cancer.

Posts.Title: HELP!!! PLZ 38 year old with high PSA

Posts.Content: Supplements are a common addiction and part of the denial process. An ongoing healthy diet with regular exercise is work. It promotes general health and strength. Supplements are easy. You buy them and consume them with little effort. Get your BMI between 19 and 25. Reducing body fat takes work and discipline to transform your life habits. Taking supplements does little to nothing to transform your habits or improve health. One example, drinking a high sugar processed fruit juice such as pomegranite juice substitues processed sugar and damaged/empty micro-nutrients for real food. Mega dosing on herbs and vitamins can only stress your liver and kidneys and irtitate your bladder and urethra. It's never too late to begin a healthy diet and exercise regime. It will develop strength. It will not directly cure cancer. Your heightened state of renewed commitment to your health is a good thing. Looking for quick fixes is a warning flag of old behaviors. You know what a healthy life style is. You've known it all your life. Yet here you are. Relax and go about the business of transforming your diet and sedentary life style. Reduce your weight. Stop alcohol. Reduce caffeine. Drink water and tea. Exercise. Reduce red meats. Increase fresh vegetables. Increase olive oil. Eliminate processed foods, fats, dressings. You know the drill. Spend time buying fresh foods, preparing them, and eating them. Learn to eat what's in season. Do not, I repeat, do not focus on reducing your PSA. Your PSA is your friend. Reduce your BMI. I just got back from Italy, you know what? They are thin!

Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: The operative word is salvage followed with extreme caution. I suspect this is a procedure for those who chose radiation for an organ confined cancer and it was incomplete, and this surgery was developed to address a very difficult and limited condition and is not meant as a preferred order of treatment. Patient selection for this procedure is critical. Kudos to them for developing a technically challenging procedure most find to daunting to attempt and do not recommend. I do not see it as standard protocal equivalent to the current standard of SRT after RP, but some consider it a rapidly growing occurrence. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25765848 https://www.karger.com/Article/FullText/371893 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10910157 (Department of Urology, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York) https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/t...lvage-surgery/ Pretty high side effect numbers including rectal injury. "The greatest risk is that it may have to be converted to a radical cystoprostatectomy (removal of the prostate and the bladder). This procedure is necessary in as many as 20 percent of patients who decide on salvage surgery, and, in addition to the additional trauma, it is associated with less good long-term outcomes. "
Posts.Title: Salvage Radical Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: The 4+3 is not slow growing and you have a significant amount of it. Be careful to not collapse your facts, i.e. PC is slow growing, into all the facts. The majority of prostate cancer is slow growing. The majority of PC is 3+3 and 3+4. You have 4+3. It is not slow growing and it is not like 3+4. Because of your young age surgery now and radiation later is the most common path. Best case scenario is surgery does the trick, but with 4 +3 recurrence is more of a concern. Let's say your recurrence happens in 10 years. You then treat with radiation at 64. If it comes back in another 10 years you have hormones at 74 and that gets you what it gets you. Short story, surgery first buys you a longer treatment game. As a youg person, my view is to treat this as a chronic disease you manage such as diabetes. PC "cures" mostly are windows of time. Radiation leaves the prostate in place. Generally not a problem for an older person who will die of something else before the prostate regenerates the cancer that was irradicated by the radiation, if it was a slow growing type, i.e. 3s or 3+4s. If a higher grade it can regenerate sooner. With a successful surgery only minute amounts of prostate remain to continue to harbor or generate cancer. Again if you are producing 3s and 3+4s not a big problem, but if you are producing 4s and up it moves quicker. This scenario is more managable with follow up radiation and/or hormone therapy. Worst case scenario is that of a good friend of mine with 4+3 and 57. Surgery missed a significant portion. The suspicion is they were to go wide on the right and went wide on the left instead. Follow up radiation was not very effective, and he is now looking at hormone therapy from this point forward. All side effects are present. Not a happy camper. So, best advice imo, don't dally with primary G4, start with surgery, and most important find a competent team.

AgeInfo.Phrase: then treat with radiation at 64 <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z>
years you have hormones at 74 and that gets you what

Posts.Title: New and trying to come up with a plan

Posts.Content: I am unaware of any diagnostic regime that can declare the cancer is confined to the prostate. This applies more as the grade of aggressiveness increases. There are no guarantees with this disease. I mention this not to disspell hope, but for two intents; a good doctor knows this, and it is a consideration in choosing treatment. Aggressive cancers are especially notorious for migrating out of the prostate early. Age, extent and grade of cancer, and physical health are all critical considerations in choosing radiation or surgery/radiation. Surgery is a younger man's game.

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Your age and the volume of cancer you have indicates eventual treatment. The question then is what type treatment and when. You're still a candidate for surgery, but that window narrows as cancer volume expands and age increases. Surgery sooner than later is best for surgery outcomes. If you choose radiation you may want to meet with a radiation team to assess your options for eventual treatment. Then you will have completed the AS game plan which includes a plan for future treatment. AS doesn't put everything on hold. Regarding your language, you may think you are a good candidate for AS, but the medical community does not agree. So be clear in that. Your plan is more watchful waiting or let's wait 6 months and see what happens. Not that there is anything wrong with this. I make this distinction becasue AS is a very succesful program that many will be tempted to coop as cover for non treatment, indecision, or simply waiting. This calculation also includes a best guess at your normal life expectancy usually based on family history. In the end, a biopsy is a crude and incomplete diagnostic tool. Part of your calculation includes acceptance you only have a piece of the picture. Bottom line, most medical professionals will disagree with your choice. The peculiar state of the prostate conversation today means most will not push back hard on whatever you decide. They state their view and move on. What did your doctor recommend?

Posts.Content: Track your PSA history. Regardless of spiking if it has a steadily rising baseline it bears attention. Your PSA is high regardless of its pattern. Your prostate is twice normal size. This is not moderate, imo, and causes a concern about the experience of who is reading it. Pheripheral zone cancer is difficult to biopsy. A fusion guided biopsy is next. Using MRIs for PC is new business and skill/interpretation/experience can vary. Stay on top of this and do not hang your hat on just one fact such as this MRI reading. All signs indicate cancer at a very young age which is an aspect of aggressive cancer, imo. Completing your signature is essential to filling in the blanks for you. There is more history here than you have shared to direct you.
Posts.Title: MRI Results-- please advise

Posts.Content: What I like about this study is they avoided speculating on cause. The results speak for themselves. When you let an outcome hang out there unexplained and undefended you allow the space for the impact on those who's bias is to immediately deny the cause you present. It is a very powerful way to make a point. Those who advocated for the reduction in screening are left to their own thoughts. It took a lot of discipline for the designers of this study to limit their study to just the results, but highly effective. Glad to see it. My girlfriend emailed this to me yesterday, and her conclusion was as obvious as it is to most except those who were responsible for the reduction in screening. It will take longer for them to adjust their thinking to the facts. It works to give them the space to be alone with the facts and their responsibility in it.

"The most vulnerable men are getting less counseling,"

Posts.Title: Husband died from cancer, Widow of Veteran in Need

Posts.Content: Your young age makes you a good candidate for surgery if you are physically fit. Surgery gives you the option of follow up radiation if necessary. It also gives you the pathology report of the removed prostate giving you good information about the extent for making choices moving forward. Creating an expected life expectancy is also helpful in making choices. For example, my grandparents and parents lived well into their 80s and 90s except those who passed from another cancer and common maladies associated with being overweight. At the moment, I expect to live into my late 80s. This helped me choose a treatment regime for a longer game, i.e. surgery first. Of course, the cancer had to cooperate and be reasonably treatable with surgery, i.e confined to the prostate and/or prostate bed.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband having first consult after DX

Posts.Content: I agree Highlander. Yet here is what the poster said, "At this point we have been told that it is all contained in the prostate." This may or may not be what the doctor said. If I knew this statement was certain, more so than a doctor's opinion, I would choose surgery assuming I was active and in excellent physical condition and expected to live well into my 80s or more. If there was a risk of long term incontinence as an outcome of a more aggressive surgery due to cancer beyond the capsule I would be investigating my radiation options. The highky aggressive nature makes this a more likely option. The all contained comment confuses it. What a good doctor can say is the scans do not detect cancer. Yet, they have detectable limits and highly aggressive cancers are difficult to predict. There are no guarantees. What I have found is some doctors begin to shorten their conversations over time leaving out details they consider nonessential to a treatment path they have already chosen for the patient. Imo, declaring a highly aggressive cancer in a man in his late 60s is confined to the prostate is a hopeful statement. Not that there is anything wrong with that as long as it is spoken in that way, ie the tests indicate a good posdibility the cancer is still local. I suspect the oncologist will not be so ready to declare the extent of the cancer while a surgeon can always correct himself with a post surgery/pathology report after the fact. Then the patient discovers the true nature of the disease and their options. I suspect most surgeons in most intermediate cases believe in the surgery radiation combo. Family history in this situation is also important and I am not just referring to prostate cancer history, but to longevity which is often genetic. How long do the males in the family naturally live? This has an important impact on the treatment choice. With such limited information (no history) indicating it was discovered recently, I believe hormone and radiation is a reasonable choice for an aggressive cancer. The comment "it is confined" indicates there is value in another opinion because I question a doctor who makes such a declaration.

AgeInfo.Phrase: a man in his late 60s is confined to the prostate

Posts.Title: Father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Get a copy of the report. Location is useful to know. Diagnosis of this disease comes in bits and pieces. You put them together to create a picture, or profile. Most medical institutions have patient portals to access results on line. Actively participate until a treatment plan is in place. I'd like to know the MRI report results.
Posts.Title: New Here, seeking guidance, father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: You're at a higher risk if you had antibiotics prescribed for you before. It can set you up for antibiotics resistant strains. Often doctor's will prescribe it for rising PSA to rule out infection as the source and it will often produce a drop in PSA. Eventually a biopsy is performed and it puts you at a slightly higher risk. Still good odds when you consider the alternative. Don't borrow trouble. I'd be more concerned by the potential side affects of Cipro which can be a long lasting risk after treatment has stopped.
Posts.Title: Infection timing after biopsy?

Posts.Content: Do not wait. A negative biopsy is not evidence it is nothing. For those who are vigilant a first time false negative is common. At your age, a steady rising PSA is very indicative of something going on and with no other symptoms it may not be BHP. BHP is an annoying condition you will most likely be aware of. PC is often silent until it's later in the game. Serious cancer's can present with low PSAs, and PC has many levels from indolent to highly aggressive and many act differently. You are now in the hunt for cancer until you find it or fortunate enough to never find it. This is not something you can walk away from with a negative biopsy. This is a vigilance that will last the rest of your life until your are too old to care. Kind of like breast cancer for women. Welcome to the club. Early detection is the key to beating this disease. It is a very treatable disease if you are vigilant and do not dismiss it or forget about it. The back pain is most likely something else, but keep it on your list. There are a lot of buts. Denial and delay are the two demons of cancer in any form. 2.5 to 3.0 PSA is the trigger point for young men to start taking it seriously, imo. You will find that on general med info sites, not just here. This is not, "Am I the 1 in 7 who gets prostate cancer?" and you can get past the screening phase if lucky. No, this is a different animal and in this regard is unlike breast cancer. 80% of all men will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. For practical purposes, it is statiscally inevitable. When it starts matters. It is also growing in the population and starting at earliar ages. No one knows the source ,but there are clues. It seems to be both genetic and evironmental. Here's the take away. Starting at your young age is a good indicator this is something you will have to deal with. Stay on top of it. Take time to accept it and don't let it off your radar screen. While it doesn't seem like it, you are fortunate to even be screening for it. I've been told only 17% of general practises screen for PSA. I'm not saying you have cancer. I'm saying you now have cancer awareness. Do you have a family history? There are also other risk factors such as weight and race. This is the best forum out there, imo. Take care of your health and you will live a full and happy life.

Posts.Content: There are three tests; 0.1, <0.02, and 0.001. The 0.001 is the ultrsensitive. They are all sensitive and accurate to their limit. There is no jiggle room within each test. The value in the ultrasensitive is the ability to establish a trend before 0.030. 0.03 is now considered the most effective threshold for salvage radiation. If you are using the <0.02 test you may not see it coming as soon.

Posts.Title: PSA increase follow up:

Posts.Content: AS has given the answer I believe you asked for. In addition, I want to emphasize along with my other brothers the array of test information that goes into a diagnosis; gender, age, family history, ethnicity, culture, DRE exam for tactile abnormalities and size (ultrsound), urinary and erectile symptoms, 3TMRI with a fusion biopsy, TURP, and the TRUS biopsy. There is another viewing scope procedure I can't recall. Pet and CT scans for the whole body. And time, tracking these that change with time and how. We have a plethora of puzzle pieces to use to build the picture of the disease. The ones that prove cancer are the ones that collect tissue samples. You can add a pathological inspection of a removed prostate. This is the most definitive of the type of cancer and it's location. All the others are statistically based in their value.
Posts.Title: Other PSA testing options - list needed

Posts.Content: It is my understand the DaVinci tool has an electric wire used to stimulate the nerve to reveal it's location. Ultimately, I suspect the laparoscopic procedure will be untethered from it's cable and operated wirelessly as a robotic device. It is the future.
Posts.Title: Dr. Bal Carter, at Johns Hopkins, retiring....

Posts.Content: Antibiotics and hormone therapy will alter you PSA, but neither or curative treatments. Despite a Gleason score of 6 which many consider a less agressive form of prostate cancer, your age indicates it's onset to be aggressive by nature and time will work against you. Many outlive prostate cancer and die of other age related illnesses, because in most forms Pc is slow growing. You no longer have this advantage. In my opinion, you are being mistreated. The use of antibiotics to treat prostate cancer is your first clue.

Posts.Title: Criteria for choosing Surgeon

Posts.Content: I was told 10 days by the doctor. It was scheduled by the office nurse at 12 days. I saw no problem with the 12, but wondered about it at the time. HOWEVER, I was one of those who developed bladder spasms near the end. VERY painful and uncomfortable. Those extra two day were not fun. As stated, there may be a medical reason discovered during the surgery for the extra time, but that should have been explained by the doctor post surgery. I've seen many posts sharing 7 days which seemed pretty quick to me considering the importance of a good heal on such a vital connection. I am not a doctor, but having had the experience I can see an increased risk of taking it longer than necessary. It impacts the bladder, healing, and recovery, and increases the risk of infection/irritation/accidents. I was always afraid I'd hook it on something. Even things we don't think of such as being in an automobile accident can cause complications. It's pretty important plumbing we are dealing with. Call the office, and get a reasonable explanation or other arrangements. When things happen different from what you are told by the doctor you have a responsibility to speak up. There can always be miscommunication or mistakes on their side. As an aside, I only strapped it on the leg when going out or to work. Most of the time I used the larger bag and carried it around and pretty much avoided going out except for work and my daughter's graduation. Don't strap it too tight. Loosen it when your just sitting around. My brother may have given himself a clot in his leg as a complication of keeping it too tight. Either way he developed a clot in that leg and had to go on blood thinners.

Posts.Title: Resuming TRT after RP with positive margin?

Posts.Content: Why are you being screened for prostate cancer at your very young age? Why was the MRI done before your biopsy? Why is the doctor recommending surgery? Are you in a higher risk ethnic group? MRIs can miss detecting both small low grade and small aggressive cancers. Biopsy can miss also and there is a risk of other more aggressive cancer being present and undetected. Your young age is a wild card. Your survival challenge is greater because your exposure is longer. A cancer that begins growing so soon will have a longer time to generate mischief regardless of it's aggressiveness. Volume alone can eventually impact quality of life causing all the symptoms of more aggressive cancers. In general, early detection and early treatment yields better results with this disease. You are a candidate for AS, but more diagnostic efforts are part of that protocol to monitor your cancer. "A" means active. Your PSA is high for your age and cancer type. A second opinion on the Gleason scoring is recommended, imo, as well as genetic testing. You are fortunate to have discovered this.

Posts.Content: A word of caution. High dosage of green tea supplement may cause liver and kidney damage. This may translate to high dosages of antioxidants of any kind being harmful to the liver and kidneys. "According to the National Institutes of Health, unregulated supplements now account for 20 percent of drug-related liver injuries. And it doesn't take too many pills to do damage, so Bonkovsky recommends completely avoiding supplements with green tea extract in them. If you have to take one, he says to limit it to no more than 500 milligrams (mg) catechins per day. This might be harder than it sounds, as some of the supplements the researchers tested had up to 700mg in one capsule and came with recommendations to take more several daily." Most supplement products are unregulated and many are produced in countries known to have troublesome manufacturing histories.

Posts.Title: Very Sensitive Urethra, Apparently

Posts.Content: I agree Highlander. Yet here is what the poster said, "At this point we have been told that it is all contained in the prostate." This may or may not be what the doctor said. If I knew this statement was certain, more so than a doctor's opinion, I would choose surgery assuming I was active and in excellent physical condition and expected to live well into my 80s or more. If there was a risk of long term incontinence as an outcome of a more aggressive surgery due to cancer beyond the capsule I would be investigating my radiation options. The highky aggressive nature makes this a more likely option. The all contained comment confuses it. What a good doctor can say is the scans do not detect cancer. Yet, they have detectable limits and highly aggressive cancers are difficult to predict. There are no guarantees. What I have found is some doctors begin to shorten their conversations over time leaving out details they consider nonessential to a treatment path they have already chosen for the patient. Imo, declaring a highly aggressive cancer in a man in his late 60s is confined to the prostate is a hopeful statement. Not that there is anything wrong with that as long as it is spoken in that way, ie the tests indicate a good posdibility the cancer is still local. I suspect the oncologist will not be so ready to declare the extent of the cancer while a surgeon can always correct himself with a post surgery/pathology report after the fact. Then the patient discovers the true nature of the disease and their options. I suspect most surgeons in most intermediate cases believe in the surgery radiation combo. Family history in this situation is also important and I am not just referring to prostate cancer history, but to longevity which is often genetic. How long do the males in the family naturally live? This has an important impact on the treatment choice. With such limited information (no history) indicating it was discovered recently, I believe hormone and radiation is a reasonable choice for an aggressive cancer. The comment "it is confined" indicates there is value in another opinion because I question a doctor who makes such a declaration.

AgeInfo.Phrase: a man in his late 60s is confined to the prostate

Posts.Title: Father recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: For me at the moment, it stands at 7. I wish I had acted at 5. It took an intervention by my GP to get me taking responsibility for my disease. June is my two year test. We will see. It never ends. Grateful to be dealing with the possibility of BCR as my concern now.

Posts.Title: 9-year survival differences: aggressive vs. conservative treatment for advanced PC

Posts.Content: Everything seems to be pointing in the direction of cancer developing. His age is the biggest concern. He is young for this to begin. I recommend treading very carefully with a BHP diagnosis or treatment when evidence indicates you may be tracking cancer. It may be present and often is in the presence of cancer. It will not kill you. Cancer will. Good news, early detection is the key and you are right on it.
Posts.Title: Is there a reputable on line prostate MRI second opinion site?

Posts.Content: Studies have shown that detection and treatment as early as .03 improves treatment outcomes. You need 3 decimals to see that coming in time. My health system uses .2 as the mark between undetectable and detectable. I do not agree with it. Remember, these are all moving targets as we develop a protoccol that works best for everyone. It's not noise for everyone.

Posts.Title: genome tested, lots of badness

Posts.Content: My choice was surgery to remove as much of the source of the cancer as possible and to determine as complete a pathology of the cancer as possible. Then radiation to follow. Since both surgery and radiation are effective in different ways I wanted the most effective benefits of both. Fortunately my age, physical and mental fitness, diagnosis, and resources were suited for this approach. I am playing the game with one goal, to die of something else. Knowing that achieving a goal is most successful when separated into smaller incremental goals I do not expect this to happen in one event, but a series of smaller consecutive events until the day I pass of something else. In support of Jim's very important note regarding test limitations, it is not certain your cancer is confined to your prostate, and your scans are clear of detectable levels of cancer. The scans are not certain either. You have Gleason 4 cancer and your PSA is over 10. Those facts are more certain. As a technical writer you can understand the temptations that exist in the use of language, and how we step over the details to hear what we want. This also applies to the temptation to over think an issue to avoid the obvious and unpleasant realities. It explains your lengthy post and conclusion to pursue a treatment that is very much less used than others raising the very obvious question why? And in your signature, May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy. Not certain how that can be guaranteed. In the same reference to use of language, referring to Gleason grading as a flip of the coin is dangerous thinking. It is a professional assessment made by experienced doctors of pathology using a scoring system many decades in the making. They may differ slightly, but rarely are mistakes made and it is not a random selection. You may seek a second opinion of your Gleason score. Also, your rise in PSA did not come out of the blue. A 3.9 was a serious warning flag yet you allowed 2 years to pass before checking it again, and may even have ignored a recommendation to consider a biopsy then. All of this is not to beat you up or point out what you did wrong. It is to warn you how we use language to mislead ourselves and justify who, what, and where we are in our lives. My advice, get clear in your language and get out of your head. For most of us, this disease becomes an opportunity to clear our heads and learn again how to focus on what is real and important. It shows up first in our language.

Posts.Title: Questions regarding Bowel movement after surgery

Posts.Content: Many want to make the choice between radiation and surgery a choice between the best treatment choice, i.e. one is a better choice than another. How I see it is they are different treatments. It's like asking what's a better way to travel; planes, trains, or automobiles? If it's very close you can walk. To far to walk you can drive. To far to drive you can fly. Each mode is more effective than another for a specific travel profile. Some are afraid to fly so they drive or take a bus. They all get you somewhere. They all work for what they are designed to do, and they are not universally interchangeable. They are different. Surgery and radiation each have a specific patient profile that makes them more effective for that profile than the other. I will not go so far as to say they are interchangable. One can be done in lieu of the other in lots of profiles. It doesn't mean it is better. There are clear patient profiles where the majority of professionals will agree on the mode of treatment. Then a clear profile where either will work with pros and cons. Then there are those profiles that exclude one treatment as not medically possible or recommended. There are multible biases; provider bias, patient bias, and confirmation bias. Provider bias: surgeons prefer surgery and radiologist prefer radiotherapy. Yet competent professionals will acknowledge when the patient's profile trumps their skill set and is better served by the other. Patient bias: each of us has a bias for surgery or radiation independent of what we know and our own profile. For example, going in I'd hope my profile matches up with surgery. That bias comes from thinking if it's small, unentangled, and can be cleanly removed - remove it. My bias is against radiation as toxic and crude and used when the line between healthy and diseased tissue can not be made with a scaple. Sounds very reasonable, but it is still a bias that tempts me to hear only those things about my profile supporting surgety. (Someone with a radiation bias can speak for that.) Confirmation bias: a patient chooses and then begins to listen for any and only evidence that supports his choice as the best choice. This is automatic and we all do it. The upside is we have a multitude of effective, tried, and proven treatment choices. The best advice is to stay out of the weeds and go main stream, imo. This is a little off topic, but it applies to how we misuse language. If you use the words right and wrong, better or worse, good or bad you are making a moral judgment. Those words are exclusive to moral language yet we collapse them into other judgment choices. The consideration is what will work and how effective will it be. We want to be right more than anything often times at the expense of what works.
Posts.Title: Rising PSA and decisions to make

Posts.Content: Monograms are useful. I used them to run what ifs, mostly to understand the nature of the beast. I found it to be reassuring the more I learned. I understand looking forward to the surgery. It's an aspect of taking care of business. It is a statistics game. You want to be realistic and practical. Collect the information, follow the trail, paint the picture with what you know, make best and worse case scenarios for the holes in the picture, and keep moving forward. Having an understanding of the risks and a plan for the what ifs allows you to get on with your life, imo.
Posts.Title: Accuracy of online Calculators

Posts.Content: Do not wait. A negative biopsy is not evidence it is nothing. For those who are vigilant a first time false negative is common. At your age, a steady rising PSA is very indicative of something going on and with no other symptoms it may not be BHP. BHP is an annoying condition you will most likely be aware of. PC is often silent until it's later in the game. Serious cancer's can present with low PSAs, and PC has many levels from indolent to highly aggressive and many act differently. You are now in the hunt for cancer until you find it or fortunate enough to never find it. This is not something you can walk away from with a negative biopsy. This is a vigilance that will last the rest of your life until your are too old to care. Kind of like breast cancer for women. Welcome to the club. Early detection is the key to beating this disease. It is a very treatable disease if you are vigilant and do not dismiss it or forget about it. The back pain is most likely something else, but keep it on your list. There are a lot of buts. Denial and delay are the two demons of cancer in any form. 2.5 to 3.0 PSA is the trigger point for young men to start taking it seriously, imo. You will find that on general med info sites, not just here. This is not, "Am I the 1 in 7 who gets prostate cancer?" and you can get past the screening phase if lucky. No, this is a different animal and in this regard is unlike breast cancer. 80% of all men will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. For practical purposes, it is statiscally inevitable. When it starts matters. It is also growing in the population and starting at earliar ages. No one knows the source ,but there are clues. It seems to be both genetic and evironmental. Here's the take away. Starting at your young age is a good indicator this is something you will have to deal with. Stay on top of it. Take time to accept it and don't let it off your radar screen. While it doesn't seem like it, you are fortunate to even be screening for it. I've been told only 17% of general practises screen for PSA. I'm not saying you have cancer. I'm saying you now have cancer awareness. Do you have a family history? There are also other risk factors such as weight and race. This is the best forum out there, imo. Take care of your health and you will live a full and happy life.

Posts.Title: Infection timing after biopsy?

Posts.Content: I assume prostate cells regenerate the gland by dividing. Enlarging prostate is caused by older cells not dying in a normal cell life time period. Something shifts and they live longer, and the gland begins to enlarge. To me, that alone is a precursor of a shifting dna similar to cancer if not cancer, i.e. precancerous activity. I assume a "healthy" cell produces a cancerous one i.e. G3, 4, 5, etc. Does a cell produce just 3s, or 3s and sometimes 4s. Or, does the way a cell shifts to producing cancer cells remain static? A specific "healthy" cell will only produce 3s. It seems most common they will produce relatively close to a specific aggressiveness, i.e. 3s & 4s, or 4s & 5s, 8s & 9s, etc. In this scenario I can see how one specific gland may have a set pattern of aggressiveness. Now, are they points on a line, i.e. some 3s are more aggressive than other 3s? I suspect so leading to some 3s become volume problems while others do not. 2s are never a problem. 3s may be or not depending on their aggressiveness within the range of 3. 4s and up are always a problem regardless of amount. "Healthy" cells if producing 4s will continue to produce 4s. Do they produce them at a consistent rate across the gland? Will 4s always represent 5% of a specific glands tumor production? Even if this is the case, 4s now have a life of their own and they prefer to live it elsewhere in the body. Time is a factor so now the reference to doubling time. At some point, depending on your age and the nature of that 4, it will overwelhm the 3s and the effective outcome of metastasis will be 4s galore. Is time the only distinction between 3+4 and 4+3?

AgeInfo.Phrase: aggressiveness  i e  3s & 4s  or 4s & 5s  8s

Posts.Title: What does your Gleason score actually mean?

Posts.Content: Why are you being screened for prostate cancer at your very young age? Why was the MRI done before your biopsy? Why is the doctor recommending surgery? Are you in a higher risk ethnic group? MRIs can miss detecting both small low grade and small aggressive cancers. Biopsy can miss also and there is a risk of other more aggressive cancer being present and undetected. Your young age is a wild card. Your survival challenge is greater because your exposure is longer. A cancer that begins growing so soon will have a longer time to generate mischief regardless of it's aggressiveness. Volume alone can eventually impact quality of life causing all the symptoms of more aggressive cancers. In general, early detection and early treatment yields better results with this disease. You are a candidate for AS, but more diagnostic efforts are part of that protocol to monitor your cancer. "A" means active. Your PSA is high for your age and cancer type. A second opinion on the Gleason scoring is recommended, imo, as well as genetic testing. You are fortunate to have discovered this.
Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: I was told 10 days by the doctor. It was scheduled by the office nurse at 12 days. I saw no problem with the 12, but wondered about it at the time. HOWEVER, I was one of those who developed bladder spasms near the end. VERY painful and uncomfortable. Those extra two day were not fun. As stated, there may be a medical reason discovered during the surgery for the extra time, but that should have been explained by the doctor post surgery. I've seen many posts sharing 7 days which seemed pretty quick to me considering the importance of a good heal on such a vital connection. I am not a doctor, but having had the experience I can see an increased risk of taking it longer than necessary. It impacts the bladder, healing, and recovery, and increases the risk of infection/irritation/accidents. I was always afraid I'd hook it on something. Even things we don't think of such as being in an automobile accident can cause complications. It's pretty important plumbing we are dealing with. Call the office, and get a reasonable explanation or other arrangements. When things happen different from what you are told by the doctor you have a responsibility to speak up. There can always be miscommunication or mistakes on their side. As an aside, I only strapped it on the leg when going out or to work. Most of the time I used the larger bag and carried it around and pretty much avoided going out except for work and my daughter's graduation. Don't strap it too tight. Loosen it when your just sitting around. My brother may have given himself a clot in his leg as a complication of keeping it too tight. Either way he developed a clot in that leg and had to go on blood thinners.

Posts.Title: Surgery at Hopkins - Post Surgical Interactions?

Posts.Content: Okay, I'll bite. How is a 3% probability of prostate cancer measured? For example, it is statistical proven measurement a PSA over 10% indicates more than a 60% probability of prostate cancer. More importantly, if cancer is to be identified at a stage when it is still curable it should be detected before the PSA rises much above 10. I know of no specific indicator of prostate cancer that measures at the sensitivity of a 3% probability except the probability every man meets this criteria. Every man has at least a 15% (may be higher now) probability of having prostate cancer and it rises with age. By the time you're 70 it is 80%.
Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: Thank you for sharing.
Posts.Title: Fairwind's Journey

Posts.Content: Do not wait. A negative biopsy is not evidence it is nothing. For those who are vigilant a first time false negative is common. At your age, a steady rising PSA is very indicative of something going on and with no other symptoms it may not be BHP. BHP is an annoying condition you will most likely be aware of. PC is often silent until it's later in the game. Serious cancer's can present with low PSAs, and PC has many levels from indolent to highly aggressive and many act differently. You are now in the hunt for cancer until you find it or fortunate enough to never find it. This is not something you can walk away from with a negative biopsy. This is a vigilance that will last the rest of your life until your are too old to care. Kind of like breast cancer for women. Welcome to the club. Early detection is the key to beating this disease. It is a very treatable disease if you are vigilant and do not dismiss it or forget about it. The back pain is most likely something else, but keep it on your list. There are a lot of buts. Denial and delay are the two demons of cancer in any form. 2.5 to 3.0 PSA is the trigger point for young men to start taking it seriously, imo. You will find that on general med info sites, not just here. This is not, "Am I the 1 in 7 who gets prostate cancer?" and you can get past the screening phase if lucky. No, this is a different animal and in this regard is unlike breast cancer. 80% of all men will have prostate cancer by the time they are 80. For practical purposes, it is statiscally inevitable. When it starts matters. It is also growing in the population and starting at earliar ages. No one knows the source ,but there are clues. It seems to be both genetic and evironmental. Here's the take away. Starting at your young age is a good indicator this is something you will have to deal with. Stay on top of it. Take time to accept it and don't let it off your radar screen. While it doesn't seem like it, you are fortunate to even be screening for it. I've been told only 17% of general practises screen for PSA. I'm not saying you have cancer. I'm saying you now have cancer awareness. Do you have a family history? There are also other risk factors such as weight and race. This is the best forum out there, imo. Take care of your health and you will live a full and happy life.

Posts.Title: Interesting how my GPs approach Prostate and other cancers

Posts.Content: That's a horse of a different color. A search reveals over 38% of the general population in the US will be diagnosed with a cancer at some time in their lives. These statistic are available for specific types of cancer as well and are available for the UK. Developing prostate cancer for men is 11.5% and dying of it is 1 in 41 or 2.45%. These numbers are increasing. An average age group, statiscally, to approach a rate of 3% is 25-49 which has a 3.8% rate. You must live in a very young community or a 3% rate may indicate a less than average rate of cancer screening. Your local healthcare group may be revealing a less than average rate of cancer screening rather than a high level of proactive care. Or, your community may be a statistical cancer healthy anomally.

Posts.Title: Two Quick Questions regarding PSA test

Posts.Content: Many want to make the choice between radiation and surgery a choice between the best treatment choice, i.e. one is a better choice than another. How I see it is they are different treatments. It's like asking what's a better way to travel; planes, trains, or automobiles? If it's very close you can walk. To far to walk you can drive. To far to drive you can fly. Each mode is more effective than another for a specific travel profile. Some are afraid to fly so they drive or take a bus. They all get you somewhere. They all work for what they are designed to do, and they are not universally interchangeable. They are different. Surgery and radiation each have a specific patient profile that makes them more effective for that profile than the other. I will not go so far as to say they are interchangable. One can be done in lieu of the other in lots of profiles. It doesn't mean it is better. There are clear patient profiles where the majority of professionals will agree on the mode of treatment. Then a clear profile where either will work with pros and cons. Then there are those profiles that exclude one treatment as not medically possible or recommended. There are multible biases; provider bias, patient bias, and confirmation bias. Provider bias: surgeons prefer surgery and radiologist prefer radiotherapy. Yet competent professionals will acknowledge when the patient's profile trumps their skill set and is better served by the other. Patient bias: each of us has a bias for surgery or radiation independent of what we know and our own profile. For example, going in I'd hope my profile matches up with surgery. That bias comes from thinking if it's small, unentangled, and can be cleanly removed - remove it. My bias is against radiation as toxic and crude and used when the line between healthy and diseased tissue can not be made with a scaple. Sounds very reasonable, but it is still a bias that tempts me to hear only those things about my profile supporting surgety. (Someone with a radiation bias can speak for that.) Confirmation bias: a patient chooses and then begins to listen for any and only evidence that supports his choice as the best choice. This is automatic and we all do it. The upside is we have a multitude of effective, tried, and proven treatment choices. The best advice is to stay out of the weeds and go main stream, imo. This is a little off topic, but it applies to how we misuse language. If you use the words right and wrong, better or worse, good or bad you are making a moral judgment. Those words are exclusive to moral language yet we collapse them into other judgment choices. The consideration is what will work and how effective will it be. We want to be right more than anything often times at the expense of what works.

Have you tried physical therapy wirth a specialist in pelvic floor muscles? In other words, try everything before choosing surgery solutions, imo.

Posts.Title: Is second opinion for pathology need post surgery?

Posts.Content: You want to keep moving. Just getting up every hour to walk around the house a few minutes works. You want to avoid DVT or blood clots in the legs. While movement helps dispel the residual gas and the pains it causes and aids in healing, the real threat is lower extremity blood clots. The older we are the greater the risk as a surgery complication. My brother had this. It's an unecessary complication with a regimen of blood thinning meds not to mention the risk to your life. If you absolutely can't move around do calf exercises while laying or sitting to keep blood moving in your legs. Google them. As you recover and choose to use the leg bag to get out of the house, do not strap it too tight or wear it for long periods of time. This can also contribute to blood clots by suppressing circulation.

Posts.Content: Mine was painful but bearable. Inserting the probe is uncomfortable. The device is spring loaded so you will hear popping noises as each needle is deployed. Use breathing techniques. You will also do a bowel cleanse beforehand. Suspend your exercise routines afterwards until sufficiently healed.

Posts.Title: Trial: identifying clinically significant lesions in Low Risk Ca pts.

Posts.Content: I was told 10 days by the doctor. It was scheduled by the office nurse at 12 days. I saw no problem with the 12, but wondered about it at the time. HOWEVER, I was one of those who developed bladder spasms near the end. VERY painful and uncomfortable. Those extra two day were not fun. As stated, there may be a medical reason discovered during the surgery for the extra time, but that should have been explained by the doctor post surgery. I've seen many posts sharing 7 days which seemed pretty quick to me considering the importance of a good heal on such a vital connection. I am not a doctor, but having had the experience I can see an increased risk of taking it longer than necessary. It impacts the bladder, healing, and recovery, and increases the risk of infection/irritation/accidents. I was always afraid I'd hook it on something. Even things we don't think of such as being in an automobile accident can cause complications. It's pretty important plumbing we are dealing with. Call the office, and get a reasonable explanation or other arrangements. When things happen different from what you are told by the doctor you have a responsibility to speak up. There can always be miscommunication or mistakes on their side. As an aside, I only strapped it on the leg when going out or to work. Most of the time I used the larger bag and carried it around and pretty much avoided going out except for work and my daughter's graduation. Don't strap it too tight. Loosen it when your just sitting around. My brother may have given himself a clot in his leg as a complication of keeping it too tight. Either way he developed a clot in that leg and had to go on blood thinners.

Posts.Content: Interesting question so I googled it. https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidkr...-energy-drink/ Another distinction about caffiene is we consider it an "energy" booster, but it may be more accurate to say "focus" booster. Energy may be more fuel related, i.e. carbs and proteins. You may want to look into making your own smoothies and designing something tailored to your specific needs. Exercise is also an energy booster, but the hurdle is generating the energy to start exercise when you need it for energy. I am a yoga fan. It doesn't take a lot of energy to start a yoga session, but it will generate it before your finished. Walking and biking are both easy starters. Exerting energy is the key to generating energy, but we often want a quick dose of something to jump start the hard part, getting active. Hard to generate activity when you don't feel active. No easy fix I suspect. If you live in America it's more difficult to break out of the sedentary life styles. I sit at work all day and go home and want to sit some more because I'm tired from sitting all day.

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: My choice was surgery to remove as much of the source of the cancer as possible and to determine as complete a pathology of the cancer as possible. Then radiation to follow. Since both surgery and radiation are effective in different ways I wanted the most effective benefits of both. Fortunately my age, physical and mental fitness, diagnosis, and resources were suited for this approach. I am playing the game with one goal, to die of something else. Knowing that achieving a goal is most successful when separated into smaller incremental goals I do not expect this to happen in one event, but a series of smaller consecutive events until the day I pass of something else. In support of Jim's very important note regarding test limitations, it is not certain your cancer is confined to your prostate, and your scans are clear of detectable levels of cancer. The scans are not certain either. You have Gleason 4 cancer and your PSA is over 10. Those facts are more certain. As a technical writer you can understand the temptations that exist in the use of language, and how we step over the details to hear what we want. This also applies to the temptation to over think an issue to avoid the obvious and unpleasant realities. It explains your lengthy post and conclusion to pursue a treatment that is very much less used than others raising the very obvious question why? And in your signature, May 2017 with radiation oncologist decided to use IMRT to eliminate the malignancy. Not certain how that can be guaranteed. In the same reference to use of language, referring to Gleason grading as a flip of the coin is dangerous thinking. It is a professional assessment made by experienced doctors of pathology using a scoring system many decades in the making. They may differ slightly, but rarely are mistakes made and it is not a random selection. You may seek a second opinion of your Gleason score. Also, your rise in PSA did not come out of the blue. A 3.9 was a serious warning flag yet you allowed 2 years to pass before checking it again, and may even have ignored a recommendation to consider a biopsy then. All of this is not to beat you up or point out what you did wrong. It is to warn you how we use language to mislead ourselves and justify who, what, and where we are in our lives. My advice, get clear in your language and get out of your head. For most of us, this disease becomes an opportunity to clear our heads and learn again how to focus on what is real and important. It shows up first in our language.

Posts.Content: Yes, even had semi erection with catheter in. Still took over a year to regain erection function. Not as robust as before, but still improving and cialis helps. It's a better sign than nothing, but did not indicate an early recovery for me. Nor can I say it predicts a recovery, but I considered it a good sign. I'd also experience blood swelling my penis while pressing during a bowel movement. I think valves are wide open allowing a free flow in and out. Your orgasm nerves are unaffected and you can/may have an orgasm without erection. An orgasmic dream is still as possible as before. You may have pressed blood into the penis by contraction during your erotic/orgasmic dream. The valves that hold the blood in the erect penis are the ones controlled by the nerves effected by the surgery.
Posts.Title: Nocturnal Emission - ED

Posts.Content: What is your life expectancy? I put mine at between 85 and 90 on thelie side. Of course, you can die anytime, but some things are obvious; family history, fitness habits, and your personal commitment to your health. There are life expectancy calculators on line. Most insurance companies provide them. They seem remarkably accurate. They are the masters of actuarials. They put mine at 86. It seems accurate, if conservative. You can play with the differences of weight, exercise, drinking and smoking. They do not go into family history or mental health. I've had several parents and grandparent live into their 90s so there is that. Assess your mental health. Depression, even if not chronic, can be a factor in your thinking and can impact your view of your healthcare. Your PSA history indicates a reluctance to deal with healthcare issues effectively. Early detection early treatment is the mantra for prostate cancer, or any cancer. PC seems to have gotten a dangerous reputation as being non life threatening. You now know differently, or do you? If you do nothing, it is unlikely you will die of something else as most men are eager to quote (if not believe). Research death from prostate cancer. It can happen as quickly as 3 to 5 years. Research PC lymphatic invasion as the adverse condition you are confronting. PC can be successfully managed for a long time in many cases. You don't know if you don't try. We have plenty of history and diagnostic tools to help, but it is clear we can't predict how it is going to go for any one person. In fairness to you it's also a question for your doctors; what will happen if I do nothing? And, it is a very good question we all ask ourselves. If more men asked it and got it answered for themselves in a timely manner (sooner) we'd have less of them here. There may come a time for all of us when we are confronted with a treatment option worse than death. Imo, this isn't it for you unless you are dying of something else in the next 5 years you haven't shared with us. I may be wrong, but it seems you hesitated once before with this disease and here you are. Do it again and you may not have this second chance a third time.

Posts.Title: Heading for SRT

Posts.Content: Yes, you can manipulate your PSA with drugs, supplements, and diet. I did in ignorance and denial. I lost a couple of years and the possibility of earliar detection. If you do this you are undermining the value of PSA testing as your best indicator of cancer. Manipulating your PSA has no effect on the cancer. It continues to do what it does. What you may be manipulating is that potion of the PSA generated by BHP or other prostate issues. Often both conditions exist in varying degrees. You can test for your free PSA (fPSA). As you search for your 3T MRI I suggest you proceed with the TRUS biopsy anyway. You've been sitting on this for a while. While your PSA bounces may indicate other prostate issues your consistently elevated values indicates cancer is possible. The biopsy is a valuable tool and works most of the time. Don't let concerns and a search for state of the art stuff stop you from basic health care.

Posts.Title: patience

Posts.Content: I had surgery and recovered my continence in 3 months and erections within a year. I was already experiencing urgency incontinence as a symptom before the surgery. My continence and urination improved with surgery. If you are experiencing ED before surgery it will be no better after surgery. So far, surgery has worked for me. I am now 2 years post and watching closely for any recurrence. If there is I will follow up with radiation. If you are a candidate, surgery first gives you the option of salvage radiation as a follow up. Radiation first eliminates surgery as a second option. It creates too much scar tissue for surgery to be a good risk. Surgery also gives you a prostate, lymph node, and seminal vesicle pathology report of the extent and grade of the cancer. This is useful moving forward. This disease has many good treatment options for a potential cure and a long life if not curable. Early detection and early treatment is the gold standard for curing or managing this disease. You are off to a good start. Stay on top of it. As our understanding of the disease increases, low risk and indolent varieties of the disease can be managed with Active Surveillance. Your experience with your friend is a valuable early lesson. We all have treatment bias. Some more than others. Some with successful experiences and accurate information, and some not so much. Stay out the weeds. There are recognizable pitfalls along the way. This disease is treatable and manageable with decades of research and development of treatment options. This forum is a good resource, well monitored, experienced participants in many aspects of the disease and treatments, and committed to mainstream proven pathways of which there are many. Exercise and a healthy diet are good practices, but will not cure cancer. Maintaining your weight to a BMI of 19 to 25 is also good practise and will improve your health, treatment options, recovery and treatment outcomes. Avoid supplements, megadoses of vitamins, and prostate health products. They may manipulate your PSA levels, but will not cure cancer. I did it. Check my signature. An unadulterated PSA level and history is now your best friend. Some are not as lucky as you. Your PSA appears to be a reliable indicator of your cancer. You want to keep it that way as you deal with this inconvenience. There is no slightly worse Gleason score than yours. The next worse score is a 4+3 and it's a significant upgrade in risk. 3+3 is good news if you have to have this cancer. 3+4 is concerning depending on the percentage of 4. 4+3 is serious. Volume is a different statistic and the number of positive biopsy samples is an indicator of volume. In my signature you will see a high volume of 3+3 at biopsy. It was upgraded to a high volume of 3+4 after the surgery. Upgrading and down grading are possible risks due to the limits of our tools artany time in this process. Location of your positive samples is also useful to know. Some locations are a higger risk than others. Also, some areas of the prostate are difficult to reach and are often missed. You are a potential candidate for AS, but the operative word is Active. If you are considering AS you will continue testing to confirm your status is accurate and stable. In the US I advise a second opinion on biopsy G scores with Epstein's lab at John Hopkins. It is a grading that requires experience and when critical to a treatment choice benefits from a second opinion. Personally, I would not consider AS with 2 - 3+4s. Life expectancy is an important consideration. For young men with a long life expectancy and locally confined cancer surgery gives you more treatment options for a longer game plan if you need it. Dr. Walsh's, "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", most recent book edition is recommended reading. Denial and delay are the two demons of all cancer.

Everything I have read indicates the use of testosterone, cialis, or viagra to treat normal aging is not adviseable. The side effect risks are not worth it. I used cialis for healing and ED therapy after surgery, but have discontinued it once function was recovered. The only safe therapy for continued aging muscle and libido loss is a variety of exercise and a healthy diet, imo.

Posts.Content: Be careful using vitamin supplements with your kidney issues. Consult with your doctor managing your kidney issues about this diet. Vitamin supplements are an unnecessary risk if you are on a healthy diet. Their use may be advised when having to work with a restricted diet, but not indescrimanately. Friends of mine have gained weight on this treatment and were not happy about it. Also, our ability to digest protein diminishes as we age requiring more digestible protein in our diet as we age.

Posts.Title: For those on long term hormone therapy (ADT)

Posts.Content: Exercise and diet are critical elements of managing depression. Depression in it's common form is the common cold of mental health. We all get it. It is contagious from life events and from other depressed people. Use the tools available to deal with it if it effects your ability to live the life you want for yourself. It is a critical aspect of your healthcare. It will effect your general health, activity, and longevity if left unaddressed. It can also become chronic, even if low grade, if left unaddressed. Your brain will rewire itself to acceptance and a depressed way of life becomes a new normal. I know people who are addicted to it. It can be an effective mechanism for making your life smaller and dealing with aniexty or stress. Sadly, there is a stigma associated with it that is harmful and it takes courage and strength to push past it and take care of yourself. All the issues of aging can contribute to it. Best to develop the skills to manage it now because as we age we become more at risk to it. It has many and varied symptoms; anxiety, anger, irritability, substance abuse, obesity and eating disorders, inactivity, isolation, poor general health, poverty, poor healthcare, homelessness and unemployment, fatigue...... If your head is not clear, nothing else is. Put a plan in place; diet and exercise, medical support and therapy in place as you head into this adventure. Be proactive. Be prepared. If its something you know about yourself do not step over it. Take it on before it takes on you. It's real and you can make a difference in it. Just like cancer, denial and delay are the demons of depression. Cancer and depression go hand in hand, imo. You are not normal if it doesn't depress you. What is not normal is living with it as the new normal.

Posts.Title: Depression after RP

Posts.Content: What is your life expectancy? I put mine at between 85 and 90 on thelie side. Of course, you can die anytime, but some things are obvious; family history, fitness habits, and your personal commitment to your health. There are life expectancy calculators on line. Most insurance companies provide them. They seem remarkably accurate. They are the masters of actuarials. They put mine at 86. It seems accurate, if conservative. You can play with the differences of weight, exercise, drinking and smoking. They do not go into family history or mental health. I've had several parents and grandparent live into their 90s so there is that. Assess your mental health. Depression, even if not chronic, can be a factor in your thinking and can impact your view of your healthcare. Your PSA history indicates a reluctance to deal with healthcare issues effectively. Early detection early treatment is the mantra for prostate cancer, or any cancer. PC seems to have gotten a dangerous reputation as being non life threatening. You now know differently, or do you? If you do nothing, it is unlikely you will die of something else as most men are eager to quote (if not believe). Research death from prostate cancer. It can happen as quickly as 3 to 5 years. Research PC lymphatic invasion as the adverse condition you are confronting. PC can be successfully managed for a long time in many cases. You don't know if you don't try. We have plenty of history and diagnostic tools to help, but it is clear we can't predict how it is going to go for any one person. In fairness to you it's also a question for your doctors; what will happen if I do nothing? And, it is a very good question we all ask ourselves. If more men asked it and got it answered for themselves in a timely manner (sooner) we'd have less of them here. There may come a time for all of us when we are confronted with a treatment option worse than death. Imo, this isn't it for you unless you are dying of something else in the next 5 years you haven't shared with us. I may be wrong, but it seems you hesitated once before with this disease and here you are. Do it again and you may not have this second chance a third time.
