Posts.Title: Question on BCR - Using PSA to predict time until serious symptoms

Posts.Content: Your age is the wild card. It's early for this to start. Why were you screening? Is there some history or symptoms? Second opinion on the Gleason score is a good idea. Take a breath. You caught it early and it's the best position to be in. Forget the biopsy pain, and you will. You got the gold. That's all that matters.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed and overwhelmed

Posts.Content: I had surgery and recovered my continence in 3 months and erections within a year. I was already experiencing urgency incontinence as a symptom before the surgery. My continence and urination improved with surgery. If you are experiencing ED before surgery it will be no better after surgery. So far, surgery has worked for me. I am now 2 years post and watching closely for any recurrence. If there is I will follow up with radiation. If you are a candidate, surgery first gives you the option of salvage radiation as a follow up. Radiation first eliminates surgery as a second option. It creates too much scar tissue for surgery to be a good risk. Surgery also gives you a prostate, lymph node, and seminal vesicle pathology report of the extent and grade of the cancer. This is useful moving forward. This disease has many good treatment options for a potential cure and a long life if not curable. Early detection and early treatment is the gold standard for curing or managing this disease. You are off to a good start. Stay on top of it. As our understanding of the disease increases, low risk and indolent varieties of the disease can be managed with Active Surveillance. Your experience with your friend is a valuable early lesson. We all have treatment bias. Some more than others. Some with successful experiences and accurate information, and some not so much. Stay out the weeds. There are recognizable pitfalls along the way. This disease is treatable and manageable with decades of research and development of treatment options. This forum is a good resource, well monitored, experienced participants in many aspects of the disease and treatments, and committed to mainstream proven pathways of which there are many. Exercise and a healthy diet are good practices, but will not cure cancer. Maintaining your weight to a BMI of 19 to 25 is also good practise and will improve your health, treatment options, recovery and treatment outcomes. Avoid supplements, megadoses of vitamins, and prostate health products. They may manipulate your PSA levels, but will not cure cancer. I did it. Check my signature. An unadulterated PSA level and history is now your best friend. Some are not as lucky as you. Your PSA appears to be a reliable indicator of your cancer. You want to keep it that way as you deal with this inconvenience. There is no slightly worse Gleason score than yours. The next worse score is a 4+3 and it's a significant upgrade in risk. 3+3 is good news if you have to have this cancer. 3+4 is concerning depending on the percentage of 4. 4+3 is serious. Volume is a different statistic and the number of positive biopsy samples is an indicator of volume. In my signature you will see a high volume of 3+3 at biopsy. It was upgraded to a high volume of 3+4 after the surgery. Upgrading and down grading are possible risks due to the limits of our tools artany time in this process. Location of your positive samples is also useful to know. Some locations are a higger risk than others. Also, some areas of the prostate are difficult to reach and are often missed. You are a potential candidate for AS, but the operative word is Active. If you are considering AS you will continue testing to confirm your status is accurate and stable. In the US I advise a second opinion on biopsy G scores with Epstein's lab at John Hopkins. It is a grading that requires experience and when critical to a treatment choice benefits from a second opinion. Personally, I would not consider AS with 2 - 3+4s. Life expectancy is an important consideration. For young men with a long life expectancy and locally confined cancer surgery gives you more treatment options for a longer game plan if you need it. Dr. Walsh's, "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", most recent book edition is recommended reading. Denial and delay are the two demons of all cancer.

Posts.Title: incontinence almost inevitable with normal treatment?

Posts.Content: Love the perspective in this story. I know many of our brothers are dealing with a heartbreaking experience with prostate cancer, yet for most it can be an inconvenience to a life well spent. That statement was one my surgeon shared with me and it put it in perspective and resonated with me. "This is an inconvenience for you." I called back the next day and scheduled my treatment, and haven't looked back. I am beyond fortunate. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/01/f...gtype=Homepage PS: you have to read the story to find the reference.
Posts.Title: A love story with PC.

Posts.Content: Prostate cancer screening has been put in the back seat in most urologist's offices. The current myth is you will not die of prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Why do urologist not tell you things to stop before a PSA test

Posts.Content: Exercise and diet are critical elements of managing depression. Depression in it's common form is the common cold of mental health. We all get it. It is contagious from life events and from other depressed people. Use the tools available to deal with it if it effects your ability to live the life you want for yourself. It is a critical aspect of your healthcare. It will effect your general health, activity, and longevity if left unaddressed. It can also become chronic, even if low grade, if left unaddressed. Your brain will rewire itself to acceptance and a depressed way of life becomes a new normal. I know people who are addicted to it. It can be an effective mechanism for making your life smaller and dealing with aniexty or stress. Sadly, there is a stigma associated with it that is harmful and it takes courage and strength to push past it and take care of yourself. All the issues of aging can contribute to it. Best to develop the skills to manage it now because as we age we become more at risk to it. It has many and varied symptoms; anxiety, anger, irritability, substance abuse, obesity and eating disorders, inactivity, isolation, poor general health, poverty, poor healthcare, homelessness and unemployment, fatigue...... If your head is not clear, nothing else is. Put a plan in place; diet and exercise, medical support and therapy in place as you head into this adventure. Be proactive. Be prepared. If its something you know about yourself do not step over it. Take it on before it takes on you. It's real and you can make a difference in it. Just like cancer, denial and delay are the demons of depression. Cancer and depression go hand in hand, imo. You are not normal if it doesn't depress you. What is not normal is living with it as the new normal.

Posts.Title: New member Got my fingers crossed

Posts.Content: Make sure the lab report is a copy of the original and not an internal doctor's office summary. Questions and follow up question. Prostate size? What's normal? DRE (digital rectal exam) results, and explain. Cancer or no cancer? No cancer, then what are percentages of biopsy false negative for your profile? How do we monitor you going forward, testing, frequency? If cancer - low risk, intermediate or high? Do you need a second opinion of Gleason scoring if Gleason scoring is ambiguous or becomes critical to your treatment choice. Regardless of Gleason scoring is cancer volume high based on biopsy? How many samples hit cancer? Some reports have a graphic of the prostate showing where and what was found within the prostate. If not, have them draw you a picture. Where is it hard to reach with the biopsy needle and did we reach it with yours? Are you a candidate for treatment? If so, why, and what do they recommend, and why? Again, have them draw you a picture of the treatment recommendations. What is done during surgery? What is done during radiation treatments? What is done for active surveillance? (No picture needed for AS.) After the meeting, and after you have a chance to review the actual report and consider what they told you, how do you address your follow up questions? How do you get a second opinion on treatment options? Your doctor may be a surgeon and can speak to surgery, but who do you they refer you to for radiation treatment options or AS? The surgeon is not the one to address those options. Time frame going forward whatever the outcome of the biopsy? Check your local library for a copy of Walsh's book. You have time between now and your appointment to get it, skim it, and get really confused. But, relax, you will get really confused before you get clear. We all do. The booked is organized to work as a reference guide or a front to back read. You have the time. Nothing is rushed with prostate cancer. (I don't mean years, but weeks and months.) The book has all the basics you need to know so don't sweat the computer thing. However, this is a very good forum for input from experienced and dedicated fellow travelers. Compete your signature on this site. If you need help doing this seek the help of a computer literate friend. Trust but verify. Too many doctors still believe you will die of something else. If you live a long life it may not be true. So, what is your best guess of your life expectancy? Not kidding here. Your family history, education, commitment to health care, and personal fitness determine this answer and may impact your choices going forward. Take a friend to take notes. You listen and ask questions. Give yourself time to stop and consider during the meeting. Do not be concerned if you generate some lengthy empty pauses while you do this. Ask your friend if they have questions before you finish.

You are a potential candidate for AS, but the operative word is Active. If you are considering AS you will continue testing to confirm your status is accurate and stable. In the US I advise a second opinion on biopsy G scores with Epstein's lab at John Hopkins. It is a grading that requires experience and when critical to a treatment choice benefits from a second opinion. Personally, I would not consider AS with 2 - 3+4s. Life expectancy is an important consideration. For young men with a long life expectancy and locally confined cancer surgery gives you more treatment options for a longer game plan if you need it. Dr. Walsh's, "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", most recent book edition is recommended reading. Denial and delay are the two demons of all cancer.

Posts.Title: Help please

Posts.Content: I had surgery and recovered my continence in 3 months and erections within a year. I was already experiencing urgency incontinence as a symptom before the surgery. My continence and urination improved with surgery. If you are experiencing ED before surgery it will be no better after surgery. So far, surgery has worked for me. I am now 2 years post and watching closely for any recurrence. If there is I will follow up with radiation. If you are a candidate, surgery first gives you the option of salvage radiation as a follow up. Radiation first eliminates surgery as a second option. It creates too much scar tissue for surgery to be a good risk. Surgery also gives you a prostate, lymph node, and seminal vesicle pathology report of the extent and grade of the cancer. This is useful moving forward. This disease has many good treatment options for a potential cure and a long life if not curable. Early detection and early treatment is the gold standard for curing or managing this disease. You are off to a good start. Stay on top of it. As our understanding of the disease increases, low risk and indolent varieties of the disease can be managed with Active Surveillance. Your experience with your friend is a valuable early lesson. We all have treatment bias. Some more than others. Some with successful experiences and accurate information, and some not so much. Stay out the weeds. There are recognizable pitfalls along the way. This disease is treatable and manageable with decades of research and development of treatment options. This forum is a good resource, well monitored, experienced participants in many aspects of the disease and treatments, and committed to mainstream proven pathways of which there are many. Exercise and a healthy diet are good practices, but will not cure cancer. Maintaining your weight to a BMI of 19 to 25 is also good practise and will improve your health, treatment options, recovery and treatment outcomes. Avoid supplements, megadoses of vitamins, and prostate health products. They may manipulate your PSA levels, but will not cure cancer. I did it. Check my signature. An unadulterated PSA level and history is now your best friend. Some are not as lucky as you. Your PSA appears to be a reliable indicator of your cancer. You want to keep it that way as you deal with this inconvenience. There is no slightly worse Gleason score than yours. The next worse score is a 4+3 and it's a significant upgrade in risk. 3+3 is good news if you have to have this cancer. 3+4 is concerning depending on the percentage of 4. 4+3 is serious. Volume is a different statistic and the number of positive biopsy samples is an indicator of volume. In my signature you will see a high volume of 3+3 at biopsy. It was upgraded to a high volume of 3+4 after the surgery. Upgrading and down grading are possible risks due to the limits of our tools artany time in this process. Location of your positive samples is also useful to know. Some locations are a higger risk than others. Also, some areas of the prostate are difficult to reach and are often missed. You are a potential candidate for AS, but the operative word is Active. If you are considering AS you will continue testing to confirm your status is accurate and stable. In the US I advise a second opinion on biopsy G scores with Epstein's lab at John Hopkins. It is a grading that requires experience and when critical to a treatment choice benefits from a second opinion. Personally, I would not consider AS with 2 - 3+4s. Life expectancy is an important consideration. For young men with a long life expectancy and locally confined cancer surgery gives you more treatment options for a longer game plan if you need it. Dr. Walsh's, "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", most recent book edition is recommended reading. Denial and delay are the two demons of all cancer.
Posts.Title: incontinence almost inevitable with normal treatment?

Posts.Content: The G7 and 8 is concerning and I'll assume the G7 is 4+3. The location is critical also. If at the base it is a higher risk. If you have made your treatment choice then schedule it now for January. Waiting to schedule after the first of January puts you further back in the que. How will the scans impact your treatment choice? You have not shared all your information so hard to tell. If your PSA is not through the roof the scans may be protocal and hold little risk of a surprise. Even if the cancer has metastized will you still have an RP? Regardless of your finacial timimg you want to play out the possible scenarios to answer your question. For example, what do we do if the scans fail to detect anything? What do we do if they do. G4 and 5 are nothing to mess around with. Two weeks or 6 months, is it worth a couple thousand dollars. A doctor's remark from a biopsy that you have 6 months of safety with G8 is not professional, imo. The mantra is early detection early treatment. Mess with that at your own risk. Not saying you can't be prudent with money and health, but you want to lay out your critical path before moving forward.

Posts.Title: Need an answer ASAP on this please

Posts.Content: Make sure the lab report is a copy of the original and not an internal doctor's office summary. Questions and follow up question. Prostate size? What's normal? DRE (digital rectal exam) results, and explain. Cancer or no cancer? No cancer, then what are percentages of biopsy false negative for your profile? How do we monitor you going forward, testing, frequency? If cancer - low risk, intermediate or high? Do you need a second opinion of Gleason scoring if Gleason scoring is ambiguous or becomes critical to your treatment choice. Regardless of Gleason scoring is cancer volume high based on biopsy? How many samples hit cancer? Some reports have a graphic of the prostate showing where and what was found within the prostate. If not, have them draw you a picture. Where is it hard to reach with the biopsy needle and did we reach it with yours? Are you a candidate for treatment? If so, why, and what do they recommend, and why? Again, have them draw you a picture of the treatment recommendations. What is done during surgery? What is done during radiation treatments? What is done for active surveillance? (No picture needed for AS.) After the meeting, and after you have a chance to review the actual report and consider what they told you, how do you address your follow up questions? How do you get a second opinion on treatment options? Your doctor may be a surgeon and can speak to surgery, but who do you they refer you to for radiation treatment options or AS? The surgeon is not the one to address those options. Time frame going forward whatever the outcome of the biopsy? Check your local library for a copy of Walsh's book. You have time between now and your appointment to get it, skim it, and get really confused. But, relax, you will get really confused before you get clear. We all do. The booked is organized to work as a reference guide or a front to back read. You have the time. Nothing is rushed with prostate cancer. (I don't mean years, but weeks and months.) The book has all the basics you need to know so don't sweat the computer thing. However, this is a very good forum for input from experienced and dedicated fellow travelers. Compete your signature on this site. If you need help doing this seek the help of a computer literate friend. Trust but verify. Too many doctors still believe you will die of something else. If you live a long life it may not be true. So, what is your best guess of your life expectancy? Not kidding here. Your family history, education, commitment to health care, and personal fitness determine this answer and may impact your choices going forward. Take a friend to take notes. You listen and ask questions. Give yourself time to stop and consider during the meeting. Do not be concerned if you generate some lengthy empty pauses while you do this. Ask your friend if they have questions before you finish.

Posts.Title: Dealing with Short Term Incontinence Post Surgical Post Catheter

Posts.Content: A note about the lower colon. It's a muscle and its primary role is to remove water from the stool. It is a recycling machine. It explains the diarrhea when it's function is disrupted or damaged by radiation. The hope is it will recover fully or at least partially. Be aware of possible dehydration.

Posts.Title: Newbie from Ottawa

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maximus The next steps, he informed me, will be to get a bone scan done to make sure it has not spread to my bones, and a CAT scan to make sure it has not spread to my lymph nodes and surrounding tissues. I will let you know when these results come in. Yes, the next thing is to complete his signature. Please correct me, but my understanding is these scans can not make sure it has not spread as stated. They can only determine if it is possible the cancer has spread beyond surgery as a treatment choice while still leaving a grey area between. Do doctors speak this way or is it what we hear? Or do doctors speak in partial truths thinking we can't handle the whole truth? Or, are we being sent on our happy way by doctors too busy to share the whole truth? Very disconcerting to hear words used so carelessly in matters of life and death by those sworn to do no harm. Nothing is certain with this disease unless the tissue itself is sitting in a lab, and even then we need second opinions on some matters.

Posts.Title: Results of two studies - When is the outcome of 3+4=7 similar to 3+3=6?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD My doctor told me this used to be the thinking but that has changed. It is now believed cancer does not get more aggressive but its aggressiveness is set at the time it starts. Here is an excerpt from an article that supports this. Cancer lethality set early The study looked for changes in cancer aggressiveness in men diagnosed with prostate cancer from 1982 to 2004. All of the men had their prostates removed after diagnosis, and biopsy samples were taken from the glands. The Harvard team reexamined the samples and graded them using a tool called the Gleason score, which assigns a number from 2 to 10 based on how abnormal the cells look under a microscope. High-scoring or “high-grade cancers” tend to be the most lethal. Over the study period, fewer and fewer men were diagnosed with advanced, late-stage prostate cancers that had spread beyond the prostate gland. This reflected the growing use of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing to diagnose prostate cancers earlier and earlier. In contrast, the proportion of high-grade cancers, as measured by the Gleason score, remained relatively stable rather than gradually becoming more aggressive. Previous studies have seen a similar pattern. “It’s a very interesting study that confirms what previous studies have found,” says Dr. Marc B. Garnick, a prostate cancer specialist at Harvard-affiliated Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center who was not involved in the study. “There may be rare exceptions, but in the vast majority the cancer is born with a particular Gleason score.” Please post the link to the study. I accept a 3 remains a 3, and whatever causes a cell to produce a 3 may be fixed. But, many men have cells that produce 3 and 4s. Are these the same cells producing 3s and 4s? Will the proportion of cells produce 3s and 4s consistently, for example 4s will always be limited to 5% of new cancer cells? If the aggressiveness relationship is fixed then maybe we go to decimals, i.e. 3.5 or 3.8

Posts.Content: A second opinion on the samples from Epstein's lab at Hopkins may be a good idea to confirm no G4, again. Volume, PSA velocity, and density all factor in. My G6 was high volume with increasing velocity and upgraded to G3+4 after removal. One thing I've been learning is the risk of hanging everything on one good factor, such as your G6. Posts.Content: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4647137/ We can not generalize about testosterone and Pca. Studies have shown it to have potential treatment possibilities for Pca with heavy doses following deprivation shocking Pca into remission. The fact remains that older men experience a natural reduction in testosterone at the same time as their risk of Pca increases. PSA, while not 100%, remains for most men the single most reliable indicator of prostate cancer we have today.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD My doctor told me this used to be the thinking but that has changed. It is now believed cancer does not get more aggressive but its aggressiveness is set at the time it starts. Here is an excerpt from an article that supports this. Cancer lethality set early The study looked for changes in cancer aggressiveness in men diagnosed with prostate cancer from 1982 to 2004. All of the men had their prostates removed after diagnosis, and biopsy samples were taken from the glands. The Harvard team reexamined the samples and graded them using a tool called the Gleason score, which assigns a number from 2 to 10 based on how abnormal the cells look under a microscope. High-scoring or “high-grade cancers” tend to be the most lethal. Over the study period, fewer and fewer men were diagnosed with advanced, late-stage prostate cancers that had spread beyond the prostate gland. This reflected the growing use of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing to diagnose prostate cancers earlier and earlier. In contrast, the proportion of high-grade cancers, as measured by the Gleason score, remained relatively stable rather than gradually becoming more aggressive. Previous studies have seen a similar pattern. “It’s a very interesting study that confirms what previous studies have found,” says Dr. Marc B. Garnick, a prostate cancer specialist at Harvard-affiliated Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center who was not involved in the study. “There may be rare exceptions, but in the vast majority the cancer is born with a particular Gleason score.” Please post the link to the study. I accept a 3 remains a 3, and whatever causes a cell to produce a 3 may be fixed. But, many men have cells that produce 3 and 4s. Are these the same cells producing 3s and 4s? Will the proportion of cells produce 3s and 4s consistently, for example 4s will always be limited to 5% of new cancer cells? If the aggressiveness relationship is fixed then maybe we go to decimals, i.e. 3.5 or 3.8

Posts.Content: Be clear about the scans. Their sensitivity is crude. They are not a 100% pass if clear or we'd be using them to detect prostate cancer. They can't see the small stuff. If they light up, surgery is most likely off the table. Then you have bigger problems. They are never an indicator the cancer is confined to the prostate. It works one way not both ways. Maybe I'm missing it, but how can anything be offered not knowing the poster's profile? Age, family history, medical history, health, BMI, hormone use, it all matters in treatment choices.

This strikes at the heart of the prostate cancer dilemma and is present at every phase of the disease, a cancer that has many forms from indolent to aggressive occurring predominately in an older population. Posts.Title: Pathology Results

Posts.Content: It is the nature of the cancer to migrate towards the nerve pathways and then out into the body. It is a highly common finding, but statisticslly not useful in itself of predicting future recurrence. In other words, it is part of the natural progression of the disease, but not a key indicator of future risk. Your other findings are the critical ones, and they are all good. PNI is a precursor to more critical pathology and yours are all negative. That said, and not to spoil the day but to be clear, there are no guarantees with cancer. Your report is the best outcome of the facts. Enjoy it! Imo, it highlights your choice to treat your disease was a good one and timely. Sooner is most often better with this disease, but soon enough works as well. Enjoy the moment and commit to monitoring your status for possible recurrence. Worry has no useful role. If anything, life may be a little sweeter for you.

Posts.Content: Highlander, it may be possible. But IceStationZebra is a different case. Low testosterone as a condition of obesity is common. Fat disrupts the hormone regulating system. "Bulking" up with testostetone can "mask" obesity. It becomes a vicous swirl. Obesity leads to fatigue and ED now made worse by supplementation. Supplementation causes the body to stop it's own production. Testes shrink. It goes from bad to worse. There is no easy answer, just a simple one. For ISZ, it's lose 100 lbs. Even that herculean task will disrupt his hormone regulating system even more as the stored products in the fat flood his system as the body processes it. A endocrinologist should be supervising hormone therapy for serious maladies. Urologists and ED experts seem to be playing around the edges of a very powerful and complicated system we know little about, imo. I expect we will see more fall out in the PC numbers in younger men as the commercialization of testosterone as an answer to male aging increases before it stops.

Posts.Content: Be careful. You are both young to be presenting with PC. If you were both on testosterone supplements it may be viewed suspiciously as the source of your PC presenting early. I have heard it's influence can be for early, small, and aggressive cancers. Nobody knows what is normal for testosterone. Everyone wants what testosterone provides; energy, vitality, libido, limber, erections, muscle mass, etc. Who wouldn't, but at what price? Professional advice from Mayo is to not use testosterone supplements to counter normal aging. There have been studies that confuse this issue. What we do know. One proven treatment for advanced prostate cancer is to effectively use drug therapy to reduce testosterone to very low levels and force/stun prostate cancer into remission. The implication in this proven treatment is PC responds to testosterone. It can respond and adjust to manipualtion of testosterone and become resistant to it or continue to thrive at varying levels. It's a wild card. It's use now may affect use later when you may really need it. My advice, unless you have a life threatening issue addressed by testosterone supplementation it is safer to avoid it unless neccesary to combat PC. I am no expert in this, but when I hear talk of experimenting with it in the presence of PC the hair on my neck goes up. Especially, when it's use may have been the source of it presenting as it has. Nobody can claim you are clear of cancer, now or after RP. The commercialized pressure through advertising to influence patients to ask doctors for certain drug therapies seems to cause some doctors to throw up their hands and let you have your way. Sort of an eyes wide open, except you really don't know. You just want to be young again. The symptoms of testosterone use are many.

Posts.Title: Supra Pubic Catheter with Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: It seems you are waiting too long. Why? Denial and delay are the demons of cancer and the appearance is you are conspiring with them to your own demise. Do you have extenuating circumstances? Your doctor's annoyance may not be the result of a long day, but consider a long day helping people who want and need her help who are suffering with things that maybe can't be helped to then be confronted by someone who is squandering the help that will make a difference. Is there a reason you were not prepared for this meeting? Prostate cancer is treatable for those who want to be treated. This is no surprise for you. Your surgery failed to cure your cancer. This was evident with the pathology report. Your MRI did not come back clean. It came back with no detectable cancer. Big difference. It can't detect small stuff including aggressive dangerous stuff which you had and still have. Your PSA test is the critical test, not the MRI. Men on this site debate the nuance of starting salvage treatment at a PSA .03 or .1 or .2. You are over 6. A question I have is why isn't this treatment plan and follow up already mapped out with specific responses planned for specific thresholds? Why is this a question now 6 months after the surgery and pathology report?

Posts.Title: High-Dose Rate Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Here's a good article on 4+3 and an article on grading in general. G7 has two values, G3+4 and G4+3. A significant difference exists between them. In short, G4+3 is a higher risk. Another consideration is the volume, or number of cores. You have a significant volume on the one side. All the cores on that side hit cancer. That indicates a possibility of a very high volume on that side. 6/12 across the whole prostate is considered a significant volume. While you may have time I'd not characterize this report as indicating a very slow growing cancer. A third consideration, your father is young. For a better picture of that side, you may ask for a 3T MRI. The article I linked offers the possibility it may be downgraded. You will only know this two ways. A second expert opinion on the biopsy slides. I'd recommend this. It may effect your treatment options. Or a pathology report after surgery. One of the values of surgery is you get a more complete pathology report of the cancer. This often matters in higher risk treatment options to determine the extent of localized cancer for follow up radiation treatments. A biopsy can not sample seminal vessicals or lymph nodes or be good indicators of extension or margins of the prostate. My recommendation is you continue to move forward in informing yourself, diagnosing and considering treatment options. The fact your doctor is pursuing additional scans is evidence of a well founded concern with the biopsy report. http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr...scovery_96.php https://www.cancer.org/treatment/understanding-your-diagnosis/tests/understanding-your-pathology-report/prostate-pathology/prostate-cancer-pathology.html
Posts.Title: Dad just diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic With regard to MRI's, for what it's worth, my own uro doesn't think nearly as highly of them as many studies do. We should make use of what hi PIRAD lesions they do find. As I've said in another thread, I think it's a mistake to do a targeted biopsy with only a few cores that investigate only the imaged lesions and forgoes the standard 12 cores in all zones. And where there is suspicion of PCa, the default should be that the biopsy is still done after a negative mpMRI in a biopsy-naive man. I've been thinking about a quip I saw in someone's signature in another (planted aquarium) forum (referring, I think, to nutrient testing): "A man with a watch knows what time it is. A man with two watches isn't sure." I don't think that applies to PCa testing/diagnosis -- Isn't it better to favor the test(s) that indicate there is disease, and then investigate? Yesterday I added a paper to Topic (C) in the Subforum that found that 2.8% of high-grade metastatic PCa has a PSA of 4 or less at diagnosis. ________ OK, I had to Google that watch quip. Turn's out it's Segal's Law, which you can Wiki. "The pitfalls of too much conflicting information when making a decision." Or too much incomplete or partial information. Imagine everything we know is accurate, but only in part.
Posts.Title: In U.S. 11% of payers cover MRI in biopsy-naive patients; rest require a neg. biopsy

Posts.Content: You do know enough to seek out a urologist that is highy skilled in prostate cancer. This may well be of other causes, but your in the age range and want to begin monitoring for prostate cancer regardless. It may be nothing and your number goes back down. It may be something and needs watching. It may be something that needs treatment soon or someday. So, find a good urologist who specializes in prostate cancer and establish a working relationship. Good advice above. One step at a time: skilled specialist urologist, PHI testing, and see what's next. Now that you have your eyes on it you want to keep this risk on your radar screen and go about living your life. Be grateful. You got an early wake up call. All men are not so lucky as you almost experienced. I've been told only 17% of general practices screen for PSA. Who knows how many don't pay attention when they do. I want to acknowledge you for following it up. Well done. Early detection is the mantra. Welcome!
Posts.Title: PSA INCREASE 2.8 in one year. Doc not alarmed.

Posts.Content: Be careful. You are both young to be presenting with PC. If you were both on testosterone supplements it may be viewed suspiciously as the source of your PC presenting early. I have heard it's influence can be for early, small, and aggressive cancers. Nobody knows what is normal for testosterone. Everyone wants what testosterone provides; energy, vitality, libido, limber, erections, muscle mass, etc. Who wouldn't, but at what price? Professional advice from Mayo is to not use testosterone supplements to counter normal aging. There have been studies that confuse this issue. What we do know. One proven treatment for advanced prostate cancer is to effectively use drug therapy to reduce testosterone to very low levels and force/stun prostate cancer into remission. The implication in this proven treatment is PC responds to testosterone. It can respond and adjust to manipualtion of testosterone and become resistant to it or continue to thrive at varying levels. It's a wild card. It's use now may affect use later when you may really need it. My advice, unless you have a life threatening issue addressed by testosterone supplementation it is safer to avoid it unless neccesary to combat PC. I am no expert in this, but when I hear talk of experimenting with it in the presence of PC the hair on my neck goes up. Especially, when it's use may have been the source of it presenting as it has. Nobody can claim you are clear of cancer, now or after RP. The commercialized pressure through advertising to influence patients to ask doctors for certain drug therapies seems to cause some doctors to throw up their hands and let you have your way. Sort of an eyes wide open, except you really don't know. You just want to be young again. The symptoms of testosterone use are many.

Posts.Content: I'd have a concern that a mistake was made. Less likely on Epstein's part, but did he get the right sample or did you get the right reports? Second opinions are for confirmation. This isn't that. This resolves nothing. These findings are too far apart to be useful or believable. The temptation is obvious. Cherry pick the one you want. You've tossed us a softball. Why? I'm confused. How many samples we're taken and how many were sent to Epstein? Please complete your signature. What is your PSA, family, DRE, and symptom histories? Why are you testing at 43? Is this your first biopsy? How did you manage a 3T MRI fusion biopsy as your first? The short answer is either resolve the disparity or act on the higher risk option, imo. What does your doctor say? Too much is missing in this conversation. With what you have chosen to share, your profile is still unclear and you have no path forward other than to resolve the disparity. You can't hang your hat on either one without more information you may have and we do not. So, you tell us. Bottom line seems to be you asking for help while you are withholding. It usually implies an agenda or bias. For you, which one comes closes to matching the rest of your profile? My own experience, my cancer was worse than what the biopsy revealed. I knew it when I was honest with myself about everything else. I had surgery and the results confirmed what I knew, not what I wanted.

Most do not want to know and the industry is comfortable with it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor The Good News about positive surgical margins is in this November 2017 Discovery (Johns Hopkins) article: https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brad...to-perspective Quoting Jeffery Epstein from the article: " “it is not uncommon for the margins to be positive – to have tumor at the cut edge, which potentially could indicate that some cancer has been left behind.” However, he adds, “only about half of prostate cancers with positive margins recur after surgery.” This also means that half of men who have positive margins never have a recurrence of cancer." "Because Epstein has looked at tens of thousands of prostate specimens in his distinguished career, he knows that the positive surgical margin itself is not as important as some other factors." " In a current study of 4,082 consecutive patients undergoing radical prostatectomy between 2010 and 2014 at Johns Hopkins, Epstein and colleagues showed that men who had a lower Gleason score at the margin were less likely to have a return of PSA after surgery, and “we conclude that the Gleason score of the cancer at the positive margin site should routinely be documented. This might spare men who have lower-grade cancer at the margin from post-operative radiation therapy.” I sure hope they are correct! Thanks. I will pass it on to my friend.

Posts.Title: Still in Zero club, plus question about someone else

Posts.Content: This isn't rocket science. It's prostate cancer. A biopsy will be your next step. You want the most experienced group. This is the group who has the most patients. Over thinking this will lead you to make mistakes. Avoiding a biopsy or hiring a doctor who will accomodate you avoiding a biopsy will have a predictable outcome. You will not get a biopsy sooner, but later. With cancer later is bad, sooner is good. Delaying a biopsy delays detection of cancer. Cancer left undetected can grow more and be more difficult to treat. All the tests you mention do not detect cancer. They only suggest you may have cancer. You already know you may have cancer. There is no going back. You will now be monitoring or treating prostate cancer the rest of your life. Welcome to our club. Only a biopsy detects cancer. Avoid a biopsy and you avoid detecting your cancer. Not a good place to be. That outcome is the only sure thing in this scenario. Cancer does two things very well. It grows and it screws with your head. The best path with this disease is the conventional path. The majic bullet here is everyone who has gone before you. Do not squander the work and sacrifice they have made to offer you a cure. Early detection, early treatment. Get out of your head and into a urologist office that specializes in curing prostate cancer. The bigger and more experienced the better. Cancer is a numbers and statistics game, not a who's smarter game. Discipline and ruthless persistence wins this game, not avoidance. The focus of your post is how to avoid a biopsy. You want to clear that out. Whatever is driving that is working against you. Do what you have to to get yourself to a place you are demanding a biopsy and as many as it takes. Then you may have a chance to move forward. Avoiding healthcare is not a good place to be. If you do one thing, let it be a biopsy. Get a biopsy. Get two if that's what it takes. Or three or four. If you want to cure your cancer, it begins with a biopsy.
Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: Had a go around with my urologist's office trying to get my PSA tested via ultra-sensitive. Asked for ultra-sensitive (<0.02, but didn't get it). Apparently an office nurse is not knowledgeable in the distinctions. He said he'd huddle with them and make it clear what a <0.1 test is and what ultra-sensitive is. I had three blood tests in the last two weeks; two <0.10 and finally the one I want, <0.02. Quest is not helpful. They say they only order off the order. What seems to work with Quest is a script for: Post RP, Ultra-sensitive. Geesh! We got into a conversation about my aquaintance who thought he caught it early with a G3+4 only to find out he has positve margins after an open surgery. My urologist, who I consider competent at DaVinci, admitted his personal margin rates are going up even when he thinks he's cutting wide. He said his peers are having the same experience. His thoughts; only 17% of GPs are testing PSA which translates into 4 out of 5 cases are going undetected. He is seeing patients later than sooner: ergo, margin rates are going up. We didn't get into AS impact on his margin rates. My personal thoughts are prostate cancer is also becoming more aggressive in the general population. I have no data to support this. I can only imagine that prostate cancer is not sitting quietly waiting for us to find a cure. We may be in a valley and losing the battle of early detection.

Posts.Title: Update on PC detection from my Urologist

Posts.Content: Had a go around with my urologist's office trying to get my PSA tested via ultra-sensitive. Asked for ultra-sensitive (<0.02, but didn't get it). Apparently an office nurse is not knowledgeable in the distinctions. He said he'd huddle with them and make it clear what a <0.1 test is and what ultra-sensitive is. I had three blood tests in the last two weeks; two <0.10 and finally the one I want, <0.02. Quest is not helpful. They say they only order off the order. What seems to work with Quest is a script for: Post RP, Ultra-sensitive. Geesh! We got into a conversation about my aquaintance who thought he caught it early with a G3+4 only to find out he has positve margins after an open surgery. My urologist, who I consider competent at DaVinci, admitted his personal margin rates are going up even when he thinks he's cutting wide. He said his peers are having the same experience. His thoughts; only 17% of GPs are testing PSA which translates into 4 out of 5 cases are going undetected. He is seeing patients later than sooner: ergo, margin rates are going up. We didn't get into AS impact on his margin rates. My personal thoughts are prostate cancer is also becoming more aggressive in the general population. I have no data to support this. I can only imagine that prostate cancer is not sitting quietly waiting for us to find a cure. We may be in a valley and losing the battle of early detection.

Posts.Title: Update on PC detection from my Urologist

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic This is a good question, and here is my understanding. The impetus to try a plant-derived (or other natural compound) often can come from(1) anecdotal evidence that something helps another condition or disease, and (2) its chemical structure or family is similar to another compound that has demonstrated a desired effect. Studies are then done in vitro, where the compound is put in contact with tissue cultures of a PCa line. Researchers are looking for apoptosis, or the ability of the substance to cause the malignant cells to undergo the normal programmed death of healthy prostate cells (cancer cells are zombies they live on and on, grow, replace healthy tissue and don't function properly); healthy cells of most organs die at a certain point in their lives and are replaced). I see studies about new natural substances inducing apoptosis in PCa cells every month--which only means that they warrant being studied. If the substance is extracted and integrated in a diet as a supplement, it's reasonable to think that a lowering of PSA is from a direct effect on the tumor cells. The British Pomi-T study was formulated specifically for a study (capsules of green tea, broccoli, tumeric, and pomegranate); see Subforum (S) #9. The study was double-blind, randomized and placebo controlled. There was a lowering of PSA and another commentary I've put there states that this lowering was accompanied by a reduction of lesion size on imaging. That's the best kind of evidence, which, unfortunately, we don't usually have. I believe further studies are underway on Pomi-T, which was commercialized. I've been taking it. I think if you read the research studies you'll find discussion about various proposed mechanisms of action that substances have on PCa cells. But getting back to your point, there is current thinking that inflammation itself plays a role in the carcinogenesis of PCa, so the picture is complex! Good answer if you don't have cancer. Meaning, once you have cancer the cancer rules the context. The horse is out of the barn and avoiding cancer or delaying treatment is not the issue. If it is untreatable, then by all means.
Posts.Title: polyphenois

Posts.Content: We look for BCR to guide us in treatment, not delay. If I am ultimately going to need a second round of treatment I'd rather know sooner than later and treat it sooner than later. the only thing that alters that view is if the study reports the supplement cures cancer, not just slow it. A "slower" growing G4 still has a risk the longer it is alive and in my body. As long as these reports only report a drop or slowing of PSA and no actual regression of G4 and 5, I'm a skeptic.

Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: Without much of your personal information it is difficult to speculate. The odds are its both cancer and something else. A steady rise in your PSA is your best indicator. A false negative on the biopsy can be a fifty fifty possibility based on your personal body specifics. Personally, I would not be taking testosterone with your PSA history. One negative biopsy with your PSA history is not proof you do not have cancer or it is safe for you to experiment with testostetone. Your doctor did the only thing he could by recommending a biopsy. It's not proof you do not have cancer. It is not advisable to use hormones to compensate for the effects of normal aging. We do not know enough about them. Are you overweight? How big is your prostate?

Posts.Title: No hurry, should I worry

Posts.Content: A drop in PSA often accompanies the use of antibiotics, but is not evidence to avoid a biopsy. Both the behavior that elevates PSA prior to the first test and now the very questionable use of antibiotic treatment as a diagnostic tool can combine to create the appearance of a drop in the second test. Did your doctor take a clean urine sample and request a culture to confirm an infection prior to prescribing a very serious course of antibiotics? (It's a rhetorical question.) Cipro is a high risk of very serious side effects drug to be used in such a cavalier manner, imo. 30% of doctors still engage in the very questionable practise of using antibiotics as a diagnostic tool. You want to proceed based on the freePSA as your only reliable PSA number at this point. Your basic PSA tests are no longer reliable as a base line due to suspect activities and now the use of antibiotics. It will be a matter of time to return your blood levels to "normal" to establish a new base line. It is unfortunate that PSA test are not preceded with a survey of behaviors and warnings as many other medical tests are. You have lost time and now exposed yourself to risk of serious side effects from the use of Cipro without diagnosis of a bacterial infection. You may want to consider a new doctor.
Posts.Title: PSA confusion

Posts.Content: I do not recommend it unless you have a real measurable need for something specific. There are members here who advocate/take specific supplements. I do use one supplement, psyllium husk fiber. I have issues with constipation. I am on a weight management regimen (6'-3.5" - 188 lbs) and just can't seem to consume enough fiber on a reduced calorie diet. I have found keeping my bowels soft, moving and evacuated aids in my continence post RP. A full colon will increase my risk of dribble incontinence with exertion. I believe keeping this system toned and working on a daily basis as we age reduces risk of colon cancer, high cholesterol, diabetes, obesity, and helps maintain liver and kidney health.

Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: This isn't rocket science. It's prostate cancer. A biopsy will be your next step. You want the most experienced group. This is the group who has the most patients. Over thinking this will lead you to make mistakes. Avoiding a biopsy or hiring a doctor who will accomodate you avoiding a biopsy will have a predictable outcome. You will not get a biopsy sooner, but later. With cancer later is bad, sooner is good. Delaying a biopsy delays detection of cancer. Cancer left undetected can grow more and be more difficult to treat. All the tests you mention do not detect cancer. They only suggest you may have cancer. You already know you may have cancer. There is no going back. You will now be monitoring or treating prostate cancer the rest of your life. Welcome to our club. Only a biopsy detects cancer. Avoid a biopsy and you avoid detecting your cancer. Not a good place to be. That outcome is the only sure thing in this scenario. Cancer does two things very well. It grows and it screws with your head. The best path with this disease is the conventional path. The majic bullet here is everyone who has gone before you. Do not squander the work and sacrifice they have made to offer you a cure. Early detection, early treatment. Get out of your head and into a urologist office that specializes in curing prostate cancer. The bigger and more experienced the better. Cancer is a numbers and statistics game, not a who's smarter game. Discipline and ruthless persistence wins this game, not avoidance. The focus of your post is how to avoid a biopsy. You want to clear that out. Whatever is driving that is working against you. Do what you have to to get yourself to a place you are demanding a biopsy and as many as it takes. Then you may have a chance to move forward. Avoiding healthcare is not a good place to be. If you do one thing, let it be a biopsy. Get a biopsy. Get two if that's what it takes. Or three or four. If you want to cure your cancer, it begins with a biopsy.

Posts.Title: polyphenois

Posts.Content: So here is my question. We use measurement of PSA to signal the activity of cancer. In studies such as these, how do we distinguish from the effect on PSA and the effect on the cancer? While I was able to manipulate my PSA with an anti-inflammatory diet and supplements what assures me it is having an impact on the cancer? For example, I can reduce a low grade fever to near normal with pain relievers yet the underlying cause goes untreated. Does a supplement reduced PSA give the cancer more time by delaying treatment? Here is my experience, I wasted a year or more denying and delaying treatment suppressing my PSA. Did I prolong my need for treatment, kick the can down the road so to speak, or did I give the cancer more time to do it's thing even if accepting it may have slowed, i.e. a stunted G4 throws off 2 metastic cells instead of 4. Prolonging treatment seems a risky business when you know, or don't know, you have G4 or 5. We use cranberry juice for UTIs. It can help, marginally, but a UTI is not cancer. I'll repeat, 20% of all liver and kidney damage is now the result of supplement use. Be careful. Delayed treatment, like death, seems a poor measure for success in these studies.

Posts.Title: PSA confusion

Posts.Content: Family history is critical. It is your best indicator of your future. All 3 of my brothers have it. All of us waited too long. Two have adverse conditions. I consider my volume an adverse condition making it three. The fourth is yet to be determined. All our profiles are similar and the PSA levels appear to match the risk amongst the four of us. Where it began in the prostate seems to be the only wild card. The second oldest is just getting started and he is older than me. I expect the worse results for him. One is planning salvage radiation with HT after a failed surgery. He is the youngest. Not much volume, but 3 positive margins. His cancer showed up on the surface at the apex. Just had his first consult with his RO after testing .03 after surgery. He is now coordinating timing of his RP healing with hip replacement surgery and it's healing. Ultrasensitive testing has given him time and space to coordinate all his healthcare issues. RT and HT are likely 6 to 8 months out for him. He is the only one taking effective advantage of my experience. The oldest is the most at risk and is being less than proactive. He chose to act after my experience, but still not soon enough. He had SVI and is testing with .1 oblivious to what his risks and possible futures may be. Ugh. The two oldest are head in the sand types and suffer depression. I also have depression, but awareness of my condition allows me to adjust for its impact on my thinking. I was the first to detect and treat thanks to my GP's strong intervention. I shared the whole way, but it made little difference in their awareness. Only the youngest has been aggressive in his self education. The two oldest have done no reading and have no idea what is in store for them or available. The medical industry is woefully lacking in proactive care for prostate cancer and this is clearly the responsibility of men. Women have proven themselves much more effective in education and awareness with breast cancer. Early detection early treatment. You are in a good place and I wish you well. PS: my reference to our PSA being reliable indicators amongst us is just that. It is relative to our familial condition. Another person's PSA value to risk may be different. Waiting to 7 for us was too long. It may be different for others. PSA is produced by healthy and cancer cells and BHP may effect total levels differently among men with cancer. Testing for free PSA helps overcome this.

I see studies about new natural substances inducing apoptosis in PCa cells every month--which only means that they warrant being studied. If the substance is extracted and integrated in a diet as a supplement, it's reasonable to think that a lowering of PSA is from a direct effect on the tumor cells. The British Pomi-T study was formulated specifically for a study (capsules of green tea, broccoli, tumeric, and pomegranate); see Subforum (S) #9. The study was double-blind, randomized and placebo controlled. There was a lowering of PSA and another commentary I've put there states that this lowering was accompanied by a reduction of lesion size on imaging. That's the best kind of evidence, which, unfortunately, we don't usually have. I believe further studies are underway on Pomi-T, which was commercialized. I've been taking it. I think if you read the research studies you'll find discussion about various proposed mechanisms of action that substances have on PCa cells. But getting back to your point, there is current thinking that inflammation itself plays a role in the carcinogenesis of PCa, so the picture is complex! Good answer if you don't have cancer. Meaning, once you have cancer the cancer rules the context. The horse is out of the barn and avoiding cancer or delaying treatment is not the issue. If it is untreatable, then by all means.

Posts.Title: Cholesterol lowering seems to be a protective mechanism against advanced PC

Posts.Content: I am not a doctor. Your body produces less urine at night. A natural hormone helps do this so you can sleep. You are used to getting up maybe once or less during the night. During the day you are drinking more and urinating more often. With BHP the increased frequency during the day is not as noticeable or disrupting as at night. Early in BHP it is not a problem during the day to urinate more often. Also, the frequent urges to urinate during the day can be consciously suppressed allowing the bladder to fill more before urinating during the day. At night you notice it more because it bothers your sleep. The urge to urinate wakes you and suppressing it keeps you awake so you go to urinate so you can go back to sleep, but it is not as much as during the day so the pressure of the full bladder is less, so less is eliminated out. As the prostate grows it constricts the urethra. The bladder muscle grows stronger to force the urine through. As the bladder muscle grows stronger it thickens. The thickening shrinks the bladder volume, and you hold less.

Posts.Title: Cholesterol lowering seems to be a protective mechanism against advanced PC

Posts.Content: OOM, I did not read a preference in the two responses. I read the question, how did you arrive at your choice of radiation vs surgery? It is a choice many have to make. Dismissing surgery based soley on side effects data is misguided in my opinion as is choosing based soley on side effects as you are discovering with the ADT. The acceptance of side effects is an integral part of all the treatment consideration for this disease. Please complete your signature and hang around with updates so we can follow your results. I'm interested in your PSA history, family history, how long your cancer was developing before treatment, and biopsy results including volume and location. Did you use any prostate treatment drugs or other drugs with hormones, testosterone, etc? I chose surgery for one of the reasons you mentioned, a pathogy report. More importantly, I chose it playing for a long term cure knowing the side effect risks. In my profile, I was not as concerned for the side effects which since have both recovered. Surgery side effects are impacted by the skill of the surgeon, fitness of the patient, and the extent of the cancer, imo, all are variables to consider when choosing surgery. I am now waiting to see if follow up radiation is necessary. I can see a high probability of living well into my 90's. I wanted as long a treatment strategy as possible. This makes me pro-surgery and pro-radiation. Regardless of the test results, I'm not sure I agree that a G9 is low risk in any consideration. My understanding of your profile is, if radiation appears inevitable because of the extent and type of the cancer, going straight to radiation may save the time and stress (including side effects) of a more extensive surgery (wider cut) with a diminshing effectiveness in the face of more advanced aggressive cancer. The doctor recommending surgery may have reason to believe it was highly probable it was still confined. I'm not so sure based on your age and Gleason score. Radiation may have been a better choice for you. Even so, an individual may still want to be more aggressive with a competent surgery option knowing they can follow up with much improved radiation and ADT options. Both RALP surgery experience and radiation treatment technology are improving making past data on side effects somewhat difficult to navigate. Surgery is more of an early detection option for low to intermediate cancers and possible cures in younger men with radiation and ADT as a follow up. Radiation is a less intrusive option for low, intermediate and high risk cancers with more radiation and ADT as a follow up. Radiation has a broader reach. Surgery has an optimal window. My understanding is combining ADT with radiation gives a significant boost to more positive outcomes. While nobody seems to like it, I have heard few cases here where it was considered intolerable and discontinued against the doctor's advice. The extra 5-20% increase in positive long term outcomes gained with ADT in the face of more aggressive and persistent disease is significant, imo. My view is there are many treatment options for this disease. There is no universally accepted one best treatment. Each is dependent on the individual patient profile. Your experience of the ADT being intolerable is a good example. Self prescribing and consistently going against the recommendation of your doctors is not a good sign. You may be not doing your homework on your doctor choices and/or second guessing yourself. Not a good place to be. Discovering you can not tolerate hormone therapy will have a huge impact on managing your disease going forward should it prove to be persistent. I'm not sure what your options will be. One of the lines of conversation in this forum is trying to fine tune the decision matrix with current technology in testing and treatment. Both the poster and you fall into this conversation. Choosing radiation, surgery, ADT, chemo, or eventually some or all is a matrix choice of how to treat this disease that cross several times depending on who, what, and when. With respect for the poster, I think you should have your own thread.

Posts.Title: Questioning the Motives of the Forum

Posts.Content: "because of the clear superiority of RT over RP in preservation of erectile function with equivalent longterm recurrence free survival. RT is also superior to RT in the significantly lower probability of either urinary incontinence or urethral stricture." The poster then goes on to say he acted against the recommendations of both his doctors. The above is bias. The patient's needs determine which option is superior, imo. "Did the uro give any reason for apparently not offering surgery as a treatment option?" This above is not bias. Everyone is free to ask "why not". Ruling out treatment options is another way of determining the need of the treatment. Why radiation, why not surgery, or why surgery and why not radiation or valid questions, imo. Especially for those confronted with this choice. "Forum Brothers will be interested in how you arrived at your decision for RT+ADT. Did you also consult with a R.O? This above is not bias. Most people want to hear the story and why you did what you did. Be prepared. If there is a bias on this site it's towards due diligence and full disclosure. You can not participate here collecting justification for your own view and expect it to be unchallenged. Surgery is an early detection treatment option, imo. Determining when that window closes is valuable. Radiation offers treatment options across the full range of the disease. My experience of this site is pro-surgery, pro-radiation, and pro-AS. If there is a bias it is for early detection and treatment of treatable disease (early or not). I, personally, am here to prepare for possible radiation therapy after my surgery, as planned. So far my plan is working for me. What drives the need for it to be considered superior to other treatment plans? Anyone who claims one treatment model is universally superior is not clear about the risks of the disease and those who are dealing with it. It's classic bias and justification of a personal choice. Claiming to be a doctor only doubles down on that in a very questionable way, imo. What was missing, and I'm guilty of this a lot, was "why are you here sharing?" Do you want to tell your story, looking for advice, camaraderie, or giving back. If your not clear in this people will use what you share to serve their own needs, bias or not. Often people show up to share the exuberance of having made a choice only to have it immediately challenged or asked to share what went on behind the curtain. Difficult to say the least. Made more difficult by the need to justify to themselves it is the "right" choice. When, imo, the only question is will/did it work? The fear of a right/wrong choice drives most people, before and after and more so after. Try instead, will/did it work or not for me.

Posts.Title: PSA confusion

Posts.Content: A drop in PSA often accompanies the use of antibiotics, but is not evidence to avoid a biopsy. Both the behavior that elevates PSA prior to the first test and now the very questionable use of antibiotic treatment as a diagnostic tool can combine to create the appearance of a drop in the second test. Did your doctor take a clean urine sample and request a culture to confirm an infection prior to prescribing a very serious course of antibiotics? (It's a rhetorical question.) Cipro is a high risk of very serious side effects drug to be used in such a cavalier manner, imo. 30% of doctors still engage in the very questionable practise of using antibiotics as a diagnostic tool. You want to proceed based on the freePSA as your only reliable PSA number at this point. Your basic PSA tests are no longer reliable as a base line due to suspect activities and now the use of antibiotics. It will be a matter of time to return your blood levels to "normal" to establish a new base line. It is unfortunate that PSA test are not preceded with a survey of behaviors and warnings as many other medical tests are. You have lost time and now exposed yourself to risk of serious side effects from the use of Cipro without diagnosis of a bacterial infection. You may want to consider a new doctor.

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: Treatment options may depend on how long you expect to live. Make an estimate of your expected life span as part of your calculus. And yes, doing so is confronting, but also liberating and surprisingly not difficult. We are all in our end game here. Average expected life span in this country is 78. Higher education, fitness, responsible healthcare, genetics, will, and activity can extend it into your 90s. Planning out how you deal with this disease ongoingly can change if your life expectancy is 5, 10, 15, or 20 years out. Based solely on your biopsy results you are having, not unexpectedly, a recurrence. Waiting until a .2 PSA to consider action indicates your choice to not be aggressive with early detection and treatment options. Standard of care in this situation is usually full body scans to see if it's spread to detectable limits outside the prostate bed. Then treatment with radiation to the prostate bed supplemented with hormone deprivation therapy to boost its effect. Treatment outside the prostate bed depends on if, when, and where they find it. The longer you wait the greater the risk it has/will metastasize. So you know, a retest can happen immediately. There is no reason I am aware of to wait 1-2 months.

Posts.Title: Forum Poll on shared decision making

Posts.Content: I'd tecommend uPSA, but your health system/doctor has to be on board. They will have their own protocal for action. No reason to test for levels they will not act on. You want them to align. I/my health system use(s) the intermediate level test to 2 decimal points, <0.02 is the lowest sensitivity. I'd prefer the uPSA, but this works for me. My final G was 3+4, but due to volume my doc put my risk for recurrence at 20%. After 1 year, the doc recommended annual checks. I requested to stay on a 6 month schedule. He's confident, I'm diligent. He understood. Earliar is better on salvage radiation, imo.

Posts.Content: I recommend treatment of 3+4. It's also a high volume of cancer. The volume on one side is very high. I wonder how unusal that is, and is no cancer biopsied on the other side suspect? I see the volume on the one side as an adverse condition, imo. Your prostate size of 18cc seems suspect now as well. Does the report provide an updated estimated size? Curious to hear what the doctor says.
Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: Family history is critical. It is your best indicator of your future. All 3 of my brothers have it. All of us waited too long. Two have adverse conditions. I consider my volume an adverse condition making it three. The fourth is yet to be determined. All our profiles are similar and the PSA levels appear to match the risk amongst the four of us. Where it began in the prostate seems to be the only wild card. The second oldest is just getting started and he is older than me. I expect the worse results for him. One is planning salvage radiation with HT after a failed surgery. He is the youngest. Not much volume, but 3 positive margins. His cancer showed up on the surface at the apex. Just had his first consult with his RO after testing .03 after surgery. He is now coordinating timing of his RP healing with hip replacement surgery and it's healing. Ultrasensitive testing has given him time and space to coordinate all his healthcare issues. RT and HT are likely 6 to 8 months out for him. He is the only one taking effective advantage of my experience. The oldest is the most at risk and is being less than proactive. He chose to act after my experience, but still not soon enough. He had SVI and is testing with .1 oblivious to what his risks and possible futures may be. Ugh. The two oldest are head in the sand types and suffer depression. I also have depression, but awareness of my condition allows me to adjust for its impact on my thinking. I was the first to detect and treat thanks to my GP's strong intervention. I shared the whole way, but it made little difference in their awareness. Only the youngest has been aggressive in his self education. The two oldest have done no reading and have no idea what is in store for them or available. The medical industry is woefully lacking in proactive care for prostate cancer and this is clearly the responsibility of men. Women have proven themselves much more effective in education and awareness with breast cancer. Early detection early treatment. You are in a good place and I wish you well. PS: my reference to our PSA being reliable indicators amongst us is just that. It is relative to our familial condition. Another person's PSA value to risk may be different. Waiting to 7 for us was too long. It may be different for others. PSA is produced by healthy and cancer cells and BHP may effect total levels differently among men with cancer. Testing for free PSA helps overcome this.

Posts.Content: https://www.google.com/search?source...6jA4GQ_RqRc0M: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_location Here are links to a map and terms. It's at the left of the middle and lower in the inner front center portion of the prostate..... Left - left Medial - at the center Apical - at the apex Prostate top and bottom or reversed to what we'd think. The apex, or top, is towards our feet. The base, or bottom, is towards our head. The report is not referring to the base or apex of the gland, but the apex of the transition zone which is mostly in the inner center and mostly to the front. It wraps around the urethra. So, left, center, towards your feet of the transition zone, and the transition zone is center and slightly to the front of the gland. Nothing to worry about. It is difficult to reach with a needle from the rectum since it's on the side away from the rectum or front. One of the problems with TRUS biopsy is difficulty reaching some areas. You're ahead of the game with the MRI. Relax and wait for the report. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/25327466/ "TZ cancer prostate is associated with favorable pathologic features and better recurrence-free survival despite being diagnosed with larger cancers and higher PSA values. Tumor location should be taken into account when stratifying patient risk before and after prostatectomy, particularly with the evolving role of imaging in prostate cancer management."
Posts.Title: Location on Prostate

Posts.Content: "because of the clear superiority of RT over RP in preservation of erectile function with equivalent longterm recurrence free survival. RT is also superior to RT in the significantly lower probability of either urinary incontinence or urethral stricture." The poster then goes on to say he acted against the recommendations of both his doctors. The above is bias. The patient's needs determine which option is superior, imo. "Did the uro give any reason for apparently not offering surgery as a treatment option?" This above is not bias. Everyone is free to ask "why not". Ruling out treatment options is another way of determining the need of the treatment. Why radiation, why not surgery, or why surgery and why not radiation or valid questions, imo. Especially for those confronted with this choice. "Forum Brothers will be interested in how you arrived at your decision for RT+ADT. Did you also consult with a R.O? This above is not bias. Most people want to hear the story and why you did what you did. Be prepared. If there is a bias on this site it's towards due diligence and full disclosure. You can not participate here collecting justification for your own view and expect it to be unchallenged. Surgery is an early detection treatment option, imo. Determining when that window closes is valuable. Radiation offers treatment options across the full range of the disease. My experience of this site is pro-surgery, pro-radiation, and pro-AS. If there is a bias it is for early detection and treatment of treatable disease (early or not). I, personally, am here to prepare for possible radiation therapy after my surgery, as planned. So far my plan is working for me. What drives the need for it to be considered superior to other treatment plans? Anyone who claims one treatment model is universally superior is not clear about the risks of the disease and those who are dealing with it. It's classic bias and justification of a personal choice. Claiming to be a doctor only doubles down on that in a very questionable way, imo. What was missing, and I'm guilty of this a lot, was "why are you here sharing?" Do you want to tell your story, looking for advice, camaraderie, or giving back. If your not clear in this people will use what you share to serve their own needs, bias or not. Often people show up to share the exuberance of having made a choice only to have it immediately challenged or asked to share what went on behind the curtain. Difficult to say the least. Made more difficult by the need to justify to themselves it is the "right" choice. When, imo, the only question is will/did it work? The fear of a right/wrong choice drives most people, before and after and more so after. Try instead, will/did it work or not for me.

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: Those are probably measurement variations and not evidence your prostate is shrinking even though it may have from the turmeric. Add up extremely young age, artificially suppressed PSA and rising PSA in the face of anti-inflammatory (turmeric) supplements and you are at risk for smaller more aggressive cancer. Testosterone is a wild card. If you were under the care of a endocrinologist and testing your blood levels and administering it carefully to well within normal ranges for your age it may be safe. This is usually not the case. It is unadviseable for use for the effects of normal ageing. We know very little about it. Best to avoid it except for medically significant necessary treatment. 3TMRI is a good idea as long as it results in another biopsy, but it will miss the smaller stuff including the aggressive smaller stuff. However you proceed, a follow up biopsy appears to be in your future. Consider a larger sample number this time.

Curious to hear what the doctor says.
Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: Treatment options may depend on how long you expect to live. Make an estimate of your expected life span as part of your calculus. And yes, doing so is confronting, but also liberating and surprisingly not difficult. We are all in our end game here. Average expected life span in this country is 78. Higher education, fitness, responsible healthcare, genetics, will, and activity can extend it into your 90s. Planning out how you deal with this disease ongoingly can change if your life expectancy is 5, 10, 15, or 20 years out. Based solely on your biopsy results you are having, not unexpectedly, a recurrence. Waiting until a .2 PSA to consider action indicates your choice to not be aggressive with early detection and treatment options. Standard of care in this situation is usually full body scans to see if it's spread to detectable limits outside the prostate bed. Then treatment with radiation to the prostate bed supplemented with hormone deprivation therapy to boost its effect. Treatment outside the prostate bed depends on if, when, and where they find it. The longer you wait the greater the risk it has/will metastasize. So you know, a retest can happen immediately. There is no reason I am aware of to wait 1-2 months.
