Posts.Title: Being thankful in times of challenge!

Posts.Content: OOM, I did not read a preference in the two responses. I read the question, how did you arrive at your choice of radiation vs surgery? It is a choice many have to make. Dismissing surgery based soley on side effects data is misguided in my opinion as is choosing based soley on side effects as you are discovering with the ADT. The acceptance of side effects is an integral part of all the treatment consideration for this disease. Please complete your signature and hang around with updates so we can follow your results. I'm interested in your PSA history, family history, how long your cancer was developing before treatment, and biopsy results including volume and location. Did you use any prostate treatment drugs or other drugs with hormones, testosterone, etc? I chose surgery for one of the reasons you mentioned, a pathogy report. More importantly, I chose it playing for a long term cure knowing the side effect risks. In my profile, I was not as concerned for the side effects which since have both recovered. Surgery side effects are impacted by the skill of the surgeon, fitness of the patient, and the extent of the cancer, imo, all are variables to consider when choosing surgery. I am now waiting to see if follow up radiation is necessary. I can see a high probability of living well into my 90's. I wanted as long a treatment strategy as possible. This makes me pro-surgery and pro-radiation. Regardless of the test results, I'm not sure I agree that a G9 is low risk in any consideration. My understanding of your profile is, if radiation appears inevitable because of the extent and type of the cancer, going straight to radiation may save the time and stress (including side effects) of a more extensive surgery (wider cut) with a diminshing effectiveness in the face of more advanced aggressive cancer. The doctor recommending surgery may have reason to believe it was highly probable it was still confined. I'm not so sure based on your age and Gleason score. Radiation may have been a better choice for you. Even so, an individual may still want to be more aggressive with a competent surgery option knowing they can follow up with much improved radiation and ADT options. Both RALP surgery experience and radiation treatment technology are improving making past data on side effects somewhat difficult to navigate. Surgery is more of an early detection option for low to intermediate cancers and possible cures in younger men with radiation and ADT as a follow up. Radiation is a less intrusive option for low, intermediate and high risk cancers with more radiation and ADT as a follow up. Radiation has a broader reach. Surgery has an optimal window. My understanding is combining ADT with radiation gives a significant boost to more positive outcomes. While nobody seems to like it, I have heard few cases here where it was considered intolerable and discontinued against the doctor's advice. The extra 5-20% increase in positive long term outcomes gained with ADT in the face of more aggressive and persistent disease is significant, imo. My view is there are many treatment options for this disease. There is no universally accepted one best treatment. Each is dependent on the individual patient profile. Your experience of the ADT being intolerable is a good example. Self prescribing and consistently going against the recommendation of your doctors is not a good sign. You may be not doing your homework on your doctor choices and/or second guessing yourself. Not a good place to be. Discovering you can not tolerate hormone therapy will have a huge impact on managing your disease going forward should it prove to be persistent. I'm not sure what your options will be. One of the lines of conversation in this forum is trying to fine tune the decision matrix with current technology in testing and treatment. Both the poster and you fall into this conversation. Choosing radiation, surgery, ADT, chemo, or eventually some or all is a matrix choice of how to treat this disease that cross several times depending on who, what, and when. With respect for the poster, I think you should have your own thread.

Posts.Title: Location on Prostate

Posts.Content: Imo, fear is an emotion and like all emotions not to be trusted. Fear is a liar of the worse kind. It is a remnant of a past age. It requires management, time, and resources with no reward. It short circuits the mind. Using it as a warning flag is balanced only by the skill to dismiss it. Only after dismissing a fearful state can one be in a cognizant state. Fear is a rational creature created by a rational process subject to rationalization and the distortion of reality. It exists only in the mind. You do not want to spend time in fear. It's as simple a response as a deer in headlights. It paralyzes you, doesn't work, temps you to rationalize, and is unnecessary in every way. Fear does not exist out there in the universe. It exists only in thought and mind. Only by learning to recognize and dismiss it can you move forward. We have nothing real to fear. Fear is made up. In any struggle, challenge, or way of being you want to be clear of fear to be yourself. Fear used to control yourself and others is something you want to go to work on to disappear.
Posts.Title: Fear is a liar

Posts.Content: You're not giving us much information to help you. Complete your signature. See the signature sticky. So far, everything you have shared indicates you have prostate cancer and are a candidate for treatment. The one location you have shared is pathologically favorable. Your doctor will explain your options. Without more information what can we say? What's your age, Gleason score, biopsy report, MRI report, prostate size, PSA history, DRE, urinary symptoms, family history, health, etc. This is your medical chart. It will help you to have a clear view of your disease. Dr. Patrick Walsh's -"How to Survive Prostate Cancer" is a good place to start. Usually there is time to educate yourself, seek second opinions, and consider your options. Have someone attend your doctors meeting with you and take notes while you listen and ask questions. You may benefit from stepping back a second, remember to breath, get your bearings, and regroup here. Start by completing your signature like the other forum brothers. Mine is in my profile. Your first task is to have a clear and concise view of the important facts of you and your disease and be able to share them consisely. Generally, surgery and radiation are both effective with a different rate of side effects. With surgery the side effects are immediate and resolve within a year or more or not depending on the aggressiveness of the surgery required by the aggressiveness and extent of the cancer. With radiation the side effects may show up years later and then remain chronic. With surgery you get a complete pathology report indicating actual grade and extent and areas of extension. This is useful if the cancer is more aggressive or advanced and more treatment, usually radiation, may be necessary. Generally age is a consideration. Younger and healthier men tolerate surgery easier with less permanent side effects. Surgery also allows radiation as a follow up treatment option. Robotic and open have similar outcomes. Each has perceived nuances. The majority are robotic. Radiation is less invasive. The smaller the treatment area the better, and/or the older and less viable a candidate for surgery the better. Common side effects are similar, but show up later. Additional side effects are radiation damage to bowel and bladder with possible second cancers from the radiation. Surgery following radiation is rare and difficult. Additional radiation following radiation is becoming more available, but still new. Radiation has a much larger field of choices and treatment options driven, I suspect, by the opportunity of men wanting to avoid surgery and the continuing advancements in radiation treatments in general. You have to drill down to the ones that are proven and effective. HIFU is not one of those. If you are considering both you should meet with both a surgeon and a radiologist.

Posts.Content: Regarding the kegel comments, it fits into try something different if what you are doing is not working. I had to focus on control when exerting as my last step to continenece. I agree with the PSA testing for you, but which 2 digit test? They run from <0.06 to <0.01 from what I have seen. Mine was <0.01 and is now <0.02. They tried to change it to <0.06, but I am interested in early treatment so I asked for better and I got the <0.02 from Quest. It satisfies me, and more so as each 6 months goes by, but still I want to know when it crosses the 0.03 mark. His insistence on 0.2 as the trigger for treatment I suspect is specific to you and may be influenced by your age. If it's a hard and fast rule for everyone it occurs as a caution flag and may reflect a bias on his part, imo. I suggest you participate in this discussion and choice with him if it comes to past. Bottom line, you are on top of this.

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I like what I am hearing from the MO and RO. I am not so confident in your urologist and suggest you follow his advice for a second opinion from a urologist highly skilled in RP (radical prostatectomy) as your next step....Since I assume you know this I say it for others, the location of the known extension in fatty tissue is an accelerant. Did the doctor recommend, in your best interest, another surgeon to move the surgery forward?...Since you have no symptoms that will be improved by surgery (your prostate has remained small - I really question this result and suggest you confirm your prostate size) radiation may be a better fit. It's a question for each of the doctors....I am not so confident in your urologist and suggest you follow his advice for a second opinion from a urologist highly skilled in RP (radical prostatectomy) as your next step. I did not take this route, but from what I have learned you are well served by taking yourself to a cancer center with experience in prostate cancer....My urologist ordered an MRI to map out the extent of the cancer before surgery. I recommend it be considered before whatever your next step is....
